progression"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "502791"}], "url": "http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/general/athletics/usain-bolt-injury-relay-career-retirement-jamaica-team-furious-delay-video-watch-yohan-blake-a7890651.html", "body": "The Jamaican relay team hit out at the World Athletics Championships' organisers in London as Usain Bolt labelled the delay to his final race on Saturday \"crazy\", with the sprint legend ending his career in agony after being struck down by injury.\n\nAs Great Britain powered their way to a stunning gold in the men's 4x100m relay with the third-quickest time in history, Bolt was struck down midway through his stint with what has been revealed as cramp in his left leg.\n\nThe race started 10 minutes later than planned, with the teams being held in the warm-up area for nearly 30 minutes before they were able to run out into the London Stadium, and Bolt's teammate Yohan Blake spoke afterwards of their concern with how the preparations were dragging on.\n\nUsain Bolt's best moments 10 show all Usain Bolt's best moments 1/10 Beijing 2008 100m final (9.69 seconds, 2008 Beijing Olympics)\n\nBolt wins his first Olympic gold after destroying the competition in Beijing.\n\nGetty\n\n2/10 Beijing 2008 200m final (19.30 seconds, 2008 Beijing Olympics)\n\nBolt doubles up in China after wining the 200m with a new world record time.\n\nGetty\n\n3/10 Beijing 2008 4x100m final (37.10 seconds, 2008 Beijing Olympics)\n\nThe Jamiacan 4x100m relay team make it a hat-trick in Beijing for Bolt.\n\nGetty\n\n4/10 Berlin 2009 100m final (9.58 seconds 2009 Berlin World Championships)\n\nBold sets a 100m world record of 9.58s at the Berlin World Athletics Championships, a feat that still stands today.\n\nGetty\n\n5/10 Berlin 2009 200m final (19.19 seconds, 2009 Berlin World Championships)\n\nBolt doubles up again with a new world record in the 200m final.\n\nGetty\n\n6/10 London 2012 100m final (9.63 seconds, 2012 London Olympics)\n\nOlympic gold medal No 4 arrives in London with 100m success.\n\nGetty\n\n7/10 London 2012 200m final (19.32 seconds, 2012 London Olympics)\n\nA fifth Olympic gold quickly follows as Bolt wins the 200m.\n\nGetty\n\n8/10 London 2012 4x100m final (36.64 seconds, 2012 London Olympics)\n\nJamaica continue their dominance of men's sprinting with 4x100m relay gold in London.\n\nGetty\n\n9/10 Rio 2016 100m final (9.81 seconds, 2016 Rio Olympics)\n\nDespite fears over his form, Bolt retains his Olympic gold medal in Rio after winning the 100m final.\n\nGetty\n\n10/10 Rio 2016 200m final (19.78 second, Rio 2016 Olympics)\n\nBolt celebrates crossing the line for his eighth Olympic gold in the 200m final\n\nGetty\n\nThe concern was so great that Bolt turned to Blake before the raise to express his unhappiness, and Blake furiously hit out at organisers immediately after the race after having to watch the women's high jump medal presentation overrun.\n\n\"I think they were holding us too long in the call room,\" Blake said on Saturday night. \"The walk was too long. Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me, 'Yohan, I think this is crazy'.\n\n'No regrets' for Usain Bolt after 100m final\n\n\"It was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run. We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us.\n\n\"We were over warm. And to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggling like that...The race was 10 minutes late, we were kept 40 minutes and it was a 300 metre walk. It was crazy.\"\n\nRead more Great Britain storm to surprise gold in men's 4x100m relay final\n\nJamaica failed to finish the race as Bolt lay prone on the track, but he dismissed the aid of a wheelchair to get up and cross the line before waving goodbye to the crowd, with Bolt now unlikely to race in Zurich as had been hinted if the injury proves worse than first feared. The Jamaican team medic, Dr Kevin Jones, played down any long-term injuries though and claimed the injury was just cramp.\n\n\"It's cramp in his left hamstring but a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Dr Jones said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nGreat Britain and USA were ahead of Jamaica when Bolt suffered injury (Getty)\n\nHowever, his other two sprint teammates, Omar McLeod and Julian Forte, were in agreement with Blake that 30-year-old Bolt's final farewell had been doomed to fail because of the delays.\n\n\"It's heart-wrenching,\" said 110m hurdle gold medallist McLeod. \"I gave it my all and I really wanted Usain to leave golden, or even if it was just a medal, it was really heart-wrenching.\n\n\"I couldn't believe it, I'm in shock, utter disbelief.\n\n\"It was ridiculous, man. We were there around 45 minutes waiting outside, I think they had three medal ceremonies before we went out so we were really trying our hardest to stay warm and keep upbeat, but it was ridiculous. We waited a really long time. I drank like two bottles of water.\"\n\nBolt was struck down while running the final leg for Jamaica (Getty)\n\nForte added: \"I really wanted to be a part of the team that sends Usain off in style. Unfortunately it's one of those things, it's part of sport.\n\n\"They kept us in the call room for an extremely long time in our running kits, and it's not the warmest over here and they had us around there for quite a while, so I think they really need to look into that and do something about it.\n\n\"We were excited, we were ready, we had been doing some hand offs and everybody was feeling good, but they kept us hanging around for a long time, you know. So it's just really crazy.\"\n\nJamaica failed to finish due to Bolt's injury (Getty)\n\nThe frustration with the long wait before the race was not contained to the Jamaican team, with USA sprinter and 100m gold medallist Justin Gatlin expressing sympathy for his long-time rival Bolt as he agreed with the cause of the injury.\n\n\"You can't really have this night or championship define what he's done in the past. From 2008 on, Usain Bolt has done amazing things. Tonight is not going to define who he is. He is still the man,\" said Gatlin, whose USA team finished runner-up to Great Britain.\n\n\"This is a farewell tour, we take our hats off to him and we hope he gets better.\n\n\"I know it's TV magic, and everybody has to be prepared on time to make everything happen for the viewers at home, (but) I personally think that we were held in the stadium a little too long without our clothes on, and there was a little draught in there. I lost all my sweat and body heat.\n\nBolt's teammates believe the pre-race delayed caused his injury (Getty)\n\nWhen asked if he thought that contributed to Bolt's injury, the 35-year-old Gatlin said: \"I believe so.\n\n\"Knowing how Usain performs, he's always ready, he's always making sure he's not injured and it's very rare to see Usain injured when he comes to performances.\"\n\nGatlin believes Bolt will run again despite his planned retirement (Reuters)\n\nHowever, Gatlin believes that London 2017 will not be the last time that Bolt is seen on the track.\n\n\"I'm going to win my 100, he's coming back in a year or two,\" Gatlin added. \"He'll be ready. He has a passion for the sport, he loves the fans, the fans love him. It's something you can't walk away too easy from.\"\n\nMore about: World Athletics Championships Usain Bolt Yohan Blake Reuse content", "time": "09:37:00"}

"id": "1333564"}], "url": "http://gulfnews.com/sport/athletics/sad-farewell-for-injured-usain-bolt-as-britain-win-4x100m-relay-1.2073100", "body": "LONDON: Usain Bolt's glittering career swansong came crashing to an end when he pulled up on the anchor leg of the world 4x100m relay won by Britain on Saturday.\n\nBolt received the baton with Jamaica in third, but halfway down his leg the towering sprinter pulled up clutching his left thigh, eventually doing a forward roll to the ground, to gasps from the 60,000 sell out London Stadium.\n\nThe British quartet of Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake claimed gold in 37.47 seconds, with the Justin Gatlin-led US four taking silver at 0.05sec and Japan a surprise bronze (38.04).\n\nBolt missed out on his bid to retain his 100m title earlier in the week, losing out to Gatlin and silver medallist Christian Coleman, who ran relay anchor for the Americans on Saturday.\n\nBut hopes were high for Bolt's final competitive race, with Jamaica also boasting newly-crowned 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake in their line-up.\n\nJamaica were afforded a rousing welcome from the crowd, Bolt applauding the stands, with pictures of him constantly shown on the stadium's big screens.\n\nGatlin and the US team also including another convicted doping cheat, Mike Rodgers, and Jaylen Bacon were booed when introduced although the jeering was less than for the individual 100m event.\n\nA close first three legs saw Britain, the United States and Jamaica level-pegged for the final leg.\n\nBut there was to be drama as a visibly swearing Bolt pulled up, allowing the Japanese quartet to nip in for third.\n\nThe result means Bolt, 100 and 200m world record holder, finishes his career with 14 world medals to go with eight Olympic golds.\n\nUsain Bolt retired from track and field championships after Jamaica in the 4x100m relay at the world championships in London.\n\nUnfortunately there was to be no fairytale as he pulled up and collapsed injured on the track running the anchor leg.\n\nHere AFP Sports looks at his glittering career in numbers.\n\n1: World bronze, after being beaten in the 100m in London 2017 by Americans Justin Gatlin and Christian Coleman\n\n3: The number of Olympic treble sprint doubles, in Beijing 2008, London 2012 and Rio 2016. It should have been a treble treble including all three relay titles, but teammate Nesta Carter tested positive for doping in the Chinese capital\n\n4: Times Bolt has been named Laureus World Sportsman of the Year: 2009, 2010, 2013, 2017\n\n5: The number of sprinters to have beaten Bolt over 100m: Gatlin, Coleman, Jamaica's Asafa Powell, American Tyson Gay and Antigua's Daniel Bailey\n\n6: Times Bolt has won the IAAF Male Athlete of the Year: 2008, 2009, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2016\n\n9.63: the second fastest time ever run, when Bolt scorched to 100m gold at the 2008 Beijing Olympics\n\n14: world medals amassed since making his debut in Helsinki in 2005, when he finished eighth and last in the 200m final\n\n14.35: the world best Bolt set over 150 metres in Manchester, England, in 2009. He ran the final 100 metres in a startling 8.70sec, the fastest time ever recorded\n\n30.97: His best time over the rarely-run 300m, set in 2010. Only South African Wayde van Niekerk and American Michael Johnson have gone faster\n\n31: The Jamaican turns 31 on August 21\n\n36.84: The world record for the 4x100m relay set at the London Olympics, Bolt anchoring a team also comprising Nesta Carter, Michael Frater and Yohan Blake. Bolt had been part of two previous world relay records, in Beijing in 2008 (though this was later voided) and at the 2011 Daegu worlds\n\n37.58: Bolt's average speed in km/h (23.35mph) in his 100m world record race. Should you subtract his reaction time of 0.15sec, his time is actually 9.43sec, making his average speed 38.18km/h (23.72mph)\n\n41: The number of strides it took for Bolt to cover the 100m on his record-setting run in the German capital\n\n44.72: Top speed in km/h (27.79mph) reached during his 100m run in Berlin in 2009, between the 60 to 80-metre mark\n\n53: The number of times Bolt has run sub-10 second 100m races\n\n34.2 million: Dollars earned by Bolt last year according to a list of the world's richest sportspeople by Forbes magazine", "time": "04:39:00"}

(Source: Reuters) Usaint Bolt last race, when and where to watch World Athletics Championship, TV channel, live streamingI'm always excited to run relays, says Usain Bolt ahead of his final 4\u00d7100 metresWho is Justin Gatlin and why was he booed?\n\nUsain Bolt's final appearance on the track ended in agony on Saturday as he pulled up injured running the final leg of the World Championships 4\u00d7100 metres relay as Britain beat the United States for a shock gold medal.\n\nBolt, who had to settle for bronze in the individual 100 metres, had been hoping to sign off from the sport by leading Jamaica to a fifth successive relay gold but they were already struggling in third when he collected the baton.\n\nAs he tried to gain ground, Bolt pulled up and fell to the floor with what looked like a hamstring injury. The United States, with individual gold and silver medallists Justin Gatlin and Christian Coleman running the second and fourth legs, had been expected to push the Jamaicans all the way.\n\nInstead, a brilliantly executed race by Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Danny Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake gave Britain gold in 37.47 seconds, the best time in the world this year. (Source: Instagram) Usain Bolt limps out of final race, Great Britain win Gold in World Championships 4x100m relayUsaint Bolt last race, when and where to watch World Athletics Championship, TV channel, live streamingI'm always excited to run relays, says Usain Bolt ahead of his final 4\u00d7100 metres\n\nUsain Bolt has thanked his fans after the Jamaican's last race ended in a disappointing manner. Bolt pulled up injury during the final leg of 4\u00d7100 metres relay at the World Championships. He took to social media and wrote, \"Thank You my peeps. Infinite love for my fans \u1f64c\u1f3fd\u1f64c\u1f3fd\" on his Instagram account.\n\nLater, the sprint great's teammates revealed that Bolt continuously apologised to them for not getting over the line. \"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\n\"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on,\" McLeod said.\n\nOn the other side, Justin Gatlin who bagged the gold in 100m last week paid tribute to Bolt. \"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury). I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete,\" he added.\n\nThe event was eventually won by the Great Britain. Earlier, Bolt had to settle with bronze in his last 100m race by registering a time of 9.95 seconds. He was stunned by Gatlin of USA and Christian Coleman of USA who took home the gold and silver medals respectively with times of 9.92 and 9.94 seconds. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justin_Gatlin", "label": {"eng": "Justin Gatlin"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "320483"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4_\u00d7_100_metres_relay", "label": {"eng": "4 \u00d7 100 metres relay"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "320499"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anchor_leg", "label": {"eng": "Anchor leg"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "489170"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germaine_Mason", "label": {"eng": "Germaine Mason"}, "score": 1, "type": "person", "id": "1175898"}], "url": "http://www.espn.com/athletics/story/_/id/20326247", "body": "LONDON -- Injured or not, he would have lost. The man we once cheered was already gone.\n\nUsain Bolt would have won. The Usain Bolt we carry in our hearts would have roared back from third place Saturday in the final race of his career, won gold in the 4x100-meter relay and engraved his legacy with one last thrilling victory.\n\nUsain Bolt was not in London for the 2017 World Championships. Someone else showed up in his place -- this Other Bolt who finished third in the 100 last week, then caught a cramp in the 4x100 and could not finish the race.\n\nUsain Bolt is the man with three world records, nine Olympic triumphs and countless come-from-behind victories, who said in Rio last summer, \"There was no one on that track that could outrun me to the finish.\"\n\nThe Other Bolt was outrun to the finish three times in London -- and that was just in the 100. So, when the Other Bolt got the baton in third place on the 4x100 anchor leg, it was clear he was not going to win.\n\nIt was the worst possible ending for an athlete whose performances and personality kept his struggling sport afloat. Despite this disastrous final meet, Usain Bolt remains the greatest sprinter of all time and one of the most thrilling and popular athletes ever. The memories of the Other Bolt will fade, just as they did of so many other greats who chose not to leave at their peak. Which is their right -- to compete as long as their sport gives them joy, not as long as they show us what we want to see.\n\n\"No one wants to see Usain go out like that, with an injury on the track in that way,\" said Justin Gatlin, who took gold in the 100 and helped the U.S. men win silver in the 4x100 relay. Great Britain won the relay and China finished third.\n\n\"He's done so much from 2008 to now,\" Gatlin added. \"I think we can look past everything that happened in this championship and congratulate him on his legendary career.\"\n\nBolt always said his joy came from the fans. Asked why he didn't retire after Rio, his third consecutive Olympics with three gold medals, Bolt said he wanted to run one more season so the people could feel him one more time -- and vice versa.\n\nThat made his ending even sadder. The 60,000 faithful fans who came to Olympic Stadium to witness history Saturday were deprived of the traditional last lap around the stadium. The sporting world went to bed without a word from their hero. There would be no iconic \"To Di World\" pose -- he went straight to the infirmary and left the arena without a public word. The Jamaican team doctor, Kevin Jones, said he was struck down by a cramp in his left hamstring, \"but a lot of pain is from the disappointment of losing the race.\"\n\nOne has to wonder what the Other Bolt thought as he took the baton on the anchor leg, exited the exchange zone and found himself one stride behind American Christian Coleman and two behind Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake of Great Britain.\n\nHe took six strides toward the finish line of his career. The gap did not close. On the seventh, he threw his head back with a grimace, hopped twice to keep weight off his left leg and somersaulted to the track.\n\nDid he realize he could not win? What I'm about to say would be inconceivable for Usain Bolt, but ... since his reign began at the 2008 Olympics, he had never been injured in a major race. Could the Other Bolt have chosen to succumb to a twinge in his own body rather than lose to another man?\n\nBlasphemy, I know.\n\nBolt is 31, with a history of niggling back and hamstring injuries. Is there any graceful way to age? On Saturday, the runners were kept waiting longer than scheduled before their race as the temperature dipped toward 60 degrees. His heart has never been questioned. Enough of that.\n\nIt did seem like his heart was elsewhere this final season, though. Maybe with his close friend Germaine Mason, whose fatal motorcycle accident in April left Bolt despondent. Or skipping ahead to a life that doesn't require a Spartan existence and vomit-inducing workouts. Bolt made more than $60 million in 2016. The good life beckons.\n\n\"He's a living legend and we look up to him respectfully,\" said Sashalee Forbes, a Jamaican sprinter who won bronze in the women's 4x100. \"He shows us whether you're down or not, you still can get across that finish line.\"\n\nThe Other Bolt limped across the finish line, through the tunnel and disappeared. Let him go. Let's hold on to the memory of Usain Bolt, in first place.", "time": "02:46:00"}

"http://www.rappler.com/sports/by-sport/other-sports/178562-iaaf-4x100-relay-bolt-injured-britain-wins", "body": "SAD FAREWELL. Jamaica's Usain Bolt lies on the track after pulling up injured in the final of the men's 4x100m relay athletics event at the 2017 IAAF World Championships. Andrej Isakovic/AFP\n\nLONDON, United Kingdom - Usain Bolt's glittering career swansong came crashing to an end when he pulled up with a leg cramp on the anchor leg of the world 4x100m relay won by Britain at the IAAF World Championships on Saturday, August 12.\n\nBolt received the baton with Jamaica in 3rd, but halfway down the finishing straight the towering sprinter pulled up clutching his left thigh, eventually doing a forward somersault to the ground, to gasps from the 60,000 sell out London Stadium.\n\nThe British quartet of Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake claimed gold in 37.47 seconds, with the Justin Gatlin-led US 4 taking silver at 0.05sec and Japan a surprise bronze (38.04).\n\nJamaican team doctor Dr Kevin Jones said Bolt had suffered from \"cramp in his left hamstring\".\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jones said.\n\n\"The last 3 weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nSecond leg runner Julian Forte added: \"He didn't tell us exactly what happened but from what I saw, it looked like a strain or a cramp of some sort.\n\n\"He kept apologizing to us but we told him there was no need to apologize - injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nNewly-crowned 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, Jamaica's lead-off runner, added: \"Everybody was jelly, everybody was pumped. (Bolt's injury) just happened. Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nBolt missed out on his bid to retain his 100m title earlier in the week, losing out to Gatlin and silver medallist Christian Coleman, who ran relay anchor for the Americans on Saturday.\n\nBut hopes were high for Bolt's final competitive race, with Jamaica also boasting McLeod, Forte and 2011 world champion Yohan Blake in their line-up.\n\nJamaica were afforded a rousing welcome from the crowd, a relaxed-looking Bolt applauding the stands, with pictures of him constantly shown on the stadium's big screens.\n\nGatlin, who has served two doping bans, and the US team also including another convicted doping cheat, Mike Rodgers, and Jaylen Bacon were booed when introduced although the jeering was less pronounced than for the individual 100m event.\n\nA close first 3 legs saw Britain, the United States and Jamaica, seeking a 5th consecutive world title, level-pegged for the final leg.\n\nHigh drama\n\nBut there was to be high drama as a visibly swearing Bolt pulled up in obvious pain, allowing the Japanese quartet to edge in for 3rd.\n\nThe result means Bolt, 100 and 200m world record holder, finishes his career with 14 world career medals, one behind American Allyson Felix, to go with 8 Olympic golds.\n\nAmid wild home celebrations, Bolt was attended to by medics, but refused a ride in a wheelchair off the track, instead finally getting up and limping alongside his teammates through to the finish line and then off into the bowels of the stadium for treatment.\n\nIt was a sad exit for an athlete who has lit up the track when the sport has been dragged through its worst-ever crisis, racked by doping and corruption scandals that went to the very heart of athletics' governing body.\n\nAnd what a gaping hole his absence will leave, no matter how brave a face the IAAF try to put on it.\n\nSince confirming his sprinting dominance with triple gold at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Bolt spent 9 seasons amassing 19 global golds, 13 of which have come in individual events.\n\nAllied with a charismatic personality, it has guaranteed Bolt recognition as one of the world's most successful sportsmen. Last year alone he earned $34.2 million, according to Forbes. - Rappler.com", "time": "02:34:00"}

"wiki", "id": "1053871"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omar_McLeod", "label": {"eng": "Omar McLeod"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1333564"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Talbot_(athlete)", "label": {"eng": "Daniel Talbot (athlete)"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1402134"}], "url": "http://zeenews.india.com/news/usain-bolt-fails-to-strike-in-his-final-race-goes-down-with-cramp-in-4-100m-relay-2032498.html", "body": "London: Usain Bolt ended his illustrious career in agony after he injured himself while running the last lap of the 4x100m relay race at the World Championships here. Bolt, who was anchoring the Jamaican team, limped after running a few meters and fell down on the ground in pain, holding his head with both hands in dejection. Great Britain won the gold while the United States and Japan took the silver and bronze respectively.\n\nThe British quartet of Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake claimed gold in 37.47 seconds, while Justin Gatlin-led US won silver in 37.52 seconds and Japan took the bronze in 38.04 seconds.\n\nJamaican team doctor Dr Kevin Jones said Bolt had suffered from cramp in his left hamstring.\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race. The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him,\" Jones said.\n\nSecond leg runner Julian Forte added, \"He didn't tell us exactly what happened but from what I saw, it looked like a strain or a cramp of some sort. He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nNewly-crowned 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, Jamaica's lead-off runner, added,\"Everybody was jelly, everybody was pumped. (Bolt's injury) just happened. Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nBolt missed out on his bid to retain his 100m title earlier in the week, losing out to Gatlin and silver medallist Christian Coleman, who ran relay anchor for the Americans on Saturday.\n\nBut hopes were high for Bolt's final competitive race, with Jamaica also boasting McLeod, Forte and 2011 world champion Yohan Blake in their line-up.\n\nJamaica was afforded a rousing welcome from the crowd, a relaxed-looking Bolt applauding the stands, with pictures of him constantly shown on the stadium's big screens.\n\nGatlin, who has served two doping bans, and the US team also including another convicted doping cheat, Mike Rodgers, and Jaylen Bacon were booed when introduced although the jeering was less pronounced than for the individual 100m event.\n\nA close first three legs saw Britain, the United States and Jamaica, seeking a fifth consecutive world title, level-pegged for the final leg.\n\nBut there was to be high drama as a visibly swearing Bolt pulled up in obvious pain, allowing the Japanese quartet to edge in for third.\n\nThe result means Bolt, 100 and 200m world record holder, finishes his career with 14 world career medals, one behind American Allyson Felix, to go with eight Olympic golds.\n\nAmid wild home celebrations, Bolt was attended to by medics, but refused a ride in a wheelchair off the track, instead finally getting up and limping alongside his teammates through to the finish line and then off into the bowels of the stadium for treatment.\n\nIt was a sad exit for an athlete who has lit up the track when the sport has been dragged through its worst-ever crisis, racked by doping and corruption scandals that went to the very heart of athletics' governing body.\n\nAnd what a gaping hole his absence will leave, no matter how brave a face the IAAF try to put on it.\n\nSince confirming his sprinting dominance with triple gold at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Bolt spent nine seasons amassing 19 global golds, 13 of which have come in individual events.\n\nAllied with a charismatic personality, it has guaranteed Bolt recognition as one of the world's most successful sportsmen. Last year alone he earned $34.2 million, according to Forbes.", "time": "01:45:00"}

"body": "Usain Bolt \"was really cold\" before pulling up with injury in his last championship final, according to his Jamaican relay team-mates.\n\nBolt's London finale ended in disappointment as he suffered a muscle cramp before the end of the 4x100m relay final which was won by Great Britain.\n\nYohan Blake said: \"The race was 10 minutes late, we were kept 40 minutes. It was crazy.\n\n\"They were holding us too long.\"\n\nBolt had hoped to bring an end to his career with another two gold medals in London but leaves with only a bronze from last weekend's 100m.\n\nAnd, seconds after taking the baton for Jamaica's anchor leg, he pulled up and tumbled to the floor with Dr Kevin Jones, Jamaica's team doctor, confirming Bolt had cramp in his left hamstring.\n\n\"It was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run,\" added former world 100m champion Blake.\n\n\"We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us.\n\n\"It hurts to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggle like that.\"\n\n110m hurdle champion Omar McLeod, who led out the Jamaican team which had won the 4x100m relay in each of the last four world championships, echoed the criticism of delays at the start of the final.\n\nMo Farah's lap of honour after his second place in the 5,000m final seemed to delay the schedule, with Farah also receiving his medal before the relay final.\n\n\"It's heart-wrenching,\" he said. \"I gave it my all and I really wanted Usain to leave golden, or even if it was just a medal.\n\n\"It was ridiculous, man. We waited a really long time. I drank two bottles of water.\n\n\"But Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\n100m champion Justin Gatlin called Bolt 'still the best in the world' after he won silver behind Great Britain, and also felt that the weather may have played a part in Bolt's injury.\n\n\"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury),\" he said. \"I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\n\"I think it was just one season too many,\" said former Olympic champion Michael Johnson.\n\n\"I think Bolt was prepared to not win but I don't think he would have expected his last race to end like that. He would have wanted to cross the finish line.\n\n\"Even if he was just closing on the guys ahead - he wanted to give this crowd a show so they can say \"I saw Usain Bolt run down the finishing straight.\"\n\n\"That was disappointing to see. We saw him in a way we have never seen before. In the 100m straining to try to finish and now we see him limping.\"\n\nFormer Olympic medallist Darren Campbell believes that Bolt's impact off the track is almost as hard to replace as his skill and records on it.\n\nBolt's charisma, charm and character have made him one of the most recognisable and marketable people on the planet.\n\n\"Any stadium that Usain Bolt decides to grace ends up being full, that tells you all you need to know,\" Campbell said.\n\n\"What we are witnessing is so powerful, so inspirational, he can't be replaced. How do you replace him - as a sports star and a human being?\n\n\"Usain Bolt treats you the same whether you are a dignitary or the poorest man in the world. That's a unique skill.\n\n\"Whether he was a successful sports person or not, I think he would still have that flamboyant character. How do you teach that? I don't think you can.\"", "time": "23:37:00"}

"http://www.themalaymailonline.com/sports/article/bolt-anchors-jamaica-into-finals", "body": "File photo of Usain Bolt of Jamaica reacting after the men's 100 m final race in London, August 5, 2017. -- Reuters pic London, August 12 -- Usain Bolt's bid to bring the curtain down on his glittering career with a 15th world gold medal remained on track as Jamaica qualified for the final of the 4x100m relay.\n\nBolt took the unusual step of racing the relay heats, something usually reserved for the more unheralded members of the squad.\n\nTyquendo Tracey, Julian Forte and Michael Campbell safely negotiated the first three legs before Bolt steered his team home in a winning, season's best of 37.95 seconds.\n\n\"It's been brilliant. The energy in the stadium is outstanding,\" Bolt said, hailing the deafening support in the packed-out London Stadium \"not just for me but the whole championships\".\n\nBolt said his emotions were still in check at the thought of bowing out of track and field.\n\n\"For me it's hard to be sad because the energy I'm getting from the crowd is brilliant, I'm just happy.\"\n\nBolt's bid to retain his 100m title went up in smoke as American Justin Gatlin won gold, with Christian Coleman taking silver.\n\nIt was the first time Bolt had been beaten at a major championships since the 4x100m relay at the 2007 worlds in Osaka.\n\nThe 100 and 200m world record holder, who also anchored the Jamaican squad to a world record in the relay of 36.84sec at the 2012 London Olympics, will be back at the track for the final at 2050 GMT.\n\nBolt has amassed eight Olympic golds and 14 world medals, 11 of which are gold, the Jamaican having won two silvers in 2007 before his 100m bronze in London.\n\nNo matter the result of the relay, organisers said Bolt will be afforded a dedicated lap of honour on Sunday in tribute to his amazing track career.\n\nGatlin ran the second leg for the US team, led off by Mike Rodgers, another dope cheat, BeeJay Lee and Coleman on anchor.\n\nThey clocked 37.70 seconds to finish 0.06sec ahead of Britain.\n\nAlso qualifying for the final were France, China, Japan, Turkey and Canada. -- AFP", "time": "10:58:00"}

"Nesta Carter"}, "score": 2, "type": "person", "id": "460437"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Jones_(American_football)", "label": {"eng": "Kevin Jones (American football)"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "546615"}], "url": "http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/sports/usain-bolts-running-career-ends-in-agony/articleshow/60043352.cms", "body": "LONDON: Irony was at its cruellest as Usain Leo Bolt pulled up hurt in his final competitive race to end, in a cry of pain and agony, a decade of dominance that is unrivalled in the history of track and field.\n\nBolt failed to finish the men's 4x100m relay race of the World Athletics Championships here after he pulled a hamstring at the home straight.\n\nThe astonishing turn of events marred what was expected to be a golden farewell.\n\nRunning the final race of his career, the 30-year-old Bolt, after taking the baton from his Jamaican teammate Yohan Blake, suffered cramps on his left hamstring as he tried, in vain, to chase down the British and American rivals in the last lap of the race.\n\nNeeding to make a lot of ground, Bolt began his familiar initial long strides but could not produce the trademark explosive burst of speed and suddenly stumbled, hobbled a few strides before falling on the track in pain and agony.\n\n\"It's cramp in his left hamstring but a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race. The last three weeks have been hard for him. We hope for the best for him,\" Jamaican team doctor Kevin Jones said later.\n\nIt was a terrible sight at the Olympic stadium, the theatre of his three gold winning exploits in the 2012 Olympic Games. Bolt went down on his knees with hands on his head in dejection and was then lying alone on the tracks for a while before Blake and the other teammates, Julian Forte and Omar McLeod, gathered around him.\n\nThe towering Jamaican, who had dominated the sprint race like nobody else, was helped to his feet. As he limped over the finishing line, the crowd applauded him.\n\nThe result sheet, however, showed DNF (Did Not Finish) against the Jamaicans.\n\nThe scene this weekend was more heartbreaking than last Saturday when Bolt was beaten by his long-time rival Justin Gatlin in the 100m dash in his last individual race.\n\nThe last time, Bolt took a lap of honour to acknowledge the support and adulation of the crowd. But this time, there was no lap of honour and with Britain winning the gold, the crowd gave more attention to their home heroes and Bolt disappeared to the medical room.\n\nFor that matter, there was no kissing of the finish line nor the celebrated \"Lightening Bolt' pose, which fans around the world got used to all these years. The showman actually did not turn up on this night.\n\nIn fact, it looked like the lap of honour he took while winning the bronze in the 100m dash on August 5 would be his final farewell to the crowd. But it is learnt that the IAAF and local organisers have decided to arrange a lap of honour on the final day of the championships.\n\nBritain won the gold in 37.47 seconds while United States (38.01) and Japan took the silver and bronze respectively. Bolt would have had his task cut out, if he did not suffer the injury, to fight his way into the gold medal picture, as he was some three meters behind the British counterpart when he took the baton from Blake.\n\nGatlin, who was booed by the London crowd for snatching the gold medal from Bolt in the 100m, paid a tribute to his rival.\n\n\"Usain Bolt is a great athlete. I am sorry he got this injury. I think it was the elements. But he is still the best in the world,\" said Gatlin.\n\n\"You can't let these championships define what he has done in the past. He has done amazing things. He's still the man, you know. The was his farewell race and we wish him the best and hope he recovers soon,\" added the American who ran the second leg in the relay race.\n\n\"Usain's name will always live on,\" Bolt's team-mate Omar McLeod, who ran the first leg, said.\n\nBolt ended the World Championships in disappointment by collecting just a bronze but he will still be considered the greatest sprinter of all time and saviour of a sport for long mired in doping controversies.\n\nNo man has ever dominated sprint like Bolt since he won a gold each in the 100m and 200m in the 2008 Beijing Olympics and for nearly 10 years, he strode like a colossus with his running prowess and charisma.\n\nHe has won eight Olympic and 11 World Championships gold medals before coming here.\n\nHe has won three gold each in all three Olympics he has taken part, but returned the gold he won in 4x100m relay in Beijing after team-mate Nesta Carter tested positive for a prohibited substance. He has won three gold in all World Championships from 2009 till this edition, except the 100m event in 2011, when he false started to be disqualified.\n\nHe has also won a silver each in 200m and 4x100m relay in the 2007 Osaka World Championships. Taking into account the bronze in 100m here, he has won 22 medals in Olympics and World Championships taken together, with 19 of them gold.\n\nThe 'Muhammed Ali of Athletics', as christened by world athletics body boss Sebastian Coe, Bolt is one of the most charismatic athletes across all sports and he would be remembered as someone who has brought more fans to athletics at a time when public cynicism of the sport was on the rise due to doping controversies.\n\nThe latest -- and the biggest -- controversy to hit athletics was the Russian scandal in which the country was accused of systematic state-sponsored doping programme.\n\nDespite these scandals, Bolt kept the fans intact, his exploits and charisma brought more youngsters to the sport, a fact Coe has admitted.\n\nBolt's successes are unprecedented and all the short sprint records are his. He holds the 100m (9.58 seconds) and 200m (19.19 seconds) world records -- both of them set during the 2009 Berlin World Championships.\n\nSince 2007, he has run 54 100m races (excluding heats) and won all but six. In 200m races since 2008, he has lost just one out of 30.\n\nHe emerged as a prodigious talent for the first time by winning the 200m as a 15-year-old in the 2002 World Junior Championships at his hometown Kingston. He then won another 200m gold in the World Youth Championships in Canada. Bolt's young career was, however, rocked by injuries for a few years, but he came back stronger in 2006.\n\nBolt was initially thought to be more suited to run in 200m and 400m as he had difficulty in smoothly starting out of the blocks but, in 2007, his celebrated coach Glenn Mills, who has been with him since 2005, allowed him to run the 100m.\n\nIn his native Jamaica, he is the most well-known athlete -- and possibly the most famous public figure. Thousands turned out in his domestic farewell event in Kingston earlier this year.\n\nHis exit from the competitive stage -- though the IAAF wants him to be associated as global brand ambassador -- will bring shudders to athletics bosses.\n\nBolt's clean image has been a contrast to his long-time rival Gatlin, who is considered the opposite of the Jamaican.\n\nAnd the IAAF has banked on the Jamaican's clean image to shield the dope-tainted sport.\n\nOne of the richest sportspersons in the world, he reportedly earns more than USD 30 million a year, mostly through endorsements.\n\nThe greatest entertainer that athletics -- perhaps all sports -- have known, Bolt, unlike Ali, has rarely given opinions on issues beyond sport.\n\nBut the Jamaican wants to coin superlatives about himself like the boxing legend, and fans and media lapped up the idea.\n\nJust before this championships, he had demanded that the world write one last headline about him -- \"Unbeatable. Unstoppable\".\n\nJust after his 200m triumph at the 2012 London Olympics, he had declared, \"I am a living legend. Bask in my glory!\"\n\nThe world will continue to bask in his glory!", "time": "07:38:00"}

"type": "person", "id": "546615"}], "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/sports/report-greatest-bolt-s-running-career-ends-in-agony-2528446", "body": "Irony was at its cruellest as Usain Leo Bolt pulled up hurt in his final competitive race to end, in a cry of pain and agony, a decade of dominance that is unrivalled in the history of track and field.\n\nBolt failed to finish the men's 4x100m relay race of the World Athletics Championships here after he pulled a hamstring at the home straight.\n\nThe astonishing turn of events marred what was expected to be a golden farewell.\n\nRunning the final race of his career, the 30-year-old Bolt, after taking the baton from his Jamaican teammate Yohan Blake, suffered cramps on his left hamstring as he tried, in vain, to chase down the British and American rivals in the last lap of the race.\n\nNeeding to make a lot of ground, Bolt began his familiar initial long strides but could not produce the trademark explosive burst of speed and suddenly stumbled, hobbled a few strides before falling on the track in pain and agony.\n\n\"It's cramp in his left hamstring but a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race. The last three weeks have been hard for him. We hope for the best for him,\" Jamaican team doctor Kevin Jones said later.\n\nIt was a terrible sight at the Olympic stadium, the theatre of his three gold winning exploits in the 2012 Olympic Games. Bolt went down on his knees with hands on his head in dejection and was then lying alone on the tracks for a while before Blake and the other teammates, Julian Forte and Omar McLeod, gathered around him.\n\nThe towering Jamaican, who had dominated the sprint race like nobody else, was helped to his feet. As he limped over the finishing line, the crowd applauded him.\n\nThe result sheet, however, showed DNF (Did Not Finish) against the Jamaicans.\n\nThe scene this weekend was more heartbreaking than last Saturday when Bolt was beaten by his long-time rival Justin Gatlin in the 100m dash in his last individual race.\n\nThe last time, Bolt took a lap of honour to acknowledge the support and adulation of the crowd. But this time, there was no lap of honour and with Britain winning the gold, the crowd gave more attention to their home heroes and Bolt disappeared to the medical room.\n\nFor that matter, there was no kissing of the finish line nor the celebrated \"Lightening Bolt' pose, which fans around the world got used to all these years. The showman actually did not turn up on this night.\n\nIn fact, it looked like the lap of honour he took while winning the bronze in the 100m dash on August 5 would be his final farewell to the crowd. But it is learnt that the IAAF and local organisers have decided to arrange a lap of honour on the final day of the championships.\n\nBritain won the gold in 37.47 seconds while United States (38.01) and Japan took the silver and bronze respectively.\n\nBolt would have had his task cut out, if he did not suffer the injury, to fight his way into the gold medal picture, as he was some three meters behind the British counterpart when he took the baton from Blake.\n\nGatlin, who was booed by the London crowd for snatching the gold medal from Bolt in the 100m, paid a tribute to his rival.\n\n\"Usain Bolt is a great athlete. I am sorry he got this injury. I think it was the elements. But he is still the best in the world,\" said Gatlin.\n\n\"You can't let these championships define what he has done in the past. He has done amazing things. He's still the man, you know. The was his farewell race and we wish him the best and hope he recovers soon,\" added the American who ran the second leg in the relay race.\n\n\"Usain's name will always live on,\" Bolt's team-mate Omar McLeod, who ran the first leg, said.\n\nBolt ended the World Championships in disappointment by collecting just a bronze but he will still be considered the greatest sprinter of all time and saviour of a sport for long mired in doping controversies.\n\nNo man has ever dominated sprint like Bolt since he won a gold each in the 100m and 200m in the 2008 Beijing Olympics and for nearly 10 years, he strode like a colossus with his running prowess and charisma.\n\nHe has won eight Olympic and 11 World Championships gold medals before coming here.\n\nHe has won three gold each in all three Olympics he has taken part, but returned the gold he won in 4x100m relay in Beijing after team-mate Nesta Carter tested positive for a prohibited substance. He has won three gold in all World Championships from 2009 till this edition, except the 100m event in 2011, when he false started to be disqualified.\n\nHe has also won a silver each in 200m and 4x100m relay in the 2007 Osaka World Championships. Taking into account the bronze in 100m here, he has won 22 medals in Olympics and World Championships taken together, with 19 of them gold.\n\nThe 'Muhammed Ali of Athletics', as christened by world athletics body boss Sebastian Coe, Bolt is one of the most charismatic athletes across all sports and he would be remembered as someone who has brought more fans to athletics at a time when public cynicism of the sport was on the rise due to doping controversies.\n\nThe latest -- and the biggest -- controversy to hit athletics was the Russian scandal in which the country was accused of systematic state-sponsored doping programme.\n\nDespite these scandals, Bolt kept the fans intact, his exploits and charisma brought more youngsters to the sport, a fact Coe has admitted.\n\nBolt's successes are unprecedented and all the short sprint records are his. He holds the 100m (9.58 seconds) and 200m (19.19 seconds) world records -- both of them set during the 2009 Berlin World Championships.\n\nSince 2007, he has run 54 100m races (excluding heats) and won all but six. In 200m races since 2008, he has lost just one out of 30.\n\nHe emerged as a prodigious talent for the first time by winning the 200m as a 15-year-old in the 2002 World Junior Championships at his hometown Kingston. He then won another 200m gold in the World Youth Championships in Canada. Bolt's young career was, however, rocked by injuries for a few years, but he came back stronger in 2006.\n\nBolt was initially thought to be more suited to run in 200m and 400m as he had difficulty in smoothly starting out of the blocks but, in 2007, his celebrated coach Glenn Mills, who has been with him since 2005, allowed him to run the 100m.\n\nIn his native Jamaica, he is the most well-known athlete -- and possibly the most famous public figure. Thousands turned out in his domestic farewell event in Kingston earlier this year.\n\nHis exit from the competitive stage -- though the IAAF wants him to be associated as global brand ambassador -- will bring shudders to athletics bosses.\n\nBolt's clean image has been a contrast to his long-time rival Gatlin, who is considered the opposite of the Jamaican.\n\nAnd the IAAF has banked on the Jamaican's clean image to shield the dope-tainted sport.\n\nOne of the richest sportspersons in the world, he reportedly earns more than USD 30 million a year, mostly through endorsements.\n\nThe greatest entertainer that athletics -- perhaps all sports -- have known, Bolt, unlike Ali, has rarely given opinions on issues beyond sport.\n\nBut the Jamaican wants to coin superlatives about himself like the boxing legend, and fans and media lapped up the idea.\n\nJust before this championships, he had demanded that the world write one last headline about him -- \"Unbeatable.\n\nUnstoppable\".\n\nJust after his 200m triumph at the 2012 London Olympics, he had declared, \"I am a living legend. Bask in my glory!\" The world will continue to bask in his glory!\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency feed.)", "time": "06:42:00"}

"http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/sports/2017/08/12/bolt-anchors-jamaica-world-4x100-relay-finals/", "body": "Shares\n\nJamaica's Usain Bolt (C) race to victory on the anchor leg ahead of Canada's Mobolade Ajomale (R) and Cuba's Jose Luis Gaspar to win their heat in the 4x100m relay at the IAAF World Championships at the London Stadium in London, on August 12, 2017 \u00a9 AFP / Jewel SAMAD\n\nLONDON, United Kingdom, Aug 12 - Usain Bolt's bid to bring the curtain down on his glittering career with a 15th world gold medal remained on track as Jamaica qualified for the final of the 4x100m relay.\n\nBolt took the unusual step of racing the relay heats, something usually reserved for the more unheralded members of the squad.\n\nTyquendo Tracey, Julian Forte and Michael Campbell safely negotiated the first three legs before Bolt steered his team home in a winning, season's best of 37.95 seconds.\n\n\"It's been brilliant. The energy in the stadium is outstanding,\" Bolt said, hailing the deafening support in the packed-out London Stadium \"not just for me but the whole championships\".\n\nBolt said his emotions were still in check at the thought of bowing out of track and field.\n\n\"For me it's hard to be sad because the energy I'm getting from the crowd is brilliant, I'm just happy.\n\n\"There are no words to describe how I am feeling.\"\n\nBolt acknowledged that Yohan Blake would likely come in for the final, all the while praising his less experienced relay teammates.\n\n\"The young runners in our team -- it is just about executing and coming through the race for them,\" he said.\n\n\"We have been training that relay, there were some camps. Still there were some mistakes. Yohan Blake coming in for the final is definitely good.\"\n\nBolt's bid to retain his 100m title went up in smoke as American Justin Gatlin won gold, with Christian Coleman taking silver.\n\nIt was the first time Bolt had been beaten at a major championships since the 4x100m relay at the 2007 worlds in Osaka.\n\nThe 100 and 200m world record holder, who also anchored the Jamaican squad to a world record in the relay of 36.84sec at the 2012 London Olympics, will be back at the track for the final at 2050 GMT.\n\nBolt has amassed eight Olympic golds and 14 world medals, 11 of which are gold, the Jamaican having won two silvers in 2007 before his 100m bronze in London.\n\nNo matter the result of the relay, organisers said Bolt will be afforded a dedicated lap of honour on Sunday in tribute to his amazing track career.\n\nGatlin ran the second leg for the US team, led off by Mike Rodgers, another dope cheat, BeeJay Lee and Coleman on anchor.\n\nThey clocked 37.70 seconds to finish 0.06sec ahead of Britain.\n\n\"It felt good,\" said Rodgers. \"It feels like second nature because we work well together.\n\n\"We are confident we can win. We will go and prepare well for tonight.\"\n\nAlso qualifying for the final were France, China, Japan, Turkey and Canada.\n\nShares", "time": "12:17:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Talbot_(athlete)", "label": {"eng": "Daniel Talbot (athlete)"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1402134"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tori_Bowie", "label": {"eng": "Tori Bowie"}, "score": 1, "type": "wiki", "id": "1405606"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chijindu_Ujah", "label": {"eng": "Chijindu Ujah"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1417682"}], "url": "http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/08/sad-farewell-bolt-ends-glittering-career-injury-170812220846617.html", "body": "Usain Bolt pulled up with injury on the anchor leg of the 4x100 metres relay final at the World Athletics Championships.\n\nUsain Bolt pulled up with an injury on the anchor leg of the 4x100 metres relay final at the World Athletics Championships on Saturday as the last race of his unparalleled career ended in high drama.\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift when, straining hard to catch the leaders, he suddenly suffered a hamstring injury, began hobbling and ended up coming to a halt after doing a forward roll on the track.\n\nAfter a short while, though, he rose gingerly to his feet and limped across the line to huge cheers from the 56,000 crowd.\n\nThat wasn't the only surprise. Britain went on to beat the United States in a tight finish.\n\nREAD MORE: Usain Bolt, from strong child to track king\n\nThe 60,000-capacity stadium was primed for one last Bolt show, one last \"To the World\" pose after a victory, but the injury made it blatantly clear why Bolt is ready to retire. His body can no longer hold up.\n\nHis teammates on the once-fabled Jamaican sprint squad were far from unmatchable, too. Bolt had just too much to make up in the final 100 metres as both Britain and the US were ahead and even Japan was even.\n\nAs Bolt fell to the ground, the leg with the golden shoe giving way, the crowd still went wild because the home team went on to win gold in 37.47 seconds, 0.05 seconds ahead of the US.\n\nThe brilliantly executed race by Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Danny Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake gave Britain gold in 37.47 seconds, breaking an 18-year-old national record, and the world title for the first time.\n\nThe result means Bolt, 100 and 200m world record holder, finishes his career with 14 world career medals, one behind American Allyson Felix, to go with eight Olympic golds.\n\nAmid wild home celebrations, Bolt was attended to by medics, but refused a ride in a wheelchair off the track, instead finally getting up and limping alongside his teammates through to the finish line and then off into the stadium for treatment.\n\nIt was a sad exit for an athlete who has lit up the track when the sport has been dragged through its worst-ever crisis, racked by doping and corruption scandals that went to the very heart of athletics' governing body.\n\nSince confirming his sprinting dominance with triple gold at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Bolt spent nine seasons amassing 19 global golds, 13 of which have come in individual events.\n\nAllied with a charismatic personality, it has guaranteed Bolt recognition as one of the world's most successful sportsmen. Last year alone he earned $34.2m, according to Forbes.\n\nAl Jazeera's Sonia Gallego, reporting from London, said Bolt would be remembered as one of the all time great athletes.\n\n\"It's very unlikely that we're going to see anyone of his ilk very soon,\" she said.\n\n\"So really quite a sad end to Usain Bolt's career but hopefully not the end of him as a personality and as an ambassador for the sport.\"\n\nBefore Bolt came onto the track, he was consoling Mo Farah, his long-distance equivalent who had just lost his first major race since 2011 when he failed to get gold in the 5,000 metres.\n\nFarah also was bidding farewell to the track, coming up short of his fifth straight 5,000-10,000 double at major championships in a sprint against Muktar Edris of Ethiopia.\n\nFarah, now 34 years old and a six-time world champion, knew the opposition would be gunning for him. And they did.\n\nThey boxed Farah in. They changed the pace of the race. They made him work hard knowing that his 10,000-metre victory on the opening day of the championships would take something out of his punishing finish.\n\n\"I gave it all,\" Farah said. \"I didn't have a single bit left at the end.\"\n\nAl Jazeera's Sonia Gallego said that Farah's silver was disappointing but that he had made a gracious lap of honour and posed with fans.\n\n\"Certainly a very honourable end for a tremendous athlete and certainly quite sad to see it happen in a place where he had made his name in such spectacular fashion back in the 2012 Olympics,\" said Gallego.\n\nTori Bowie was the unlikely first double gold medalist at the championships, anchoring the US team to the 4x100-metre relay title ahead of Britain and Jamaica.\n\nAt the same time, Allyson Felix, running the second leg on the winning team, earned a record 15th medal at the world championships in a career going back to 2005.\n\nBowie, who won the 100 metres this week, ran a strong anchor leg, leaving behind the opposition to finish in 41.82 seconds.\n\n\"Two gold medals is amazing for me,\" Bowie said. \"We are on top of the world.\"\n\nBritain took silver in 42.12 and two-time defending champion Jamaica earned bronze in 42.19.", "time": "00:00:00"}

"http://www.firstpost.com/sports/iaaf-world-athletics-championships-2017-usain-bolt-aims-to-retire-on-high-as-jamaica-qualify-for-relay-final-3923411.html", "body": "London: Usain Bolt's bid to bring the curtain down on his glittering career with a 15th world gold medal remained on track as Jamaica qualified for the final of the 4x100 metres relay.\n\nBolt took the unusual step of racing the relay heats, something usually reserved for the more unheralded members of the squad.\n\nJamaica's Usain Bolt during the men's 4x100m relay. AP\n\nTyquendo Tracey, Julian Forte and Michael Campbell safely negotiated the first three legs before Bolt steered his team home in a winning, season's best of 37.95 seconds.\n\n\"It's been brilliant. The energy in the stadium is outstanding,\" Bolt said, hailing the deafening support in the packed-out London Stadium \"not just for me but the whole championships\".\n\nBolt said his emotions were still in check at the thought of bowing out of track and field.\n\n\"For me it's hard to be sad because the energy I'm getting from the crowd is brilliant, I'm just happy.\"\n\n\"There are no words to describe how I am feeling.\"\n\nBolt acknowledged that Yohan Blake would likely come in for the final, all the while praising his less experienced relay teammates.\n\n\"The young runners in our team -- it is just about executing and coming through the race for them,\" he said.\n\n\"We have been training that relay, there were some camps. Still there were some mistakes. Yohan Blake coming in for the final is definitely good.\"\n\nBolt's bid to retain his 100m title went up in smoke as American Justin Gatlin won gold, with Christian Coleman taking silver.\n\nIt was the first time Bolt had been beaten at a major championships since the 4x100m relay at the 2007 worlds in Osaka.\n\nThe 100 and 200m world record holder, who also anchored the Jamaican squad to a world record in the relay of 36.84sec at the 2012 London Olympics, will be back at the track for the final at 2050 GMT.\n\nBolt has amassed eight Olympic golds and 14 world medals, 11 of which are gold, the Jamaican having won two silvers in 2007 before his 100m bronze in London.\n\nNo matter the result of the relay, organisers said Bolt will be afforded a dedicated lap of honour on Sunday in tribute to his amazing track career.\n\nGatlin ran the second leg for the US team, led off by Mike Rodgers, another dope cheat, BeeJay Lee and Coleman on anchor.\n\nThey clocked 37.70 seconds to finish 0.06sec ahead of Britain.\n\n\"It felt good,\" said Rodgers. \"It feels like second nature because we work well together.\n\n\"We are confident we can win. We will go and prepare well for tonight.\"\n\nAlso qualifying for the final were France, China, Japan, Turkey and Canada.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 12, 2017 05:04 pm | Updated Date: Aug 12, 2017 05:07 pm\n\nTags :#Christian coleman#Gatlin#Iaaf world championships 2017#Jamaica#Julian forte#London#Michael campbell#Osaka#Tyquendo tracey#Usain bolt#Yohan blake", "time": "11:46:00"}

"http://www.hindustantimes.com/other-sports/usain-bolt-will-be-back-in-a-year-or-two-justin-gatlin/story-GufacTj2uXETbjE6TNqguJ.html", "body": "Usain Bolt ended his career as an 11-time World Champion. (Twitter )\n\nJustin Gatlin remains convinced Usain Bolt will return to athletics after injury dramatically ruined his farewell in the 4x100 metres relay final in London on Saturday.\n\nBolt looked set to head into retirement with a record-equalling 15th IAAF World Championships medal but pulled up with an apparent hamstring injury and failed to finish the final leg of the race.\n\n(Read | Usain Bolt collapses in final race, Great Britain seal 4x100m relay gold)\n\nGreat Britain snatched the gold medal from the United States as the 30-year-old lay prone on the track, Christian Coleman beaten to the line by Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake.\n\nGatlin, who beat Coleman and Bolt to 100m gold last weekend, has previously expressed his opinion that his long-time rival will return to the sport in the future and reiterated those thoughts following an unbecoming farewell for the eight-time Olympic champion.\n\n(Read | Usain Bolt's record-breaking career in numbers)\n\n\"He's coming back in a year or two, he'll be ready. He has a passion for the sport, the fans love him, it's something you just can't walk away from that easy,\" said Gatlin.\n\n\"He's a showman, he wants to come out and I think he'll do a great job if he comes back to track and field. We've got a lot of young guys like Coleman, like [Jaylen] Bacon, myself, we're hungry to go out there for good competition.\"\n\nNot the way you want to see a legend like \u26a1\ufe0f end his #IAAFWorlds career. Heal soon, @usainbolt. -- USATF (@usatf)\n\nAugust 12, 2017\n\nRegardless of whether he returns to the track, Bolt is sure to be remembered as an all-time great - having secured 100m and 200m doubles at three successive Olympic Games as well as setting new world records in each event.\n\n(Read | 'Infinite love for fans': Usain Bolt thankful for support as stellar career ends)\n\n\"You can't really have this night define what he's done in the past,\" Gatlin added. \"From 2008 on, Usain Bolt has done amazing things and tonight is not going to define who he is.\n\n\"He's still the man, and this is farewell so we take our hat off to him, hope he gets well soon.\"\n\nGatlin was one of many competitors who suggested a lengthy wait ahead of Saturday's relay may have contributed to Bolt's injury.\n\n\"We were in the stadium for a while, you guys know how chilly it is down here,\" he said. \"We had a cool breeze in the back and I think with that a lot of our muscles were cramping up from having our clothes off a little too early.\n\n\"Hopefully it's just a cramp and it'll go away, but I hope he doesn't dwell on it.\"", "time": "00:59:00"}

"http://sports.inquirer.net/260310/usain-bolt-world-relay-britain-athletics-world-4x100m", "body": "Usain Bolt's glittering career swansong came crashing to an end when he pulled up with a leg cramp on the anchor leg of the world 4x100m relay won by Britain on Saturday.\n\nBolt received the baton with Jamaica in third, but halfway down the finishing straight the towering sprinter pulled up clutching his left thigh, eventually doing a forward somersault to the ground, to gasps from the 60,000 sell out London Stadium.\n\nThe British quartet of Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake claimed gold in 37.47 seconds, with the Justin Gatlin-led US four taking silver at 0.05sec and Japan a surprise bronze (38.04).\n\nJamaican team doctor Dr. Kevin Jones said Bolt had suffered from \"cramp in his left hamstring.\"\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jones said.\n\n\"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nSecond leg runner Julian Forte added: \"He didn't tell us exactly what happened but from what I saw, it looked like a strain or a cramp of some sort.\n\n\"He kept apologizing to us but we told him there was no need to apologize -- injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nNewly-crowned 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, Jamaica's lead-off runner, added: \"Everybody was jelly, everybody was pumped. (Bolt's injury) just happened. Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nBolt missed out on his bid to retain his 100m title earlier in the week, losing out to Gatlin and silver medalist Christian Coleman, who ran relay anchor for the Americans on Saturday.\n\nBut hopes were high for Bolt's final competitive race, with Jamaica also boasting McLeod, Forte and 2011 world champion Yohan Blake in their line-up.\n\nJamaica were afforded a rousing welcome from the crowd, a relaxed-looking Bolt applauding the stands, with pictures of him constantly shown on the stadium's big screens.\n\nGatlin, who has served two doping bans, and the US team also including another convicted doping cheat, Mike Rodgers, and Jaylen Bacon were booed when introduced although the jeering was less pronounced than for the individual 100m event.\n\nA close first three legs saw Britain, the United States and Jamaica, seeking a fifth consecutive world title, level-pegged for the final leg.\n\nHigh drama\n\nBut there was to be high drama as a visibly swearing Bolt pulled up in obvious pain, allowing the Japanese quartet to edge in for third.\n\nThe result means Bolt, 100 and 200m world record holder, finishes his career with 14 world career medals, one behind American Allyson Felix, to go with eight Olympic golds.\n\nAmid wild home celebrations, Bolt was attended to by medics, but refused a ride in a wheelchair off the track, instead finally getting up and limping alongside his teammates through to the finish line and then off into the bowels of the stadium for treatment.\n\nIt was a sad exit for an athlete who has lit up the track when the sport has been dragged through its worst-ever crisis, racked by doping and corruption scandals that went to the very heart of athletics' governing body.\n\nAnd what a gaping hole his absence will leave, no matter how brave a face the IAAF try to put on it.\n\nSince confirming his sprinting dominance with triple gold at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Bolt spent nine seasons amassing 19 global golds, 13 of which have come in individual events.\n\nAllied with a charismatic personality, it has guaranteed Bolt recognition as one of the world's most successful sportsmen. Last year alone he earned $34.2 million, according to Forbes.", "time": "00:32:00"}

Stadium.\n\nThe British quartet of Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake claimed gold in 37.47 seconds, with the Justin Gatlin-led US four taking silver at 0.05sec and Japan a surprise bronze (38.04).\n\nJamaican team doctor Dr Kevin Jones said Bolt had suffered from \"cramp in his left hamstring\".\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jones said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nSecond leg runner Julian Forte added: \"He didn't tell us exactly what happened but from what I saw, it looked like a strain or a cramp of some sort. He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise - injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nNewly-crowned 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, Jamaica's lead-off runner, added: \"Everybody was jelly, everybody was pumped. (Bolt's injury) just happened. Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nBolt missed out on his bid to retain his 100m title earlier in the week, losing out to Gatlin and silver medallist Christian Coleman, who ran relay anchor for the Americans on Saturday.\n\nBut hopes were high for Bolt's final competitive race, with Jamaica also boasting McLeod, Forte and 2011 world champion Yohan Blake in their line-up.\n\nJamaica were afforded a rousing welcome from the crowd, a relaxed-looking Bolt applauding the stands, with pictures of him constantly shown on the stadium's big screens.\n\nGatlin, who has served two doping bans, and the US team also including another convicted doping cheat, Mike Rodgers, and Jaylen Bacon were booed when introduced although the jeering was less pronounced than for the individual 100m event.\n\nA close first three legs saw Britain, the United States and Jamaica, seeking a fifth consecutive world title, level-pegged for the final leg.\n\nHIGH DRAMA\n\nBut there was to be high drama as a visibly swearing Bolt pulled up in obvious pain, allowing the Japanese quartet to edge in for third.\n\nThe result means Bolt, 100 and 200m world record holder, finishes his career with 14 world career medals, one behind American Allyson Felix, to go with eight Olympic golds.\n\nAmid wild home celebrations, Bolt was attended to by medics, but refused a ride in a wheelchair off the track, instead finally getting up and limping alongside his teammates through to the finish line and then off into the bowels of the stadium for treatment.\n\nIt was a sad exit for an athlete who has lit up the track when the sport has been dragged through its worst-ever crisis, racked by doping and corruption scandals that went to the very heart of athletics' governing body.\n\nAnd what a gaping hole his absence will leave, no matter how brave a face the IAAF try to put on it.\n\nSince confirming his sprinting dominance with triple gold at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Bolt spent nine seasons amassing 19 global golds, 13 of which have come in individual events.\n\nAllied with a charismatic personality, it has guaranteed Bolt recognition as one of the world's most successful sportsmen. Last year alone he earned US$34.2 million, according to Forbes.", "time": "22:15:00"}

pm Commander Peshawar Corps visits Rajgal Valley, praises troops' morale\n\nUsain Bolt's bid to bring the curtain down on his glittering career with a 15th world gold medal remained on track as Jamaica qualified for the final of the 4x100m relay.\n\nBolt took the unusual step of racing the relay heats, something usually reserved for the more unheralded members of the squad.\n\nTyquendo Tracey, Julian Forte and Michael Campbell safely negotiated the first three legs before Bolt steered his team home in a winning, season's best of 37.95 seconds.\n\n\"It's been brilliant. The energy in the stadium is outstanding,\" Bolt said, hailing the deafening support in the packed-out London Stadium \"not just for me but the whole championships\".\n\nBolt said his emotions were still in check at the thought of bowing out of track and field.\n\n\"For me it's hard to be sad because the energy I'm getting from the crowd is brilliant, I'm just happy.\n\n\"There are no words to describe how I am feeling.\"\n\nBolt acknowledged that Yohan Blake would likely come in for the final, all the while praising his less experienced relay teammates.\n\n\"The young runners in our team -- it is just about executing and coming through the race for them,\" he said.\n\n\"We have been training that relay, there were some camps. Still there were some mistakes. Yohan Blake coming in for the final is definitely good.\"\n\nBolt's bid to retain his 100m title went up in smoke as American Justin Gatlin won gold, with Christian Coleman taking silver.\n\nIt was the first time Bolt had been beaten at a major championships since the 4x100m relay at the 2007 worlds in Osaka.\n\nThe 100 and 200m world record holder, who also anchored the Jamaican squad to a world record in the relay of 36.84sec at the 2012 London Olympics, will be back at the track for the final at 2050 GMT.\n\nBolt has amassed eight Olympic golds and 14 world medals, 11 of which are gold, the Jamaican having won two silvers in 2007 before his 100m bronze in London.\n\nNo matter the result of the relay, organisers said Bolt will be afforded a dedicated lap of honour on Sunday in tribute to his amazing track career.\n\nGatlin ran the second leg for the US team, led off by Mike Rodgers, another dope cheat, BeeJay Lee and Coleman on anchor.\n\nThey clocked 37.70 seconds to finish 0.06sec ahead of Britain.\n\n\"It felt good,\" said Rodgers. \"It feels like second nature because we work well together.\n\n\"We are confident we can win. We will go and prepare well for tonight.\"\n\nAlso qualifying for the final were France, China, Japan, Turkey and Canada.", "time": "14:35:00"}

"http://www.dnaindia.com/sports/report-watch-world-athletics-championships-when-usain-bolt-got-floored-in-final-race-of-glittering-career-2528344", "body": "Bolt, arguably the greatest athlete of all time, pulled up and fell to the floor with what looked like a hamstring injury.\n\nUsain Bolt's unparalleled career ended in extraordinary drama on Saturday as he pulled up with injury on the anchor leg of his very last race, the 4x100 metres relay final at the World Championships.\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track. Yet the sport's greatest entertainer was determined that one of the finest careers in sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair.\n\nSo the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried team mates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 metres to the line. The official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the team mates he felt he had let down. \"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\" McLeod added: \"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nTHIRD PLACE\n\nJustin Gatlin, the American winner of the individual 100 metres who had consigned Bolt to third place in his final individual race last Saturday, paid tribute to his rival.\n\n\"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury). I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said. \"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\nKevin Jones, the Jamaican team doctor, said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring. Blake was angry at having to wait for two medal ceremonies to take place before the race.\n\n\"It was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run ... we were kept 40 minutes. It was crazy,\" Blake said. \"They were holding us too long. We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us. It hurts to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggle like that.\"\n\nJamaican team manager Ian Forbes praised Bolt for \"going out there and giving his all\" and added that the squad were \"very saddened\".\n\n\"The diagnostic work will be done shortly to determine how serious it is. He was able to walk to the team bus so hopefully that signals it's not as serious as it possibly could be,\" Forbes said.\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favourite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track.\n\nFive years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics.\n\nYet in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000 metres, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell. Their leaving of the track scene leaves a void in the sport that does not look like being filled any time soon.\n\nHeartbreaking ending to a legendary career: Usain Bolt suffered cramp in his final race at #London2017 and didn't make it to the finish line pic.twitter.com/6zhDnFd5j8 -- People's Daily,China (@PDChina)\n\nAugust 13, 2017", "time": "03:41:00"}
