"USAIN Bolt's glittering career swansong came crashing to an end when he pulled up injured on the anchor leg of the 4x100m relay at the World Championships on Sunday morning (AEST).\n\nBolt received the baton with Jamaica in third, but halfway down the finishing straight the towering sprinter pulled up clutching his left thigh, eventually doing a forward somersault to the ground, to gasps from the 60,000 watching on at London Stadium.\n\nThe British quartet of Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake claimed gold in 37.47 seconds, with the Justin Gatlin-led US four taking silver and Japan a surprise bronze.\n\nThe result means Bolt, 100 and 200m world record holder, finishes his career with 14 world career medals, one behind American Allyson Felix, to go with eight Olympic golds.\n\nBolt was attended to by medics but refused a ride in a wheelchair off the track, instead finally getting up and limping alongside his teammates through to the finish line and then off into the bowels of the stadium for treatment.\n\nIt was a sad exit for an athlete who has lit up the track when the sport has been dragged through its worst-ever crisis, racked by doping and corruption scandals that went to the very heart of athletics' governing body.\n\nHere's how the world reacted to Bolt's disastrous day.\n\nBolt's teammate Yohan Blake slammed organisers for letting the medal presentation for the women's high jump run overtime, which meant the start of the relay was delayed by roughly 10 minutes.\n\nBlake also said Bolt had a bad feeling before the race about what the delayed start time would mean.\n\n\"A hero of the sport to go down like that, as a true friend, I didn't like it one bit,\" Blake said. \"They were holding us too long.\n\n\"To be holding us so long was atrocious.\n\n\"Usain was getting cold and he said, 'I don't like this'.\n\n\"They were holding us too long.\n\n\"Too many presentations so the race was 10 minutes long. It was cold.\"\n\nJamaican team doctor Kevin Jones later clarified Bolt suffered from a hamstring cramp, but the physical pain was overshadowed by the emotional anguish.\n\n\"It's cramps in his left hamstring but a lot of pain is from the disappointment of losing the race. The last three weeks have been hard for him, we hope for the best,\" Jones said.\n\nJones also reiterated Blake's concerns, saying: \"It was cold back there, and the guys were complaining.\"\n\nAmerican Justin Gatlin, who defeated Bolt in the 100m final while relegating him to third, agreed there was a problem with how the race was organised.\n\n\"We took (our) clothes off a little too early. Bolt was running out there cold.\"\n\nJamaican team not happy with being kept waiting before relay. Meant they got cold. They think Bolt suffered from cramp but too early to say. -- Natalie Pirks (@Natpirks)\n\nAugust 12, 2017\n\nUsain Bolt doesn't need to apologise to anyone. He may think he needs to, but his teammates say he doesn't owe anyone -- least of all them -- anything.\n\n\"He didn't tell us exactly what happened but from what I saw, it looked like a strain or a cramp of some sort,\" second leg runner Julian Forte said.\n\n\"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise -- injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nNewly-crowned 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, Jamaica's lead-off runner, added: \"Everybody was jelly, everybody was pumped. (Bolt's injury) just happened. Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nTHE LEGACY LIVES ON\n\nThe World Championships in London have deviated from the perfect script the 30-year-old sprinter's career has seemingly followed for its entirety. But while he missed out on 100m glory to convicted drug cheat Gatlin and left the relay without a medal, his legacy will not suffer.\n\nNew York Times sports writer Christopher Clarey said it was a cruel way for Bolt's career to end, but he will still be remembered as \"not only one of global sport's great athletes but one of its great entertainers, as well\".\n\nBolt's American rival Gatlin said: \"He is still the best in the world.\"\n\nBolt probably one year too many. Sad to see him go down in his final race. Personally I think he has been amazing for the sport. #Respect -- Michael Johnson (@MJGold)\n\nAugust 12, 2017\n\nIt's tough to see Usain Bolt end his career the way he did but his amazing legacy is unscathed. Bolt's the greatest sprinter of all time. -- Tyler Dragon (@TheTylerDragon)\n\nAugust 12, 2017\n\nWow. That was a heartbreaking finish to Bolt's career. Doesn't impact his legacy in my book. Still a transcendent champion. -- Braden Keith (@Braden_Keith)\n\nAugust 12, 2017\n\nSince confirming his sprinting dominance with triple gold at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Bolt spent nine seasons amassing 19 global golds, 13 of which have come in individual events.\n\nSadness was the overwhelming feeling on social media as Bolt's disaster caused a buzz in the Twittersphere.", "time": "22:49:00"}

"http://www.egyptindependent.com/bolt-gets-jamaica-relay-final-grand-farewell/", "body": "Usain Bolt set the stage for his grand farewell, powering down the finishing straight Saturday to qualify Jamaica for the 4\u00d7100-meter relay final at the world championships.\n\nFittingly, he will face Justin Gatlin and the United States in the final chapter of his unparalleled career.\n\nBoth nations won their heats early Saturday, though the U.S. relay squad got the baton around with more aplomb than Jamaica, which had to rely on Bolt to clinch victory.\n\nAnd Bolt relished the adulation at the 60,000-capacity Olympic Stadium.\n\n\"They've been outstanding so far, and continue to surprise me and give me energy,\" Bolt said.\n\nFor the best part of the past decade, though, Bolt has been 100 percent reliable in getting relay gold for the island nation. The last time Jamaica lost a world championship final was in Bolt's rookie year in 2007, when he ran the second leg and only took silver behind the Americans.\n\nEver since, Bolt has flaunted his power at the end of every major championship, getting the third gold medal for himself and sometimes another world record for Jamaica.\n\nThis year, however, he only got bronze in the 100 behind Gatlin. And the result in the relay is no longer a foregone conclusion.\n\nThe United States, with Gatlin running the second leg, won the first heat in a world leading time of 37.70 seconds. The Americans beat Britain and Japan, both of which also qualified.\n\n\"My team did a great job,\" said Gatlin, the oldest of the squad at 35. \"They're thinking and acting like veterans and I'm proud of them.\"\n\nChristian Coleman took silver in the 100 ahead of Bolt and it gave the U.S. team an added boost.\n\n\"Having the gold and silver medal on the same relay team, which hasn't been done in a long time, it gives us kind of a confidence booster that the speed can get around the track,\" Gatlin said.\n\nBolt stepped out on the track for the second heat, and the Jamaicans needed him. Trailing when he got the baton on the anchor leg, Bolt powered away, quickly swept past his rivals and had time to look to his right before crossing in 37.95 seconds.\n\nStill, Bolt was supportive of his young teammates.\n\n\"They came out here and did the job we wanted them to do, and that's to get us to the finals. They executed and ran well for a young team,\" Bolt said. \"Over the years, this will be the team bringing in the golds.\"\n\nIn the women's heats, both nations are also through.\n\nAllyson Felix stayed in line to become the athlete with the most medals in world championships history when she helped the American relay team qualify.\n\nRunning the second leg, Felix and her teammates crossed first in a season's leading time of 41.84 seconds, beating Britain and Switzerland. They also advanced to the final.\n\nIn the second heat, Germany beat two-time defending champion Jamaica to qualify along with Brazil.\n\nThe Netherlands, with 200-meter champion Dafne Schippers running the second leg, qualified on time.\n\nFelix has won 14 medals at the world championships and can move up to 16 if she runs the 4\u00d7400 relay and the United States wins medals in both events.\n\nIn the decathlon, two-time world champion Trey Hardee of the United States hit the third hurdle and clattered into the next one during the 110-meter hurdles to end his medal chances.\n\nIn the first of five events on the final day of the two-day competition, Kevin Mayer of France set a third personal record to easily stay atop the standings with 5,485 points. Rico Freimuth of Germany was in second place with 5,377 points, while Damian Warner of Canada had the fastest time in the hurdles of 13.63 seconds to move into third.\n\nAlso, British runner Mo Farah will compete in his last race on the track at a major championship when he goes for a fourth straight world title in the 5,000. He won a third 10,000-meter gold on the first day of the championships.", "time": "11:42:00"}

pulled up injured on the anchor leg of the 4x100m relay at the World Championships on Sunday morning (AEST).\n\nBolt received the baton with Jamaica in third, but halfway down the finishing straight the towering sprinter pulled up clutching his left thigh, eventually doing a forward somersault to the ground, to gasps from the 60,000 watching on at London Stadium.\n\nThe British quartet of Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake claimed gold in 37.47 seconds, with the Justin Gatlin-led US four taking silver and Japan a surprise bronze.\n\nThe result means Bolt, 100 and 200m world record holder, finishes his career with 14 world career medals, one behind American Allyson Felix, to go with eight Olympic golds.\n\nBolt was attended to by medics but refused a ride in a wheelchair off the track, instead finally getting up and limping alongside his teammates through to the finish line and then off into the bowels of the stadium for treatment.\n\nIt was a sad exit for an athlete who has lit up the track when the sport has been dragged through its worst-ever crisis, racked by doping and corruption scandals that went to the very heart of athletics' governing body.\n\nBolt's teammate Yohan Blake slammed organisers for letting the medal presentation for the women's high jump run overtime, which meant the start of the relay was delayed by roughly 10 minutes.\n\nBlake also said Bolt had a bad feeling before the race about what the delayed start time would mean.\n\n\"A hero of the sport to go down like that, as a true friend, I didn't like it one bit,\" Blake said.\n\n\"Usain was getting cold and he said, 'I don't like this'.\n\n\"They were holding us too long.\n\n\"Too many presentations so the race was 10 minutes long. It was cold.\"\n\nJamaican team doctor Kevin Jones later clarified Bolt suffered from a hamstring cramp, but the physical pain was overshadowed by the emotional anguish.\n\n\"It's cramps in his left hamstring but a lot of pain is from the disappointment of losing the race. The last three weeks have been hard for him, we hope for the best,\" Jones said.\n\nJones also reiterated Blake's concerns, saying: \"It was cold back there, and the guys were complaining.\"\n\nAmerican Justin Gatlin, who defeated Bolt in the 100m final while relegating him to third, agreed there was a problem with how the race was organised.\n\n\"We took (our) clothes off a little too early. Bolt was running out there cold.\"\n\nUsain Bolt doesn't need to apologise to anyone. He may think he needs to, but his teammates say he doesn't owe anyone - least of all them - anything.\n\n\"He didn't tell us exactly what happened but from what I saw, it looked like a strain or a cramp of some sort,\" second leg runner Julian Forte said.\n\n\"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise - injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nNewly-crowned 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, Jamaica's lead-off runner, added: \"Everybody was jelly, everybody was pumped. (Bolt's injury) just happened. Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"", "time": "02:46:00"}

planned or thought about, Usain Bolt says final goodbye to Team Jamaica and extends love for fans after seeing curtains being drawn to his illustrious track & field career in a rather disheartening manner.\n\nThe greatest sprinter of all time probably deserved a better ending but his swansong came crashing to an end when he pulled up with a cramp on the anchor leg of the world 4x100m relay won by Britain.\n\nWATCH: Usain Bolt limps out with cramp in final race of his career at IAAF World Championships\n\nBolt received the baton with Jamaica in third, but halfway down the finishing straight the towering sprinter pulled up clutching his left thigh, eventually doing a forward somersault to the ground, to gasps from the 60,000 sell out London Stadium.\n\nBolt had earlier missed out on his bid to retain his 100m title earlier in the week, losing out to Gatlin and silver medallist Christian Coleman.\n\nBut hopes were high for Bolt's final competitive race, with Jamaica also boasting McLeod, Forte and 2011 world champion Yohan Blake in their line-up.\n\nJamaica were afforded a rousing welcome from the crowd, a relaxed-looking Bolt applauding the stands, with pictures of him constantly shown on the stadium's big screens.\n\nBut there was to be high drama as a visibly swearing Bolt pulled up in obvious pain, allowing the British quartet of Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake claim gold in 37.47 seconds, with the Justin Gatlin-led US four taking silver at 0.05sec and Japan a surprise bronze (38.04).\n\nThe 30-year-old Jamaican said goodbye to his teammates for an instagram post and sent inifinite love to fans for their constant support.\n\nJamaican team doctor Dr Kevin Jones later confirmed that Bolt had suffered from \"cramp in his left hamstring\".\n\nThe result means Bolt, 100 and 200m world record holder, finishes his career with 14 world career medals, one behind American Allyson Felix, to go with eight Olympic golds", "time": "04:50:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warming_up", "label": {"eng": "Warming up"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "492684"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallace_Spearmon", "label": {"eng": "Wallace Spearmon"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "527099"}], "url": "http://sports.abs-cbn.com/generalsports/news/2017/08/13/bolt-takes-tumble-can-t-complete-final-race-worlds-29669", "body": "Jamaica's Usain Bolt lies on the track after he was injured in the Men's 4x100 meters relay final at the World Athletics Championships in London Saturday, Aug. 12, 2017. (AP Photo/Martin Meissner)\n\nBy Eddie Pells, Associated Press\n\nLONDON (AP) -- Usain Bolt was ramping into warp speed when suddenly, stunningly, the sprint turned into a somersault.\n\nFifteen steps into the final homestretch of his final race, something gave in his left hamstring. The World's Fastest Man skittered to a stop -- hopping, skipping, jumping, then finally dropping to the ground and tumbling forward before coming to a rest.\n\nWhile the winning team from Britain crossed the finish line, Bolt was writhing on the track, where he eventually wound up chest down with his face pressed into Lane 5. He was certainly every bit as stunned as any of the 60,000-plus who packed the stadium Saturday, or the millions watching one of the world's most entertaining showmen make his final curtain call in the 4x100-meter relay at world championships.\n\nThere was no celebration. No gold, no silver, not even a consolation bronze, the likes of which Bolt received a week earlier in his final 100-meter race.\n\nJamaica closed the night with \"DNF\" by its name: Did Not Finish. Dead last. Bolt was helped into a wheelchair, but eventually got to his feet and, assisted by his teammates, limped gingerly across the finish line. He gave a few waves to the crowd, then left for the trainer's room, and with that, presumably left track and field forever.\n\n\"Injuries are part of our sport and, always, of course, it's sad to see,\" said Wallace Spearmon, the American sprinter who has been close with Bolt for years and was on hand helping the U.S. team. \"So, yeah, it's tragic.\"\n\nThe Jamaican team doctor, Kevin Jones, diagnosed the injury that brought a strange end to Bolt's career as, simply, a cramp in the champion's left hamstring.\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jones said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nWatching track's No. 1 sprinter and celebrity dropping to the ground was nothing short of jaw-dropping -- so much so that the fact that Britain won the race, outrunning a United States team that, somewhat amazingly, didn't drop the baton, almost seemed like an afterthought.\n\nNethaneel Mitchell-Blake held off U.S. anchorman Christian Coleman down the stretch and the Brits won their first-ever world title in the 4x100 in 37.47 seconds.\n\nWhen Bolt took the baton from Yohan Blake for his final homestretch, he was in third place, but that was no cause for concern. In virtually each of the seven relay golds he's won at the Olympics and world championships, Bolt has reeled in the competition down the stretch and won going away, much the same as all his 100 victories have played out.\n\nFive years and one day earlier, on the very same track, Bolt helped Jamaica set the world record. That run of 36.84 seconds earned Bolt the sixth of nine Olympic victories.\n\nBut last week in the 100, Bolt's extra gear was not enough either to catch Coleman, who finished second, or to hold off Justin Gatlin, the oft-booed American who came from behind to finish first.\n\nCould he have caught his relay competition in this one? Nobody will ever know. Bolt was gaining no ground at the 30-meter mark, which is when he felt the pain in his leg and went tumbling.\n\nAfterward, there was plenty of second-guessing to be done. Most of it came at the expense of the IAAF, which made the sprinters wait about 40 minutes from the time they were summoned from the warm-up room to the time the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I think this is crazy,\" Blake said. \"Forty minutes. Waiting. Warming up. Waiting. Warming up. It just should not happen. To have your champion go out like that. It's crazy.\"\n\nSaid Gatlin, who remains insistent that Bolt will be back someday: \"We lost all of our heat, all of our sweat, and we went out there cold.\"\n\nPart of the wait was for the U.S. women's relay team to finish its victory celebration. Tori Bowie anchored the win and, with one day left in the meet, is the only athlete to win two gold medals in London. Also, a medal ceremony was held for Russian high jump champion Mariya Lasitskene, who is competing as a neutral athlete because of the doping crisis in her country and got to listen not to her own anthem, but to the IAAF's theme song, as she stood on the podium.\n\nOther winners included Kevin Mayer of France in the decathlon and Johannes Vetter, whose victory in the javelin throw gave Germany its first gold of the championships.\n\nIn the undercard to the relays, Muktar Edris held off Mo Farah of Britain in the 5,000. With help of his Ethiopian teammates, Edris won a tactical cat-and-mouse race and denied Farah his fifth straight long-distance double, counting world championships and Olympics.\n\nAs if to prove that point one last time, he did it again -- this time without even finishing the race.", "time": "00:54:00"}

"Decathlon"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "328733"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relay_race", "label": {"eng": "Relay race"}, "score": 5, "type": "wiki", "id": "332246"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/110_metres_hurdles", "label": {"eng": "110 metres hurdles"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "333752"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mo_Farah", "label": {"eng": "Mo Farah"}, "score": 1, "type": "person", "id": "338647"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4_\u00d7_400_metres_relay", "label": {"eng": "4 \u00d7 400 metres relay"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "341956"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dafne_Schippers", "label": {"eng": "Dafne Schippers"}, "score": 2, "type": "person", "id": "347331"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hurdling", "label": {"eng": "Hurdling"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "352623"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damian_Warner", "label": {"eng": "Damian Warner"}, "score": 1, "type": "person", "id": "399431"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trey_Hardee", "label": {"eng": "Trey Hardee"}, "score": 2, "type": "person", "id": "399433"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anchor_leg", "label": {"eng": "Anchor leg"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "489170"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rico_Freimuth", "label": {"eng": "Rico Freimuth"}, "score": 1, "type": "person", "id": "793403"}], "url": "http://www.wvva.com/story/36120876/bolt-gets-jamaica-into-the-relay-final-for-grand-farewell", "body": "LONDON (AP) - Usain Bolt set the stage for his grand farewell, powering down the finishing straight Saturday to qualify Jamaica for the 4x100-meter relay final at the world championships.\n\nFittingly, he will face Justin Gatlin and the United States in the final chapter of his unparalleled career.\n\nBoth nations won their heats early Saturday, though the U.S. relay squad got the baton around with more aplomb than Jamaica, which had to rely on Bolt to clinch victory.\n\nAnd Bolt relished the adulation at the 60,000-capacity Olympic Stadium.\n\n\"They've been outstanding so far, and continue to surprise me and give me energy,\" Bolt said.\n\nFor the best part of the past decade, though, Bolt has been 100 percent reliable in getting relay gold for the island nation. The last time Jamaica lost a world championship final was in Bolt's rookie year in 2007, when he ran the second leg and only took silver behind the Americans.\n\nEver since, Bolt has flaunted his power at the end of every major championship, getting the third gold medal for himself and sometimes another world record for Jamaica.\n\nThis year, however, he only got bronze in the 100 behind Gatlin. And the result in the relay is no longer a foregone conclusion.\n\nThe United States, with Gatlin running the second leg, won the first heat in a world leading time of 37.70 seconds. The Americans beat Britain and Japan, both of which also qualified.\n\n\"My team did a great job,\" said Gatlin, the oldest of the squad at 35. \"They're thinking and acting like veterans and I'm proud of them.\"\n\nChristian Coleman took silver in the 100 ahead of Bolt and it gave the U.S. team an added boost.\n\n\"Having the gold and silver medal on the same relay team, which hasn't been done in a long time, it gives us kind of a confidence booster that the speed can get around the track,\" Gatlin said.\n\nBolt stepped out on the track for the second heat, and the Jamaicans needed him. Trailing when he got the baton on the anchor leg, Bolt powered away, quickly swept past his rivals and had time to look to his right before crossing in 37.95 seconds.\n\nStill, Bolt was supportive of his young teammates.\n\n\"They came out here and did the job we wanted them to do, and that's to get us to the finals. They executed and ran well for a young team,\" Bolt said. \"Over the years, this will be the team bringing in the golds.\"\n\nIn the women's heats, both nations are also through.\n\nAllyson Felix stayed in line to become the athlete with the most medals in world championships history when she helped the American relay team qualify.\n\nRunning the second leg, Felix and her teammates crossed first in a season's leading time of 41.84 seconds, beating Britain and Switzerland. They also advanced to the final.\n\nIn the second heat, Germany beat two-time defending champion Jamaica to qualify along with Brazil.\n\nThe Netherlands, with 200-meter champion Dafne Schippers running the second leg, qualified on time.\n\nFelix has won 14 medals at the world championships and can move up to 16 if she runs the 4x400 relay and the United States wins medals in both events.\n\nIn the decathlon, two-time world champion Trey Hardee of the United States hit the third hurdle and clattered into the next one during the 110-meter hurdles to end his medal chances.\n\nIn the first of five events on the final day of the two-day competition, Kevin Mayer of France set a third personal record to easily stay atop the standings with 5,485 points. Rico Freimuth of Germany was in second place with 5,377 points, while Damian Warner of Canada had the fastest time in the hurdles of 13.63 seconds to move into third.\n\nAlso, British runner Mo Farah will compete in his last race on the track at a major championship when he goes for a fourth straight world title in the 5,000. He won a third 10,000-meter gold on the first day of the championships.\n\n___\n\nMore AP track coverage: https://www.apnews.com/tag/London2017\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.", "time": "11:12:00"}

"1053871"}], "url": "http://www.dothaneagle.com/news/ap/sports/bolt-gets-jamaica-into-the-relay-final-for-grand-farewell/article_c32729a6-c38a-50e6-b1be-8300c2b7aaea.html", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- Usain Bolt set the stage for his grand farewell, powering down the finishing straight Saturday to qualify Jamaica for the 4x100-meter relay final at the world championships.\n\nFittingly, he will face Justin Gatlin and the United States in the final chapter of his unparalleled career.\n\nBoth nations won their heats early Saturday, though the U.S. relay squad got the baton around with more aplomb than Jamaica, which had to rely on Bolt to clinch victory.\n\nAnd Bolt relished the adulation at the 60,000-capacity Olympic Stadium.\n\n\"They've been outstanding so far, and continue to surprise me and give me energy,\" Bolt said.\n\nFor the best part of the past decade, though, Bolt has been 100 percent reliable in getting relay gold for the island nation. The last time Jamaica lost a world championship final was in Bolt's rookie year in 2007, when he ran the second leg and only took silver behind the Americans.\n\nEver since, Bolt has flaunted his power at the end of every major championship, getting the third gold medal for himself and sometimes another world record for Jamaica.\n\nThis year, however, he only got bronze in the 100 behind Gatlin. And the result in the relay is no longer a foregone conclusion.\n\nThe United States, with Gatlin running the second leg, won the first heat in a world leading time of 37.70 seconds. The Americans beat Britain and Japan, both of which also qualified.\n\n\"My team did a great job,\" said Gatlin, the oldest of the squad at 35. \"They're thinking and acting like veterans and I'm proud of them.\"\n\nChristian Coleman took silver in the 100 ahead of Bolt and it gave the U.S. team an added boost.\n\n\"Having the gold and silver medal on the same relay team, which hasn't been done in a long time, it gives us kind of a confidence booster that the speed can get around the track,\" Gatlin said.\n\nBolt stepped out on the track for the second heat, and the Jamaicans needed him. Trailing when he got the baton on the anchor leg, Bolt powered away, quickly swept past his rivals and had time to look to his right before crossing in 37.95 seconds.\n\nStill, Bolt was supportive of his young teammates.\n\n\"They came out here and did the job we wanted them to do, and that's to get us to the finals. They executed and ran well for a young team,\" Bolt said. \"Over the years, this will be the team bringing in the golds.\"\n\nIn the women's heats, both nations are also through.\n\nAllyson Felix stayed in line to become the athlete with the most medals in world championships history when she helped the American relay team qualify.\n\nRunning the second leg, Felix and her teammates crossed first in a season's leading time of 41.84 seconds, beating Britain and Switzerland. They also advanced to the final.\n\nIn the second heat, Germany beat two-time defending champion Jamaica to qualify along with Brazil.\n\nThe Netherlands, with 200-meter champion Dafne Schippers running the second leg, qualified on time.\n\nFelix has won 14 medals at the world championships and can move up to 16 if she runs the 4x400 relay and the United States wins medals in both events.\n\nIn the decathlon, two-time world champion Trey Hardee of the United States hit the third hurdle and clattered into the next one during the 110-meter hurdles to end his medal chances.\n\nIn the first of five events on the final day of the two-day competition, Kevin Mayer of France set a third personal record to easily stay atop the standings with 5,485 points. Rico Freimuth of Germany was in second place with 5,377 points, while Damian Warner of Canada had the fastest time in the hurdles of 13.63 seconds to move into third.\n\nAlso, British runner Mo Farah will compete in his last race on the track at a major championship when he goes for a fourth straight world title in the 5,000. He won a third 10,000-meter gold on the first day of the championships.\n\n-- -- --\n\nMore AP track coverage: https://www.apnews.com/tag/London2017", "time": "11:07:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yohan_Blake", "label": {"eng": "Yohan Blake"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "343533"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sport_of_athletics", "label": {"eng": "Sport of athletics"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1053871"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omar_McLeod", "label": {"eng": "Omar McLeod"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1333564"}], "url": "http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/sports/2017/08/13/organisers-blame-bolts-world-champs-collapse-team-mates/", "body": "Shares\n\nJamaica's Usain Bolt falls after injuring himself in the final of the men's 4x100m relay at the 2017 IAAF World Championships at the London Stadium in London on August 12, 2017 \u00a9 AFP / DANIEL LEAL-OLIVAS\n\nLONDON, United Kingdom, Aug 13 - Usain Bolt's dramatic and inglorious end to his top level career was the fault of world championship organisers, his furious team-mates claimed.\n\nThe 30-year-old 100 metres and 200m world record-holder collapsed on the London Stadium track whilst anchoring Jamaica in the final of the 4x100m on Saturday as cramp gripped his leg.\n\nBolt lay prone on the track but waved away the offer of a wheelchair and eventually, aided by his three team-mates, limped across the line before making a hasty exit -- not the way the man who had won triple Olympic gold at the same stadium in 2012 would have wished his competitive career in championships to finish.\n\nBut his team-mates complained that his problem was caused by organisers keeping the relay teams waiting in the cold before their race as several medal ceremonies were held.\n\n\"I think they were holding us too long in the call room. The walk was too long. Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me, 'Yohan, I think this is crazy. 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run',\" said Yohan Blake, who branded the wait as \"crazy\".\n\n\"We kept warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting,\" added the 2011 100m world champion, who also won Olympic relay gold in 2012 and 2016 with Bolt.\n\nJamaica's Usain Bolt goes down after pulling up injured in the final of the men's 4x100m relay athletics event at the 2017 IAAF World Championships at the London Stadium in London on August 12, 2017 \u00a9 AFP / Adrian DENNIS\n\n\"I think it got the better of us. We were over warm.\n\n\"To see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggling like that.\n\n\"The race was 10 minutes late and we were kept 40 minutes.\"\n\nBolt may not have led Jamaica to a glorious finale anyway, though, as he took the baton well behind eventual winners Great Britain and the US.\n\nBut Jamaica's 110m hurdles world champion Omar McLeod -- who ran the first leg -- likewise pointed the finger at organisers for denying his country's greatest star a more fitting swansong.\n\n\"It's heart wrenching,\" said McLeod, who is also the Olympic champion.\n\n\"It was ridiculous man, we were there around 45 minutes waiting outside, I think they had three medal ceremonies before we went out so we were really trying our hardest to stay warm and keep upbeat.\n\n\"But it was ridiculous. We waited a really long time. I drank like two bottles of water.\"\n\nJamaica's Usain Bolt goes down after pulling up injured in the final of the men's 4x100m relay at the 2017 IAAF World Championships at the London Stadium in London on August 12, 2017 \u00a9 AFP / Jewel SAMAD\n\nTheir criticism echoed that of Justin Gatlin, who led an American 1-2 alongside team-mate Christian Coleman to deny Bolt a farewell gold in the individual 100m.\n\n\"I think it was the elements. I am sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" said Gatlin.\n\n\"It was a recipe. I don't want to say this, I understand we need to be ready early, but I think we took our clothes off a little too early.\n\n\"It's a little chilly in here so I think that's where the cramp came from. That's what he suffered with. He was running out there cold.\"\n\nDespite his relatively unsuccessful championships -- in which he will exit with just a single bronze medal -- Bolt will still be accorded a final lap of honour in a tribute ceremony before the curtain comes down on the world championships later on Sunday.\n\nShares", "time": "11:11:00"}

"http://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2017/08/12/more-sports/track-field/bolt-guides-jamaica-100-meter-relay-final-grand-farewell/", "body": "LONDON - Usain Bolt set the stage for his grand farewell, powering down the finishing straight Saturday to qualify Jamaica for the 4\u00d7100-meter relay final at the world championships.\n\nFittingly, he will face Justin Gatlin and the United States in the final chapter of his unparalleled career on the same night.\n\nBoth nations won their heats early Saturday, though the U.S. relay squad got the baton around with more aplomb than Jamaica, which had to rely on Bolt to clinch victory.\n\nAnd Bolt relished the adulation at the 60,000-capacity Olympic Stadium.\n\n\"They've been outstanding so far, and continue to surprise me and give me energy,\" Bolt said.\n\nFor the best part of the past decade, though, Bolt has been 100 percent reliable in getting relay gold for the island nation. The last time Jamaica lost a world championship final was in Bolt's rookie year in 2007, when he ran the second leg and only took silver behind the Americans, in Osaka.\n\nEver since, Bolt has flaunted his power at the end of every major championship, getting the third gold medal for himself and sometimes another world record for Jamaica.\n\nThis year, however, he only got bronze in the 100 behind Gatlin. And the result in the relay is no longer a foregone conclusion.\n\nThe United States, with Gatlin running the second leg, won the first heat in a world leading time of 37.70 seconds. The Americans beat Britain and Japan, both of which also qualified.\n\n\"My team did a great job,\" said Gatlin, the oldest of the squad at 35. \"They're thinking and acting like veterans and I'm proud of them.\"\n\nChristian Coleman took silver in the 100 ahead of Bolt and it gave the U.S. team an added boost.\n\n\"Having the gold and silver medal on the same relay team, which hasn't been done in a long time, it gives us kind of a confidence booster that the speed can get around the track,\" Gatlin said.\n\nBolt stepped out on the track for the second heat, and the Jamaicans needed him. Trailing when he got the baton on the anchor leg, Bolt powered away, quickly swept past his rivals and had time to look to his right before crossing in 37.95 seconds.\n\nStill, Bolt was supportive of his young teammates.\n\n\"They came out here and did the job we wanted them to do, and that's to get us to the finals. They executed and ran well for a young team,\" Bolt said. \"Over the years, this will be the team bringing in the golds.\"\n\nIn the women's heats, both nations are also through.\n\nAllyson Felix stayed in line to become the athlete with the most medals in world championships history when she helped the American relay team qualify.\n\nRunning the second leg, Felix and her teammates crossed first in a season's leading time of 41.84 seconds, beating Britain and Switzerland. They also advanced to the final.\n\nIn the second heat, Germany beat two-time defending champion Jamaica to qualify along with Brazil.\n\nThe Netherlands, with 200-meter champion Dafne Schippers running the second leg, qualified on time.\n\nFelix has won 14 medals at the world championships and can move up to 16 if she runs the 4\u00d7400 relay and the United States wins medals in both events.\n\nIn the decathlon, two-time world champion Trey Hardee of the United States hit the third hurdle and clattered into the next one during the 110-meter hurdles to end his medal chances.\n\nIn the first of five events on the final day of the two-day competition, Kevin Mayer of France set a third personal record to easily stay atop the standings with 5,485 points. Rico Freimuth of Germany was in second place with 5,377 points, while Damian Warner of Canada had the fastest time in the hurdles of 13.63 seconds to move into third.\n\nAlso, British runner Mo Farah will compete in his last race on the track at a major championship when he goes for a fourth straight world title in the 5,000. He won a third 10,000-meter gold on the first day of the championships.", "time": "12:58:00"}

"url": "http://www.timescall.com/sports/pro-sports/ci_31215379/usain-bolt-ends-stellar-career-pain?source=rss", "body": "LONDON -- Usain Bolt ended his stellar career in excruciating pain.\n\nThe Jamaican great crumpled to the track with a left-leg injury as he was chasing a final gold medal for the Jamaican 4x100-meter relay team on Saturday at the world championships.\n\nHaving to make up lots of ground on the anchor leg, Bolt suddenly screamed, stumbled and somersaulted as he came down, his golden farewell shattered by the first injury he has experienced at a major competition.\n\nThat wasn't the only surprise. Britain went on to beat the United States in a tight finish.\n\nThe 60,000-capacity stadium was primed for one last Bolt show, one last \"To the World\" pose after a victory, but the injury made it blatantly clear why Bolt is ready to retire. His body can no longer hold up.\n\n\"He is still the best in the world,\" said Justin Gatlin, Bolt's American rival who ended up with 100-meter gold and relay silver.\n\nBolt's teammates on the once-fabled Jamaican sprint squad were far from unmatchable, too. Bolt just had too much to make up in the final 100 meters as both Britain and the United States were ahead and even Japan was even.\n\nAs Bolt fell to the ground, the leg with the golden shoe giving way, the crowd still went wild because the home team went on to win gold in 37.47 seconds, .05 seconds ahead of the United States.\n\n\"It's a cramp in his left hamstring, but a lot of the pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jamaican team doctor Kevin Jones said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nThe race will certainly be remembered for the gut-wrenching way in which the sport's greatest athlete was forced to end his career.\n\n\"It just happened,\" Jamaican leadoff runner Omar McLeod said. \"Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nIt was yet another amazing upset in a championship of so many.\n\nBefore Bolt came onto the track, he was consoling Mo Farah, his long-distance equivalent who had just lost his first major race since 2011 when he failed to get gold in the 5,000 meters.\n\nFarah also was bidding farewell to the track, coming up short of his fifth straight 5,000-10,000 double at major championships in a sprint against Muktar Edris Ethiopia.\n\n\"I gave it all,\" Farah said. \"I didn't have a single bit left at the end.\"\n\nInstead, Tori Bowie was the unlikely first double gold medalist at the championships, anchoring the U.S. team to the 4x100-meter relay title ahead of Britain and Jamaica.\n\nAt the same time, Allyson Felix, running the second leg on the winning team, earned a record 15th medal at the world championships in a career going back to 2005.", "time": "00:40:00"}

"http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/more-sports/athletics/world-athletics-championships-usain-bolt-anchors-jamaica-into-4x100m-relay-final/articleshow/60033793.cms", "body": "LONDON: Usain Bolt's bid to bring the curtain down on his glittering career with a 15th world gold medal remained on track as Jamaica qualified for the final of the 4x100m relay.\n\nBolt took the unusual step of racing the relay heats, something usually reserved for the more unheralded members of the squad.\n\nTyquendo Tracey, Julian Forte and Michael Campbell safely negotiated the first three legs before Bolt steered his team home in a winning, season's best of 37.95 seconds.\n\n\"It's been brilliant. The energy in the stadium is outstanding,\" Bolt said, hailing the deafening support in the packed-out London Stadium \"not just for me but the whole championships\".\n\nBolt said his emotions were still in check at the thought of bowing out of track and field.\n\n\"For me it's hard to be sad because the energy I'm getting from the crowd is brilliant, I'm just happy.\"\n\nBolt's bid to retain his 100m title went up in smoke as American Justin Gatlin won gold, with Christian Coleman taking silver.\n\nIt was the first time Bolt had been beaten at a major championships since the 4x100m relay at the 2007 worlds in Osaka.\n\nThe 100 and 200m world record holder, who also anchored the Jamaican squad to a world record in the relay of 36.84sec at the 2012 London Olympics, will be back at the track for the final at 2050 GMT.\n\nBolt has amassed eight Olympic golds and 14 world medals, 11 of which are gold, the Jamaican having won two silvers in 2007 before his 100m bronze in London.\n\nNo matter the result of the relay, organisers said Bolt will be afforded a dedicated lap of honour on Sunday in tribute to his amazing track career.\n\nGatlin ran the second leg for the US team, led off by Mike Rodgers, another dope cheat, BeeJay Lee and Coleman on anchor.\n\nThey clocked 37.70 seconds to finish 0.06sec ahead of Britain.\n\nAlso qualifying for the final were France, China, Japan, Turkey and Canada.\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.", "time": "10:55:00"}

"http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/sports/2017/08/13/usain-bolt-numbers/", "body": "Shares\n\nUsain Bolt injured in his final race\n\nLONDON, United Kingdom, Aug 13- Usain Bolt retired from track and field championships after the 4x100m relay at the world championships in London.\n\nUnfortunately there was to be no fairytale as he pulled up and collapsed injured on the track running the anchor leg.\n\nHere AFP Sports looks at his glittering career in numbers.\n\n1 - world bronze, after being beaten in the 100m in London 2017 by Americans Justin Gatlin and Christian Coleman\n\n3 - the number of Olympic treble sprint doubles, in Beijing 2008, London 2012 and Rio 2016. It should have been a treble treble including all three relay titles, but teammate Nesta Carter tested positive for doping in the Chinese capital\n\n4 - times Bolt has been named Laureus World Sportsman of the Year: 2009, 2010, 2013, 2017\n\n5 - the number of sprinters to have beaten Bolt over 100m: Gatlin, Coleman, Jamaica's Asafa Powell, American Tyson Gay and Antigua's Daniel Bailey\n\n6 - times Bolt has won the IAAF Male Athlete of the Year: 2008, 2009, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2016\n\n8 - Olympic gold medals: 100, 200m (2008, 2012, 2016); 4x100m relay (2012, 2016)\n\nUsain Bolt\n\n9.58 - the world record he set for the 100m at the 2009 worlds in Berlin\n\n9.63 - the second fastest time ever run, when Bolt scorched to 100m gold at the 2008 Beijing Olympics\n\n9 - times Bolt has run sub-9.77 seconds or faster for the 100m\n\n11 - world gold medals: 100m (2009, 2013, 2015); 200m (2009, 2011, 2013, 2015); 4x100m relay (2009, 2011, 2013, 2015)\n\n14 - world medals amassed since making his debut in Helsinki in 2005, when he finished eighth and last in the 200m final\n\n14.35 - the world best Bolt set over 150 metres in Manchester, England, in 2009. He ran the final 100 metres in a startling 8.70sec, the fastest time ever recorded\n\n19 - major global medals\n\n19.19 - the world record he set for the 200m at the 2009 worlds in Berlin\n\n30.97 - his best time over the rarely-run 300m, set in 2010. Only South African Wayde van Niekerk and American Michael Johnson have gone faster\n\n31 - the Jamaican turns 31 on August 21\n\nUsain Bolt celebrates his 100m victory at the IAAF World Championships, Beijing 2015, PHOTO/IAAF/Getty Images\n\n36.84 - the world record for the 4x100m relay set at the London Olympics, Bolt anchoring a team also comprising Nesta Carter, Michael Frater and Yohan Blake. Bolt had been part of two previous world relay records, in Beijing in 2008 (though this was later voided) and at the 2011 Daegu worlds\n\n37.58 - Bolt's average speed in km/h (23.35mph) in his 100m world record race. Should you subtract his reaction time of 0.15sec, his time is actually 9.43sec, making his average speed 38.18km/h (23.72mph)\n\n41 - the number of strides it took for Bolt to cover the 100m on his record-setting run in the German capital\n\n44.72 - top speed in km/h (27.79mph) reached during his 100m run in Berlin in 2009, between the 60 to 80-metre mark\n\n53 - the number of times Bolt has run sub-10 second 100m races\n\n195 - his height in centimetres, or 6ft 5in\n\n4.82 million -followers on Twitter\n\n7.4 million - followers on Instagram\n\n18.8 million - follows of his Facebook page\n\n34.2 million - dollars earned by Bolt last year according to a list of the world's richest sportspeople by Forbes magazine\n\nShares", "time": "21:58:00"}

goodbye\n\nUsain Bolt's final two races are two that he will probably want to forget.\n\nOn Aug. 5, 35-year-old American sprinter Justin Gatlin upset Bolt in the 100 meters at the world championships, which is Bolt's signature event. On Saturday night, Bolt injured himself during his anchor leg of the 4x100 meter relay final. He was unable to finish the race.\n\nBolt eventually crossed the finish line with the rest of his teammates behind him after the race was over, according to NBC Sports.\n\nBolt is widely recognized as the greatest sprinter of all time. In an eight-year period from 2008 to 2016, Bolt won 20 Olympic and world championship gold medals in the 21 events he entered. He won three consecutive Olympic 100 meter titles and 200 meter titles, according to Olympic.org.\n\nAfter winning the 4x100m title in Brazil, Bolt confirmed that the 2017 world championships would be his final event.\n\n\" I'm going to miss this sport and I'm going to miss the Games because it's the biggest event possible for any athlete,\" Bolt told Olympic.org. \"But I've proven that I'm the greatest in this sport and, for me, it's mission accomplished.\"\n\nEven with the two disappointing finishes, people still took to Twitter to congratulate Bolt on his illustrious career:", "time": "20:24:00"}

Bolt, having been passed the baton by Yohan Blake, was in third behind Great Britain and the United...\"\n\nJustin Gatlin agreed with the complaints of the Jamaican relay team that a long wait before their 4x100m final at the World Championships on Saturday contributed to the injury suffered by Usain Bolt in his last race.\n\nBolt, having been passed the baton by Yohan Blake, was in third behind Great Britain and the United States, who eventually won gold and silver, but pulled up almost 50m from the line and fell to the track.\n\nJamaica's team doctor later said that the 30-year-old had suffered a hamstring cramp.\n\nBolt's teammates complained that a 45-minute wait in the call room before the race had hampered their preparations.\n\n\"I think they were holding us too long in the call room,'' Blake told reporters. \"Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me 'Yohan, I think this is crazy. Forty minutes and two medal presentations before our run.''\n\nGatlin, who beat Bolt to gold in the 100m last Saturday, agreed with the complaints and laid the blame at the television scheduling for the event.\n\n\"I know it's TV magic, and everybody has to be prepared on time to make everything happen for the viewers at home.\n\n\"(But) I personally think that we were held in the stadium a little too long without our clothes on, and there was a little draught in there. I lost all my sweat and body heat,'' Gatlin said.\n\nWhen asked if he thought that contributed to Bolt's injury, the 35-year-old said: \"I believe so.\n\n\"Knowing how Usain performs, he's always ready, he's always making sure he's not injured and it's very rare to see Usain injured when he comes to performances.''\n\nGatlin ran the second leg for the United States as they finished runners-up behind Britain, who became world champions for the first time.\n\nAmidst the home crowd's jubilation, there was also relief at the sight of Bolt being able to walk off the track after being helped to his feet by his teammates.\n\n\"I'm not sure what the extent of his injury is, but when I saw him go down I thought it was a calf cramp or a hamstring cramp. But he walked off the track, so that's good thing.", "time": "12:03:00"}

"wiki", "id": "1053871"}], "url": "http://www.themalaymailonline.com/sports/article/gatlin-hails-bolt-the-showman-despite-relay-flop", "body": "Jamaica's Usain Bolt (centre) reacts after hurting himself during the final of the men's 4x100m relay athletics event at the 2017 IAAF World Championships at the London Stadium in London on August 12, 2017. -- AFP picLONDON, Aug 13 -- A sentimental Justin Gatlin hailed Usain Bolt as an \"amazing showman\" whose career would certainly not be defined by him pulling up with cramp in the world 4x100m relay, the Jamaican's final competitive race.\n\nThere was high drama in Saturday's relay as anchor man Bolt received the baton in third place behind eventual gold medallists Britain and runners-up America.\n\nLess than 50 metres down the track, Bolt suddenly pulled up, clutching his left leg, tumbling to the track with what was later diagnosed as a hamstring cramp.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now,\" said Gatlin, who stormed to 100m gold in London, US teammate Christian Coleman taking silver to relegate Bolt to a disappointing bronze in his individual send-off.\n\n\"In the warm-up area we give ourselves respect and greet each other,\" Gatlin said of Bolt, who bows out of competition with a startling haul of eight Olympic gold medals and 14 world medals, nine of which are gold.\n\nGatlin, who has served two doping bans, put the blame for Bolt's cramp partly at the amount of time the athletes spent on the track before the starter's gun went off.\n\n\"There was a cool breeze out there. But the conditions were the same for everybody,\" said the 35-year-old, who won the 100m at the 2004 Olympics in Athens and the 2005 worlds in Helsinki before serving his second ban between 2006-10 for taking testosterone.\n\nChilly conditions unhelpful\n\n\"I think it was the elements. I am sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world.\n\n\"It was a recipe. I don't want to say this but I understand we need to be ready early but I think we took our clothes off a little too early. It's a little chilly in here so I think that's where the cramp came from. That's what he suffered with. He was running out there cold.\"\n\nBut Gatlin, who was roundly booed at the London Stadium before both the 100m and relay, insisted: \"Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\n\n\"You can't let this championships define what he's done in the past. He has done amazing things. He's still the man, you know. The was his farewell race and we wish him the best and hope he recovers soon.\"\n\nReferring to Bolt's mooted future ambassadorial role within athletics' world governing body the IAAF, Gatlin added: \"He's coming back in a couple of years. He'll be ready, he has a passion for the sport.\n\n\"He loves the fans and they love him. He loves the sport too much to walk away. He's a showman.\"\n\nJapan snatched a surprise bronze medal, Kenji Fujimitsu moved to comment: \"Thank you, Bolt. He was an inspiration for us.\"\n\nOmar McLeod, the newly-crowned 110m hurdler and Jamaica's lead-off runner in the relay, added: \"Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\" -- AFP", "time": "02:52:00"}

"url": "http://www.deccanherald.com/content/627724/bolt-wins-relay-heats-his.html", "body": "Jamaica's Usain Bolt prepares for his leg of a men's 4x100-meter relay first round heat during the World Athletics Championships in London. AP/PTI.\n\nUsain Bolt began the countdown to his final race by anchoring Jamaica to the 4x100m relay finals with an easy win in the heats here today.\n\nRunning in his penultimate race of his illustrious career, Bolt eased past the finishing line as he helped the defending champions Jamaica win the second heat in 37.95 seconds, their season's best, to enter the final round with third best time.\n\nThe Jamaican quartet of Tyquendo Tracey, Julian Forte, Micheal Campbell and Bolt led the eight-team second heat from beginning to the end.\n\nExperienced Yohan Blake, who finished fourth in the men's 100m final and failed to qualify for the final round in 200m, did not start in the heats but Bolt later said that he will return in the final race.\n\nIn his trademark style, Bolt grabbed the baton from Campbell, who ran the third leg, and blasted ahead of all his rivals and slowed down while approaching the finish line to conserve energy for the finals.\n\nThe top three from each of the two heats and next two fastest finishers from the remaining qualify for the final round.\n\nThe United States team of Mike Rodgers, Justin Gatlin, Bee Jay Lee and Christian Coleman won the first heat in 37.70 seconds, the world leading time this season, to clock the overall best time going into the final round.\n\nGreat Britain clocked the second best time of 37.76, while France were fourth with their season's best of 38.03.\n\nChina (38.20), who had finished second in the 2015 edition at home, Japan (37.21), who took a surprise silver in the Rio Olympics, Turkey (38.44) and Canada (38.48) -- third in both 2015 World Championships and Rio Olympics -- completed the eight-team final round which will run later tonight.\n\nBolt, who has anchored the gold-winning Jamaican team in both 2015 World Championships and Rio Games, will be seeking his 20th global title and would want to hang up his boots with a yellow metal in his final race of his glittering career.\n\nHe lost the 100m dash last Saturday in his final individual race, settling for a bronze.\n\nHis long-time American rival Gatlin, who has twice served bans for doping, won the gold while Coleman took the silver as the London Olympic stadium and the global television audience were stunned at the turn of events.\n\nWidely considered as the greatest sprinter of all time, Bolt has won eight Olympic and 11 World Championships gold medals beginning with a 100m and 200m double at the 2008 Beijing Olympics.\n\nSince then he has dominated the shorter two sprint events like none in athletics history. His Jamaican team had also won the 4x100m relay gold in Beijing but it had to return the medal after one member of the quartet -- Nesta Carter -- tested positive for a prohibited substance.\n\nOn the last day of his international career, fans jostled for space to have a glimpse of Bolt at the warm-up arena, adjacent to the stadium and television cameras were fixed at him to have a shot of the towering Jamaican.\n\nWhenever the giant screen inside the stadium showed him doing the baton exchange practice with his Jamaican team-mates in preparation for the 4x100m relay race at the warm-up arena, the capacity crowd cheered loudly.\n\nThe showman, as usual, entertained the crowd as he acknowledged the cheers as he entered the stadium for the relay heats. He did his routine marking of his starting position and did a few run-downs imitating baton exchange.\n\nAfter easing past the finish line, Bolt ran down the track as he usually does and clapped towards the crowd.\n\n\"There are no words to describe how I am feeling. I get so much support from the crowd. I appreciate that a lot. All the energy I am getting from the crowd. It is brilliant,\" Bolt said after the race.\n\n\"The young runners in our team -- it is just about executing and coming through the race for them. We have been training that relay, there were some camps. Still there were some mistakes. Yohan Blake is coming in for the final is definitely good.\"\n\nIn the women's 4x100m relay, all the medal contenders -- United States, Great Britain, Germany and defending champions Jamaica -- progressed to the final round without much trouble, while the Bahamas quartet failed to finish in the second heat due to a poor second baton change.\n\nOlympic champions United States won the first heat in a world leading time of 41.84 seconds, even in the absence of individual 100m champion Torie Bowie.\n\nGreat Britain finished second in that heat -- and also second overall -- with 41.93, the third fastest time ever produced by a British quartet.\n\nDefending champions Jamaica (42.50) finished second behind Germany (42.34) in the second heat.\n\nSwitzerland (42.50) qualified with the fourth fastest time overall while Netherlands (42.64), Brazil (42.77) and Trinidad and Tobago (42.91) completed the final round line-up.\n\nAmerican runner Allyson Felix later said that Bowie will return in the final round.", "time": "14:00:00"}

"http://www.dnaindia.com/sports/report-did-world-athletics-championships-organisers-rob-usain-bolt-of-final-glory-2528416", "body": "Jamaica's Usain Bolt falls after injuring himself in the final of the men's 4x100m relay event at the 2017 IAAF World Championships at the London Stadium in London on August 12 (AFP)\n\nJustin Gatlin agreed with the complaints of the Jamaican relay team that a long wait before their 4x100m final at the World Championships on Saturday contributed to the injury suffered by Usain Bolt in his last race.\n\nBolt, having been passed the baton by Yohan Blake, was in third behind Great Britain and the United States, who eventually won gold and silver, but pulled up almost 50 metres from the line and fell to the track.\n\nJamaica's team doctor later said that the 30-year-old had suffered a hamstring cramp. Bolt's team mates complained that a 45-minute wait in the call room before the race had hampered their preparations.\n\n\"I think they were holding us too long in the call room,\" Blake told reporters. \"Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me 'Yohan, I think this is crazy'. Forty minutes and two medal presentations before our run.\"\n\nGatlin, who beat Bolt to gold in the 100m last Saturday, agreed with the complaints and laid the blame at the television scheduling for the event. \"I know it's TV magic, and everybody has to be prepared on time to make everything happen for the viewers at home. (But) I personally think that we were held in the stadium a little too long without our clothes on, and there was a little draught in there. I lost all my sweat and body heat,\" Gatlin said.\n\nWhen asked if he thought that contributed to Bolt's injury, the 35-year-old said: \"I believe so. Knowing how Usain performs, he's always ready, he's always making sure he's not injured and it's very rare to see Usain injured when he comes to performances.\"\n\nGatlin ran the second leg for the United States as they finished runners-up behind Britain, who became world champions for the first time. Amidst the home crowd's jubilation, there was also relief at the sight of Bolt being able to walk off the track after being helped to his feet by his team mates.\n\n\"I'm not sure what the extent of his injury is, but when I saw him go down I thought it was a calf cramp or a hamstring cramp. But he walked off the track, so that's good thing. I hope that he gets well soon,\"", "time": "05:41:00"}

been brilliant. The energy in the stadium is outstanding,\" Bolt said, hailing the deafening support in the packed-out London Stadium \"not just for me but the whole championships\".\n\nBolt said his emotions were still in check at the thought of bowing out of track and field.\n\n\"For me it's hard to be sad because the energy I'm getting from the crowd is brilliant, I'm just happy.\n\n\"There are no words to describe how I am feeling.\"\n\nBolt acknowledged that Yohan Blake would likely come in for the final, all the while praising his less experienced relay teammates.\n\n\"The young runners in our team -- it is just about executing and coming through the race for them,\" he said.\n\n\"We have been training that relay, there were some camps. Still there were some mistakes. Yohan Blake coming in for the final is definitely good.\"\n\nBolt's bid to retain his 100m title went up in smoke as American Justin Gatlin won gold, with Christian Coleman taking silver.\n\nIt was the first time Bolt had been beaten at a major championships since the 4x100m relay at the 2007 worlds in Osaka.\n\nThe 100 and 200m world record holder, who also anchored the Jamaican squad to a world record in the relay of 36.84sec at the 2012 London Olympics, will be back at the track for the final at 2050 GMT.\n\nBolt has amassed eight Olympic golds and 14 world medals, 11 of which are gold, the Jamaican having won two silvers in 2007 before his 100m bronze in London.\n\nNo matter the result of the relay, organisers said Bolt will be afforded a dedicated lap of honour on Sunday in tribute to his amazing track career.\n\nGatlin ran the second leg for the US team, led off by Mike Rodgers, another dope cheat, BeeJay Lee and Coleman on anchor.\n\nThey clocked 37.70 seconds to finish 0.06sec ahead of Britain.\n\n\"It felt good,\" said Rodgers. \"It feels like second nature because we work well together.\n\n\"We are confident we can win. We will go and prepare well for tonight.\"\n\nAlso qualifying for the final were France, China, Japan, Turkey and Canada.", "time": "11:51:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chijindu_Ujah", "label": {"eng": "Chijindu Ujah"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1417682"}], "url": "http://www.firstpost.com/sports/iaaf-world-athletics-championships-2017-usain-bolt-ends-career-on-sad-note-pulls-up-injured-in-last-race-3924563.html", "body": "London: Usain Bolt's glittering career swan song came crashing to an end when he pulled up injured on the anchor leg of the world 4x100m relay won by Britain on Saturday.\n\nBolt received the baton with Jamaica in third, but halfway down the finishing straight the towering sprinter pulled up clutching his left thigh, eventually doing a forward somersault to the ground, to gasps from the 60,000 sell out London Stadium.\n\nUsain Bolt lies on the track after pulling up injured in the final of the men's 4x100m relay. AFP\n\nThe British quartet of Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake claimed gold in 37.47 seconds, with the Justin Gatlin-led US four taking silver at 0.05sec and Japan a surprise bronze (38.04).\n\n\"He didn't tell us exactly what happened but from what I saw, it looked like a strain or a cramp of some sort,\" second leg runner Julian Forte said.\n\n\"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise -- injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nNewly-crowned 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, Jamaica's lead-off runner, added: \"Everybody was jelly, everybody was pumped. (Bolt's injury) just happened. Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nBolt missed out on his bid to retain his 100m title earlier in the week, losing out to Gatlin and silver medallist Christian Coleman, who ran relay anchor for the Americans on Saturday.\n\nBut hopes were high for Bolt's final competitive race, with Jamaica also boasting McLeod, Forte and 2011 world champion Yohan Blake in their line-up.\n\nJamaica were afforded a rousing welcome from the crowd, a relaxed-looking Bolt applauding the stands, with pictures of him constantly shown on the stadium's big screens.\n\nGatlin, who has served two doping bans, and the US team also including another convicted doping cheat, Mike Rodgers, and Jaylen Bacon were booed when introduced although the jeering was less pronounced than for the individual 100m event.\n\nA close first three legs saw Britain, the United States and Jamaica, seeking a fifth consecutive world title, level-pegged for the final leg.\n\nHigh drama\n\nBut there was to be high drama as a visibly swearing Bolt pulled up in obvious pain, allowing the Japanese quartet to edge in for third.\n\nThe result means Bolt, 100 and 200m world record holder, finishes his career with 14 world career medals, one behind American Allyson Felix, to go with eight Olympic golds.\n\nAmid wild home celebrations, Bolt was attended to by medics, but refused a ride in a wheelchair off the track, instead finally getting up and limping alongside his teammates through to the finish line and then off into the bowels of the stadium for treatment.\n\nIt was a sad exit for an athlete who has lit up the track when the sport has been dragged through its worst-ever crisis, racked by doping and corruption scandals that went to the very heart of athletics' governing body.\n\nAnd what a gaping hole his absence will leave, no matter how brave a face the IAAF try to put on it.\n\nSince confirming his sprinting dominance with triple gold at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Bolt spent nine seasons amassing 19 global golds, 13 of which have come in individual events.\n\nAllied with a charismatic personality, it has guaranteed Bolt recognition as one of the world's most successful sportsmen. Last year alone he earned $34.2 million, according to Forbes.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 13, 2017 03:45 am | Updated Date: Aug 13, 2017 03:55 am\n\nTags :#Adam gemili#Allyson felix#Chijindu ujah#Christian coleman#Daniel talbot#Iaaf#Iaaf world athletics championships 2017#Jamaica relay team#Jaylen bacon#Julian forte#Justin gatlin#Mike rodgers#Nethaneel mitchell-blake#Omar mcleod#Usain bolt#Yohan blake", "time": "22:55:00"}

"http://www.hindustantimes.com/other-sports/usain-bolt-s-record-breaking-career-in-numbers/story-IHZ1qtukIPAkkOW3oKyCpJ.html", "body": "The illustrious career of Usain Bolt ended in dramatic fashion on Saturday as the sprint icon pulled up with an injury in his final race, the men's 4x100m final at the World Championships in London.\n\nBolt sensationally failed to finish the anchor leg for Jamaica, an apparent hamstring injury ending his hopes of bowing out with a 12th World Championships gold medal. Great Britain instead took gold ahead of the United States and Japan.\n\n(Read | Usain Bolt collapses in final race, Great Britain seal 4x100m relay gold)\n\nThere had been disappointment for Bolt in London last weekend when he had to settle for a bronze medal behind Justin Gatlin and Christian Coleman in the 100m, his last individual race.\n\nHowever, Bolt nevertheless ends his career as an undoubted great - having transcended his sport and made history on numerous occasions.\n\n(Read | Dafne Schippers retains 200m crown at IAAF\u2009World Championships)\n\nFollowing his last outing, we take a look at the numbers that highlight his stunning success.\n\n9.58 - Bolt's blistering 100 metre world-record time, set in the 2009 World Championships final.\n\n22 - How many years Michael Johnson held the men's 200m record of 19.32 seconds, before Bolt broke it in 2008 in Beijing - a benchmark he has since lowered to 19.19secs.\n\n19 - Major gold medals Bolt has won in his career, having had his 4x100m relay title from the 2008 Olympics revoked due to Nesta Carter's doping violation.\n\nYou can't write a script for sport.\n\nGet well soon, @usainbolt. Thank you for being the \u1f410.#IAAFworlds pic.twitter.com/52c0g79v0w -- SPIKES (@spikesmag)\n\nAugust 12, 2017\n\n27.79 - Bolt's top speed in miles-per-hour, between the 60m and 80m marks, as he set his world-record 100m time in 2009.\n\n36.84 - The world-record time he and his Jamaica team-mates clocked in the 2012 4x100m relay Olympic final.\n\n7 - The number of times Bolt has set a world-record time across his specialist events.\n\n6 - Bolt's record tally of IAAF World Athlete of the Year awards.\n\n34.2 million - Bolt's estimated yearly earnings, in dollars, by Forbes, who calculate him to be the 88th best-paid celebrity in the world - in between Real Madrid footballer Gareth Bale and NBA star Derrick Rose.", "time": "02:45:00"}

"http://cw39.com/2017/08/13/agony-for-usain-bolt-as-he-pulls-up-injured-in-track-farewell/", "body": "LONDON -- Usain Bolt's farewell appearance at the world championships ended in painful and disastrous fashion as he pulled up injured on the final leg of the men's 4x100m relay Saturday.\n\nBolt took the baton for Jamaica in third place but within a few strides he had fallen to the ground, clutching his left leg, as host Britain secured a shock gold ahead of a United States team containing Justin Gatlin.\n\nThe 30-year-old Bolt, beaten into third in the individual 100m behind Gatlin and his US team compatriot Christian Coleman, was comforted by teammates after getting to his feet, his face etched in pain.\n\nThe capacity crowd in the London Stadium was still digesting the shock earlier defeat for home hero Mo Farah in the men's 5,000m final, before the drama of Bolt's last agonizing appearance.\n\nREAD: Bolt in numbers - Why the Jamaican is the greatest\n\nREAD: Gatlin spoils Bolt's individual farewell\n\nHe had been bidding for a 12th world championship gold to bring down the curtain on his glittering career, but instead limped out of the London Stadium arena.\n\nVictory for the British quartet of CJ Ujah, Adam Gemili, who ran a storming second leg, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake was stunning compensation for Farah's earlier defeat.\n\nThey won in 37.47 seconds, with the US taking silver at 0.05sec and Japan with a surprise bronze.\n\nFor his massive global following, the perfect script would have seen the Bolt of old running down Britain and the US for yet another gold, but it was not to be.\n\n\"He didn't tell us exactly what happened but from what I saw, it looked like a strain or a cramp of some sort,\" teammate Julian Forte told IAAF radio.\n\n\"He kept apologizing to us but we told him there was no need to apologize -- injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nJamaican team doctor Dr Kevin Jones told AFP that Bolt had suffered from \"cramp in his left hamstring\".\n\n\"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him,\" he added.\n\nJamaica's 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, who ran the first leg for the quartet, summed up the feeling of everyone.\n\n\"Usain Bolt's name will always live on,\" he said.\n\nBut another teammate, Yohan Blake, who won Olympic relay gold with Bolt in 2012 and 2016, slammed organizers for the delay in starting the race because of medal ceremonies.\n\n\"Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me, 'Yohan, I think this is crazy',\" he said.\n\nFarah, who won the 10,000 title in dramatic fashion of the opening day at the London Stadium, had to settle for silver behind Ethiopian Muktar Edris in his final championship race on the track.\n\nHe edged out American Paul Chelimo in a desperate dash for the line, the last mile of a hitherto slow run race run in just under four minutes.\n\nFarah, 34, will now turn his attention to the marathon after failing in his bid to double up at the Olympics or World Championship for the fifth time, including double gold in London 2012 and the Rio Games last year.\n\nEdris, a former world junior champion, timed his last lap burst to perfection to win in 13 minutes 32.79 seconds, copying Farah's famous Mobot gesture as he crossed the line.\n\nIt was not the farewell Farah wanted, but he pointed to his earlier exertions in a dramatic 10,000m final as reason for lacking his usual devastating finish.\n\n\"The 10,000m took a lot more out of me than I had realized,\" he told BBC Sport.\n\n\"I gave it my all. I didn't have a single thing left to give at the end.\"", "time": "14:26:00"}

"label": {"eng": "4 \u00d7 100 metres relay"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "320499"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolt_(2008_film)", "label": {"eng": "Bolt (2008 film)"}, "score": 5, "type": "wiki", "id": "322557"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamstring", "label": {"eng": "Hamstring"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "323465"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decathlon", "label": {"eng": "Decathlon"}, "score": 1, "type": "wiki", "id": "328733"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tumbling_(gymnastics)", "label": {"eng": "Tumbling (gymnastics)"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "329547"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mo_Farah", "label": {"eng": "Mo Farah"}, "score": 1, "type": "person", "id": "338647"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yohan_Blake", "label": {"eng": "Yohan Blake"}, "score": 2, "type": "person", "id": "343533"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallace_Spearmon", "label": {"eng": "Wallace Spearmon"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "527099"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Jones_(American_football)", "label": {"eng": "Kevin Jones (American football)"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "546615"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muktar_Edris", "label": {"eng": "Muktar Edris"}, "score": 1, "type": "person", "id": "709359"}], "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/competing-as-neutral-athlete-klishina-of-russia-gets-silver/2017/08/11/248cc1e6-7ef3-11e7-b2b1-aeba62854dfa_story.html", "body": "LONDON -- Usain Bolt was ramping into warp speed when suddenly, stunningly, the sprint turned into a somersault.\n\nFifteen steps into the final homestretch of his final race, something gave in his left hamstring. The World's Fastest Man skittered to a stop -- hopping, skipping, jumping, then finally dropping to the ground and tumbling forward before coming to a rest.\n\nWhile the winning team from Britain crossed the finish line, Bolt was writhing on the track, where he eventually wound up chest down with his face pressed into Lane 5. He was certainly every bit as stunned as any of the 60,000-plus who packed the stadium Saturday, or the millions watching one of the world's most entertaining showmen make his final curtain call in the 4x100-meter relay at world championships.\n\nThere was no celebration. No gold, no silver, not even a consolation bronze, the likes of which Bolt received a week earlier in his final 100-meter race.\n\nJamaica closed the night with \"DNF\" by its name: Did Not Finish. Dead last. Bolt was helped into a wheelchair, but eventually got to his feet and, assisted by his teammates, limped gingerly across the finish line. He gave a few waves to the crowd, then left for the trainer's room, and with that, presumably left track and field forever.\n\n\"Injuries are part of our sport and, always, of course, it's sad to see,\" said Wallace Spearmon, the American sprinter who has been close with Bolt for years and was on hand helping the U.S. team. \"So, yeah, it's tragic.\"\n\nThe Jamaican team doctor, Kevin Jones, diagnosed the injury that brought a strange end to Bolt's career as, simply, a cramp in the champion's left hamstring.\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jones said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nWatching track's No. 1 sprinter and celebrity dropping to the ground was nothing short of jaw-dropping -- so much so that the fact that Britain won the race, outrunning a United States team that, somewhat amazingly, didn't drop the baton, almost seemed like an afterthought.\n\nNethaneel Mitchell-Blake held off U.S. anchorman Christian Coleman down the stretch and the Brits won their first-ever world title in the 4x100 in 37.47 seconds.\n\nWhen Bolt took the baton from Yohan Blake for his final homestretch, he was in third place, but that was no cause for concern. In virtually each of the seven relay golds he's won at the Olympics and world championships, Bolt has reeled in the competition down the stretch and won going away, much the same as all his 100 victories have played out.\n\nFive years and one day earlier, on the very same track, Bolt helped Jamaica set the world record. That run of 36.84 seconds earned Bolt the sixth of nine Olympic victories.\n\nBut last week in the 100, Bolt's extra gear was not enough either to catch Coleman, who finished second, or to hold off Justin Gatlin, the oft-booed American who came from behind to finish first.\n\nCould he have caught his relay competition in this one? Nobody will ever know. Bolt was gaining no ground at the 30-meter mark, which is when he felt the pain in his leg and went tumbling.\n\nAfterward, there was plenty of second-guessing to be done. Most of it came at the expense of the IAAF, which made the sprinters wait about 40 minutes from the time they were summoned from the warm-up room to the time the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I think this is crazy,\" Blake said. \"Forty minutes. Waiting. Warming up. Waiting. Warming up. It just should not happen. To have your champion go out like that. It's crazy.\"\n\nSaid Gatlin, who remains insistent that Bolt will be back someday: \"We lost all of our heat, all of our sweat, and we went out there cold.\"\n\nPart of the wait was for the U.S. women's relay team to finish its victory celebration. Tori Bowie anchored the win and, with one day left in the meet, is the only athlete to win two gold medals in London. Also, a medal ceremony was held for Russian high jump champion Mariya Lasitskene, who is competing as a neutral athlete because of the doping crisis in her country and got to listen not to her own anthem, but to the IAAF's theme song, as she stood on the podium.\n\nOther winners included Kevin Mayer of France in the decathlon and Johannes Vetter, whose victory in the javelin throw gave Germany its first gold of the championships.\n\nIn the undercard to the relays, Muktar Edris held off Mo Farah of Britain in the 5,000. With help of his Ethiopian teammates, Edris won a tactical cat-and-mouse race and denied Farah his fifth straight long-distance double, counting world championships and Olympics.\n\nIt was a fun race to watch.\n\nBut nobody steals the show the way Bolt does.\n\nAs if to prove that point one last time, he did it again -- this time without even finishing the race.\n\n___\n\nMore AP track coverage: https://www.apnews.com/tag/London2017\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.", "time": "22:34:00"}
