in a world-leading time of 37.47 seconds, the US - booed upon entry with 100m champion Justin Gatlin on the second leg - second and Japan taking the bronze.\n\nBolt looks on in horror. Pic: Getty\n\nThe crocked Bolt was soon joined by his team-mates Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, who helped him to his feet and across the line before departing down the tunnel.\n\nRather than bemoaning a far from fitting end to the 30-year-old's distinguished career, the crowd inside London Stadium were lost in celebration for the victorious home nation.\n\nBolt missed out on his bid to retain his 100m title earlier in the week, losing out to Gatlin and silver medallist Christian Coleman, who ran relay anchor for the Americans on Saturday.\n\nBut hopes were high for Bolt's final competitive race, with Jamaica also boasting newly-crowned 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake in their line-up.\n\nBolt with his shattered teammates. "Tumbling (gymnastics)"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "329547"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relay_race", "label": {"eng": "Relay race"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "332246"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yohan_Blake", "label": {"eng": "Yohan Blake"}, "score": 2, "type": "person", "id": "343533"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallace_Spearmon", "label": {"eng": "Wallace Spearmon"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "527099"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Jones_(American_football)", "label": {"eng": "Kevin Jones (American football)"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "546615"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muktar_Edris", "label": {"eng": "Muktar Edris"}, "score": 1, "type": "person", "id": "709359"}], "url": "http://www.dothaneagle.com/news/ap/sports/bolt-takes-a-tumble-and-can-t-complete-final-race/article_c32729a6-c38a-50e6-b1be-8300c2b7aaea.html", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- Usain Bolt was ramping into warp speed when suddenly, stunningly, the sprint turned into a somersault.\n\nFifteen steps into the final homestretch of his final race, something gave in his left hamstring. The World's Fastest Man skittered to a stop -- hopping, skipping, jumping, then finally dropping to the ground and tumbling forward before coming to a rest.\n\nWhile the winning team from Britain crossed the finish line, Bolt was writhing on the track, where he eventually wound up chest down with his face pressed into Lane 5. He was certainly every bit as stunned as any of the 60,000-plus who packed the stadium Saturday, or the millions watching one of the world's most entertaining showmen make his final curtain call in the 4x100-meter relay at world championships.\n\nThere was no celebration. No gold, no silver, not even a consolation bronze, the likes of which Bolt received a week earlier in his final 100-meter race.\n\nJamaica closed the night with \"DNF\" by its name: Did Not Finish. Dead last. Bolt was helped into a wheelchair, but eventually got to his feet and, assisted by his teammates, limped gingerly across the finish line. He gave a few waves to the crowd, then left for the trainer's room, and with that, presumably left track and field forever.\n\n\"Injuries are part of our sport and, always, of course, it's sad to see,\" said Wallace Spearmon, the American sprinter who has been close with Bolt for years and was on hand helping the U.S. team. \"So, yeah, it's tragic.\"\n\nThe Jamaican team doctor, Kevin Jones, diagnosed the injury that brought a strange end to Bolt's career as, simply, a cramp in the champion's left hamstring.\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jones said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nWatching track's No. 1 sprinter and celebrity dropping to the ground was nothing short of jaw-dropping -- so much so that the fact that Britain won the race, outrunning a United States team that, somewhat amazingly, didn't drop the baton, almost seemed like an afterthought.\n\nNethaneel Mitchell-Blake held off U.S. anchorman Christian Coleman down the stretch and the Brits won their first-ever world title in the 4x100 in 37.47 seconds.\n\nWhen Bolt took the baton from Yohan Blake for his final homestretch, he was in third place, but that was no cause for concern. In virtually each of the seven relay golds he's won at the Olympics and world championships, Bolt has reeled in the competition down the stretch and won going away, much the same as all his 100 victories have played out.\n\nFive years and one day earlier, on the very same track, Bolt helped Jamaica set the world record. That run of 36.84 seconds earned Bolt the sixth of nine Olympic victories.\n\nBut last week in the 100, Bolt's extra gear was not enough either to catch Coleman, who finished second, or to hold off Justin Gatlin, the oft-booed American who came from behind to finish first.\n\nCould he have caught his relay competition in this one? Nobody will ever know. Bolt was gaining no ground at the 30-meter mark, which is when he felt the pain in his leg and went tumbling.\n\nAfterward, there was plenty of second-guessing to be done. Most of it came at the expense of the IAAF, which made the sprinters wait about 40 minutes from the time they were summoned from the warm-up room to the time the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I think this is crazy,\" Blake said. \"Forty minutes. Waiting. Warming up. Waiting. Warming up. It just should not happen. To have your champion go out like that. It's crazy.\"\n\nSaid Gatlin, who remains insistent that Bolt will be back someday: \"We lost all of our heat, all of our sweat, and we went out there cold.\"\n\nPart of the wait was for the U.S. women's relay team to finish its victory celebration. Tori Bowie anchored the win and, with one day left in the meet, is the only athlete to win two gold medals in London. Also, a medal ceremony was held for Russian high jump champion Mariya Lasitskene, who is competing as a neutral athlete because of the doping crisis in her country and got to listen not to her own anthem, but to the IAAF's theme song, as she stood on the podium.\n\nOther winners included Kevin Mayer of France in the decathlon and Johannes Vetter, whose victory in the javelin throw gave Germany its first gold of the championships.\n\nIn the undercard to the relays, Muktar Edris held off Mo Farah of Britain in the 5,000. With help of his Ethiopian teammates, Edris won a tactical cat-and-mouse race and denied Farah his fifth straight long-distance double, counting world championships and Olympics.\n\nIt was a fun race to watch.\n\nBut nobody steals the show the way Bolt does.\n\nAs if to prove that point one last time, he did it again -- this time without even finishing the race.\n\n-- -- --\n\nMore AP track coverage: https://www.apnews.com/tag/London2017", "time": "00:15:00"}

"https://inews.co.uk/essentials/sport/usain-bolt-brought-excessive-delay-medal-ceremonies-says-jamaican-relay-team/", "body": "Usain Bolt crashed to the track in agony during the 4x100m relay at the World Championships in London (Getty Images)\n\nThe organisers of the World Championships in Lodnon came under fire on Saturday night after the Jamaican 4x100m relay team accused them of causing Usain Bolt's debilitating cramp that wrecked his final major race.\n\nBolt was in third place but still gaining on the United States and shock gold medallists Great Britain when he suddenly pulled up halfway through his anchor leg to grab his hamstring and collapse to the ground in visible agony.\n\n\"I think they were holding us too long in the call room,\" said an exasperated Yohan Blake. \"Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me 'Yohan, I think this is crazy'. Forty minutes and two medal presentations before our run.\n\nChampion Struggling\n\n\"We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us,\" he said. \"We were over warm. And to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggling like that. It was just crazy.\"\n\nHis sentiment was echoed by Omar McLeod and Julian Forte, who criticised organisers for the 10-minute delay after the medal ceremonies for the men's 5,000m, in which Mo Farah won silver, and then for the women's high jump.\n\n\"It was ridiculous man, we were there around 45 minutes waiting outside, I think they had three medal ceremonies before we went so we were really trying our hardest to stay warm and keep upbeat,\" McLeod told reporters.\n\nRidiculous Wait\n\n\"But it was ridiculous. We waited a really long time. I drank like two bottles of water. It's heart-wrenching. I gave it my all and I really wanted Usain to leave golden, or even if it was just a medal, it was really heart-wrenching.\n\nSaid Forte: \"They kept us in the call room for an extremely long time in our running kits and it's not the warmest over here. They had us around there for really quite a while, so I think they really need to do something about it.\n\nBolt refused to be taken off the track in a wheelchair or stretcher, but it was still a hugely disappointing way for him to end a glittering career that has seen him dominate sprinting for over a decade. He did not stop for interviews.\n\nPain from Losing\n\nIn a statement, the Jamaican team doctor Kevin Jones said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring but that most his pain ultimately came from the disappointment of losing. He added Bolt had found the last few weeks hard.\n\nJustin Gatlin, who added relay silver to his individual gold from earlier on at the championships, reiterated his belief that Bolt would stage a comeback in time for the 2019 world titles in Doha after a difficult campaign in London.\n\n\"From 2008, Usain Bolt has done amazing things,\" said Gatlin. \"Tonight is not going to define who he is. He's still the man. And this is his farewell tour, his farewell race, so we have to take our hat off to him. I hope he gets well soon.\n\nComing Back\n\n\"I've got to say it, I'm going to win my hundred dollars. He's coming back in a year or two. He'll be ready. He has a passion for the sport, he loves the fans, the fans love him, it's not something you can walk away too easy from.\n\n\"He's a showman. I think he will do a great job if he comes back to track and field. We've got a lot of young guys like [the United States' anchor Christian] Coleman, myself, and we're hungry to go out there for good competition.\"", "time": "23:34:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tori_Bowie", "label": {"eng": "Tori Bowie"}, "score": 1, "type": "wiki", "id": "1405606"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chijindu_Ujah", "label": {"eng": "Chijindu Ujah"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1417682"}], "url": "http://ethiopiaforums.com/sad-farewell-as-bolt-ends-glittering-career-with-injury-news/31397/", "body": "ShareTwitGoogle+E-mail\n\nUsain Bolt pulled up with an injury on the anchor leg of the 4\u00d7100 metres relay final at the World Athletics Championships on Saturday as the last race of his unparalleled career ended in high drama.\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift when, straining hard to catch the leaders, he suddenly suffered a hamstring injury, began hobbling and ended up coming to a halt after doing a forward roll on the track.\n\nAfter a short while, though, he rose gingerly to his feet and limped across the line to huge cheers from the 56,000 crowd.\n\nThat wasn't the only surprise. Britain went on to beat the United States in a tight finish.\n\nREAD MORE: Usain Bolt, from strong child to track king\n\nThe 60,000-capacity stadium was primed for one last Bolt show, one last \"To the World\" pose after a victory, but the injury made it blatantly clear why Bolt is ready to retire. His body can no longer hold up.\n\nHis teammates on the once-fabled Jamaican sprint squad were far from unmatchable, too. Bolt had just too much to make up in the final 100 metres as both Britain and the US were ahead and even Japan was even.\n\nBolt - 100 and 200m world record holder - finishes his career with 14 world career medals [John Sibley/Reuters]\n\nAs Bolt fell to the ground, the leg with the golden shoe giving way, the crowd still went wild because the home team went on to win gold in 37.47 seconds, 0.05 seconds ahead of the US.\n\nThe brilliantly executed race by Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Danny Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake gave Britain gold in 37.47 seconds, breaking an 18-year-old national record, and the world title for the first time.\n\nThe result means Bolt, 100 and 200m world record holder, finishes his career with 14 world career medals, one behind American Allyson Felix, to go with eight Olympic golds.\n\nInside Jamaica's running factory: Bolt inspires the next generation\n\nAmid wild home celebrations, Bolt was attended to by medics, but refused a ride in a wheelchair off the track, instead finally getting up and limping alongside his teammates through to the finish line and then off into the stadium for treatment.\n\nIt was a sad exit for an athlete who has lit up the track when the sport has been dragged through its worst-ever crisis, racked by doping and corruption scandals that went to the very heart of athletics' governing body.\n\nSince confirming his sprinting dominance with triple gold at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Bolt spent nine seasons amassing 19 global golds, 13 of which have come in individual events.\n\nAllied with a charismatic personality, it has guaranteed Bolt recognition as one of the world's most successful sportsmen. Last year alone he earned $34.2m, according to Forbes.\n\nAl Jazeera's Sonia Gallego, reporting from London, said Bolt would be remembered as one of the all time great athletes.\n\n\"It's very unlikely that we're going to see anyone of his ilk very soon,\" she said.\n\n\"So really quite a sad end to Usain Bolt's career but hopefully not the end of him as a personality and as an ambassador for the sport.\"\n\nMo Farah's swansong\n\nBefore Bolt came onto the track, he was consoling Mo Farah, his long-distance equivalent who had just lost his first major race since 2011 when he failed to get gold in the 5,000 metres.\n\nFarah also was bidding farewell to the track, coming up short of his fifth straight 5,000-10,000 double at major championships in a sprint against Muktar Edris of Ethiopia.\n\nFarah, now 34 years old and a six-time world champion, knew the opposition would be gunning for him. And they did.\n\nMo Farah Farah, now 34 years old, is a six-time world champion [Patrick Smith/Getty Images]\n\nThey boxed Farah in. They changed the pace of the race. They made him work hard knowing that his 10,000-metre victory on the opening day of the championships would take something out of his punishing finish.\n\n\"I gave it all,\" Farah said. \"I didn't have a single bit left at the end.\"\n\nAl Jazeera's Sonia Gallego said that Farah's silver was disappointing but that he had made a gracious lap of honour and posed with fans.\n\n\"Certainly a very honourable end for a tremendous athlete and certainly quite sad to see it happen in a place where he had made his name in such spectacular fashion back in the 2012 Olympics,\" said Gallego.\n\nUS takes gold in women's relay\n\nBowie (R) who won the 100 metres this week, ran a strong anchor leg, leaving behind the opposition to finish in 41.82 seconds [Alexander Hassenstein/Getty]\n\nTori Bowie was the unlikely first double gold medalist at the championships, anchoring the US team to the 4\u00d7100-metre relay title ahead of Britain and Jamaica.\n\nAt the same time, Allyson Felix, running the second leg on the winning team, earned a record 15th medal at the world championships in a career going back to 2005.\n\nBowie, who won the 100 metres this week, ran a strong anchor leg, leaving behind the opposition to finish in 41.82 seconds.\n\n\"Two gold medals is amazing for me,\" Bowie said. \"We are on top of the world.\"\n\nBritain took silver in 42.12 and two-time defending champion Jamaica earned bronze in 42.19.\n\nSource: Al Jazeera and news agencies\n\nMore From Our Site\n\nSource Link\n\nShareTwitGoogle+E-mail See Also: Ethiopia club used intel gathered from Supersport TV to frustrate Sundowns", "time": "12:02:00"}

{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sport_of_athletics", "label": {"eng": "Sport of athletics"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1053871"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omar_McLeod", "label": {"eng": "Omar McLeod"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1333564"}], "url": "http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/sport/archives/2017/08/14/2003676493", "body": "Usain Bolt's unparalleled career ended in extraordinary drama on Saturday as he pulled up with injury on the anchor leg of his very last race, the 4x100m relay final at the World Championships.\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few meters adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with a cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track.\n\nYet, the sport's greatest entertainer was determined that one of the finest careers in sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair.\n\nSo the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried teammates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30m to the line.\n\nThe official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish, but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the teammates he felt he had let down.\n\n\"He kept apologizing to us, but we told him there was no need to apologize,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\n\"It just happened -- Usain Bolt's name will always live on,\" McLeod added.\n\nJustin Gatlin, the American winner of the individual 100m who had consigned Bolt to third place in his final individual race on Saturday last week, paid tribute to his rival.\n\n\"I think it was the elements [that caused the injury]. I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said. \"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\nJamaican team doctor Kevin Jones said Bolt had suffered a cramp in his left hamstring.\n\nBlake was angry at having to wait for two medal ceremonies to take place before the race.\n\n\"It was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run ... we were kept 40 minutes. It was crazy,\" Blake said. \"They were holding us too long.\"\n\n\"We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us. It hurts to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggle like that,\" Blake said.\n\nJamaican team manager Ian Forbes praised Bolt for \"going out there and giving his all\" and added that the squad were \"very saddened.\"\n\n\"The diagnostic work will be done shortly to determine how serious it is. He was able to walk to the team bus so hopefully that signals it's not as serious as it possibly could be,\" Forbes said.\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favorite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track.\n\nFive years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics.\n\nYet, in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000m, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell.", "time": "16:53:00"}

"id": "527099"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Jones_(American_football)", "label": {"eng": "Kevin Jones (American football)"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "546615"}], "url": "http://www.dentonrc.com/sports/sports-ap-headlines/2017/08/12/bolt-takes-tumble-complete-final-race-worlds", "body": "LONDON -- Usain Bolt was ramping into warp speed when suddenly, stunningly, the sprint turned into a somersault.\n\nFifteen steps into the final homestretch of his final race, something gave in his left hamstring. The World's Fastest Man skittered to a stop -- hopping, skipping, jumping, then finally dropping to the ground and tumbling forward before coming to a rest.\n\nWhile the winning team from Britain crossed the finish line, Bolt was writhing on the track, where he eventually wound up chest down with his face pressed into Lane 5. He was certainly every bit as stunned as any of the 60,000-plus who packed the stadium Saturday, or the millions watching one of the world's most entertaining showmen make his final curtain call in the 4x100-meter relay at world championships.\n\nThere was no celebration. No gold, no silver, not even a consolation bronze, the likes of which Bolt received a week earlier in his final 100-meter race.\n\nJamaica closed the night with \"DNF\" by its name: Did Not Finish. Dead last. Bolt was helped into a wheelchair, but eventually got to his feet and, assisted by his teammates, limped gingerly across the finish line. He gave a few waves to the crowd, then left for the trainer's room, and with that, presumably left track and field forever.\n\n\"Injuries are part of our sport and, always, of course, it's sad to see,\" said Wallace Spearmon, the American sprinter who has been close with Bolt for years and was on hand helping the U.S. team. \"So, yeah, it's tragic.\"\n\nThe Jamaican team doctor, Kevin Jones, diagnosed the injury that brought a strange end to Bolt's career as, simply, a cramp in the champion's left hamstring.\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jones said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nWatching track's No. 1 sprinter and celebrity dropping to the ground was nothing short of jaw-dropping -- so much so that the fact that Britain won the race, outrunning a United States team that, somewhat amazingly, didn't drop the baton, almost seemed like an afterthought.\n\nNethaneel Mitchell-Blake held off U.S. anchorman Christian Coleman down the stretch and the Brits won their first-ever world title in the 4x100 in 37.47 seconds.\n\nWhen Bolt took the baton from Yohan Blake for his final homestretch, he was in third place, but that was no cause for concern. In virtually each of the seven relay golds he's won at the Olympics and world championships, Bolt has reeled in the competition down the stretch and won going away, much the same as all his 100 victories have played out.\n\nFive years and one day earlier, on the very same track, Bolt helped Jamaica set the world record. That run of 36.84 seconds earned Bolt the sixth of nine Olympic victories.\n\nBut last week in the 100, Bolt's extra gear was not enough either to catch Coleman, who finished second, or to hold off Justin Gatlin, the oft-booed American who came from behind to finish first.\n\nCould he have caught his relay competition in this one? Nobody will ever know. Bolt was gaining no ground at the 30-meter mark, which is when he felt the pain in his leg and went tumbling.\n\nAfterward, there was plenty of second-guessing to be done. Most of it came at the expense of the IAAF, which made the sprinters wait about 40 minutes from the time they were summoned from the warm-up room to the time the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I think this is crazy,\" Blake said. \"Forty minutes. Waiting. Warming up. Waiting. Warming up. It just should not happen. To have your champion go out like that. It's crazy.\"\n\nSaid Gatlin, who remains insistent that Bolt will be back someday: \"We lost all of our heat, all of our sweat, and we went out there cold.\"\n\nPart of the wait was for the U.S. women's relay team to finish its victory celebration. Tori Bowie anchored the win and, with one day left in the meet, is the only athlete to win two gold medals in London. Also, a medal ceremony was held for Russian high jump champion Mariya Lasitskene, who is competing as a neutral athlete because of the doping crisis in her country and got to listen not to her own anthem, but to the IAAF's theme song, as she stood on the podium.\n\nOther winners included Kevin Mayer of France in the decathlon and Johannes Vetter, whose victory in the javelin throw gave Germany its first gold of the championships.\n\nIn the undercard to the relays, Muktar Edris held off Mo Farah of Britain in the 5,000. With help of his Ethiopian teammates, Edris won a tactical cat-and-mouse race and denied Farah his fifth straight long-distance double, counting world championships and Olympics.\n\nAs if to prove that point one last time, he did it again -- this time without even finishing the race.", "time": "00:34:00"}

suddenly, stunningly, the sprint turned into a somersault.\n\nFifteen steps into the final homestretch of his final race, something gave in his left hamstring. The World's Fastest Man skittered to a stop -- hopping, skipping, jumping, then finally dropping to the ground and tumbling forward before coming to a rest.\n\nWhile the winning team from Britain crossed the finish line, Bolt was writhing on the track, where he eventually wound up chest down with his face pressed into Lane 5. He was certainly every bit as stunned as any of the 60,000-plus who packed the stadium Saturday, or the millions watching one of the world's most entertaining showmen make his final curtain call in the 4x100-meter relay at world championships.\n\nThere was no celebration. No gold, no silver, not even a consolation bronze, the likes of which Bolt received a week earlier in his final 100-meter race.\n\nJamaica closed the night with \"DNF\" by its name: Did Not Finish. Dead last. Bolt was helped into a wheelchair, but eventually got to his feet and, assisted by his teammates, limped gingerly across the finish line. He gave a few waves to the crowd, then left for the trainer's room, and with that, presumably left track and field forever.\n\n\"Injuries are part of our sport and, always, of course, it's sad to see,\" said Wallace Spearmon, the American sprinter who has been close with Bolt for years and was on hand helping the U.S. team. \"So, yeah, it's tragic.\"\n\nThe Jamaican team doctor, Kevin Jones, diagnosed the injury that brought a strange end to Bolt's career as, simply, a cramp in the champion's left hamstring.\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jones said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nWatching track's No. 1 sprinter and celebrity dropping to the ground was nothing short of jaw-dropping -- so much so that the fact that Britain won the race, outrunning a United States team that, somewhat amazingly, didn't drop the baton, almost seemed like an afterthought.\n\nNethaneel Mitchell-Blake held off U.S. anchorman Christian Coleman down the stretch and the Brits won their first-ever world title in the 4x100 in 37.47 seconds.\n\nWhen Bolt took the baton from Yohan Blake for his final homestretch, he was in third place, but that was no cause for concern. In virtually each of the seven relay golds he's won at the Olympics and world championships, Bolt has reeled in the competition down the stretch and won going away, much the same as all his 100 victories have played out.\n\nFive years and one day earlier, on the very same track, Bolt helped Jamaica set the world record. That run of 36.84 seconds earned Bolt the sixth of nine Olympic victories.\n\nBut last week in the 100, Bolt's extra gear was not enough either to catch Coleman, who finished second, or to hold off Justin Gatlin, the oft-booed American who came from behind to finish first.\n\nCould he have caught his relay competition in this one? Nobody will ever know. Bolt was gaining no ground at the 30-meter mark, which is when he felt the pain in his leg and went tumbling.\n\nAfterward, there was plenty of second-guessing to be done. Most of it came at the expense of the IAAF, which made the sprinters wait about 40 minutes from the time they were summoned from the warm-up room to the time the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I think this is crazy,\" Blake said. \"Forty minutes. Waiting. Warming up. Waiting. Warming up. It just should not happen. To have your champion go out like that. It's crazy.\"\n\nSaid Gatlin, who remains insistent that Bolt will be back someday: \"We lost all of our heat, all of our sweat, and we went out there cold.\"\n\nPart of the wait was for the U.S. women's relay team to finish its victory celebration. Tori Bowie anchored the win and, with one day left in the meet, is the only athlete to win two gold medals in London. Also, a medal ceremony was held for Russian high jump champion Mariya Lasitskene, who is competing as a neutral athlete because of the doping crisis in her country and got to listen not to her own anthem, but to the IAAF's theme song, as she stood on the podium.\n\nOther winners included Kevin Mayer of France in the decathlon and Johannes Vetter, whose victory in the javelin throw gave Germany its first gold of the championships.\n\nIn the undercard to the relays, Muktar Edris held off Mo Farah of Britain in the 5,000. With help of his Ethiopian teammates, Edris won a tactical cat-and-mouse race and denied Farah his fifth straight long-distance double, counting world championships and Olympics.\n\nAs if to prove that point one last time, he did it again -- this time without even finishing the race.", "time": "23:53:00"}

Bolt was running the anchor leg for Jamaica in the 4 x 100-meter relay final at the 2017 World Championships in Athletics when he suffered a leg cramp, collapsed to the track and ultimately left in tears.\n\nAfterward, Bolt lamented the sad ending to his remarkable career but also thanked his fans.\n\n\"Not the way that I wanted to end my championship,\" Bolt said on Snapchat, according to NBC Sports. \"I left everything out there on the track. track with a left-leg injury as he was chasing a final gold medal for the Jamaican 4x100-meter relay team on Saturday at the world championships.\n\nHaving to make up lots of ground on the anchor leg, Bolt suddenly screamed, stumbled and somersaulted as he came down, his golden farewell shattered by the first injury he has experienced at a major competition.\n\nThat wasn't the only surprise. Britain went on to beat the United States in a tight finish.\n\nThe 60,000-capacity stadium was primed for one last Bolt show, one last \"To the World\" pose after a victory, but the injury made it blatantly clear why Bolt is ready to retire. His body can no longer hold up.\n\n\"He is still the best in the world,\" said Justin Gatlin, Bolt's American rival who ended up with 100-meter gold and relay silver.\n\nBolt's teammates on the once-fabled Jamaican sprint squad were far from unmatchable, too. Bolt just had too much to make up in the final 100 meters as both Britain and the United States were ahead and even Japan was even.\n\nAs Bolt fell to the ground, the leg with the golden shoe giving way, the crowd still went wild because the home team went on to win gold in 37.47 seconds, .05 seconds ahead of the United States.\n\n\"It's a cramp in his left hamstring, but a lot of the pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jamaican team doctor Kevin Jones said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nThe race will certainly be remembered for the gut-wrenching way in which the sport's greatest athlete ended his career.\n\nBefore Bolt came onto the track, he was consoling Mo Farah, his long-distance equivalent who had just lost his first major race since 2011 when he failed to get gold in the 5,000 meters.\n\nFarah also was bidding farewell to the track, coming up short of his fifth straight 5,000-10,000 double at major championships in a sprint against Muktar Edris of Ethiopia.\n\n\"I gave it all,\" Farah said. \"I didn't have a single bit left at the end.\"", "time": "03:01:00"}

"https://in.reuters.com/article/athletics-world-m100relay-bolt-idINKBN1AT03K", "body": "LONDON (Reuters) - Usain Bolt's unparalleled career ended in extraordinary drama on Saturday as he pulled up with injury on the anchor leg of his very last race, the 4x100 metres relay final at the World Championships.\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track.\n\nYet the sport's greatest entertainer was determined that one of the finest careers in sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair.\n\nSo the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried team mates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 metres to the line.\n\nThe official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the team mates he felt he had let down.\n\n\"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nMcLeod added: \"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nJustin Gatlin, the American winner of the individual 100 metres who had consigned Bolt to third place in his final individual race last Saturday, paid tribute to his rival.\n\n\"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury). I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\nKevin Jones, the Jamaican team doctor, said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring.\n\nBlake was angry at having to wait for two medal ceremonies to take place before the race.\n\n\"It was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run ... we were kept 40 minutes. It was crazy,\" Blake said. \"They were holding us too long.\n\n\"We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us.\n\n\"It hurts to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggle like that.\"\n\nJamaican team manager Ian Forbes praised Bolt for \"going out there and giving his all\" and added that the squad were \"very saddened\".\n\n\"The diagnostic work will be done shortly to determine how serious it is. He was able to walk to the team bus so hopefully that signals it's not as serious as it possibly could be,\" Forbes said.\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favourite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track.\n\nFive years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics.\n\nYet in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000 metres, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell.\n\nTheir leaving of the track scene leaves a void in the sport that does not look like being filled any time soon.", "time": "04:54:00"}

"http://registerguard.com/rg/sports/35856319-81/nothing-but-a-big-bolt-of-pain-in-the-end.html.csp", "body": "LONDON -- Usain Bolt was ramping into warp speed when suddenly, stunningly, the sprint turned into a somersault.\n\nFifteen steps into the final homestretch of his final race, something gave in his left hamstring. The World's Fastest Man skittered to a stop -- hopping, skipping, jumping, then finally dropping to the ground and tumbling forward before coming to a rest.\n\nWhile the winning team from Britain crossed the finish line, Bolt was writhing on the track, where he eventually wound up chest down with his face pressed into Lane 5. He was certainly every bit as stunned as any of the 60,000-plus who packed the stadium Saturday, or the millions watching one of the world's most entertaining showmen make his final curtain call in the 4x100-meter relay at the IAAF World Track & Field Championships.\n\nThere was no celebration. No gold, no silver, not even a consolation bronze, the likes of which Bolt received a week earlier in his final 100-meter race.\n\nJamaica closed the night with \"DNF\" by its name: Did Not Finish. Dead last. Bolt was helped into a wheelchair, but eventually got to his feet and, assisted by his teammates, limped gingerly across the finish line. He gave a few waves to the crowd, then left for the trainer's room, and with that, presumably left track and field forever.\n\n\"Injuries are part of our sport and, always, of course, it's sad to see,\" said Wallace Spearmon, the American sprinter who has been close with Bolt for years and was on hand helping the U.S. team. \"So, yeah, it's tragic.\"\n\nThe Jamaican team doctor, Kevin Jones, diagnosed the injury that brought a strange end to Bolt's career as, simply, a cramp in the champion's left hamstring.\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jones said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nWatching track's No. 1 sprinter and celebrity dropping to the ground was nothing short of jaw-dropping -- so much so that the fact that Britain won the race, outrunning a United States team that, somewhat amazingly, didn't drop the baton, almost seemed like an afterthought.\n\nNethaneel Mitchell-Blake held off U.S. anchorman Christian Coleman down the stretch and the Brits won their first-ever world title in the 4x100 in 37.47 seconds.\n\nWhen Bolt took the baton from Yohan Blake for his final homestretch, he was in third place, but that was no cause for concern. In virtually each of the seven relay golds he's won at the Olympics and world championships, Bolt has reeled in the competition down the stretch and won going away, much the same as all his 100 victories have played out.\n\nFive years and one day earlier, on the very same track, Bolt helped Jamaica set the world record. That run of 36.84 seconds earned Bolt the sixth of nine Olympic victories.\n\nBut last week in the 100, Bolt's extra gear was not enough either to catch Coleman, who finished second, or to hold off Justin Gatlin, the oft-booed American who came from behind to finish first.\n\nCould he have caught his relay competition in this one? Nobody will ever know. Bolt was gaining no ground at the 30-meter mark, which is when he felt the pain in his leg and went tumbling.\n\nAfterward, there was plenty of second-guessing to be done. Most of it came at the expense of the IAAF, which made the sprinters wait about 40 minutes from the time they were summoned from the warm-up room to the time the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I think this is crazy,\" Blake said. \"Forty minutes. Waiting. Warming up. Waiting. Warming up. It just should not happen. To have your champion go out like that. It's crazy.\"\n\nSaid Gatlin, who remains insistent that Bolt will be back someday: \"We lost all of our heat, all of our sweat, and we went out there cold.\"\n\nPart of the wait was for the U.S. women's relay team to finish its victory celebration. Tori Bowie anchored the win and, with one day left in the meet, is the only athlete to win two gold medals in London.\n\nAlso, a medal ceremony was held for Russian high jump champion Mariya Lasitskene, who is competing as a neutral athlete because of the doping crisis in her country and got to listen not to her own anthem, but to the IAAF's theme song, as she stood on the podium.\n\nOther winners included Kevin Mayer of France in the decathlon and Johannes Vetter, whose victory in the javelin throw gave Germany its first gold of the championships.", "time": "06:47:00"}

{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omar_McLeod", "label": {"eng": "Omar McLeod"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1333564"}], "url": "http://www.emirates247.com/sports/injury-floors-bolt-and-ruins-final-farewell-2017-08-13-1.657501", "body": "Usain Bolt's unparalleled career ended in extraordinary drama on Saturday as he pulled up with injury on the anchor leg of his very last race, the 4x100 metres relay final at the World Championships.\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track.\n\nYet the sport's greatest entertainer was determined that one of the finest careers in sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair.\n\nSo the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried team mates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 metres to the line.\n\nThe official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the team mates he felt he had let down.\n\n\"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nMcLeod added: \"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nTHIRD PLACE\n\nJustin Gatlin, the American winner of the individual 100 metres who had consigned Bolt to third place in his final individual race last Saturday, paid tribute to his rival.\n\n\"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury). I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\nKevin Jones, the Jamaican team doctor, said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring.\n\nBlake was angry at having to wait for two medal ceremonies to take place before the race.\n\n\"It was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run ... we were kept 40 minutes. It was crazy,\" Blake said. \"They were holding us too long.\n\n\"We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us.\n\n\"It hurts to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggle like that.\"\n\nJamaican team manager Ian Forbes praised Bolt for \"going out there and giving his all\" and added that the squad were \"very saddened\".\n\n\"The diagnostic work will be done shortly to determine how serious it is. He was able to walk to the team bus so hopefully that signals it's not as serious as it possibly could be,\" Forbes said.\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favourite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track.\n\nFive years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics.\n\nYet in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000 metres, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell.\n\nTheir leaving of the track scene leaves a void in the sport that does not look like being filled any time soon.", "time": "09:08:00"}

anchor man Bolt received the baton in third place behind eventual gold medallists Britain and runners-up America.\n\nA sentimental Justin Gatlin hailed Usain Bolt as an \"amazing showman\" whose career would certainly not be defined by him pulling up with cramp in the world 4x100m relay, the Jamaican's final competitive race.\n\nThere was high drama in Saturday's relay as anchor man Bolt received the baton in third place behind eventual gold medallists Britain and runners-up America.\n\nLess than 50 metres down the track, Bolt suddenly pulled up, clutching his left leg, tumbling to the track with what was later diagnosed as a hamstring cramp.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now,\" said Gatlin, who stormed to 100m gold in London, US teammate Christian Coleman taking silver to relegate Bolt to a disappointing bronze in his individual send-off.\n\n\"In the warm-up area we give ourselves respect and greet each other,\" Gatlin said of Bolt, who bows out of competition with a startling haul of eight Olympic gold medals and 14 world medals, nine of which are gold.\n\nGatlin, who has served two doping bans, put the blame for Bolt's cramp partly at the amount of time the athletes spent on the track before the starter's gun went off.\n\n\"There was a cool breeze out there. But the conditions were the same for everybody,\" said the 35-year-old, who won the 100m at the 2004 Olympics in Athens and the 2005 worlds in Helsinki before serving his second ban between 2006-10 for taking testosterone.\n\nChilly conditions unhelpful\n\n\"I think it was the elements. I am sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world.\n\n\"It was a recipe. I don't want to say this but I understand we need to be ready early but I think we took our clothes off a little too early. It's a little chilly in here so I think that's where the cramp came from. That's what he suffered with. He was running out there cold.\"\n\nBut Gatlin, who was roundly booed at the London Stadium before both the 100m and relay, insisted: \"Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\n\n\"You can't let this championships define what he's done in the past. He has done amazing things. He's still the man, you know. The was his farewell race and we wish him the best and hope he recovers soon.\"\n\nReferring to Bolt's mooted future ambassadorial role within athletics' world governing body the IAAF, Gatlin added: \"He's coming back in a couple of years. He'll be ready, he has a passion for the sport.\n\n\"He loves the fans and they love him. He loves the sport too much to walk away. He's a showman.\"\n\nJapan snatched a surprise bronze medal, Kenji Fujimitsu moved to comment: \"Thank you, Bolt. He was an inspiration for us.\"\n\nOmar McLeod, the newly-crowned 110m hurdler and Jamaica's lead-off runner in the relay, added: \"Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"", "time": "02:55:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anchor_leg", "label": {"eng": "Anchor leg"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "489170"}], "url": "http://saudigazette.com.sa/article/515001/Sports/Usain-Bolt", "body": "LONDON -- Usain Bolt set the stage for his grand farewell, powering down the finishing straight Saturday to qualify Jamaica for the 4x100-meter relay final at the world championships.\n\nFittingly, he will face Justin Gatlin and the US in the final chapter of his unparalleled career.\n\nBoth nations won their heats early Saturday, though the US relay squad got the baton around with more aplomb than Jamaica, which had to rely on Bolt to clinch victory.\n\nAnd Bolt relished the adulation at the 60,000-capacity Olympic Stadium.\n\n\"They've been outstanding so far, and continue to surprise me and give me energy,\" Bolt said.\n\nFor the best part of the past decade, though, Bolt has been 100 percent reliable in getting relay gold for the island nation. The last time Jamaica lost a world championship final was in Bolt's rookie year in 2007, when he ran the second leg and only took silver behind the Americans.\n\nEver since, Bolt has flaunted his power at the end of every major championship, getting the third gold medal for himself and sometimes another world record for Jamaica.\n\nThis year, however, he only got bronze in the 100 behind Gatlin. And the result in the relay is no longer a foregone conclusion.\n\nThe US, with Gatlin running the second leg, won the first heat in a world leading time of 37.70 seconds. The Americans beat Britain and Japan, both of which also qualified.\n\n\"My team did a great job,\" said Gatlin, the oldest of the squad at 35. \"They're thinking and acting like veterans and I'm proud of them.\"\n\nChristian Coleman took silver in the 100 ahead of Bolt and it gave the US team an added boost.\n\n\"Having the gold and silver medal on the same relay team, which hasn't been done in a long time, it gives us kind of a confidence booster that the speed can get around the track,\" Gatlin said.\n\nBolt stepped out on the track for the second heat, and the Jamaicans needed him. Trailing when he got the baton on the anchor leg, Bolt powered away, quickly swept past his rivals and had time to look to his right before crossing in 37.95 seconds.\n\nIn the women's heats, both nations are also through.\n\nAllyson Felix stayed in line to become the athlete with the most medals in world championships history when she helped the American relay team qualify.\n\nRunning the second leg, Felix and her teammates crossed first in a season's leading time of 41.84 seconds, beating Britain and Switzerland. They also advanced to the final.\n\nIn the second heat, Germany beat two-time defending champion Jamaica to qualify along with Brazil.\n\nThe Netherlands, with 200-meter champion Dafne Schippers running the second leg, qualified on time.\n\nFelix has won 14 medals at the world championships and can move up to 16 if she runs the 4x400 relay and the United States wins medals in both events.\n\nIn the decathlon, two-time world champion Trey Hardee of the United States hit the third hurdle and clattered into the next one during the 110-meter hurdles to end his medal chances.\n\nIn the first of five events on the final day of the two-day competition, Kevin Mayer of France set a third personal record to easily stay atop the standings with 5,485 points. Rico Freimuth of Germany was in second place with 5,377 points, while Damian Warner of Canada had the fastest time in the hurdles of 13.63 seconds to move into third. -- AP", "time": "03:38:00"}

"id": "527099"}], "url": "https://www.thenationalherald.com/171926/bolt-takes-tumble-cant-complete-final-race-worlds/", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- Usain Bolt was ramping into warp speed when suddenly, stunningly, the sprint turned into a somersault.\n\nFifteen steps into the final homestretch of his final race, something gave in his left hamstring. The World's Fastest Man skittered to a stop -- hopping, skipping, jumping, then finally dropping to the ground and tumbling forward before coming to a rest.\n\nWhile the winning team from Britain crossed the finish line, Bolt was writhing on the track, where he eventually wound up chest down with his face pressed into Lane 5. He was certainly every bit as stunned as any of the 60,000-plus who packed the stadium Saturday, or the millions watching one of the world's most entertaining showmen make his final curtain call in the 4\u00d7100-meter relay at world championships.\n\nThere was no celebration. No gold, no silver, not even a consolation bronze, the likes of which Bolt received a week earlier in his final 100-meter race.\n\nJamaica closed the night with \"DNF\" by its name: Did Not Finish. Dead last. Bolt was helped into a wheelchair, but eventually got to his feet and, assisted by his teammates, limped gingerly across the finish line. He gave a few waves to the crowd, then left for the trainer's room, and with that, presumably left track and field forever.\n\n\"Injuries are part of our sport and, always, of course, it's sad to see,\" said Wallace Spearmon, the American sprinter who has been close with Bolt for years and was on hand helping the U.S. team. \"So, yeah, it's tragic.\"\n\nThe Jamaican team doctor, Kevin Jones, diagnosed the injury that brought a strange end to Bolt's career as, simply, a cramp in the champion's left hamstring.\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jones said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nWatching track's No. 1 sprinter and celebrity dropping to the ground was nothing short of jaw-dropping -- so much so that the fact that Britain won the race, outrunning a United States team that, somewhat amazingly, didn't drop the baton, almost seemed like an afterthought.\n\nNethaneel Mitchell-Blake held off U.S. anchorman Christian Coleman down the stretch and the Brits won their first-ever world title in the 4\u00d7100 in 37.47 seconds.\n\nWhen Bolt took the baton from Yohan Blake for his final homestretch, he was in third place, but that was no cause for concern. In virtually each of the seven relay golds he's won at the Olympics and world championships, Bolt has reeled in the competition down the stretch and won going away, much the same as all his 100 victories have played out.\n\nFive years and one day earlier, on the very same track, Bolt helped Jamaica set the world record. That run of 36.84 seconds earned Bolt the sixth of nine Olympic victories.\n\nBut last week in the 100, Bolt's extra gear was not enough either to catch Coleman, who finished second, or to hold off Justin Gatlin, the oft-booed American who came from behind to finish first.\n\nCould he have caught his relay competition in this one? Nobody will ever know. Bolt was gaining no ground at the 30-meter mark, which is when he felt the pain in his leg and went tumbling.\n\nAfterward, there was plenty of second-guessing to be done. Most of it came at the expense of the IAAF, which made the sprinters wait about 40 minutes from the time they were summoned from the warm-up room to the time the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I think this is crazy,\" Blake said. \"Forty minutes. Waiting. Warming up. Waiting. Warming up. It just should not happen. To have your champion go out like that. It's crazy.\"\n\nSaid Gatlin, who remains insistent that Bolt will be back someday: \"We lost all of our heat, all of our sweat, and we went out there cold.\"\n\nPart of the wait was for the U.S. women's relay team to finish its victory celebration. Tori Bowie anchored the win and, with one day left in the meet, is the only athlete to win two gold medals in London. Also, a medal ceremony was held for Russian high jump champion Mariya Lasitskene, who is competing as a neutral athlete because of the doping crisis in her country and got to listen not to her own anthem, but to the IAAF's theme song, as she stood on the podium.\n\nOther winners included Kevin Mayer of France in the decathlon and Johannes Vetter, whose victory in the javelin throw gave Germany its first gold of the championships.\n\nIn the undercard to the relays, Muktar Edris held off Mo Farah of Britain in the 5,000. With help of his Ethiopian teammates, Edris won a tactical cat-and-mouse race and denied Farah his fifth straight long-distance double, counting world championships and Olympics.\n\nAs if to prove that point one last time, he did it again -- this time without even finishing the race.", "time": "08:37:00"}

"https://guardian.ng/sport/sad-farewell-for-injured-bolt-as-britain-win-4x100m-relay/", "body": "Usain Bolt's glittering career swansong came crashing to an end when he pulled up injured on the anchor leg of the world 4x100m relay won by Britain on Saturday.\n\nBolt received the baton with Jamaica in third, but halfway down the finishing straight the towering sprinter pulled up clutching his left thigh, eventually doing a forward somersault to the ground, to gasps from the 60,000 sell out London Stadium.\n\nThe British quartet of Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake claimed gold in 37.47 seconds, with the Justin Gatlin-led US four taking silver at 0.05sec and Japan a surprise bronze (38.04).\n\nBolt missed out on his bid to retain his 100m title earlier in the week, losing out to Gatlin and silver medallist Christian Coleman, who ran relay anchor for the Americans on Saturday.\n\nBut hopes were high for Bolt's final competitive race, with Jamaica also boasting newly-crowned 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake in their line-up.\n\nJamaica were afforded a rousing welcome from the crowd, a relaxed-looking Bolt applauding the stands, with pictures of him constantly shown on the stadium's big screens.\n\nGatlin, who has served two doping bans, and the US team also including another convicted doping cheat, Mike Rodgers, and Jaylen Bacon were booed when introduced although the jeering was less pronounced than for the individual 100m event.\n\nA close first three legs saw Britain, the United States and Jamaica, seeking a fifth consecutive world title, level-pegged for the final leg.\n\nHigh drama\n\nBut there was to be high drama as a visibly swearing Bolt pulled up in obvious pain, allowing the Japanese quartet to edge in for third.\n\nThe result means Bolt, 100 and 200m world record holder, finishes his career with 14 world career medals, one behind American Allyson Felix, to go with eight Olympic golds.\n\nAmid wild home celebrations, Bolt was attended to by medics, but refused a ride in a wheelchair off the track, instead finally getting up and limping alongside his teammates through to the finish line and then off into the bowels of the stadium for treatment.\n\nIt was a sad exit for an athlete who has lit up the track when the sport has been dragged through its worst-ever crisis, racked by doping and corruption scandals that went to the very heart of athletics' governing body.\n\nAnd what a gaping hole his absence will leave, no matter how brave a face the IAAF try to put on it.\n\nSince confirming his sprinting dominance with triple gold at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Bolt spent nine seasons amassing 19 global golds, 13 of which have come in individual events.\n\nAllied with a charismatic personality, it has guaranteed Bolt recognition as one of the world's most successful sportsmen. Last year alone he earned $34.2 million, according to Forbes.", "time": "07:12:00"}

"url": "http://www.thehindu.com/sport/athletics/iaaf-athletics-world-championships-injury-floors-bolt-ruins-final-farewell/article19484800.ece", "body": "Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track.\n\nUsain Bolt's unparalleled career ended in extraordinary drama on Saturday as he pulled up with injury on the anchor leg of his very last race, the 4x100 metres relay final at the World Championships.\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track.\n\nYet the sport's greatest entertainer was determined that one of the finest careers in sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair.\n\nSo the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried team mates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 metres to the line.\n\nThe official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the team mates he felt he had let down.\n\n\"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nMcLeod added: \"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nThird place\n\nJustin Gatlin, the American winner of the individual 100 metres who had consigned Bolt to third place in his final individual race last Saturday, paid tribute to his rival.\n\n\"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury). I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\nKevin Jones, the Jamaican team doctor, said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring.\n\nBlake was angry at having to wait for two medal ceremonies to take place before the race.\n\n\"It was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run ... we were kept 40 minutes. It was crazy,\" Blake said. \"They were holding us too long.\n\n\"We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us.\n\n\"It hurts to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggle like that.\"\n\nJamaican team manager Ian Forbes praised Bolt for \"going out there and giving his all\" and added that the squad were \"very saddened\".\n\n\"The diagnostic work will be done shortly to determine how serious it is. He was able to walk to the team bus so hopefully that signals it's not as serious as it possibly could be,\" Forbes said.\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favourite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track.\n\nFive years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics.\n\nYet in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000 metres, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell.\n\nTheir leaving of the track scene leaves a void in the sport that does not look like being filled any time soon. (Additional reporting by Greg Stutchbury; Editing by Ed Osmond/Peter Rutherford)", "time": "02:04:00"}

member Yohan Blake has blamed the delay in starting the race for Usain Bolt's injury that ended his glorious career in agony at the World Athletics Championships.\n\nBolt, running the final race of his career, suffered cramps on his left hamstring as he sought to chase down the British and American rivals in the last lap of the men's 4x100m relay race. He suddenly stumbled and hobbled a few strides before falling down on the track in pain and agony.\n\nBlake said the lengthy wait in cold conditions contributed to Bolt's injury. The final race of Saturday's evening session started later than initially planned, following medal ceremonies for the men's 5000m and women's high jump.\n\n\"They were holding us too long...it was atrocious. That long wait contributed (to Bolt's injury). Inside it was cold. We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us,\" Blake said.\n\n\"You have to think about the athletes because we were in the mixed zone too long, over 40 minutes. A hero of the sport to go down like that? As a true friend, I didn't like it one bit. He was saying he was sorry, but there was nothing to be sorry for, he's done it for us (during his career).\n\n\"It was cold and there was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run. It was crazy,\" added the 2011 world 100m champion Blake. Justin Gatlin, who snatched a gold in 100m dash to spoil Bolt's individual farewell race, suggested the same.\n\n\"I think it was the elements. I am sorry he (Bolt) got this injury. I understand the magic of TV and that everything has to happen for viewers at home but we were held a little long before we went out. We were out of our clothes and it was quite cold. I lost all my heat and sweat. I think if that hadn't happened, may be we would have run quicker, as would other teams,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"It was a recipe (for possible injury). I don't want to say this but I understand we need to be ready early but I think we took our clothes off a little too early. It's a little chilly in here so I think that's where the cramp came from. That's what he (Bolt) suffered with. He was running out there cold,\" added Gatlin who ran the second leg for silver- winning American team.\n\nBolt was his long-time rival and he lost five successive Olympic and World Championship races to him. Nonetheless, Gatlin paid tribute to the Jamaican.\n\n\"No one wants to see Usain go out like that, with an injury. All of us up here have been inspired by his career in some way. If we look past what happened at this championship, he has had an incredible career and that should be celebrated,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"He has done so much for athletics, from 2008 until now. Everything has happened so fast. Congratulations on his legendary career,\" he added.\n\nChristian Coleman, who ran the anchor leg for USA, said, \"Usain Bolt is a legend, he has inspired us. I was just blessed to be here, to be on the line with him. I will tell my grandkids about this one day.\"\n\nIn fact, he had beaten Bolt thrice in this championships - in 100m semi-finals, finals (where he took a silver) and the sprint relay.", "time": "13:42:00"}

"http://www.ndtv.com/world-news/usain-bolts-last-race-ends-in-disaster-as-he-limps-out-injured-1737009", "body": "London: Usain Bolt's glittering career swansong came crashing to an end when he pulled up injured on the anchor leg of the world 4x100m relay won by Britain on Saturday.\n\nBolt received the baton with Jamaica in third, but halfway down the finishing straight the towering sprinter pulled up clutching his left thigh, eventually doing a forward somersault to the ground, to gasps from the 60,000 sell out London Stadium.\n\nThe British quartet of Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake claimed gold in 37.47 seconds, with the Justin Gatlin-led US four taking silver at 0.05sec and Japan a surprise bronze (38.04).\n\nBolt missed out on his bid to retain his 100m title earlier in the week, losing out to Gatlin and silver medallist Christian Coleman, who ran relay anchor for the Americans on Saturday.\n\nBut hopes were high for Bolt's final competitive race, with Jamaica also boasting newly-crowned 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake in their line-up.\n\nJamaica were afforded a rousing welcome from the crowd, a relaxed-looking Bolt applauding the stands, with pictures of him constantly shown on the stadium's big screens.\n\nGatlin, who has served two doping bans, and the US team also including another convicted doping cheat, Mike Rodgers, and Jaylen Bacon were booed when introduced although the jeering was less pronounced than for the individual 100m event.\n\nA close first three legs saw Britain, the United States and Jamaica, seeking a fifth consecutive world title, level-pegged for the final leg.\n\nHigh drama\n\nBut there was to be high drama as a visibly swearing Bolt pulled up in obvious pain, allowing the Japanese quartet to edge in for third.\n\nThe result means Bolt, 100 and 200m world record holder, finishes his career with 14 world career medals, one behind American Allyson Felix, to go with eight Olympic golds.\n\nAmid wild home celebrations, Bolt was attended to by medics, but refused a ride in a wheelchair off the track, instead finally getting up and limping alongside his teammates through to the finish line and then off into the bowels of the stadium for treatment.\n\nIt was a sad exit for an athlete who has lit up the track when the sport has been dragged through its worst-ever crisis, racked by doping and corruption scandals that went to the very heart of athletics' governing body.\n\nAnd what a gaping hole his absence will leave, no matter how brave a face the IAAF try to put on it.\n\nSince confirming his sprinting dominance with triple gold at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Bolt spent nine seasons amassing 19 global golds, 13 of which have come in individual events.\n\nAllied with a charismatic personality, it has guaranteed Bolt recognition as one of the world's most successful sportsmen. Last year alone he earned $34.2 million, according to Forbes.\n\n(Except for the headline, this story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is published from a syndicated feed.)", "time": "19:36:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mite", "label": {"eng": "Mite"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "337099"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mo_Farah", "label": {"eng": "Mo Farah"}, "score": 1, "type": "person", "id": "338647"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yohan_Blake", "label": {"eng": "Yohan Blake"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "343533"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anchor_leg", "label": {"eng": "Anchor leg"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "489170"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omar_McLeod", "label": {"eng": "Omar McLeod"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1333564"}], "url": "http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/sports/athletics-injury-floors-bolt-and-ruins-final-farewell/articleshow/60041235.cms", "body": "LONDON, Aug 12 (Reuters) - Usain Bolt's unparalleled career ended in extraordinary drama on Saturday as he pulled up with injury on the anchor leg of his very last race, the 4x100 metres relay final at the World Championships.\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track.\n\nYet the sport's greatest entertainer was determined that one of the finest careers in sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair.\n\nSo the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried team mates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 metres to the line.\n\nThe official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the team mates he felt he had let down.\n\n\"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nMcLeod added: \"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nJustin Gatlin, the American winner of the individual 100 metres who had consigned Bolt to third place in his final individual race last Saturday, paid tribute to his rival.\n\n\"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury). I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\nKevin Jones, the Jamaican team doctor, said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring.\n\nBlake was angry at having to wait for two medal ceremonies to take place before the race.\n\n\"It was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run ... we were kept 40 minutes. It was crazy,\" Blake said. \"They were holding us too long.\n\n\"We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us.\n\n\"It hurts to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggle like that.\"\n\nJamaican team manager Ian Forbes praised Bolt for \"going out there and giving his all\" and added that the squad were \"very saddened\".\n\n\"The diagnostic work will be done shortly to determine how serious it is. He was able to walk to the team bus so hopefully that signals it's not as serious as it possibly could be,\" Forbes said.\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favourite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track.\n\nFive years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics.\n\nYet in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000 metres, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell.\n\nTheir leaving of the track scene leaves a void in the sport that does not look like being filled any time soon. (Additional reporting by Greg Stutchbury; Editing by Ed Osmond/Peter Rutherford)", "time": "02:55:00"}

4x100m relays final at the ongoing IAAF World Championships in London, Bolt was running third, a few meters behind the two leaders after taking the baton when he suddenly pulled up, hobbled and "url": "http://www.deccanherald.com/content/627869/blake-blames-delays-bolts-injury.html", "body": "Jamaican sprint relay team member Yohan Blake has blamed the delay in starting the race for Usain Bolt's injury that ended his glorious career in agony at the World Championships here.\n\nBolt, running the final race of his career, suffered cramps on his left hamstring as he sought to chase down the British and American rivals in the last lap of the men's 4x100m relay race. He suddenly stumbled and hobbled a few strides before falling down on the track in pain and agony.\n\nBlake said the lengthy wait in cold conditions contributed to Bolt's injury. The final race of Saturday's evening session started later than initially planned, following medal ceremonies for the men's 5000m and women's high jump.\n\n\"They were holding us too long...it was atrocious. That long wait contributed (to Bolt's injury). Inside it was cold. We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us,\" Blake said.\n\n\"You have to think about the athletes because we were in the mixed zone too long, over 40 minutes. A hero of the sport to go down like that? As a true friend, I didn't like it one bit. He was saying he was sorry, but there was nothing to be sorry for, he's done it for us (during his career).\n\n\"It was cold and there was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run. It was crazy,\" added the 2011 world 100m champion Blake.\n\nJustin Gatlin, who snatched a gold in 100m dash to spoil Bolt's individual farewell race, suggested the same.\n\n\"I think it was the elements. I am sorry he (Bolt) got this injury. I understand the magic of TV and that everything has to happen for viewers at home but we were held a little long before we went out. We were out of our clothes and it was quite cold. I lost all my heat and sweat. I think if that hadn't happened, may be we would have run quicker, as would other teams,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"It was a recipe (for possible injury). I don't want to say this but I understand we need to be ready early but I think we took our clothes off a little too early. It's a little chilly in here so I think that's where the cramp came from. That's what he (Bolt) suffered with. He was running out there cold,\" added Gatlin who ran the second leg for silver- winning American team.\n\nBolt was his long-time rival and he lost five successive Olympic and World Championship races to him. Nonetheless, Gatlin paid tribute to the Jamaican.\n\n\"No one wants to see Usain go out like that, with an injury. All of us up here have been inspired by his career in some way. If we look past what happened at this championship, he has had an incredible career and that should be celebrated,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"He has done so much for athletics, from 2008 until now. Everything has happened so fast. Congratulations on his legendary career,\" he added.\n\nChristian Coleman, who ran the anchor leg for USA, said, \"Usain Bolt is a legend, he has inspired us. I was just blessed to be here, to be on the line with him. I will tell my grandkids about this one day.\"\n\nIn fact, he had beaten Bolt thrice in this championships -- in 100m semifinals, finals (where he took a silver) and the sprint relay.", "time": "10:34:00"}
