"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sport_of_athletics", "label": {"eng": "Sport of athletics"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1053871"}], "url": "http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/sports/gatlin-hails-bolt-the_107637?profile=1511", "body": "LONDON, United Kingdom (AFP) -- A sentimental Justin Gatlin hailed Usain Bolt as an \"amazing showman\" whose career would certainly not be defined by him pulling up with a cramp in the world 4x100m relay, the Jamaican's final competitive race.\n\nThere was high drama in yesterday's relay as anchor -man Bolt received the baton in third place behind eventual gold medallists Britain and runners-up America.\n\nLess than 50 metres down the track, Bolt suddenly pulled up, clutching his left leg, tumbling to the track with what was later diagnosed as a hamstring cramp.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now,\" said Gatlin, who stormed to 100m gold in London, US teammate Christian Coleman taking silver, to relegate Bolt to a disappointing bronze in his individual send-off.\n\n\"In the warm-up area we give ourselves respect and greet each other,\" Gatlin said of Bolt, who bows out of competition with a startling haul of eight Olympic gold medals and 14 world medals, nine of which are gold.\n\nGatlin, who has served two doping bans, put the blame for Bolt's cramp partly at the amount of time the athletes spent on the track before the starter's gun went off.\n\n\"There was a cool breeze out there, but the conditions were the same for everybody,\" said the 35-year-old, who won the 100m at the 2004 Olympics in Athens and the 2005 worlds in Helsinki before serving his second ban between 2006-10 for taking testosterone.\n\n\"I think it was the elements. I am sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world.\n\n\"It was a recipe. I don't want to say this, but I understand we need to be ready early. but I think we took our clothes off a little too early. It's a little chilly in here so I think that's where the cramp came from. That's what he suffered with. He was running out there cold.\"\n\nBut Gatlin, who was roundly booed at the London Stadium before both the 100m and relay, insisted: \"Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\n\n\"You can't let this championships define what he's done in the past. He has done amazing things. He's still the man, you know. This was his farewell race and we wish him the best and hope he recovers soon.\"\n\nReferring to Bolt's mooted future ambassadorial role within athletics' world governing body the IAAF, Gatlin added: \"He's coming back in a couple of years. He'll be ready; he has a passion for the sport.\n\n\"He loves the fans and they love him. He loves the sport too much to walk away. He's a showman.\"\n\nJapan snatched a surprise bronze medal, and Kenji Fujimitsu moved to comment: \"Thank you, Bolt. He was an inspiration for us.\"\n\nOmar McLeod, the newly crowned 110m hurdler and Jamaica's lead-off runner in the relay, added: \"Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"", "time": "03:24:00"}

{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omar_McLeod", "label": {"eng": "Omar McLeod"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1333564"}], "url": "http://www.thestar.com.my/sport/athletics/2017/08/13/bolt-pulls-up-injured-in-final-race-of-his-career/", "body": "LONDON (Reuters) - Usain Bolt's unparalleled career ended in extraordinary drama on Saturday as he pulled up with injury on the anchor leg of his very last race, the 4x100 metres relay final at the World Championships.\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track.\n\nYet the sport's greatest entertainer was determined that one of the finest careers in sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair.\n\nSo the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried team mates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 metres to the line.\n\nThe official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the team mates he felt he had let down.\n\n\"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nMcLeod added: \"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nTHIRD PLACE\n\nJustin Gatlin, the American winner of the individual 100 metres who had consigned Bolt to third place in his final individual race last Saturday, paid tribute to his rival.\n\n\"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury). I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\nKevin Jones, the Jamaican team doctor, said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring.\n\nBlake was angry at having to wait for two medal ceremonies to take place before the race.\n\n\"It was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run ... we were kept 40 minutes. It was crazy,\" Blake said. \"They were holding us too long.\n\n\"We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us.\n\n\"It hurts to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggle like that.\"\n\nJamaican team manager Ian Forbes praised Bolt for \"going out there and giving his all\" and added that the squad were \"very saddened\".\n\n\"The diagnostic work will be done shortly to determine how serious it is. He was able to walk to the team bus so hopefully that signals it's not as serious as it possibly could be,\" Forbes said.\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favourite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track.\n\nFive years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics.\n\nYet in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000 metres, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell.\n\nTheir leaving of the track scene leaves a void in the sport that does not look like being filled any time soon.\n\n(Additional reporting by Greg Stutchbury; Editing by Ed Osmond/Peter Rutherford)", "time": "07:52:00"}

"Omar McLeod"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1333564"}], "url": "https://www.geo.tv/latest/153445-athletics-injury-floors-bolt-and-ruins-final-farewell", "body": "LONDON: Usain Bolt's unparalleled career ended in extraordinary drama on Saturday as he pulled up with injury on the anchor leg of his very last race, the 4x100 metres relay final at the World Championships.\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with a cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling, and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track.\n\nYet the sport's greatest entertainer was determined that one of the finest careers in the sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair.\n\nSo the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried team mates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte, and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 metres to the line.\n\nThe official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the team mates he felt he had let down.\n\n\"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nMcLeod added: \"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nJustin Gatlin, the American winner of the individual 100 metres who had consigned Bolt to third place in his final individual race last Saturday, paid tribute to his rival.\n\n\"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury). I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\nKevin Jones, the Jamaican team doctor, said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring.\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" he said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nJamaican team manager Ian Forbes praised Bolt for \"going out there and giving his all\" and added that the squad were \"very saddened\".\n\n\"The diagnostic work will be done shortly to determine how serious it is. He was able to walk to the team bus so hopefully that signals it's not as serious as it possibly could be,\" Forbes said.\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favourite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track.\n\nFive years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics.\n\nYet in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000 metres, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell.\n\nTheir leaving the track scene leaves a void in the sport that does not look like being filled anytime soon.", "time": "23:36:00"}

member Yohan Blake has blamed the delay in starting the race for Usain Bolt's injury that ended his glorious career in agony at the World Championships here.\n\nBolt, running the final race of his career, suffered cramps on his left hamstring as he sought to chase down the British and American rivals in the last lap of the men's 4x100m relay race. He suddenly stumbled and hobbled a few strides before falling down on the track in pain and agony.\n\nBlake said the lengthy wait in cold conditions contributed to Bolt's injury. The final race of Saturday s evening session started later than initially planned, following medal ceremonies for the men's 5000m and women's high jump.\n\n\"They were holding us too long...it was atrocious. That long wait contributed (to Bolt's injury). Inside it was cold.\n\nWe keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us,\" Blake said.\n\n\"You have to think about the athletes because we were in the mixed zone too long, over 40 minutes. A hero of the sport to go down like that? As a true friend, I didn't like it one bit. He was saying he was sorry, but there was nothing to be sorry for, he's done it for us (during his career).\n\n\"It was cold and there was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run. It was crazy,\" added the 2011 world 100m champion Blake.\n\nJustin Gatlin, who snatched a gold in 100m dash to spoil Bolt's individual farewell race, suggested the same.\n\n\"I think it was the elements. I am sorry he (Bolt) got this injury. I understand the magic of TV and that everything has to happen for viewers at home but we were held a little long before we went out. We were out of our clothes and it was quite cold. I lost all my heat and sweat. I think if that hadn't happened, may be we would have run quicker, as would other teams,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"It was a recipe (for possible injury). I don't want to say this but I understand we need to be ready early but I think we took our clothes off a little too early. It's a little chilly in here so I think that's where the cramp came from. That's what he (Bolt) suffered with. He was running out there cold,\" added Gatlin who ran the second leg for silver- winning American team.\n\nBolt was his long-time rival and he lost five successive Olympic and World Championship races to him. Nonetheless, Gatlin paid tribute to the Jamaican.\n\n\"No one wants to see Usain go out like that, with an injury. All of us up here have been inspired by his career in some way. If we look past what happened at this championship, he has had an incredible career and that should be celebrated,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"He has done so much for athletics, from 2008 until now.\n\nEverything has happened so fast. Congratulations on his legendary career,\" he added.\n\nChristian Coleman, who ran the anchor leg for USA, said, \"Usain Bolt is a legend, he has inspired us. I was just blessed to be here, to be on the line with him. I will tell my grandkids about this one day.\"\n\nIn fact, he had beaten Bolt thrice in this championships -- in 100m semifinals, finals (where he took a silver) and the sprint relay.\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency feed.)", "time": "10:14:00"}

I lost all my sweat and body heat,\" Gatlin said.\n\nWhen asked if he thought that contributed to Bolt's injury, the 35-year-old said: \"I believe so.\n\n\"Knowing how Usain performs, he's always ready, he's always making sure he's not injured and it's very rare to see Usain injured when he comes to performances.\"\n\nGatlin ran the second leg for the United States as they finished runners-up behind Britain, who became world champions for the first time.\n\nAmidst the home crowd's jubilation, there was also relief at the sight of Bolt being able to walk off the track after being helped to his feet by his team mates.\n\n\"I'm not sure what the extent of his injury is, but when I saw him go down I thought it was a calf cramp or a hamstring cramp. "body": "Usain Bolt bows out from athletics tonight as he takes to the track for one final race: the men's 4x100m relay at the London 2017 World Championships.\n\nThe Jamaican started the final countdown to his retirement by guiding his team through to Saturday's final earlier this morning.\n\nJamaica finished in 37.95 seconds - slower than Great Britain and the USA from the first heat - but will be expected to challenge for the podium in the final.\n\nHere's everything you need to know:\n\nWhat time does it start?\n\nThe men's 4x100m final is due to start at 9.50pm.\n\nWhere can I watch it?\n\nThe race will be broadcast on BBC One. Coverage starts at 6.30pm.\n\nWhat's the latest? Read more Usain Bolt's defeat is a reminder that the best man doesn't always win\n\nWell, unless you've spent the last week under a rock, you'll know that Bolt is eyeing one final gold medal in his illustrious career before he steps down from the sport.\n\nLast weekend's 100m final threw up something of a surprise after Justin Gatlin claimed a shock gold - much to the disapproval of the London Stadium audience - while Bolt was forced to settle for bronze.\n\nNonetheless, the 30-year-old now has the chance to make amends for such a result and end on a glorious golden high with his Jamaican team-mates in tonight's 4x100m relay final.\n\nSaturday's 4X100m semi-final fastest qualifiers: USA: 37.70 secs GB: 37.76 secs Jamaica: 37.95 secs USA qualified fastest for Saturday's final (Getty) Who's in Jamaica's relay team?\n\nTyquendo Tracey, Julian Forte, Michael Campbell and Usain Bolt make up the quartet, with the eight-time Olympian running the anchor leg.\n\nWho's in Britain's relay team?\n\nDanny Talbot, Adam Gemili, Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake and CJ Ujah.\n\nWho's in USA's relay team?\n\nBeeJay Lee, Christian Coleman, Justin Gatlin and Mike Rodgers.\n\nWhat's been said?\n\n\"For me it's hard to be sad because of the energy I am getting from the crowd, I just feel happy and blessed,\" Bolt said after Saturday's semi-final.\n\n\"It's been brilliant, the energy in the stadium is outstanding. I knew it was going to be like this, I appreciate you guys coming out and supporting not just me but the whole World Championships.\"\n\nBolt praised the London crowd after Saturday's semi-finals (Getty)\n\nOdds\n\nUSA to win: 8/11\n\nJamaica to win: 5/4\n\nGreat Britain & NI: 10/1\n\nMore about: Usain Bolt World Athletics Championships Reuse content", "time": "12:38:00"}

"http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/more-sports/athletics/yohan-blake-blames-delays-for-usain-bolts-injury/articleshow/60045047.cms", "body": "LONDON: Jamaican sprint relay team member Yohan Blake has blamed the delay in starting the race for Usain Bolt's injury that ended his glorious career in agony at the World Athletics Championships.\n\nBolt, running the final race of his career, suffered cramps on his left hamstring as he sought to chase down the British and American rivals in the last lap of the men's 4x100m relay race. He suddenly stumbled and hobbled a few strides before falling down on the track in pain and agony.\n\nBlake said the lengthy wait in cold conditions contributed to Bolt's injury. The final race of Saturday's evening session started later than initially planned, following medal ceremonies for the men's 5000m and women's high jump.\n\n\"They were holding us too long...it was atrocious. That long wait contributed (to Bolt's injury). Inside it was cold. We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us,\" Blake said.\n\n\"You have to think about the athletes because we were in the mixed zone too long, over 40 minutes. A hero of the sport to go down like that? As a true friend, I didn't like it one bit. He was saying he was sorry, but there was nothing to be sorry for, he's done it for us (during his career).\n\n\"It was cold and there was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run. It was crazy,\" added the 2011 world 100m champion Blake.\n\nJustin Gatlin, who snatched a gold in 100m dash to spoil Bolt's individual farewell race, suggested the same.\n\n\"I think it was the elements. I am sorry he (Bolt) got this injury. I understand the magic of TV and that everything has to happen for viewers at home but we were held a little long before we went out. We were out of our clothes and it was quite cold. I lost all my heat and sweat. I think if that hadn't happened, may be we would have run quicker, as would other teams,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"It was a recipe (for possible injury). I don't want to say this but I understand we need to be ready early but I think we took our clothes off a little too early. It's a little chilly in here so I think that's where the cramp came from. That's what he (Bolt) suffered with. He was running out there cold,\" added Gatlin who ran the second leg for silver- winning American team.\n\nBolt was his long-time rival and he lost five successive Olympic and World Championship races to him. Nonetheless, Gatlin paid tribute to the Jamaican.\n\n\"No one wants to see Usain go out like that, with an injury. All of us up here have been inspired by his career in some way. If we look past what happened at this championship, he has had an incredible career and that should be celebrated,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"He has done so much for athletics, from 2008 until now. Everything has happened so fast. Congratulations on his legendary career,\" he added.\n\nChristian Coleman, who ran the anchor leg for USA, said, \"Usain Bolt is a legend, he has inspired us. I was just blessed to be here, to be on the line with him. I will tell my grandkids about this one day.\"\n\nIn fact, he had beaten Bolt thrice in this championships - in 100m semi-finals, finals (where he took a silver) and the sprint relay.\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.", "time": "08:34:00"}

"url": "http://www.msn.com/en-in/sports/sport-index/injury-floors-bolt-and-ruins-final-farewell/ar-AApWFlc?srcref=rss", "body": "Usain Bolt's unparalleled career ended in extraordinary drama on Saturday as he pulled up with injury on the anchor leg of his very last race, the 4x100 meters relay final at the World Championships. The 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few meters adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track. Yet the sport's greatest entertainer was determined that one of the finest careers in sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair. So the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried team mates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 meters to the line.\n\nThe official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the team mates he felt he had let down. \"He kept apologizing to us but we told him there was no need to apologize,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nMcLeod added: \"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nTHIRD PLACE\n\nJustin Gatlin, the American winner of the individual 100 meters who had consigned Bolt to third place in his final individual race last Saturday, paid tribute to his rival. \"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury). I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said. \"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\nKevin Jones, the Jamaican team doctor, said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring.\n\nBlake was angry at having to wait for two medal ceremonies to take place before the race.\n\n\"It was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run ... we were kept 40 minutes. It was crazy,\" Blake said. \"They were holding us too long.\n\n\"We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us.\n\n\"It hurts to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggle like that.\"\n\nJamaican team manager Ian Forbes praised Bolt for \"going out there and giving his all\" and added that the squad were \"very saddened.\" \"The diagnostic work will be done shortly to determine how serious it is. He was able to walk to the team bus so hopefully that signals it's not as serious as it possibly could be,\" Forbes said.\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favorite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track. Five years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics.\n\nYet in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000 meters, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell.\n\nTheir leaving of the track scene leaves a void in the sport that does not look like being filled any time soon.", "time": "08:30:00"}

"https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/08/12/usain-bolts-illustrious-career-ends-in-tears-after-injury-downs-him-in-final-race/", "body": "This is only the fourth time in 24 championship races that Usain Bolt has not topped the podium. (Tim Ireland/AP)\n\nIt was a heartbreaking ending to an outstanding track and field career for Usain Bolt on Saturday at the IAAF World Championships in London.\n\nSlated to run the final leg of the men's 4\u00d7100 relay for Jamaica, Bolt failed to finish after an injury led him to pull up just after teammate Yohan Blake handed him the baton.\n\nBolt collapsed on the track, as the British, American and Japanese teams soared ahead to secure their first, second and third podium spots, respectively. This is the first time since 2008 that a team other than Jamaica has won the event at a major meet.\n\nIt's unclear what exactly happened to Bolt. He managed to get up with the help of his teammates Blake, Omar McLeod and Julian Forte to eventually limp across the finish line and offer the crowd a tearful wave. Bolt also appeared to apologize to his teammates, who looked on with understanding.\n\nYohan Blake, left, and Omar McLeod console Bolt on the track. (Jewel Samad/AFP/Getty Images)\n\nBolt, 31, had run the qualifying legs for Team Jamaica without incident earlier in the day. This may have taken a toll on his muscles by the time the final rolled around at nearly 10 p.m. local time.\n\nHaving run 23 championship races since 2008, this was only the fourth time Bolt failed to win, the first time due to injury. Previously, he didn't win because of a false start, a disqualification after the fact due to a teammate's failed doping test, and last Saturday, because of an uncharacteristic performance -- Bolt came in third in the 100-meter final.\n\n[Not fake news: Usain Bolt loses back-to-back races]\n\nMeanwhile, the top of the podium has continued to evade Team USA, which finished second to Great Britain on Saturday with a time of 37.52 seconds, just five-hundredths of a second behind the leaders.\n\nBolt's longtime rival Justin Gatlin, who won the 100-meter final last Saturday, ran the second leg, but did not appear happy with the result. Before the start of the race, he called past U.S. foibles in the event \"frustrating\" and \"embarrassing.\"\n\n\"It gets to the point where it kind of fuels you,\" he said. \"You don't want to let down your country anymore.\"\n\nWhile Gatlin and the other Team USA sprinters, including Mike Rodgers, Jaylen Bacon and 100-meter silver medalist Christian Coleman, appeared disappointed with second place, it sure beats last summer's Olympic performance that saw Team USA disqualified for mishandling the baton.\n\nThe U.S. women, meanwhile, had better luck. The team of Aaliya Brown, Allyson Felix, Morolake Akinosun and Tori Bowie won gold with a time of 41.82 seconds. Great Britain came in second with a time of 42.12 seconds and Jamaica pulled in third, seven-hundredths of a second later.\n\nRead more:\n\nUsain Bolt blames starting blocks for 'very bad' first-round sprint at worlds\n\nAfter qualifying in rarely seen solo heat, Isaac Makwala fails to medal at worlds\n\nA meme is born: Norwegian sprinter has amazing reaction to win at worlds, sports viking helmet\n\nNBC Sports criticized for interviewing hurdler as she's doubled over trying to catch her breath\n\nNorovirus outbreak hits hotel housing track athletes at world championships in London", "time": "22:07:00"}

"http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/more-sports/athletics/injury-floors-bolt-and-ruins-final-farewell/articleshow/60040690.cms", "body": "LONDON: Usain Bolt's unparalleled career ended in extraordinary drama on Saturday as he pulled up with injury on the anchor leg of his very last race, the 4x100 metres relay final at the World Championships.\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track.\n\nYet the sport's greatest entertainer was determined that one of the finest careers in sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair.\n\nSo the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried team mates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 metres to the line.\n\nThe official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the team mates he felt he had let down.\n\n\"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nMcLeod added: \"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nTHIRD PLACE\n\nJustin Gatlin, the American winner of the individual 100 metres who had consigned Bolt to third place in his final individual race last Saturday, paid tribute to his rival.\n\n\"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury). I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\nKevin Jones, the Jamaican team doctor, said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring.\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" he said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nJamaican team manager Ian Forbes praised Bolt for \"going out there and giving his all\" and added that the squad were \"very saddened\".\n\n\"The diagnostic work will be done shortly to determine how serious it is. He was able to walk to the team bus so hopefully that signals it's not as serious as it possibly could be,\" Forbes said.\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favourite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track.\n\nFive years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics.\n\nYet in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000 metres, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell.\n\nTheir leaving of the track scene leaves a void in the sport that does not look like being filled any time soon.\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.", "time": "23:25:00"}

"http://www.dnaindia.com/sports/report-bolt-wins-relay-heats-in-his-penultimate-race-2527944", "body": "Usain Bolt began the countdown to his final race by anchoring Jamaica to the 4x100m relay finals with an easy win in the heats here today.\n\nRunning in his penultimate race of his illustrious career, Bolt eased past the finishing line as he helped the defending champions Jamaica win the second heat in 37.95 seconds, their season's best, to enter the final round with third best time.\n\nThe Jamaican quartet of Tyquendo Tracey, Julian Forte, Micheal Campbell and Bolt led the eight-team second heat from beginning to the end.\n\nExperienced Yohan Blake, who finished fourth in the men's 100m final and failed to qualify for the final round in 200m, did not start in the heats but Bolt later said that he will return in the final race.\n\nIn his trademark style, Bolt grabbed the baton from Campbell, who ran the third leg, and blasted ahead of all his rivals and slowed down while approaching the finish line to conserve energy for the finals.\n\nThe top three from each of the two heats and next two fastest finishers from the remaining qualify for the final round.\n\nThe United States team of Mike Rodgers, Justin Gatlin, Bee Jay Lee and Christian Coleman won the first heat in 37.70 seconds, the world leading time this season, to clock the overall best time going into the final round.\n\nGreat Britain clocked the second best time of 37.76, while France were fourth with their season's best of 38.03.\n\nChina (38.20), who had finished second in the 2015 edition at home, Japan (37.21), who took a surprise silver in the Rio Olympics, Turkey (38.44) and Canada (38.48) -- third in both 2015 World Championships and Rio Olympics -- completed the eight-team final round which will run later tonight.\n\nBolt, who has anchored the gold-winning Jamaican team in both 2015 World Championships and Rio Games, will be seeking his 20th global title and would want to hang up his boots with a yellow metal in his final race of his glittering career.\n\nHe lost the 100m dash last Saturday in his final individual race, settling for a bronze.\n\nHis long-time American rival Gatlin, who has twice served bans for doping, won the gold while Coleman took the silver as the London Olympic stadium and the global television audience were stunned at the turn of events.\n\nWidely considered as the greatest sprinter of all time, Bolt has won eight Olympic and 11 World Championships gold medals beginning with a 100m and 200m double at the 2008 Beijing Olympics.\n\nSince then he has dominated the shorter two sprint events like none in athletics history. His Jamaican team had also won the 4x100m relay gold in Beijing but it had to return the medal after one member of the quartet -- Nesta Carter -- tested positive for a prohibited substance.\n\nOn the last day of his international career, fans jostled for space to have a glimpse of Bolt at the warm-up arena, adjacent to the stadium and television cameras were fixed at him to have a shot of the towering Jamaican.\n\nWhenever the giant screen inside the stadium showed him doing the baton exchange practice with his Jamaican team-mates in preparation for the 4x100m relay race at the warm-up arena, the capacity crowd cheered loudly.\n\nThe showman, as usual, entertained the crowd as he acknowledged the cheers as he entered the stadium for the relay heats. He did his routine marking of his starting position and did a few run-downs imitating baton exchange.\n\nAfter easing past the finish line, Bolt ran down the track as he usually does and clapped towards the crowd.\n\n\"There are no words to describe how I am feeling. I get so much support from the crowd. I appreciate that a lot. All the energy I am getting from the crowd. It is brilliant,\" Bolt said after the race.\n\n\"The young runners in our team -- it is just about executing and coming through the race for them. We have been training that relay, there were some camps. Still there were some mistakes. Yohan Blake is coming in for the final is definitely good.\"\n\nIn the women's 4x100m relay, all the medal contenders -- United States, Great Britain, Germany and defending champions Jamaica -- progressed to the final round without much trouble, while the Bahamas quartet failed to finish in the second heat due to a poor second baton change.\n\nOlympic champions United States won the first heat in a world leading time of 41.84 seconds, even in the absence of individual 100m champion Torie Bowie.\n\nGreat Britain finished second in that heat -- and also second overall -- with 41.93, the third fastest time ever produced by a British quartet.\n\nDefending champions Jamaica (42.50) finished second behind Germany (42.34) in the second heat.\n\nSwitzerland (42.50) qualified with the fourth fastest time overall while Netherlands (42.64), Brazil (42.77) and Trinidad and Tobago (42.91) completed the final round line-up.\n\nAmerican runner Allyson Felix later said that Bowie will return in the final round.\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency feed.)", "time": "13:34:00"}

finishes his career with 14 world medals to go with eight Olympic golds.\n\nUsain Bolt's glittering career swansong came crashing to an end when he pulled up on the anchor leg of the world 4x100m relay won by Britain on Saturday.\n\nBolt received the baton with Jamaica in third, but halfway down his leg the towering sprinter pulled up clutching his left thigh, eventually doing a forward roll to the ground, to gasps from the 60,000 sell out London Stadium.\n\nThe British quartet of Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake claimed gold in 37.47 seconds, with the Justin Gatlin-led US four taking silver at 0.05sec and Japan a surprise bronze (38.04).\n\nBolt missed out on his bid to retain his 100m title earlier in the week, losing out to Gatlin and silver medallist Christian Coleman, who ran relay anchor for the Americans on Saturday.\n\nBut hopes were high for Bolt's final competitive race, with Jamaica also boasting newly-crowned 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake in their line-up.\n\nJamaica were afforded a rousing welcome from the crowd, Bolt applauding the stands, with pictures of him constantly shown on the stadium's big screens.\n\nGatlin and the US team also including another convicted doping cheat, Mike Rodgers, and Jaylen Bacon were booed when introduced although the jeering was less than for the individual 100m event.\n\nA close first three legs saw Britain, the United States and Jamaica level-pegged for the final leg.\n\nBut there was to be drama as a visibly swearing Bolt pulled up, allowing the Japanese quartet to nip in for third.\n\nThe result means Bolt, 100 and 200m world record holder, finishes his career with 14 world medals to go with eight Olympic golds.", "time": "http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/sports/injury-floors-usain-bolt-ruins-final-farewell-in-world-athletics-championship/article9816157.ece", "body": "The fastest man rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 metres to the line.\n\nUsain Bolt's unparalleled career ended in extraordinary drama on Saturday as he pulled up with injury on the anchor leg of his very last race, the 4x100 metres relay final at the World Championships.\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track. Yet the sport's greatest entertainer was determined that one of the finest careers in sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair.\n\nSo the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried team mates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 metres to the line.\n\nThe official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the team mates he felt he had let down. \"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nMcLeod added, \"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nThird place\n\nJustin Gatlin, the American winner of the individual 100 metres who had consigned Bolt to third place in his final individual race last Saturday, paid tribute to his rival. \"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury). I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said. \"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\nKevin Jones, the Jamaican team doctor, said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring. Blake was angry at having to wait for two medal ceremonies to take place before the race. \"It was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run ... we were kept 40 minutes. It was crazy,\" Blake said. \"They were holding us too long.\n\n\"We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us. It hurts to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggle like that.\"\n\nJamaican team manager Ian Forbes praised Bolt for \"going out there and giving his all\" and added that the squad were \"very saddened\".\n\n\"The diagnostic work will be done shortly to determine how serious it is. He was able to walk to the team bus so hopefully that signals it's not as serious as it possibly could be,\" Forbes said.\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favourite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track.\n\nFive years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics.\n\nYet in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000 metres, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell.\n\nTheir leaving of the track scene leaves a void in the sport that does not look like being filled any time soon.", "time": "05:44:00"}

for the more unheralded members of the squad.\n\nTyquendo Tracey, Julian Forte and Michael Campbell safely negotiated the first three legs before Bolt steered his team home in a winning, season's best of 37.95 seconds.\n\n\"It's been brilliant. The energy in the stadium is outstanding,\" Bolt said, hailing the deafening support in the packed-out London Stadium \"not just for me but the whole championships\".\n\nBolt said his emotions were still in check at the thought of bowing out of track and field.\n\n\"For me it's hard to be sad because the energy I'm getting from the crowd is brilliant, I'm just happy.\"\n\nBolt's bid to retain his 100m title went up in smoke as American Justin Gatlin won gold, with Christian Coleman taking silver.\n\nIt was the first time Bolt had been beaten at a major championships since the 4x100m relay at the 2007 worlds in Osaka.\n\nThe 100 and 200m world record holder, who also anchored the Jamaican squad to a world record in the relay of 36.84sec at the 2012 London Olympics, will be back at the track for the final at 2050 GMT.\n\nBolt has amassed eight Olympic golds and 14 world medals, 11 of which are gold, the Jamaican having won two silvers in 2007 before his 100m bronze in London.\n\nNo matter the result of the relay, organisers said Bolt will be afforded a dedicated lap of honour on Sunday in tribute to his amazing track career.\n\nGatlin ran the second leg for the US team, led off by Mike Rodgers, another dope cheat, BeeJay Lee and Coleman on anchor.\n\nThey clocked 37.70 seconds to finish 0.06sec ahead of Britain.\n\nAlso qualifying for the final were France, China, Japan, Turkey and Canada.", "time": "11:16:00"}

Bolt ended in dramatic fashion on Saturday as the sprint icon pulled up with an injury in his final race, the men's 4x100m final at the World Championships in London.\n\nBolt sensationally failed to finish the anchor leg for Jamaica, an apparent hamstring injury ending his hopes of bowing out with a 12th World Championships gold medal. Great Britain instead took gold ahead of the United States and Japan.\n\nThere had been disappointment for Bolt in London last weekend when he had to settle for a bronze medal behind Justin Gatlin and Christian Coleman in the 100m, his last individual race.\n\nHowever, Bolt nevertheless ends his career as an undoubted great - having transcended his sport and made history on numerous occasions.\n\nYou can't write a script for sport.\n\nGet well soon, @usainbolt. Thank you for being the .#IAAFworldspic.twitter.com/52c0g79v0w -- SPIKES (@spikesmag)\n\nAugust 12, 2017\n\nFollowing his last outing, we take a look at the numbers that highlight his stunning success.\n\n9.58 - Bolt's blistering 100 metre world-record time, set in the 2009 World Championships final.\n\n22 - How many years Michael Johnson held the men's 200m record of 19.32 seconds, before Bolt broke it in 2008 in Beijing - a benchmark he has since lowered to 19.19secs.\n\n19 - Major gold medals Bolt has won in his career, having had his 4x100m relay title from the 2008 Olympics revoked due to Nesta Carter's doping violation.\n\n27.79 - Bolt's top speed in miles-per-hour, between the 60m and 80m marks, as he set his world-record 100m time in 2009.\n\n36.84 - The world-record time he and his Jamaica team-mates clocked in the 2012 4x100m relay Olympic final.\n\n7 - The number of times Bolt has set a world-record time across his specialist events.\n\n6 - Bolt's record tally of IAAF World Athlete of the Year awards.\n\n34.2million - Bolt's estimated yearly earnings, in dollars, by Forbes, who calculate him to be the 88th best-paid celebrity in the world - in between Real Madrid footballer Gareth Bale and NBA star Derrick Rose.", "time": "20:36:00"}

"http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/sports/2017/08/13/gatlin-hails-bolt-showman-despite-relay-flop/", "body": "Shares\n\nUS athlete Justin Gatlin smiles before his heat of the men's 4x100m relay athletics event at the 2017 IAAF World Championships at the London Stadium in London on August 12, 2017 \u00a9 AFP / Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV\n\nLONDON, United Kingdom, Aug 13 - A sentimental Justin Gatlin hailed Usain Bolt as an \"amazing showman\" whose career would certainly not be defined by him pulling up with cramp in the world 4x100m relay, the Jamaican's final competitive race.\n\nThere was high drama in Saturday's relay as anchor man Bolt received the baton in third place behind eventual gold medallists Britain and runners-up America.\n\nLess than 50 metres down the track, Bolt suddenly pulled up, clutching his left leg, tumbling to the track with what was later diagnosed as a hamstring cramp.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now,\" said Gatlin, who stormed to 100m gold in London, US teammate Christian Coleman taking silver to relegate Bolt to a disappointing bronze in his individual send-off.\n\n\"In the warm-up area we give ourselves respect and greet each other,\" Gatlin said of Bolt, who bows out of competition with a startling haul of eight Olympic gold medals and 14 world medals, nine of which are gold.\n\nGatlin, who has served two doping bans, put the blame for Bolt's cramp partly at the amount of time the athletes spent on the track before the starter's gun went off.\n\n\"There was a cool breeze out there. But the conditions were the same for everybody,\" said the 35-year-old, who won the 100m at the 2004 Olympics in Athens and the 2005 worlds in Helsinki before serving his second ban between 2006-10 for taking testosterone.\n\n- Chilly conditions unhelpful -\n\n\"I think it was the elements. I am sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world.\n\n\"It was a recipe. I don't want to say this but I understand we need to be ready early but I think we took our clothes off a little too early. It's a little chilly in here so I think that's where the cramp came from. That's what he suffered with. He was running out there cold.\"\n\nBut Gatlin, who was roundly booed at the London Stadium before both the 100m and relay, insisted: \"Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\n\n\"You can't let this championships define what he's done in the past. He has done amazing things. He's still the man, you know. The was his farewell race and we wish him the best and hope he recovers soon.\"\n\nReferring to Bolt's mooted future ambassadorial role within athletics' world governing body the IAAF, Gatlin added: \"He's coming back in a couple of years. He'll be ready, he has a passion for the sport.\n\n\"He loves the fans and they love him. He loves the sport too much to walk away. He's a showman.\"\n\nJapan snatched a surprise bronze medal, Kenji Fujimitsu moved to comment: \"Thank you, Bolt. He was an inspiration for us.\"\n\nOmar McLeod, the newly-crowned 110m hurdler and Jamaica's lead-off runner in the relay, added: \"Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nShares", "time": "11:06:00"}

"http://www.brecorder.com/2017/08/13/364713/gatlin-hails-bolt-the-showman-despite-relay-flop/", "body": "LONDON: A sentimental Justin Gatlin hailed Usain Bolt as an \"amazing showman\" whose career would certainly not be defined by him pulling up with cramp in the world 4x100m relay, the Jamaican's final competitive race.\n\nThere was high drama in Saturday's relay as anchor man Bolt received the baton in third place behind eventual gold medallists Britain and runners-up America.\n\nLess than 50 metres down the track, Bolt suddenly pulled up, clutching his left leg, tumbling to the track with what was later diagnosed as a hamstring cramp.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now,\" said Gatlin, who stormed to 100m gold in London, US teammate Christian Coleman taking silver to relegate Bolt to a disappointing bronze in his individual send-off.\n\n\"In the warm-up area we give ourselves respect and greet each other,\" Gatlin said of Bolt, who bows out of competition with a startling haul of eight Olympic gold medals and 14 world medals, nine of which are gold.\n\nGatlin, who has served two doping bans, put the blame for Bolt's cramp partly at the amount of time the athletes spent on the track before the starter's gun went off.\n\n\"There was a cool breeze out there. But the conditions were the same for everybody,\" said the 35-year-old, who won the 100m at the 2004 Olympics in Athens and the 2005 worlds in Helsinki before serving his second ban between 2006-10 for taking testosterone.\n\n- Chilly conditions unhelpful -\n\n\"I think it was the elements. I am sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world.\n\n\"It was a recipe. I don't want to say this but I understand we need to be ready early but I think we took our clothes off a little too early. It's a little chilly in here so I think that's where the cramp came from. That's what he suffered with. He was running out there cold.\"\n\nBut Gatlin, who was roundly booed at the London Stadium before both the 100m and relay, insisted: \"Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\n\n\"You can't let this championships define what he's done in the past. He has done amazing things. He's still the man, you know. The was his farewell race and we wish him the best and hope he recovers soon.\"\n\nReferring to Bolt's mooted future ambassadorial role within athletics' world governing body the IAAF, Gatlin added: \"He's coming back in a couple of years. He'll be ready, he has a passion for the sport.\n\n\"He loves the fans and they love him. He loves the sport too much to walk away. He's a showman.\"\n\nJapan snatched a surprise bronze medal, Kenji Fujimitsu moved to comment: \"Thank you, Bolt. He was an inspiration for us.\"\n\nOmar McLeod, the newly-crowned 110m hurdler and Jamaica's lead-off runner in the relay, added: \"Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"", "time": "12:17:00"}

"1333564"}], "url": "http://thefrontierpost.com/injury-floors-bolt-ruins-final-farewell/", "body": "LONDON (REUTERS): Usain Bolt's unparalleled career ended in extraordinary drama on Saturday as he pulled up with injury on the anchor leg of his very last race, the 4\u00d7100 metres relay final at the World Championships.\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with a cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling, and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track.\n\nYet the sport's greatest entertainer was determined that one of the finest careers in the sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair.\n\nSo the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried team mates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte, and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 metres to the line.\n\nThe official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the team mates he felt he had let down.\n\n\"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nMcLeod added: \"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nThird place\n\nJustin Gatlin, the American winner of the individual 100 metres who had consigned Bolt to third place in his final individual race last Saturday, paid tribute to his rival.\n\n\"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury). I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\nKevin Jones, the Jamaican team doctor, said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring.\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" he said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nJamaican team manager Ian Forbes praised Bolt for \"going out there and giving his all\" and added that the squad were \"very saddened\".\n\n\"The diagnostic work will be done shortly to determine how serious it is. He was able to walk to the team bus so hopefully that signals it's not as serious as it possibly could be,\" Forbes said.\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favourite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track.\n\nFive years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics.\n\nYet in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000 metres, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell.\n\nTheir leaving the track scene leaves a void in the sport that does not look like being filled anytime soon.", "time": "06:25:00"}

on Saturday as he pulled up injured running the final leg of the World Championships 4x100 meters relay as Britain beat the United States for a shock gold medal.\n\nBolt, who had to settle for bronze in the individual 100 meters, had been hoping to sign off from the sport by leading Jamaica to a fifth successive relay gold but they were already struggling in third when he collected the baton.\n\nRelated: Usain Bolt at the championships:\n\nAs he tried to gain ground, Bolt pulled up and fell to the floor with what looked like a hamstring injury.\n\nThe United States, with individual gold and silver medallists Justin Gatlin and Christian Coleman running the second and fourth legs, had been expected to push the Jamaicans all the way.\n\nInstead, a brilliantly executed race by Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Danny Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake gave Britain gold in 37.47 seconds, the best time in the world this year.\n\nThe US took silver in 37.52 with Japan third in 38.04. "http://indianexpress.com/article/sports/sport-others/my-name-is-bolt-lightning-bolt-best-quotes-by-usain-bolt-till-date-4794846/", "body": "By: AFP | Published:August 13, 2017 2:55 pm Usain Bolt of Jamaica before the race. (Source: Reuters) Usain Bolt thanks fans for 'infinite love'Usain Bolt limps out of final race, Great Britain win Gold in World Championships 4x100m relayUsaint Bolt last race, when and where to watch World Athletics Championship, TV channel, live streaming\n\nAthletics superstar Usain Bolt's last championship race ended in dramatic fashion as he collapsed injured on the track anchoring Jamaica's 4\u00d7100 metres relay in the world championship final.\n\nHere we pick out five of his best quotes and five about him since he first light up the championship track at the 2008 Beijing Olympics:\n\nWhat they said about him\n\n\"There is no athlete that can compete with him... he's a global superstar.\" - Bolt's predecessor as an athletics superstar, Michael Johnson, whose 200 metres world record Bolt broke in the 2008 Olympic final.\n\n\"You can compare us as sprinters, but the thing I am most proud of is that I did multiple events and I long-jumped.\" -Damned with faint and grudging praise by American legend Carl Lewis who also cast aspersions as to the Jamaican doping system to which Bolt retorted: \"Carl Lewis, I have no respect for him.\"\n\n\"He is an icon. He is the best sprinter of all time.\" -Former International Olympic Committee (IOC) President Jacques Rogge, who was chided at the 2012 London Olympics for refusing to say he was a legend. Former Olympic yachtsman Rogge instead opted to nominate British yachting icon Ben Ainslie as his star of the Games.\n\n\"Nobody's ever been faster than this guy! Ever! Of all the billions of people.\" - Then-US President Barack Obama reflects on the global nature of Bolt's stardom after meeting with him in Jamaica and then performing the lightning bolt pose with him.\n\n\"Usain Bolt is now Jamaica's biggest ambassador. His personality, his ability to draw people to him (and) his showmanship have really given a boost to Brand Jamaica.\" -Jamaican Prime Minister Andrew Holness neatly sums up Bolt's gift to the Caribbean island.\n\nBolt on himself\n\n\"I am Lightning Bolt! I am not Flash Gordon or anybody. My name is Bolt, Lightning Bolt.\" - Bolt after smashing Michael Johnson's 200m world record in the 2008 Beijing Olympic final to complete his first of three individual Olympic sprint doubles.\n\n\"Manners is the key thing. Say for instance when you're growing up you're walking down the street you've got to tell everybody good morning. Everybody. You can't pass one person.\" - Bolt displaying why he has charmed everyone along the way, never forgetting the strict but grounded way he was brought up by his parents, father Wellesley and mother Jennifer.\n\n\"People come to see you run fast, but they also come to see a show, a performance... that's what I give them.\" - Bolt savvy as ever and why athletics will miss him so much: not just for his jaw-dropping brilliance but also his ability to entertain.\n\n\"I'm now a legend, I'm also the greatest athlete to live. I am in the same category as Michael Johnson.\" - Bolt after winning the 2012 Olympic 200m title to complete the individual sprint double double.\n\n\"If Queen Elizabeth knighthooded me and I would get the title Sir Usain Bolt. That would sound very nice.\" - Bolt on the possibility of joining Mo Farah as a knight of the Realm. Not wholly implausible as he has been athletics' knight in shining armour for nearly a decade.\n\nFor all the latest Sports News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: Usain Bolt", "time": "09:26:00"}

{"eng": "Yohan Blake"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "343533"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anchor_leg", "label": {"eng": "Anchor leg"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "489170"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sport_of_athletics", "label": {"eng": "Sport of athletics"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1053871"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omar_McLeod", "label": {"eng": "Omar McLeod"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1333564"}], "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4785506/index.html", "body": "By Ian Chadband\n\nLONDON, Aug 12 (Reuters) - Usain Bolt's unparalleled career ended in extraordinary drama on Saturday as he pulled up with injury on the anchor leg of his very last race, the 4x100 metres relay final at the World Championships.\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track.\n\nYet the sport's greatest entertainer was determined that one of the finest careers in sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair.\n\nSo the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried team mates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 metres to the line.\n\nThe official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the team mates he felt he had let down.\n\n\"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nMcLeod added: \"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nTHIRD PLACE\n\nJustin Gatlin, the American winner of the individual 100 metres who had consigned Bolt to third place in his final individual race last Saturday, paid tribute to his rival.\n\n\"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury). I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\nKevin Jones, the Jamaican team doctor, said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring.\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" he said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nJamaican team manager Ian Forbes praised Bolt for \"going out there and giving his all\" and added that the squad were \"very saddened\".\n\n\"The diagnostic work will be done shortly to determine how serious it is. He was able to walk to the team bus so hopefully that signals it's not as serious as it possibly could be,\" Forbes said.\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favourite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track.\n\nFive years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics.\n\nYet in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000 metres, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell.\n\nTheir leaving of the track scene leaves a void in the sport that does not look like being filled any time soon. (Editing by Ed Osmond)", "time": "23:00:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4_\u00d7_100_metres_relay", "label": {"eng": "4 \u00d7 100 metres relay"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "320499"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relay_race", "wiki", "id": "333752"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yohan_Blake", "label": {"eng": "Yohan Blake"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "343533"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warming_up", "label": {"eng": "Warming up"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "492684"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omar_McLeod", "label": {"eng": "Omar McLeod"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1333564"}], "url": "http://www.firstpost.com/sports/iaaf-world-championships-2017-usain-bolts-teammates-blame-organisers-for-athletes-inglorious-end-to-career-3926227.html", "body": "London: Usain Bolt's dramatic and inglorious end to his top level career was the fault of world championship organisers, his furious teammates claimed.\n\nThe 30-year-old 100 metres and 200m world record-holder collapsed on the London Stadium track whilst anchoring Jamaica in the final of the 4x100m on Saturday as cramp gripped his leg.\n\nBolt lay prone on the track but waved away the offer of a wheelchair and eventually, aided by his three team-mates, limped across the line before making a hasty exit -- not the way the man who had won triple Olympic gold at the same stadium in 2012 would have wished his competitive career in championships to finish.\n\nJamaica's Usain Bolt lies on the track after injuring himself during the men's 4x100m final at the World Athletics Championships in London. AP\n\nBut his team-mates complained that his problem was caused by organisers keeping the relay teams waiting in the cold before their race as several medal ceremonies were held.\n\n\"I think they were holding us too long in the call room. The walk was too long. Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me, 'Yohan, I think this is crazy. 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run',\" said Yohan Blake, who branded the wait as \"crazy\".\n\n\"We kept warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting,\" added the 2011 100m world champion, who also won Olympic relay gold in 2012 and 2016 with Bolt.\n\n\"I think it got the better of us. We were over warm.\n\n\"To see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggling like that.\n\n\"The race was 10 minutes late and we were kept 40 minutes.\"\n\nBolt may not have led Jamaica to a glorious finale anyway, though, as he took the baton well behind eventual winners Great Britain and the US.\n\nBut Jamaica's 110m hurdles world champion Omar McLeod -- who ran the first leg -- likewise pointed the finger at organisers for denying his country's greatest star a more fitting swansong.\n\n\"It's heart wrenching,\" said McLeod, who is also the Olympic champion.\n\n\"It was ridiculous man, we were there around 45 minutes waiting outside, I think they had three medal ceremonies before we went out so we were really trying our hardest to stay warm and keep upbeat.\n\n\"But it was ridiculous. We waited a really long time. I drank like two bottles of water.\"\n\nTheir criticism echoed that of Justin Gatlin, who led an American 1-2 alongside team-mate Christian Coleman to deny Bolt a farewell gold in the individual 100m.\n\n\"I think it was the elements. I am sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" said Gatlin.\n\n\"It was a recipe. I don't want to say this, I understand we need to be ready early, but I think we took our clothes off a little too early.\n\n\"It's a little chilly in here so I think that's where the cramp came from. That's what he suffered with. He was running out there cold.\"\n\nDespite his relatively unsuccessful championships -- in which he will exit with just a single bronze medal -- Bolt will still be accorded a final lap of honour in a tribute ceremony before the curtain comes down on the world championships later on Sunday.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 13, 2017 03:55 pm | Updated Date: Aug 13, 2017 03:56 pm\n\nTags :#Athletics#Christian coleman#Iaaf world championships 2017#Jamaica#Justin gatlin#Omar mcleod#Usain bolt#Yohan blake", "time": "10:37:00"}

"328733"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relay_race", "label": {"eng": "Relay race"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "332246"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starting_pistol", "label": {"eng": "Starting pistol"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "333584"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yohan_Blake", "label": {"eng": "Yohan Blake"}, "score": 2, "type": "person", "id": "343533"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_world_records_in_athletics", "label": {"eng": "List of world records in athletics"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "394893"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallace_Spearmon", "label": {"eng": "Wallace Spearmon"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "527099"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Jones_(American_football)", "label": {"eng": "Kevin Jones (American football)"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "546615"}], "url": "http://thegardenisland.com/sports_wire/bolt-takes-a-tumble-and-can-t-complete-final-race/article_9c03aaba-509d-5871-824d-e747121ed204.html", "body": "Fifteen steps into the final homestretch of his final race, something gave in his left hamstring. The World's Fastest Man skittered to a stop -- hopping, skipping, jumping, then finally dropping to the ground and tumbling forward before coming to a rest.\n\nWhile the winning team from Britain crossed the finish line, Bolt was writhing on the track, where he eventually wound up chest down with his face pressed into Lane 5. He was certainly every bit as stunned as any of the 60,000-plus who packed the stadium Saturday, or the millions watching one of the world's most entertaining showmen make his final curtain call in the 4x100-meter relay at world championships.\n\nThere was no celebration. No gold, no silver, not even a consolation bronze, the likes of which Bolt received a week earlier in his final 100-meter race.\n\nJamaica closed the night with \"DNF\" by its name: Did Not Finish. Dead last. Bolt was helped into a wheelchair, but eventually got to his feet and, assisted by his teammates, limped gingerly across the finish line. He gave a few waves to the crowd, then left for the trainer's room, and with that, presumably left track and field forever.\n\n\"Injuries are part of our sport and, always, of course, it's sad to see,\" said Wallace Spearmon, the American sprinter who has been close with Bolt for years and was on hand helping the U.S. team. \"So, yeah, it's tragic.\"\n\nThe Jamaican team doctor, Kevin Jones, diagnosed the injury that brought a strange end to Bolt's career as, simply, a cramp in the champion's left hamstring.\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jones said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nWatching track's No. 1 sprinter and celebrity dropping to the ground was nothing short of jaw-dropping -- so much so that the fact that Britain won the race, outrunning a United States team that, somewhat amazingly, didn't drop the baton, almost seemed like an afterthought.\n\nNethaneel Mitchell-Blake held off U.S. anchorman Christian Coleman down the stretch and the Brits won their first-ever world title in the 4x100 in 37.47 seconds.\n\nWhen Bolt took the baton from Yohan Blake for his final homestretch, he was in third place, but that was no cause for concern. In virtually each of the seven relay golds he's won at the Olympics and world championships, Bolt has reeled in the competition down the stretch and won going away, much the same as all his 100 victories have played out.\n\nFive years and one day earlier, on the very same track, Bolt helped Jamaica set the world record. That run of 36.84 seconds earned Bolt the sixth of nine Olympic victories.\n\nBut last week in the 100, Bolt's extra gear was not enough either to catch Coleman, who finished second, or to hold off Justin Gatlin, the oft-booed American who came from behind to finish first.\n\nCould he have caught his relay competition in this one? Nobody will ever know. Bolt was gaining no ground at the 30-meter mark, which is when he felt the pain in his leg and went tumbling.\n\nAfterward, there was plenty of second-guessing to be done. Most of it came at the expense of the IAAF, which made the sprinters wait about 40 minutes from the time they were summoned from the warm-up room to the time the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I think this is crazy,\" Blake said. \"Forty minutes. Waiting. Warming up. Waiting. Warming up. It just should not happen. To have your champion go out like that. It's crazy.\"\n\nSaid Gatlin, who remains insistent that Bolt will be back someday: \"We lost all of our heat, all of our sweat, and we went out there cold.\"\n\nPart of the wait was for the U.S. women's relay team to finish its victory celebration. Tori Bowie anchored the win and, with one day left in the meet, is the only athlete to win two gold medals in London. Also, a medal ceremony was held for Russian high jump champion Mariya Lasitskene, who is competing as a neutral athlete because of the doping crisis in her country and got to listen not to her own anthem, but to the IAAF's theme song, as she stood on the podium.\n\nOther winners included Kevin Mayer of France in the decathlon and Johannes Vetter, whose victory in the javelin throw gave Germany its first gold of the championships.\n\nIn the undercard to the relays, Muktar Edris held off Mo Farah of Britain in the 5,000. With help of his Ethiopian teammates, Edris won a tactical cat-and-mouse race and denied Farah his fifth straight long-distance double, counting world championships and Olympics.\n\nAs if to prove that point one last time, he did it again -- this time without even finishing the race.", "time": "02:58:00"}

He gave a few waves to the crowd, then left for the trainer's room, and with that, presumably left track and field forever.\n\n\"Injuries are part of our sport and, always, of course, it's sad to see,\" said Wallace Spearmon, the American sprinter who has been close with Bolt for years and was on hand helping the U.S. team. \"So, yeah, it's tragic.\"\n\nThe Jamaican team doctor, Kevin Jones, diagnosed the injury that brought a strange end to Bolt's career as, simply, a cramp in the champion's left hamstring.\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jones said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nWatching track's No. 1 sprinter and celebrity dropping to the ground was nothing short of jaw-dropping - so much so that the fact that Britain won the race, outrunning a United States team that, somewhat amazingly, didn't drop the baton, almost seemed like an afterthought.\n\nNethaneel Mitchell-Blake held off U.S. anchorman Christian Coleman down the stretch and the Brits won their first-ever world title in the 4x100 in 37.47 seconds.\n\nWhen Bolt took the baton from Yohan Blake for his final homestretch, he was in third place, but that was no cause for concern. In virtually each of the seven relay golds he's won at the Olympics and world championships, Bolt has reeled in the competition down the stretch and won going away, much the same as all his 100 victories have played out.\n\nFive years and one day earlier, on the very same track, Bolt helped Jamaica set the world record. That run of 36.84 seconds earned Bolt the sixth of nine Olympic victories.\n\nBut last week in the 100, Bolt's extra gear was not enough either to catch Coleman, who finished second, or to hold off Justin Gatlin, the oft-booed American who came from behind to finish first.\n\nCould he have caught his relay competition in this one? Nobody will ever know. Bolt was gaining no ground at the 30-meter mark, which is when he felt the pain in his leg and went tumbling.\n\nAfterward, there was plenty of second-guessing to be done. Most of it came at the expense of the IAAF, which made the sprinters wait about 40 minutes from the time they were summoned from the warm-up room to the time the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I think this is crazy,\" Blake said. \"Forty minutes. Waiting. Warming up. Waiting. Warming up. It just should not happen. To have your champion go out like that. It's crazy.\"\n\nSaid Gatlin, who remains insistent that Bolt will be back someday: \"We lost all of our heat, all of our sweat, and we went out there cold.\"\n\nPart of the wait was for the U.S. women's relay team to finish its victory celebration. Tori Bowie anchored the win and, with one day left in the meet, is the only athlete to win two gold medals in London. Also, a medal ceremony was held for Russian high jump champion Mariya Lasitskene, who is competing as a neutral athlete because of the doping crisis in her country and got to listen not to her own anthem, but to the IAAF's theme song, as she stood on the podium.\n\nOther winners included Kevin Mayer of France in the decathlon and Johannes Vetter, whose victory in the javelin throw gave Germany its first gold of the championships.\n\nIn the undercard to the relays, Muktar Edris held off Mo Farah of Britain in the 5,000. With help of his Ethiopian teammates, Edris won a tactical cat-and-mouse race and denied Farah his fifth straight long-distance double, counting world championships and Olympics.\n\nAs if to prove that point one last time, he did it again - this time without even finishing the race.\n\n___\n\nMore AP track coverage: https://www.apnews.com/tag/London2017", "time": "14:59:00"}

Bolt applauding the stands, with pictures of him constantly shown on the stadium's big screens.\n\nGatlin and the US team also including another convicted doping cheat, Mike Rodgers, and Jaylen Bacon career with 14 world medals to go with eight Olympic golds.", "time": "19:57:00"}
