"body": "Usain Bolt had a dramatic and inglorious end to his top-level career.\n\nThe 30-year-old 100 metres and 200m world record-holder collapsed on the London Stadium track whilst anchoring Jamaica in the final of the 4x100m on Saturday as cramp gripped his leg.\n\nBolt lay prone on the track but waved away the offer of a wheelchair and eventually, aided by his three team-mates, limped across the line before making a hasty exit -- not the way the man who had won triple Olympic gold at the same stadium in 2012 would have wished his competitive career in championships to finish.\n\nBut his team-mates complained that his problem was caused by organisers keeping the relay teams waiting in the cold before their race as several medal ceremonies were held.\n\n\"I think they were holding us too long in the call room. The walk was too long. Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me, 'Yohan, I think this is crazy. 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run',\" said Yohan Blake, who branded the wait as \"crazy\".\n\n\"We kept warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting,\" added the 2011 100m world champion, who also won Olympic relay gold in 2012 and 2016 with Bolt.\n\n\"I think it got the better of us. We were over warm.\n\n\"To see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggling like that.\n\n\"The race was 10 minutes late and we were kept 40 minutes.\"\n\nBolt may not have led Jamaica to a glorious finale anyway, though, as he took the baton well behind eventual winners Great Britain and the US.\n\nBut Jamaica's 110m hurdles world champion Omar McLeod -- who ran the first leg -- likewise pointed the finger at organisers for denying his country's greatest star a more fitting swansong.\n\n\"It's heart wrenching,\" said McLeod, who is also the Olympic champion.\n\n\"It was ridiculous man, we were there around 45 minutes waiting outside, I think they had three medal ceremonies before we went out so we were really trying our hardest to stay warm and keep upbeat.\n\n\"But it was ridiculous. We waited a really long time. I drank like two bottles of water.\"\n\nTheir criticism echoed that of Justin Gatlin, who led an American 1-2 alongside team-mate Christian Coleman to deny Bolt a farewell gold in the individual 100m.\n\n\"I think it was the elements. I am sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" said Gatlin.\n\n\"It was a recipe. I don't want to say this, I understand we need to be ready early, but I think we took our clothes off a little too early.\n\n\"It's a little chilly in here so I think that's where the cramp came from. That's what he suffered with. He was running out there cold.\"\n\nDespite his relatively unsuccessful championships -- in which he will exit with just a single bronze medal -- Bolt will still be accorded a final lap of honour in a tribute ceremony before the curtain comes down on the world championships later on Sunday.", "time": "11:16:00"}

"http://www.mynbc5.com/article/jamaicas-usain-bolt-injured-during-final-career-race/12003515", "body": "Usain Bolt's farewell appearance at the world championships ended in painful and disastrous fashion as he pulled up injured on the final leg of the men's 4x100m relay Saturday.\n\nBolt took the baton for Jamaica in third place but within a few strides he had fallen to the ground, clutching his left leg, as host Britain secured a shock gold ahead of a United States team containing Justin Gatlin.\n\nBolt beaten into third in the individual 100m behind Gatlin and his US team compatriot Christian Coleman, was comforted by teammates after getting to his feet, his face etched in pain.\n\nThe capacity crowd in the London Stadium was still digesting the shock earlier defeat for home hero Mo Farah in the men's 5,000m final, before the drama of Bolt's last agonizing appearance.\n\nHe had been bidding for a 12th world championship gold to bring down the curtain on his glittering career, but instead limped out of the London Stadium arena.\n\nVictory for the British quartet of CJ Ujah, Adam Gemili, who ran a storming second leg, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake was stunning compensation for Farah's earlier defeat.\n\nThey won in 37.47 seconds, with the US taking silver and Japan with a surprise bronze.\n\nFor his massive global following, the perfect script would have seen the Bolt of old running down Britain and the US for yet another gold, but it was not to be.\n\n\"He didn't tell us exactly what happened but from what I saw, it looked like a strain or a cramp of some sort,\" teammate Julian Forte told IAAF radio.\n\n\"He kept apologizing to us but we told him there was no need to apologize -- injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nJamaican team doctor Kevin Jones told AFP that Bolt had suffered from \"cramp in his left hamstring.\"\n\n\"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him,\" he added.\n\nJamaica's 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, who ran the first leg for the quartet, summed up the feeling of everyone.\n\n\"Usain Bolt's name will always live on,\" he said.\n\nBut another teammate, Yohan Blake, who won Olympic relay gold with Bolt in 2012 and 2016, slammed organizers for the delay in starting the race because of medal ceremonies.\n\n\"Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me, 'Yohan, I think this is crazy',\" he said.\n\nFarah bows out with silver\n\nFarah, who won the 10,000 title in dramatic fashion of the opening day at the London Stadium, had to settle for silver behind Ethiopian Muktar Edris in his final championship race on the track.\n\nHe edged out American Paul Chelimo in a desperate dash for the line, the last mile of a hitherto slow run race run in just under four minutes.\n\nFarah, 34, will now turn his attention to the marathon after failing in his bid to double up at the Olympics or World Championship for the fifth time, including double gold in London 2012 and the Rio Games last year.\n\nEdris, a former world junior champion, timed his last lap burst to perfection to win in 13 minutes 32.79 seconds, copying Farah's famous Mobot gesture as he crossed the line.\n\nIt was not the farewell Farah wanted, but he pointed to his earlier exertions in a dramatic 10,000m final as reason for lacking his usual devastating finish.\n\n\"The 10,000m took a lot more out of me than I had realized,\" he told BBC Sport.\n\n\"I gave it my all. I didn't have a single thing left to give at the end.\"", "time": "23:58:00"}

"1333564"}], "url": "http://www.telegraph.co.uk/athletics/2017/08/13/usain-bolts-furious-jamaica-team-blame-london-2017-organisers/", "body": "Furious Yohan Blake hit out at organisers after Usain Bolt's dramatic final race at the World Championships.\n\nEight-time Olympic champion Bolt sensationally pulled up injured with 50 metres to go of the 4x100 metres relay and fell to the track with Great Britain taking gold just ahead of the USA and Japan.\n\nThe race started 10 minutes later than scheduled with two medal ceremonies for the 5,000m - with Sir Mo Farah getting his silver medal - and the high jump taking place before.\n\nBolt's sudden injury ended his career in sorry style after he planned to retire from the track following the championships, having already won bronze in the 100m last weekend.\n\n#bolt In case you missed it. pic.twitter.com/X1qJnjS4V0 -- Ross Tucker (@Scienceofsport)\n\nAugust 12, 2017\n\nAnd Blake, who won Olympic 4x100m relay gold with Bolt and Jamaica in 2012 and 2016, believes the lengthy build-up caused Bolt's injury in London on Saturday night.\n\n\"I think they were holding us too long in the call room. The walk was too long. Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me, 'Yohan, I think this is crazy',\" said the 100m world champion from 2011.\n\n\"It was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run. We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us.\n\n\"We were over warm. And to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggling like that...\n\n\"The race was 10 minutes late, we were kept 40 minutes and it was a 300 metre walk. It was crazy.\"\n\nTeam-mate Omar McLeod echoed Blake and criticised the organisation with his heart going out to Bolt.\n\nHe said: \"It's heart-wrenching. I gave it my all and I really wanted Usain to leave golden, or even if it was just a medal, it was really heart-wrenching.\n\n\"I couldn't believe it, I'm in shock, utter disbelief.\n\n\"It was ridiculous, man. We were there around 45 minutes waiting outside, I think they had three medal ceremonies before we went out so we were really trying our hardest to stay warm and keep upbeat.\n\n\"But it was ridiculous. We waited a really long time. I drank like two bottles of water.\"\n\nTeam-mate Julian Forte, running in his first World Championships, added: \"I really wanted to be a part of the team that sends Usain off in style. Unfortunately it's one of those things, it's part of sport.\n\n\"They kept us in the call room for an extremely long time in our running kits, and it's not the warmest over here and they had us around there for quite a while, so I think they really need to look into that and do something about it.\n\n\"We were excited, we were ready, we had been doing some hand offs and everybody was feeling good, but they kept us hanging around for a long time, you know. So it's just really crazy.\"\n\nDr Kevin Jones, Jamaica's team doctor, confirmed Bolt's injury.\n\nHe said: \"It's cramp in his left hamstring but a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race. The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nThe USA's 100m champion, Justin Gatlin, had sympathy for Bolt and still expects him to return to the track, with the pair even having a bet.\n\nHe said: \"You can't really have this night or championship define what he's done in the past. From 2008 on, Usain Bolt has done amazing things. Tonight is not going to define who he is. He is still the man.\n\n\"This is a farewell tour, we take our hats off to him and we hope he gets better.\n\n\"I'm going to win my 100, he's coming back in a year or two. He'll be ready. He has a passion for the sport, he loves the fans, the fans love him. It's something you can't walk away too easy from.\"", "time": "07:24:00"}

"person", "id": "546615"}], "url": "http://www.theroar.com.au/2017/08/13/usain-bolt-breaks-down-in-final-race/", "body": "Usain Bolt ended his stellar career in excruciating pain.\n\nThe Jamaican great crumpled to the track with a left-leg injury as he was chasing a final gold medal for the Jamaican 4\u00d7100-metre relay team at the world championships in London on Saturday.\n\nHaving to make up lots of ground on the anchor leg, Bolt suddenly screamed and stumbled as he came down with his golden farewell shattered by the first injury he has experienced at a major competition.\n\nThat wasn't the only surprise. Britain went on to beat the United States in a tight finish.\n\nThe 60,000-capacity stadium was primed for one last Bolt show, one last \"To the World\" pose after a victory, but the injury made it blatantly clear why Bolt is ready to retire.\n\nHis body can no longer hold up.\n\n\"It's a cramp in his left hamstring, but a lot of the pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jamaican team doctor Kevin Jones said.\n\n\"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nHis teammates on the once-fabled Jamaican sprint squad were far from unmatchable, too.\n\nBolt had just too much to make up in the final 100 metres as both Britain and the US were ahead and even Japan was even.\n\nAs Bolt fell, the leg with the golden shoe giving way, the crowd still went wild because the home team went on to win gold in 37.47 seconds, .05 seconds ahead of the US.\n\n\"It just happened,\" Jamaican leadoff runner Omar McLeod said. \"Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"", "time": "00:37:00"}

"wiki", "id": "1053871"}], "url": "https://au.sports.yahoo.com/a/36701310/justin-gatlin-says-usain-bolt-not-retiring-from-athletics/", "body": "Justin Gatlin is convinced Usain Bolt will return to athletics after injury dramatically ruined the Jamaican's farewell in the 4x100 metre relay final in London.\n\nBolt looked set to head into retirement with a record-equaling 15th IAAF World Championships medal but pulled up with an apparent hamstring injury and failed to finish the final leg of the race.\n\nRIDICULOUS: Teammate slams organisers after Bolt injury\n\nGreat Britain snatched the gold medal from the United States, as the 30-year-old lay on the track, Christian Coleman beaten to the line by Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake.\n\nGatlin, who beat Coleman and Bolt to 100m gold last weekend, has previously expressed his opinion that his long-time rival will return to the sport in the future and reiterated those thoughts following an unbecoming farewell for the eight-time Olympic champion.\n\n\"He's coming back in a year or two, he'll be ready. He has a passion for the sport, the fans love him, it's something you just can't walk away from that easy,\" said Gatlin.\n\n\"He's a showman, he wants to come out and I think he'll do a great job if he comes back to track and field. We've got a lot of young guys like Coleman, like [Jaylen] Bacon, myself, we're hungry to go out there for good competition.\"\n\nGatlin and Bolt on Sunday. Image: Getty\n\nRegardless of whether he returns to the track, Bolt is sure to be remembered as an all-time great - having secured 100m and 200m doubles at three successive Olympic Games, as well as setting new world records in each event.\n\n\"You can't really have this night define what he's done in the past,\" Gatlin added. \"From 2008 on, Usain Bolt has done amazing things and tonight is not going to define who he is.\n\n\"He's still the man, and this is farewell so we take our hat off to him, hope he gets well soon.\"\n\nGatlin was one of many competitors who suggested a lengthy wait ahead of Saturday's relay may have contributed to Bolt's injury.\n\n\"We were in the stadium for a while, you guys know how chilly it is down here,\" he said. \"We had a cool breeze in the back and I think with that a lot of our muscles were cramping up from having our clothes off a little too early.\n\n\"Hopefully it's just a cramp and it'll go away, but I hope he doesn't dwell on it.\"", "time": "02:34:00"}

{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Jones_(American_football)", "label": {"eng": "Kevin Jones (American football)"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "546615"}], "url": "http://at.theaustralian.com.au/link/4006147a0b1f378b7e5f40b6e801019a?domain=theaustralian.com.au", "body": "He was delayed for 21 minutes in the call room and all it took was 21 strides to be cruelly cut down in his final race.\n\nThe gargantuan Usain Bolt said goodbye to his gigantic athletics career by rejecting a wheelchair proferred by concerned officials, rolling up his shorts and hobbling in pain across the finish line with his Jamaican 4x100m teammates in support.\n\nIf Bolt had managed to chase down US anchor Christian Coleman and British anchor Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake at the London Stadium, a victory would have brought about his 21st world, Olympic or Commonwealth Games gold medal. But instead it was the chilly weather of midsummer London, the officials' desire to have the athletes ready well before time, and the delayed start of the mens 4x100m relay that was blamed for Bolt's screaming and hopping down the final straight as his hamstring cramped into a blinding spasm.\n\nThink back to Bolt's explosion onto the world scene at the 2008 Beijing Olympics when he was so supreme, so confident, so thin, and so damn fast and it is almost incomprehensible to say goodbye as pain is etched across his face, limping to the medical centre, rather than playing to the crowd in a special farewell lap.\n\nThe ultimate good-time speedster is supposed to be supernatural, beyond the frailties of mere mortals who can only glance below 10 seconds.\n\nJamaica team doctor Kevin Jones said: \"It's cramp in his left hamstring but a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race.\n\n\"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nWorld champion Justin Gatlin said the delay before the relay started was a recipe for disaster.\n\n\"Aw man, you know. It was a recipe ... I understand TV magic, and I understand that we have to be ready on the time. But I think we took our clothes off a little too early in the back, under the stadium. It's chilly out here, and I think that's where the cramp came from. He suffered that by having his clothes off too early. We lost all of our heat, all of our sweat and we went out there cold.''\n\nBolt's Jamaican teammate Yohan Blake said Bolt had been complaining before the race about the time delays.\n\nThe schedule fell behind after the men's 5000m when British distance star Mo Farah finished second behind Ethiopian Mutkar Edris but went on a journey around the track in a farewell of sorts as he now intends to run in marathons.\n\nThere were delays as several medal presentations were made and the relays started about 10 minutes behind schedule.\n\nJamaican team member Omar McLeod said: \"It's heart-wrenching, I gave it my all and I really wanted Usain to leave golden, or even if it was just a medal, it was really heart-wrenching.\n\n\"I couldn't believe it, I'm in shock, utter disbelief. It was ridiculous man, we were there around 45 minutes waiting outside, I think they had three medal ceremonies before we went out so we were really trying our hardest to stay warm and keep upbeat. But it was ridiculous. We waited a really long time.''\n\nNo one was anticipating such an excruciatingly painful goodbye to his career, which has left the global track and field community with a huge void to fill.\n\nUS star Allyson Felix, who added to her bulging collection of world and Olympic medals with another gold when the US team won the women's 4x100m relay, said: \"It's just really tough to see, especially on his kind of farewell tour. We never want to see someone get hurt, but especially him. So just hoping that he's all right.''\n\nBefore the race, Bolt was in a jovial mood, boxing with the championship mascot Hero the Hedgehog in the warm-up room, and then emerging onto the track to a standing ovation.\n\nWith a pre-planned shoulder roll with his team, he warmed up on the home straight, waving and cheering and clapping to the crowd. The moment was a little overwhelming, even for Bolt, as he realised this was it: his final sprint on the biggest of stages, but he wasn't to know he would end up in the medical room, rather than on a farewell lap.\n\nYet the mood in the stadium quickly turned to joy as the British team won the gold medal ahead of the US. Japan claimed the bronze.\n\nThe capacity crowd of 55,000 also roared for Bolt, this time in a chorus of gratefulness, thanks and a huge dollop of sadness.\n\nBolt seared himself onto the consciousness of the world when his braggadocio antics and playful enthusiasm at the Beijing 2008 Olympic Games elevated him well beyond being the fastest man in the world. He continued to dominate the sprints -- only a failed drug test by a relay teammate ultimately denied him the triple-triple Olympic golds across the 100m, 200m and 4x100m relay. Many have commented that Bolt stayed a year too long: that he should have retired at the Rio Olympics, but he had always committed to the London 2017 organisers that he would support their event and he wanted to return to the Olympic track where the crowds had given him so much love.\n\nBolt would often train in southwest London, not far from the home of his agent Ricky Sims, and has long appreciated that the locals would leave him alone.\n\nEven now, Bolt is linked to the successful Nitro Athletics in Australia and is likely to make a guest appearance at next year's series, perhaps in the relay, or in one of the odd distances. That decision may hinge on how much partying he enjoys in his retirement, or if his intent to take up professional soccer is a serious one.\n\nBolt wanted to retire as unbeatable -- and while his bronze here from the 100m and his hobble in the relay was not the farewell he intended, he can be comforted that he will remain unbeatable as an athletics personality and his numerous records will stand for some time.\n\nHis 100m (9.58sec) and 200m (19.19sec) world records, set four days apart in Berlin in 2009, remain at the zenith of the sport, and well beyond the gravitational pull of the current generation of sprinters.", "time": "14:19:00"}

after Usain Bolt's dramatic final race at the World Championships.\n\nEight-time Olympic champion Bolt sensationally pulled up injured with 50 metres to go of the 4\u00d7100 metres relay and fell to the track with Great Britain taking gold just ahead of the USA and Japan.\n\nThe race started 10 minutes later than scheduled with two medal ceremonies for the 5,000m - with Sir Mo Farah getting his silver medal - and the high jump taking place before.\n\nThe Jamaicans were expected to be amongst the medals\n\nBolt's sudden injury ended his career in sorry style after he planned to retire from the track following the championships, having already won bronze in the 100m last weekend.\n\nAnd Blake, who won Olympic 4x100m relay gold with Bolt and Jamaica in 2012 and 2016, believes the lengthy build-up caused Bolt's injury in London on Saturday night.\n\n\"I think they were holding us too long in the call room. The walk was too long. Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me, 'Yohan, I think this is crazy',\" said the 100m world champion from 2011.\n\n\"It was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run. We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us.\n\n\"We were over warm. And to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggling like that...\n\nThis is not the image Usain Bolt wanted to end his career with (Adam Davy/PA)\n\n\"The race was 10 minutes late, we were kept 40 minutes and it was a 300 metre walk. It was crazy.\"\n\nTeam-mate Omar McLeod echoed Blake and criticised the organisation with his heart going out to Bolt.\n\nHe said: \"It's heart-wrenching. I gave it my all and I really wanted Usain to leave golden, or even if it was just a medal, it was really heart-wrenching.\n\n\"I couldn't believe it, I'm in shock, utter disbelief.\n\n\"It was ridiculous, man. We were there around 45 minutes waiting outside, I think they had three medal ceremonies before we went out so we were really trying our hardest to stay warm and keep upbeat.\n\n\"But it was ridiculous. We waited a really long time. I drank like two bottles of water.\"\n\nUsain Bolt finished his career with eight Olympic gold medals (Yui Mok/PA)\n\nTeam-mate Julian Forte, running in his first World Championships, added: \"I really wanted to be a part of the team that sends Usain off in style. Unfortunately it's one of those things, it's part of sport.\n\n\"They kept us in the call room for an extremely long time in our running kits, and it's not the warmest over here and they had us around there for quite a while, so I think they really need to look into that and do something about it.\n\n\"We were excited, we were ready, we had been doing some hand offs and everybody was feeling good, but they kept us hanging around for a long time, you know. So it's just really crazy.\"\n\nDr Kevin Jones, Jamaica's team doctor, confirmed Bolt's injury.\n\nHe said: \"It's cramp in his left hamstring but a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race. The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"", "time": "23:07:00"}

today, taking part in a Mexican wave alongside his teammates on the Jamaican 4x100m relay team\n\nBolt announced himself as a sporting superstar by storming to the 100m crown in Beijing 2008 in a world record 9.69 seconds, even slowing down to celebrate before reaching the line.\n\nIn the Beijing 200m, he ended Michael Johnson's reign as world record holder by racing to victory in 19.30secs.\n\nThe 2009 World Championships in Berlin saw gold medals in the 100m, 200m and the 4x100m alongside his Jamaican team mates.\n\nTwo years later, at the World Championships in Daegu, South Korea, Bolt showed his metal by winning the 200m after being sensationally disqualified from the 100m final for a false start.\n\nBolt finished the championships with another gold and another world record as Jamaica won the relay in 37.04.\n\nLondon 2012 saw another rush of golds for the Jamaican.\n\n2008 Olympic Games, Beijing - 100m Bolt announced himself as a sporting superstar by storming to the 100m crown in a world record 9.69 seconds, even slowing down to celebrate before reaching the line\n\n2009 World Championships, Berlin - 100m Bolt shattered his world record with a run of 9.58s to take golD\n\n2009 World Championships, Berlin - 200m The world's fastest man took the 200m mark to new heights by clocking 19.19\n\n2009 World Championships, Berlin - 4x100m relay Bolt added a third gold with his Jamaican team-mates in the sprint relay in a time of 37.31\n\n2011 World Championships, Daegu - 200m Having been sensationally disqualified from the 100m final for a false start, Bolt bounced back in the 200m, taking the title in 19.40\n\n2011 World Championships, Daegu - 4x100m relay Bolt finished the championships with another gold and another world record as Jamaica won the relay in 37.04\n\n2012 Olympic Games, London - 100m Bolt answered doubts about his form and fitness in emphatic fashion by defending his crown in 9.63, an Olympic record\n\n2012 Olympic Games, London - 200m He became the first man in history to retain both the Olympic 100m and 200m titles, winning over the longer distance in 19.32 and declaring afterwards he was a \"living legend\"\n\n2012 Olympic Games, London - 4x100m relay Bolt left the capital with another world record in the relay, Jamaica winning in 36.84\n\nIn the 100m, Bolt answered doubts about his form and fitness in emphatic fashion by defending his crown in 9.63, an Olympic record. This was followed by victories in the 200 and 4x100m relay.\n\nThe 2013 World Championships in Moscow saw another treble, bringing Bolt's career medal tally into double figures.\n\nTwo years later, he stormed the stage in Beijing, riding to the rescue of his beleaguered sport once again, by dashing drug-cheat Gatlin's hopes of 100m in China, accompanied by two wins in his other two favourite events.\n\nA further triple crown was secured at the Rio Olympics in 2016, although the triumph was mildly soured by his failure to set the world record in the 200m.\n\n2013: World Championships, Moscow - 100m The 26-year-old defied pouring rain and a drenched track to hold off Justin Gatlin and reclaim his crown in 9.77, his best time of the year\n\n2013: World Championships, Moscow - 200m The world's fastest man blazed to victory with an emphatic performance at the Luzhniki Stadium, storming to glory in 19.66\n\n2013: World Championships, Moscow - 4x100m relay Bolt took his World Championships career medal tally into double figures by anchoring Jamaica to gold in 37.36\n\n2015: World Championships, Beijing - 100m Riding to the rescue of his beleaguered sport once again, Bolt dashed Gatlin's hopes of 100m in China. The Jamaican lived up to his billing as the saviour of athletics as he held off the challenge of two-time drug cheat to win in 9.79\n\n2015: World Championships, Beijing - 200m Made it four straight half-lap world titles, blowing away Gatlin with a world-leading 19.55 time in front of a raucous Bird's Nest crowd\n\n2015: World Championships, Beijing - 4x100m relay Bolt wrapped up another event to remember by anchoring Jamaica to victory in a world-leading time of 37.36\n\n2016 Olympic Games, Rio - 100m Bolt overcame a now trademark sluggish start to power home in the final 50m and cross the line first in a season's best of 9.81, beating rival Gatlin into second\n\nBolt also triumphed in the 200m race and alongside his Jamaican teammates, pictured, in the 4x100m relay", "time": "21:10:00"}

"http://www.thestar.com.my/sport/athletics/2017/08/13/gatlin-blames-tv-scheduling-for-bolt-injury/", "body": "LONDON (Reuters) - Justin Gatlin agreed with the complaints of the Jamaican relay team that a long wait before their 4x100m final at the World Championships on Saturday contributed to the injury suffered by Usain Bolt in his last race.\n\nBolt, having been passed the baton by Yohan Blake, was in third behind Great Britain and the United States, who eventually won gold and silver, but pulled up almost 50 metres from the line and fell to the track.\n\nJamaica's team doctor later said that the 30-year-old had suffered a hamstring cramp.\n\nBolt's team mates complained that a 45-minute wait in the call room before the race had hampered their preparations.\n\n\"I think they were holding us too long in the call room,\" Blake told reporters. \"Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me 'Yohan, I think this is crazy'. Forty minutes and two medal presentations before our run.\"\n\nGatlin, who beat Bolt to gold in the 100m last Saturday, agreed with the complaints and laid the blame at the television scheduling for the event.\n\n\"I know it's TV magic, and everybody has to be prepared on time to make everything happen for the viewers at home.\n\n\"(But) I personally think that we were held in the stadium a little too long without our clothes on, and there was a little draught in there. I lost all my sweat and body heat,\" Gatlin said.\n\nWhen asked if he thought that contributed to Bolt's injury, the 35-year-old said: \"I believe so.\n\n\"Knowing how Usain performs, he's always ready, he's always making sure he's not injured and it's very rare to see Usain injured when he comes to performances.\"\n\nGatlin ran the second leg for the United States as they finished runners-up behind Britain, who became world champions for the first time.\n\nAmidst the home crowd's jubilation, there was also relief at the sight of Bolt being able to walk off the track after being helped to his feet by his team mates.\n\n\"I'm not sure what the extent of his injury is, but when I saw him go down I thought it was a calf cramp or a hamstring cramp. But he walked off the track, so that's good thing.", "time": "23:55:00"}

"http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4786910/index.html", "body": "Usain Bolt brought the curtain down on his glittering career at the World Championships in London.\n\nThe 30-year-old Jamaican pulled up injured in the 4\u00d7100 metres relay, meaning he finishes with 19 global titles in the greatest career athletics has ever seen.\n\nHere, Press Association Sport takes a look at five of his most memorable moments.\n\nBeijing arrival\n\nUsain Bolt\n\nA 21-year-old Bolt announced himself as track and field's newest superstar with a brilliant world record to win 100m gold at the 2008 Olympics. Fuelled by a diet of chicken nuggets, he clocked 9.69 seconds, despite crossing the line with a shoelace undone and spreading his arms and slapping his chest in celebration before the finish. International Olympic Committee president Jacques Rogge criticised his showboating as disrespectful. No-one agreed.\n\nBerlin brilliance\n\nBolt won the men's 100m final in a new world record time of 9.58 seconds during the IAAF World Championships in Berlin (John Giles/PA)\n\nBolt cemented his status as the world's greatest ever sprinter with two more eye-watering world records over 100m and 200m at the 2009 World Championships. He blazed to 9.58secs in the 100m - the biggest ever improvement in the 100m world record since electronic timing was introduced - and then took 0.11s off his 200m mark too, winning another gold in 19.19.\n\nDaegu disappointment\n\nBolt celebrates winning the men's 200 metres in Daegu, South Korea (Dave Thompson/PA)\n\nBolt's hopes of defending his world 100m title in 2011 were dashed by a dramatic false start in the final. He knew immediately what he had done, ripping his top off in frustration. The mistake was proof he was human after all. His response - gold in the 200m and 4x100m relay - was inevitable and emphatic.\n\n'Legend' in London\n\nBolt kisses his gold medal after winning the men's 100 meters at the 2012 London Olympic Games (Matt Slocum/AP)\n\nBolt arrived at the 2012 Olympics looking to become the first man in history to defend both 100m and 200m titles and, in his words, become a \"legend\" of the sport. He blitzed to 100m glory in 9.63 - the second fastest time in history - and added 200m gold in 19.32. \"I am a living legend,\" Bolt told the world's press afterwards. \"Bask in my glory.\"\n\nThe 'Saviour'\n\nUsain Bolt\n\nAs doping and corruption scandals involving those at the very top of the sport left its credibility shredded, Bolt found himself cast as athletics' 'saviour' in his sprint battles with two-time drug offender Justin Gatlin. The American went into the 2015 World Championships in Beijing with the four fastest times of the year over 100m, but Bolt defied the doubters to pip him to gold when it mattered, winning by just one hundredth of a second. He defeated him too in the 200m and then repeated the feat the following year at the Olympics in Rio.", "time": "17:18:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4_\u00d7_100_metres_relay", "label": {"eng": "4 \u00d7 100 metres relay"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "320499"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolt_(2008_film)", "label": {"eng": "Bolt (2008 film)"}, "score": 5, "type": "wiki", "id": "322557"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relay_race", "label": {"eng": "Relay race"}, "score": 5, "type": "wiki", "id": "332246"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yohan_Blake", "label": {"eng": "Yohan Blake"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "343533"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_World_Championships_in_Athletics", "label": {"eng": "2009 World Championships in Athletics"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "435673"}], "url": "http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/general/athletics/usain-bolt-london-2017-world-athletics-championships-fairy-tale-ending-veered-off-script-a7890791.html", "body": "As fairytale endings go, this was one that certainly forgot to follow the script. For Usain Bolt, these World Championships had been touted as his farewell party; a chance for the eight-time Olympian to sign off his illustrious career in style. But much to the horror of the Jamaican's adoring masses, this was a send-off that ended with red wine on the carpet, smashed plates on the floor and thousands of pounds worth in damages.\n\nEnter culprit No 1: Justin Gatlin. Living up to his villainous billing all too literally, the American gatecrashed the main event with a degree of impertinence that left a bitter aftertaste in the mouth.\n\nWith a single, admonishing finger raised to his lips, having just run the race of his life to claim a third world title and leave Bolt ruminating with bronze, the 35-year-old made a mockery of the sporting narrative that insists virtue and honesty will always triumph over the dark arts.\n\nRead more Jamaica furious over Bolt injury as they blame delays for relay agony\n\nEdging to victory by the smallest of margins last weekend - 0.03 seconds to be precise - Gatlin momentarily reduced a deafening wall of noise to a stunned, stomach-turning silence as the home crowd registered what they had just witnessed.\n\nUp next on the interloper line-up: Great Britain's very own men's relay team. Positioned in the outer lanes at the London Stadium on Saturday night, as Gatlin had been, it was now the turn of the hosts to rip up the script.\n\nPutting together a well-executed combination of changeovers and sprints, GB stormed to victory in 37.47 seconds to claim the nation's first major gold since Athens 2004. It was a victory the British quartet earned and deserved - and not one borne out by the shortcomings of their rivals.\n\nBritain's relay team deserve their success (Getty)\n\nIn contract to the hostile reception it had put on for Gatlin seven days prior, the London crowd embraced its homegrown heroes with a frenzied, gold-induced euphoria.\n\nAs Nathaneel Mitchell-Blake roared with delight after confirmation of victory, London roared back. It had been the 23-year-old, born and raised in the capital, who anchored his team to victory, pipping USA to first place on the finishing line with a well-timed dip of the head. Making the most of their big night, Mitchell-Blake and his team-mates revelled in their new-found status as world champions, lapping up every moment of it.\n\nWhich brings us to the man himself. Having spent the last nine years in defiance of the stopwatch, it seems Father Time has finally caught up with the world's fastest man - as last night all too painfully demonstrated.\n\nBolt was stunned by longtime rival Gatlin in the 100m final (Getty)\n\nStretched out on the track, clutching his hamstring in agony, here was athletics' Goliath in a moment of rare vulnerability, caught like a rabbit in the bright lights of the London Stadium. Offset against the unexpected success of Great Britain's relay team, it was an image that added to the emotional overload of the evening. Struck down on the final straight with 50m to go, Bolt's farewell was brought to a close in agonising fashion.\n\nHis team-mates were left searching for an explanation, and eventually turned to the organisers themselves as they blamed a delay in proceedings for Bolt's injury. \"I think they were holding us too long in the call room,\" Yohan Blake insisted. \"Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me, 'Yohan, I think this is crazy'.\"\n\nBut the painful reality of the matter is that, ultimately, Bolt should never have competed at this year's Championships.\n\nUsain Bolt's best moments 10 show all Usain Bolt's best moments 1/10 Beijing 2008 100m final (9.69 seconds, 2008 Beijing Olympics)\n\nBolt wins his first Olympic gold after destroying the competition in Beijing.\n\nGetty\n\n2/10 Beijing 2008 200m final (19.30 seconds, 2008 Beijing Olympics)\n\nBolt doubles up in China after wining the 200m with a new world record time.\n\nGetty\n\n3/10 Beijing 2008 4x100m final (37.10 seconds, 2008 Beijing Olympics)\n\nThe Jamiacan 4x100m relay team make it a hat-trick in Beijing for Bolt.\n\nGetty\n\n4/10 Berlin 2009 100m final (9.58 seconds 2009 Berlin World Championships)\n\nBold sets a 100m world record of 9.58s at the Berlin World Athletics Championships, a feat that still stands today.\n\nGetty\n\n5/10 Berlin 2009 200m final (19.19 seconds, 2009 Berlin World Championships)\n\nBolt doubles up again with a new world record in the 200m final.\n\nGetty\n\n6/10 London 2012 100m final (9.63 seconds, 2012 London Olympics)\n\nOlympic gold medal No 4 arrives in London with 100m success.\n\nGetty\n\n7/10 London 2012 200m final (19.32 seconds, 2012 London Olympics)\n\nA fifth Olympic gold quickly follows as Bolt wins the 200m.\n\nGetty\n\n8/10 London 2012 4x100m final (36.64 seconds, 2012 London Olympics)\n\nJamaica continue their dominance of men's sprinting with 4x100m relay gold in London.\n\nGetty\n\n9/10 Rio 2016 100m final (9.81 seconds, 2016 Rio Olympics)\n\nDespite fears over his form, Bolt retains his Olympic gold medal in Rio after winning the 100m final.\n\nGetty\n\n10/10 Rio 2016 200m final (19.78 second, Rio 2016 Olympics)\n\nBolt celebrates crossing the line for his eighth Olympic gold in the 200m final\n\nGetty\n\nMake no doubt, the events of the past week barely scratch the surface of the Jamaican's glorious career. After all, this is a man whose charisma, affability and mind-boggling performances on the track injected new life into a sport that, prior to his arrival, was in desperate need of star-studded appeal. Those with the broadest shoulders carry the greatest weight, goes the saying, and Bolt embraced this responsibility with an air of boyish insouciance that has come to embody his career and persona over the years.\n\nAfter the highs of Beijing, London and Rio, coupled with his dominance at the Worlds, the 30-year-old's legend and legacy had long been secured. Why, then, risk ending his career with the disappointment of a missed gold medal or, worse, the ignominy of an unfinished race?\n\nThe Jamaican was carrying the weight of the world on his shoulders (Getty)\n\nAs mosts athlete at the top of their game will attest to, the desire to compete and taste glory can prove infuriatingly addictive. \"I live for competition,\" Bolt said earlier in his career. \"I thrive on competition. I live to compete against the best.\"\n\nBut, in truth, the aim had in fact been to exit centre stage after Rio 2016. \"That was the initial plan [to sign off after Rio],\" he revealed in 2015. \"But my sponsor has asked me to go on for another year; to 2017 and London. But I'll be doing one event, the 100m. I can concentrate on that, and on retiring on a winning note.\"\n\nBolt's admission may have come two years ago before the Beijing World Championships and Rio Games, but it's somewhat uncomfortable to hear that commercial pressure determined the Jamaican's retirement date.\n\nBolt's London finale ended in disappointment (Getty)\n\nOf course, Bolt was not to know that one year on after making these comments he would claim three more gold medals in Brazil - but that should have been the point at which the sprinter called it a day.\n\nA victim of his own success, the truth is that the Jamaican didn't need these Championships. If anything, we needed him. An athlete without parallel in his discipline, and a sportsman who has drawn comparisons with the likes of Mohammed Ali and Pele, the 30-year-old had little to prove this summer.\n\nGatlin's gold may have shaken the sport, while GB's victory reaffirmed our love for it, but this past week will do nothing to diminish Bolt's legend - it was, instead, a timely reminder that he is human after all.\n\nMore about: World Athletics Championships Usain Bolt Justin Gatlin London Stadium Reuse content", "time": "11:42:00"}

"http://news2.onlinenigeria.com/news/general/644302-usain-bolt-by-numbers.html", "body": "Usain Bolt retired from track and field championships after Jamaica in the 4x100m relay at the world championships in London.\n\nUnfortunately there was to be no fairytale as he pulled up and collapsed injured on the track running the anchor leg.\n\nHere AFP Sports looks at his glittering career in numbers.\n\n1 - world bronze, after being beaten in the 100m in London 2017 by Americans Justin Gatlin and Christian Coleman\n\n3 - the number of Olympic treble sprint doubles, in Beijing 2008, London 2012 and Rio 2016. It should have been a treble treble including all three relay titles, but teammate Nesta Carter tested positive for doping in the Chinese capital\n\n4 - times Bolt has been named Laureus World Sportsman of the Year: 2009, 2010, 2013, 2017\n\n5 - the number of sprinters to have beaten Bolt over 100m: Gatlin, Coleman, Jamaica's Asafa Powell, American Tyson Gay and Antigua's Daniel Bailey\n\n6 - times Bolt has won the IAAF Male Athlete of the Year: 2008, 2009, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2016\n\n8 - Olympic gold medals: 100, 200m (2008, 2012, 2016); 4x100m relay (2012, 2016)\n\n9.58 - the world record he set for the 100m at the 2009 worlds in Berlin\n\n9.63 - the second fastest time ever run, when Bolt scorched to 100m gold at the 2008 Beijing Olympics\n\n14 - world medals amassed since making his debut in Helsinki in 2005, when he finished eighth and last in the 200m final\n\n14.35 - the world best Bolt set over 150 metres in Manchester, England, in 2009. He ran the final 100 metres in a startling 8.70sec, the fastest time ever recorded\n\n19 - major global medals\n\n19.19 - the world record he set for the 200m at the 2009 worlds in Berlin\n\n30.97 - his best time over the rarely-run 300m, set in 2010. Only South African Wayde van Niekerk and American Michael Johnson have gone faster\n\n31 - the Jamaican turns 31 on August 21\n\n36.84 - the world record for the 4x100m relay set at the London Olympics, Bolt anchoring a team also comprising Nesta Carter, Michael Frater and Yohan Blake. Bolt had been part of two previous world relay records, in Beijing in 2008 (though this was later voided) and at the 2011 Daegu worlds\n\n37.58 - Bolt's average speed in km/h (23.35mph) in his 100m world record race. Should you subtract his reaction time of 0.15sec, his time is actually 9.43sec, making his average speed 38.18km/h (23.72mph)\n\n41 - the number of strides it took for Bolt to cover the 100m on his record-setting run in the German capital\n\n44.72 - top speed in km/h (27.79mph) reached during his 100m run in Berlin in 2009, between the 60 to 80-metre mark\n\n53 - the number of times Bolt has run sub-10 second 100m races\n\n34.2 million - dollars earned by Bolt last year according to a list of the world's richest sportspeople by Forbes magazine", "time": "00:38:00"}

"http://www.firstpost.com/sports/iaaf-world-championships-2017-justin-gatlin-blames-event-scheduling-for-usain-bolts-hamstring-injury-3926785.html", "body": "London: Justin Gatlin agreed with the complaints of the Jamaican relay team that a long wait before their 4x100m final at the World Championships on Saturday contributed to the injury suffered by Usain Bolt in his last race.\n\nFile image of Justin Gatlin. AFP\n\nBolt, having been passed the baton by Yohan Blake, was in third behind Great Britain and the United States, who eventually won gold and silver, but pulled up almost 50 metres from the line and fell to the track.\n\nJamaica's team doctor later said that the 30-year-old had suffered a hamstring cramp.\n\nBolt's team mates complained that a 45-minute wait in the call room before the race had hampered their preparations.\n\n\"I think they were holding us too long in the call room,\" Blake told reporters. \"Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me 'Yohan, I think this is crazy'. Forty minutes and two medal presentations before our run.\"\n\nGatlin, who beat Bolt to gold in the 100m last Saturday, agreed with the complaints and laid the blame at the television scheduling for the event.\n\n\"I know it's TV magic, and everybody has to be prepared on time to make everything happen for the viewers at home.\n\n\"(But) I personally think that we were held in the stadium a little too long without our clothes on, and there was a little draught in there. I lost all my sweat and body heat,\" Gatlin said.\n\nWhen asked if he thought that contributed to Bolt's injury, the 35-year-old said: \"I believe so.\n\n\"Knowing how Usain performs, he's always ready, he's always making sure he's not injured and it's very rare to see Usain injured when he comes to performances.\"\n\nGatlin ran the second leg for the United States as they finished runners-up behind Britain, who became world champions for the first time.\n\nAmidst the home crowd's jubilation, there was also relief at the sight of Bolt being able to walk off the track after being helped to his feet by his team mates.\n\n\"I'm not sure what the extent of his injury is, but when I saw him go down I thought it was a calf cramp or a hamstring cramp. But he walked off the track, so that's good thing.\n\n\"I hope that he gets well soon,\" Gatlin added.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 13, 2017 06:08 pm | Updated Date: Aug 13, 2017 06:08 pm\n\nTags :#100 metres#4x100m relay#Athletics#Iaaf world championships 2017#Jamaica#Justin gatlin#London#United states#Usain bolt#Yohan blake", "time": "13:00:00"}

"https://www.iol.co.za/sport/athletics/organisers-to-blame-for-bolts-collapse---team-mates-10770327", "body": "LONDON - Usain Bolt's dramatic and inglorious end to his top level career was the fault of world championship organisers, his furious team-mates claimed.\n\nThe 30-year-old 100 metres and 200m world record-holder collapsed on the London Stadium track whilst anchoring Jamaica in the final of the 4x100m on Saturday as cramp gripped his leg.\n\nBolt lay prone on the track but waved away the offer of a wheelchair and eventually, aided by his three team-mates, limped across the line before making a hasty exit -- not the way the man who had won triple Olympic gold at the same stadium in 2012 would have wished his competitive career in championships to finish.\n\nBut his team-mates complained that his problem was caused by organisers keeping the relay teams waiting in the cold before their race as several medal ceremonies were held.\n\n\"I think they were holding us too long in the call room. The walk was too long. Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me, 'Yohan, I think this is crazy. 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run',\" said Yohan Blake, who branded the wait as \"crazy\".\n\n\"We kept warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting,\" added the 2011 100m world champion, who also won Olympic relay gold in 2012 and 2016 with Bolt.\n\n\"I think it got the better of us. We were over warm.\n\n\"To see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggling like that.\n\n\"The race was 10 minutes late and we were kept 40 minutes.\"\n\nThank You my peeps.\n\nInfinite love for you all\u1f64c\u1f3fd\u1f64c\u1f3fd\n\n-- Usain St. Leo Bolt (@usainbolt) August 12, 2017\n\nBolt may not have led Jamaica to a glorious finale anyway, though, as he took the baton well behind eventual winners Great Britain and the US.\n\nBut Jamaica's 110m hurdles world champion Omar McLeod -- who ran the first leg -- likewise pointed the finger at organisers for denying his country's greatest star a more fitting swansong.\n\n\"It's heart wrenching,\" said McLeod, who is also the Olympic champion.\n\n\"It was ridiculous man, we were there around 45 minutes waiting outside, I think they had three medal ceremonies before we went out so we were really trying our hardest to stay warm and keep upbeat.\n\n\"But it was ridiculous. We waited a really long time. I drank like two bottles of water.\"\n\nTheir criticism echoed that of Justin Gatlin, who led an American 1-2 alongside team-mate Christian Coleman to deny Bolt a farewell gold in the individual 100m.\n\n\"I think it was the elements. I am sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" said Gatlin.\n\n\"It was a recipe. I don't want to say this, I understand we need to be ready early, but I think we took our clothes off a little too early.\n\n\"It's a little chilly in here so I think that's where the cramp came from. That's what he suffered with. He was running out there cold.\"\n\nDespite his relatively unsuccessful championships -- in which he will exit with just a single bronze medal -- Bolt will still be accorded a final lap of honour in a tribute ceremony before the curtain comes down on the world championships later on Sunday.\n\nAFP\n\nLike us on Facebook\n\nFollow us on Twitter", "time": "10:04:00"}

"https://www.iol.co.za/sport/athletics/organisers-to-blame-for-bolts-collapse---teammates-10770327", "body": "LONDON - Usain Bolt's dramatic and inglorious end to his top level career was the fault of world championship organisers, his furious teammates claimed.\n\nThe 30-year-old 100 metres and 200m world record-holder collapsed on the London Stadium track whilst anchoring Jamaica in the final of the 4x100m on Saturday as cramp gripped his leg.\n\nBolt lay prone on the track but waved away the offer of a wheelchair and eventually, aided by his three teammates, limped across the line before making a hasty exit -- not the way the man who had won triple Olympic gold at the same stadium in 2012 would have wished his competitive career in championships to finish.\n\nBut his teammates complained that his problem was caused by organisers keeping the relay teams waiting in the cold before their race as several medal ceremonies were held.\n\n\"I think they were holding us too long in the call room. The walk was too long. Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me, 'Yohan, I think this is crazy. 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run',\" said Yohan Blake, who branded the wait as \"crazy\".\n\n\"We kept warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting,\" added the 2011 100m world champion, who also won Olympic relay gold in 2012 and 2016 with Bolt.\n\n\"I think it got the better of us. We were over warm.\n\n\"To see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggling like that.\n\n\"The race was 10 minutes late and we were kept 40 minutes.\"\n\nThank You my peeps.\n\nInfinite love for you all\u1f64c\u1f3fd\u1f64c\u1f3fd\n\n-- Usain St. Leo Bolt (@usainbolt) August 12, 2017\n\nBolt may not have led Jamaica to a glorious finale anyway, though, as he took the baton well behind eventual winners Great Britain and the US.\n\nBut Jamaica's 110m hurdles world champion Omar McLeod -- who ran the first leg -- likewise pointed the finger at organisers for denying his country's greatest star a more fitting swansong.\n\n\"It's heart wrenching,\" said McLeod, who is also the Olympic champion.\n\n\"It was ridiculous man, we were there around 45 minutes waiting outside, I think they had three medal ceremonies before we went out so we were really trying our hardest to stay warm and keep upbeat.\n\n\"But it was ridiculous. We waited a really long time. I drank like two bottles of water.\"\n\nTheir criticism echoed that of Justin Gatlin, who led an American 1-2 alongside team-mate Christian Coleman to deny Bolt a farewell gold in the individual 100m.\n\n\"I think it was the elements. I am sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" said Gatlin.\n\n\"It was a recipe. I don't want to say this, I understand we need to be ready early, but I think we took our clothes off a little too early.\n\n\"It's a little chilly in here so I think that's where the cramp came from. That's what he suffered with. He was running out there cold.\"\n\nDespite his relatively unsuccessful championships -- in which he will exit with just a single bronze medal -- Bolt will still be accorded a final lap of honour in a tribute ceremony before the curtain comes down on the world championships later on Sunday.\n\nAFP\n\nLike us on Facebook\n\nFollow us on Twitter", "time": "10:45:00"}

4x100m final at the World Championships on Saturday contributed to the injury suffered by Usain Bolt in his last race.\n\nBolt, having been passed the baton by Yohan Blake, was in third behind Great Britain and the United States, who eventually won gold and silver, but pulled up almost 50m from the line and fell to the track.\n\nJamaica's team doctor later said that the 30-year-old had suffered a hamstring cramp.\n\nBolt's teammates complained that a 45-minute wait in the call room before the race had hampered their preparations.\n\n\"I think they were holding us too long in the call room,'' Blake told reporters. \"Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me 'Yohan, I think this is crazy. Forty minutes and two medal presentations before our run.''\n\nGatlin, who beat Bolt to gold in the 100m last Saturday, agreed with the complaints and laid the blame at the television scheduling for the event.\n\n\"I know it's TV magic, and everybody has to be prepared on time to make everything happen for the viewers at home.\n\n\"(But) I personally think that we were held in the stadium a little too long without our clothes on, and there was a little draught in there. I lost all my sweat and body heat,'' Gatlin said.\n\nWhen asked if he thought that contributed to Bolt's injury, the 35-year-old said: \"I believe so.\n\n\"Knowing how Usain performs, he's always ready, he's always making sure he's not injured and it's very rare to see Usain injured when he comes to performances.''\n\nGatlin ran the second leg for the United States as they finished runners-up behind Britain, who became world champions for the first time.\n\nAmidst the home crowd's jubilation, there was also relief at the sight of Bolt being able to walk off the track after being helped to his feet by his teammates.\n\n\"I'm not sure what the extent of his injury is, but when I saw him go down I thought it was a calf cramp or a hamstring cramp. But he walked off the track, so that's good thing.", "time": "10:52:00"}

"https://www.independent.co.ug/usain-bolt-numbers/", "body": "London, United Kingdom | AFP | Usain Bolt retired from track and field championships after Jamaica in the 4x100m relay at the world championships in London.\n\nUnfortunately there was to be no fairytale as he pulled up and collapsed injured on the track running the anchor leg.\n\nHere AFP Sports looks at his glittering career in numbers.\n\n1 - world bronze, after being beaten in the 100m in London 2017 by Americans Justin Gatlin and Christian Coleman\n\n3 - the number of Olympic treble sprint doubles, in Beijing 2008, London 2012 and Rio 2016. It should have been a treble treble including all three relay titles, but teammate Nesta Carter tested positive for doping in the Chinese capital\n\n4 - times Bolt has been named Laureus World Sportsman of the Year: 2009, 2010, 2013, 2017\n\n5 - the number of sprinters to have beaten Bolt over 100m: Gatlin, Coleman, Jamaica's Asafa Powell, American Tyson Gay and Antigua's Daniel Bailey\n\n6 - times Bolt has won the IAAF Male Athlete of the Year: 2008, 2009, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2016\n\n9.63 - the second fastest time ever run, when Bolt scorched to 100m gold at the 2008 Beijing Olympics\n\n14 - world medals amassed since making his debut in Helsinki in 2005, when he finished eighth and last in the 200m final\n\n14.35 - the world best Bolt set over 150 metres in Manchester, England, in 2009. He ran the final 100 metres in a startling 8.70sec, the fastest time ever recorded\n\n30.97 - his best time over the rarely-run 300m, set in 2010. Only South African Wayde van Niekerk and American Michael Johnson have gone faster\n\n31 - the Jamaican turns 31 on August 21\n\n36.84 - the world record for the 4x100m relay set at the London Olympics, Bolt anchoring a team also comprising Nesta Carter, Michael Frater and Yohan Blake. Bolt had been part of two previous world relay records, in Beijing in 2008 (though this was later voided) and at the 2011 Daegu worlds\n\n37.58 - Bolt's average speed in km/h (23.35mph) in his 100m world record race. Should you subtract his reaction time of 0.15sec, his time is actually 9.43sec, making his average speed 38.18km/h (23.72mph)\n\n41 - the number of strides it took for Bolt to cover the 100m on his record-setting run in the German capital\n\n44.72 - top speed in km/h (27.79mph) reached during his 100m run in Berlin in 2009, between the 60 to 80-metre mark\n\n53 - the number of times Bolt has run sub-10 second 100m races\n\n34.2 million - dollars earned by Bolt last year according to a list of the world's richest sportspeople by Forbes magazine.", "time": "05:40:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justin_Gatlin", "label": {"eng": "Justin Gatlin"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "320483"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4_\u00d7_100_metres_relay", "https://fansided.com/2017/08/12/usain-bolt-pulls-up-lame-final-race-video/", "body": "Usain Bolt pulled his hamstring during the anchor leg of the 4x100m relay, giving Great Britain the win on their home turf at the IAAF World Championships.\n\nSadly for Usain Bolt, this was not the fairytale ending that he had imagined. What would've been a dream finish turned into a nightmare quickly when Jamiaca's native son suffered a pulled hamstring during his last ever race. In what was billed as his final competition, Bolt lost twice in the space of a week shattering his aura of invincibility.\n\nAfter losing to Justin Gatlin in the individual 100m race, many were hoping that Bolt could make it up by winning his country a gold medal in the relay. But while he at least won a bronze in his first race, he started limping after his first few strides following the changeover.\n\nEven though the crowd got to witness a victory for their home country, Bolt got a bigger reception than them, and most people were watching him with great concern as he was walking around the track with tears.\n\nDespite the sour taste this likely leaves in everyone's mouths, Usain Bolt shouldn't be considered anything less than the GOAT. Realistically, his legacy was already set coming into the World Championships, and he only competed so that he could leave with one last gold medal. But after seeing him struggle throughout the week, he probably should've retired after the Olympics.\n\nIt's easy to say Father Time caught up to Bolt, but he's still only 30 years old. While he probably won't compete in 2020, it's easy to think he'll come out of retirement in order to leave a more lasting image than this. But if he does that, he could end up falling even further out of favor by piling up even more losses to track's future stars.\n\nWhether or not he'll come back is sure to be a hot-button topic in the sports world.", "time": "20:36:00"}

{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asafa_Powell", "label": {"eng": "Asafa Powell"}, "score": 2, "type": "person", "id": "376116"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyson_Gay", "label": {"eng": {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis", "label": {"eng": "Carl Lewis"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "385694"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Greene_(athlete)",
