"http://www.newsandstar.co.uk/news/national/article/Great-Britain-win-gold-in-mens-sprint-relay-as-Usain-Bolt-pulls-up-injured-9d1beed2-8648-459d-88c1-8825d3adaea3-ds", "body": "Great Britain's men pulled off a stunning win in the sprint relay\n\nGreat Britain's men's 4x100 metres relay team claimed a stunning gold medal amid chaotic scenes at the World Championships in London as Usain Bolt's glorious career ended in injury and agony.\n\nThe British quartet of CJ Ujah, Adam Gemili, Danny Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake pipped the United States to gold in a world-leading 37.47 seconds, but only after Bolt had pulled up on his anchor leg and collapsed to the track.\n\nThe USA took silver in 37.52secs and Japan the bronze.\n\n\"This is the best feeling in the world, world champions,\" said Gemili, overlooked for individual selection for the championships.\n\nMitchell-Blake, who had to settle for fourth in the individual 200m, roared with delight at the finish in scenes similar to Mark Lewis-Francis' cries of delight when he crossed the line at the 2004 Athens Olympics to earn Britain sprint relay gold.\n\nThe tale since then for Britain has been one of missed chances and baton blunders. But no more, and the joy amongst the team was evident at the finish.\n\n\"We're world champions, world champions,\" Mitchell-Blake said through tears of happiness.\n\nWhile Britain celebrated, though, there were contrasting emotions for Bolt in the final race of his career.\n\nThe 30-year-old pulled up on the home straight as he sought to chase down the United States and Britain, hobbling for a few strides before falling to the track.\n\nHis team-mates gathered round him and the 19-time global champion was helped to his feet and limped over the line, applauding the crowd as he did so.\n\nIt was a sad way for Bolt to bring the curtain down on the greatest athletics career the world has ever seen, a man who has dominated, delighted and delivered ever since his record-breaking runs and gold medals at the 2008 Olympics.\n\nA golden farewell was what he deserved.\n\nBut last weekend, when Bolt had to settle for 100m bronze and drug cheat Justin Gatlin took his title, was proof enough that sport does not do fairy tales, not even for Bolt.\n\nAs if we needed any further indication that Bolt was special, he is due to perform one final lap of honour round the London Stadium on Sunday night.\n\nAs well as his 100m and 200m world records, he also surely holds the one for most laps of honour performed too.\n\nBut, after four successive sprint relay golds at the World Championships, Jamaica's reign is over.\n\nBritain's winning time, a combination of Ujah's perfect reactions, flawless changeovers and a superbly-timed dip from Mitchell-Blake to cross the line ahead of 100m silver medallist Christian Coleman, was a new national record, erasing the 18-year-old mark of 37.73.\n\n\"An amazing and outstanding performance from that British team,\" Michael Johnson said on BBC Sport.\n\n\"They beat everyone fair and square.\n\n\"They delivered on a night when everyone was here - not necessarily to see this.\n\n\"Adam Gemili was just ridiculous down the back stretch. He opened up a gap that was always going to be hard for anyone to chase down.\"", "time": "22:44:00"}

"1053871"}], "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/sport/2017/08/12/gatlin-convinced-bolt-will-be-back-after-injury-exit/", "body": "Justin Gatlin remains convinced Usain Bolt will return to athletics after injury dramatically ruined his farewell in the 4x100 metres relay final in London on Saturday.\n\nBolt looked set to head into retirement with a record-equalling 15th IAAF World Championships medal but pulled up with an apparent hamstring injury and failed to finish the final leg of the race.\n\nGreat Britain snatched the gold medal from the United States as the 30-year-old lay prone on the track, Christian Coleman beaten to the line by Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake.\n\nGatlin, who beat Coleman and Bolt to 100m gold last weekend, has previously expressed his opinion that his long-time rival will return to the sport in the future and reiterated those thoughts following an unbecoming farewell for the eight-time Olympic champion.\n\n\"He's coming back in a year or two, he'll be ready. He has a passion for the sport, the fans love him, it's something you just can't walk away from that easy,\" said Gatlin.\n\n\"He's a showman, he wants to come out and I think he'll do a great job if he comes back to track and field. We've got a lot of young guys like Coleman, like [Jaylen] Bacon, myself, we're hungry to go out there for good competition.\"\n\nNot the way you want to see a legend like end his #IAAFWorlds career. Heal soon, @usainbolt. -- USATF (@usatf)\n\nAugust 12, 2017\n\nRegardless of whether he returns to the track, Bolt is sure to be remembered as an all-time great - having secured 100m and 200m doubles at three successive Olympic Games as well as setting new world records in each event.\n\n\"You can't really have this night define what he's done in the past,\" Gatlin added. \"From 2008 on, Usain Bolt has done amazing things and tonight is not going to define who he is.\n\n\"He's still the man, and this is farewell so we take our hat off to him, hope he gets well soon.\"\n\nGatlin was one of many competitors who suggested a lengthy wait ahead of Saturday's relay may have contributed to Bolt's injury.\n\n\"We were in the stadium for a while, you guys know how chilly it is down here,\" he said. \"We had a cool breeze in the back and I think with that a lot of our muscles were cramping up from having our clothes off a little too early.\n\n\"Hopefully it's just a cramp and it'll go away, but I hope he doesn't dwell on it.\"", "time": "20:36:00"}

See photosDisney CEO sees a future without Netflix, Comcast or DirecTV\n\nJustin Gatlin agreed with the complaints of the Jamaican relay team that a long wait before their 4x100m final at the World Championships on Saturday contributed to the injury suffered by Usain Bolt in his last race.\n\nBolt, having been passed the baton by Yohan Blake, was in third behind Great Britain and the United States, who eventually won gold and silver, but pulled up almost 50 metres from the line and fell to the track.\n\nJamaica's team doctor later said that the 30-year-old had suffered a hamstring cramp.\n\nBolt's team mates complained that a 45-minute wait in the call room before the race had hampered their preparations.\n\n\"I think they were holding us too long in the call room,\" Blake told reporters. \"Usain was really cold. In fact Usain said to me 'Yohan, I think this is crazy'. Forty minutes and two medal presentations before our run.\"\n\nGatlin, who beat Bolt to gold in the 100m last Saturday, agreed with the complaints and laid the blame at the television scheduling for the event.\n\n\"I know it's TV magic, and everybody has to be prepared on time to make everything happen for the viewers at home. \"(But) I personally think that we were held in the stadium a little too long without our clothes on, and there was a little draught in there. I lost all my sweat and body heat,\" Gatlin said.\n\nWhen asked if he thought that contributed to Bolt's injury, the 35-year-old said: \"I believe so.\n\n\"Knowing how Usain performs, he's always ready, he's always making sure he's not injured and it's very rare to see Usain injured when he comes to performances.\"\n\nGatlin ran the second leg for the United States as they finished runners-up behind Britain, who became world champions for the first time.\n\nAmidst the home crowd's jubilation, there was also relief at the sight of Bolt being able to walk off the track after being helped to his feet by his team mates.\n\n\"I'm not sure what the extent of his injury is, but when I saw him go down I thought it was a calf cramp or a hamstring cramp. But he walked off the track, so that's good thing. \"I hope that he gets well soon,\" Gatlin added.\n\nFor all the latest Sports News, download Indian Express App", "time": "06:29:00"}

the greatest sprinter ever, suffered a hamstring injury, in the concluding race of his career, while on the anchor leg of the 4X100m race at the World Athletics championships in London.\n\nTHEWILL recalls that Bolt, who was hoping to ride off into the sunset with a successful showing at this year's world championships in London, met an unexpected anti-climax when he finished in third place at last week's 100-meter dash final as Justin Gatlin beat him to the title.\n\nOn Saturday, Bolt, 33-year-old, was unable to finish the 4\u00d7100 relay final for his country making it an agonizing end for the former world champion, who has set world records in the 100m and 200m sprints and taken home an astonishing eight Olympic gold medals, 11 World Championship gold medals, with two silver and a bronze medals.\n\nBolt pulled up with an apparent cramp to his left hamstring, limped for a few moments before falling to a heap on the track. His fellow teammates came to his assistance and Bolt eventually was able to get back on his feet and limp off the track.\n\nHe was later assisted by his team-mates to cross the finish line, applauding the crowd as he did so.\n\nThe host country, Great Britain, in a brilliantly executed race by Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Danny Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake, finished first in 37.47 seconds, followed by the United States (37.52) and Japan (38.04).\n\n\"It's a cramp in his left hamstring, but a lot of the pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jamaican team doctor Kevin Jones said.\n\n\"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"", "time": "06:34:00"}

"1417682"}], "url": "http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ians/injured-bolt-crashes-out-in-men-s-relay-117081300294_1.html", "body": "Jamaican superstar Usain Bolt suffered a injury midway into his anchor leg of the men's 4x100 meters relay and pulled out of the last race of career at the World Athletics Championships here.\n\nBolt, who had suffered his first 100m defeat in nine years on August 5, apparently had a pulled a muscle in his leg only 30 meters into the race on Saturday night. He limped to the finish line in agony, Xinhua news agency reported.\n\nBolt had only taken a few strides when he appeared to suffer an injury to his left leg and fell to the track in pain. He stayed down for a couple of minutes before standing up and walking to the finish line.\n\nBritain won the gold in 37.47 seconds, the US took silver in 37.52 and Japan was third in 38.04.\n\nChina, the silver medalist two years ago, finished fourth in 38.34.\n\nThe British team of Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Danny Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake broke a European record that had stood since 1999, Efe news reported.\n\nBolt, who had announced prior to the World Athletics Championships that it would be his last major competition, is one of the all-time legends of track and field.\n\nHe first burst on the scene with his performance at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, where he set new world records in winning both the 100-meter and 200-meter finals.\n\nBolt then lost virtually no race of consequence for nine years, the lone exception coming when he was disqualified for a false start at the 100-meter final at the 2011 World Championships in Daegu, South Korea.\n\nBut time finally caught up with the 30-year-old Jamaican at his final event, in which he finished third in the 100 meters last Saturday and then was unable to finish his final race.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Business Standard staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "time": "09:21:00"}

track and field championships came on Saturday night as Usain Bolt lay face down on the track and in great pain.\n\nAfter taking the baton from his teammate Yohan Blake to run the anchor leg of Jamaica's 4-x-100-meter men's relay, Bolt began to gather speed only to pull up and shout in pain from what appeared to be a left leg injury about 60 meters from the finish line.\n\nIt was hardly the farewell party that Bolt, the greatest sprinter in history, had in mind when he decided to make this meet the last of his career.\n\nHis apparent injury would normally have cast a pall over the rest of the race, but it has been a frustrating meet for Britain, the host country. And with Bolt on the ground and the Jamaicans out of contention, the gold came down to a sprint for the finish between Christian Coleman of the United States and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake of Britain.\n\nBritain won by five one-hundredths of a second, finishing in 37.47 seconds to the Americans' 37.52. As the official results flashed on the big screen, the crowd cheered wildly for Britain's second gold medal of these championships.\n\nMeanwhile, Bolt's teammates rushed to help him as he lay on the track.", "time": "21:44:00"}

"body": "By Mitch Phillips\n\nLONDON, Aug 12 (Reuters) - Usain Bolt's final appearance on the track ended in agony on Saturday as he pulled up injured running the final leg of the World Championships 4x100 metres relay as Britain beat the United States for a shock gold medal.\n\nBolt, who had to settle for bronze in the individual 100 metres, had been hoping to sign off from the sport by leading Jamaica to a fifth successive relay gold but they were already struggling in third when he collected the baton.\n\nAs he tried to gain ground, Bolt pulled up and fell to the floor with what looked like a hamstring injury.\n\nThe United States, with individual gold and silver medallists Justin Gatlin and Christian Coleman running the second and fourth legs, had been expected to push the Jamaicans all the way.\n\nInstead, a brilliantly executed race by Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Danny Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake gave Britain gold in 37.47 seconds, the best time in the world this year.\n\nThe US took silver in 37.52 with Japan third in 38.04. team deliver Britain's third medal of the World Championships\n\nBritain were leading and as he set off in pursuit he pulled up with what appeared to be a hamstring injury. "London, Aug 13 (IANS) Jamaican superstar Usain Bolt suffered a injury midway into his anchor leg of the men's 4x100 meters relay and pulled out of the last race of career at the World Athletics Championships here.\n\nBolt, who had suffered his first 100m defeat in nine years on August 5, apparently had a pulled a muscle in his leg only 30 meters into the race on Saturday night. He limped to the finish line in agony, Xinhua news agency reported.\n\nBolt had only taken a few strides when he appeared to suffer an injury to his left leg and fell to the track in pain. He stayed down for a couple of minutes before standing up and walking to the finish line.\n\nBritain won the gold in 37.47 seconds, the US took silver in 37.52 and Japan was third in 38.04.\n\nChina, the silver medalist two years ago, finished fourth in 38.34.\n\nThe British team of Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Danny Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake broke a European record that had stood since 1999, Efe news reported.\n\nBolt, who had announced prior to the World Athletics Championships that it would be his last major competition, is one of the all-time legends of track and field.\n\nHe first burst on the scene with his performance at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, where he set new world records in winning both the 100-meter and 200-meter finals.\n\nBolt then lost virtually no race of consequence for nine years, the lone exception coming when he was disqualified for a false start at the 100-meter final at the 2011 World Championships in Daegu, South Korea.\n\nBut time finally caught up with the 30-year-old Jamaican at his final event, in which he finished third in the 100 meters last Saturday and then was unable to finish his final race.\n\n--IANS\n\najb/pgh/\n\nSEARCH", "time": "09:28:00"}

"1053871"}], "url": "http://gearsofbiz.com/the-anomaly-known-as-usain-bolt/7601", "body": "The Jamaican sprint king creates a void that the athletics world is desperate to fill.\n\nWhen you think of #Track And Field, no name epitomizes the sport greater than Usain Bolt. A man gifted with unimaginable talent, the likes of which the world has never seen before. On 13th of August, 2017, Bolt will run his last competitive race at the 2017 World Championships as he calls time on an illustrious career. He will don the Jamaican colors one last time as he runs the 4 x 100 meter relay.\n\nBolt has ruled the world of track and field for almost 10 years. His breathtaking performances in Beijing catapulted him into the history books. In a 100 meter race, which usually lasts a shy under 10 seconds, it's just not fair that he can open up a 5 meter lead over his nearest opponent and start to showboat before he crosses the finish line.\n\nSuch was the extent of his God given ability and his nearest rival usually finished meters behind.\n\nBarring the one false start in Daegu in 2011 during the World Championships, Bolt's career has hardly had a single blemish. We live in an era where it's probably easier now than ever to source and consume performance enhancing drugs. It's also probably easier now than ever to get caught consuming them. Bolt however would have none of it. Who does he have to beat other thank himself?\n\nDoping in athletics rampant even at the grass root level. Young athletes are resorting to ingenious ways to abuse performance enhancing substances just to secure a college scholarship. The list of banned substances is only getting bigger and bigger. So, it's not uncommon for an athlete to consume a 'prescription drug' that is also a performance enhancer.\n\nSome athletes have consumed substances that they did not know where banned while others have been victim to sabotage by having their meals spiked.\n\nYet, not one single formal drug related accusation was thrown at Bolt. Ask any track and field athlete and they'll tell you how hard that is. Not only did he maintain a clean reputation, he also undid some of the damage his predecessors did by producing one breathtaking performance after another. While the sport is far from being clean, Bolt did what one #Usain Bolt could do. Unfortunately for athletics, it may never see another Usain Bolt.\n\nHowever, when it comes to competition, Bolt's presence surely brought about a sense of imbalance. Some say that we live in the 'Golden Age' of sprinting. Athletics is blessed to have the likes of #Justin Gatlin, Tyson Gay, Asafa Powell, and of course Bolt's training partner, Yohan Blake all running in the same era. All these athletes have two things in common.\n\n1) Wishing they did not run in the same era as Bolt and 2) a drug charge! Barring Blake, all of these sprinters have held the World 100 meter record at some point. Did Bolt raise the bar to a degree where it's just not humanly possible to compete? Yes he did!\n\nThough sporting fans around the world are mourning the retirement of the legend, several sprinters are undoubtedly happy to bid the legend farewell. Whenever Bolt laced up his boots, you knew he was going to win. His opponents knew he was going to win. The spotlight was always on him and hardly ever on the athlete that came in second. Even when bolt didn't win, the cameras were always on him after the race.\n\nWithout Bolt; Powell, Gay, Gatlin and Blake could have been much bigger stars than they are now. Bolt raised the competition that made these athletes look sub-standard. They couldn't beat Bolt even on their best day. The writing was always on the wall when Bolt ran the field and for this very reason, I believe several sprinters around the world are happy to see him off. It's almost like Bolt's retirement has shifted the balance in favor of other sprinters and in a lot of ways, made the sport unpredictable.\n\nThe track and field world will forever be indebted to Bolt for bringing the spotlight back on the sport. The sport has always been in the news for all of the wrong reasons. Constantly being plagued with charges of drug abuse, the sport needed a larger than life, insanely talented and highly charismatic \"clean\" athlete to lift the sport from shambles. The boos that Justin Gatlin had to endure on winning Bolt's final race is testimony to the fact that the world is not ready to forgive him.\n\nBolt entered the sport at the right time. He gave the sport hope. He gave other athletes hope. He gave the tiny island nation of Jamaica more than they could have ever expected. He single-handedly did what nobody else before him was able to do. The world will be eager to watch him strike his lightning bolt celebratory pose as he's ready to take center stage this week one last time.", "time": "22:36:00"}

appearing to pull a hamstring and falling to the ground as he failed to finish.\n\nWhile the Jamaican lay prone, it was Britain who crossed the line first in a world-leading time of 37.47 seconds, the US - booed upon entry with 100m champion Justin Gatlin on the second leg - second with 37.52secs and Japan taking the bronze.\n\nThe crocked Bolt was soon joined by his team-mates Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, who helped him to his feet and across the line before departing down the tunnel.\n\nRather than bemoaning a far from fitting end to the 30-year-old's distinguished career, the Bolt misses out on matching Allyson Felix's record World Championships medal haul of 15, sending him into retirement in disappointing fashion.\n\nMcLeod got Jamaica off to a good start, but Gatlin helped close the gap on the back straight.\n\nHowever, Blake - who missed out on a medal in the 100m, failed to make the 200m final and was an injury doubt in the hours leading up to the race - was overtaken around the bench by Jaylen Bacon and Daniel Talbot.\n\nThe US were joined in a battle for first by Britain, and Mitchell-Blake showed sensational pace to get to the line first, with Bolt pulling up before dropping to the deck.\n\nSource: Yui Mok\n\nThe Jamaican left the track with a wave, but largely unnoticed as London Stadium celebrated what had appeared an unlikely gold and the claims gold at world championships\n\nBolt set off on the final leg behind the United States' Christian Coleman and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake of Great Britain and pushed too hard to reach the front, US - booed upon entry with 100m champion Justin Gatlin on the second leg - second with 37.52secs and Japan taking the bronze.\n\nThe crocked Bolt was soon joined by his team-mates Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, who helped him to his feet and across the line before departing down the tunnel.\n\nRather than bemoaning a far from fitting end to the 30-year-old's distinguished career, the medal haul of 15, sending him into retirement in disappointing fashion.\n\nMcLeod got Jamaica off to a good start, but Gatlin helped close the gap on the back straight.\n\nHowever, Blake - who missed out on a medal in the 100m, failed to make the 200m final and was an injury doubt in the hours leading up to the race - was overtaken around the bend by Jaylen Bacon and Daniel Talbot.\n\nThe US were joined in a battle for first by Britain, and Mitchell-Blake showed sensational pace to get to the line first, with Bolt pulling up before dropping to the deck.\n\nThe Jamaican left the track with a "http://www.ctvnews.ca/sports/usain-bolt-ends-record-breaking-career-with-injury-1.3543456", "body": "LONDON -- Usain Bolt ended his stellar career in excruciating pain.\n\nThe Jamaican great crumpled to the track with a left-leg injury as he was chasing a final gold medal for the Jamaican 4x100-meter relay team on Saturday at the world championships.\n\nHaving to make up lots of ground on the anchor leg, Bolt suddenly screamed and stumbled as he came down with his golden farewell shattered by the first injury he has experienced at a major competition.\n\nThat wasn't the only surprise. Britain went on to beat the United States in a tight finish.\n\nThe 60,000-capacity stadium was primed for one last Bolt show, one last \"To the World\" pose after a victory, but the injury made it blatantly clear why Bolt is ready to retire. His body can no longer hold up.\n\nHis teammates on the once-fabled Jamaican sprint squad were far from unmatchable, too. Bolt had just too much to make up in the final 100 metres as both Britain and the United States were ahead and even Japan was even.\n\nAs Bolt fell to the ground, the leg with the golden shoe giving way, the crowd still went wild because the home team went on to win gold in 37.47 seconds, .05 seconds ahead of the United States.\n\nIt was yet another amazing upset in a championship of so many.\n\nBefore Bolt came onto the track, he was consoling Mo Farah, his long-distance equivalent who had just lost his first major race since 2011 when he failed to get gold in the 5,000 metres.\n\nFarah also was bidding farewell to the track, coming up short of his fifth straight 5,000-10,000 double at major championships in a sprint against Muktar Edris Ethiopia.\n\n\"I gave it all,\" Farah said. \"I didn't have a single bit left at the end.\"\n\nInstead, Tori Bowie was the unlikely first double gold medallist at the championships, anchoring the U.S. team to the 4x100-meter relay title ahead of Britain and Jamaica.\n\nAt the same time, Allyson Felix, running the second leg on the winning team, earned a record 15th medal at the world championships in a career going back to 2005.\n\nBowie, who won the 100 metres this week, ran a strong anchor leg, leaving behind the opposition to finish in 41.82 seconds.\n\n\"Two gold medals is amazing for me,\" Bowie said. \"We are on top of the world.\"\n\nBritain took silver in 42.12 and two-time defending champion Jamaica earned bronze in 42.19.\n\nIf Bolt and Farah were about farewells, the decathlon was about renewal in the wake of the retirement of two-time Olympic and world champion Ashton Eaton. And Kevin Mayer is the new \"world's greatest athlete.\"\n\nThe Frenchman produced a dominant performance over two days and 10 events, ending with a celebratory 1,500 metres.\n\nMayer won with 8,768 points. Rico Freimuth took silver with 8,564 points, while German teammate Kai Kazmirek was third with 8,488.\n\nMayer is the first Frenchman to win the title. He had only one scare during the two days of competition -- when he scaled his opening mark of 5.10 metres in the pole vault on his third and last attempt.\n\nJohannes Vetter of Germany won the javelin title with an opening throw of 89.89 metres. The German beat Jakub Vadlejch of the Czech Republic by 16 centimetres. Another Czech, Petr Frydrych, took bronze with a last throw of 88.32 metres.\n\nIn the high jump, Mariya Lasitskene of Russia cleared 2.03 metres to win ahead of Yulia Levchenko of Ukraine and Kamila Licwinko of Poland.\n\nThere was at least one veteran who did produce Saturday as Sally Pearson got another gold medal at the Olympic Stadium in London after missing much of the past two seasons because of injury.\n\nFive years after winning the 100-meter hurdles at the London Games, Pearson won the world title in 12.59 seconds.\n\nDawn Harper-Nelson of the United States was second, .04 seconds behind, and Pamela Dutiewicz of Germany took bronze in 12.72.", "time": "22:10:00"}

"http://zeenews.india.com/other-sports/iaaf-world-championships-usain-bolt-mo-farah-perfect-swansong-ends-in-dismay-2032516.html", "body": "New Delhi: It was an end of an era. And an end it did see. But in such a way, probably none had expected. Two legends, two race...two heartbreaks! Two greatest sprinters of the generation, Usain Bolt and Mo Farah were denied a perfect swansong with both ending in dismay. But the one that Bolt faced, was beyond the wildest dreams of any athletics or even a sports lover. The Jamaican sprinter limped out with a cram on his left hamstring as the team failed to finish the 4X100 metre relay.\n\nIt was 8:20 into the night. The London crowd at the Olympics stadium waited in anticipation for their hero. Mo Farah was all geared up for his final race of his career - 5000 metres race. Having previously won the 10,000 metres race in London, a few days earlier, Farah was definitely the favourite. Not because of the English crowd, well he had history to back himself up.\n\nSix years of dominance in the long distance track with 10 global titles and four double golds (10,000 and the 5000 metres race). He had clinched the double in the 2012 London Olympics and successfully defended it in Rio 2016, becoming the second person to do so and had emulated the same in the World Championships too. Apart from that he also has an unbroken streak - 5000m in 2011, the 10,000m in 2017 and the double in 2012, 2013, 2015 and 2016. The streak was yet to be broken and he was defending it yesterday in front of his nation, for one final time.\n\nBut 56,000 sports fans present at the Olympics Stadium stood in absolute astonishment as the 34-year-old dropped down in tears. He finished second. For the first time in six years. Mo Farah, who was aiming for a mythical 'quintuple-double' at home was shocked by young Ethiopian Muktar Edris. While the former champion finished with 13:33.22 on the clock, Muktar timed 13:32.79.\n\nWATCH: Usain Bolt limps out with cramp in final race of his career at IAAF World Championships\n\n\"I had tears in my eyes,\" he said after the race. \"Never had that before.\n\n\"I felt, 'Wow'. It's been an amazing journey. To achieve what I have achieved through the years has been incredible.\n\n\"And to end it in London, what a way. This is where it all started and I got little emotional because I look at my family, I look at what I've done and it gets to you because, at the end of the day, I'm just a human.\"\n\nThe London crowd had one last hope left in them. Another legend loosened himself up for his final, final race. They were once left traumatised when Bolt finished third in the 100 metres final, for the first time in his career at Worlds stage. But fans had ample hope and so did Usain Bolt that he would give his swansong a glittering goodbye.\n\nREAD: Bolt from the blue - The journey from Jamaica to his Olympic three-peat\n\nBang! Went the gun shot as the sprinters soared off their starting blocks. Great Britain took off with real pace, the Japanese followed behind. But the Jamaicans were slowly catching up. Yohan Blake blazed away to pass the baton to his final teammate, Bolt.\n\nGreat Britain was still leading then, followed by the Americans and the Jamaican team. Bolt clutched onto the baton and took off. Another sluggish start, but made an effort to tune up his speed. And just when it seemed he was catching up the hosts, he limped down the track as he had pulled a cramp on his left hamstring, sat down agonising in pain as Great Britain roared away with the gold. The team USA finished second, followed by Japan. Bolt sat there, tears rolled down his eyes as his teammates ran to console him.\n\nJamaica finished the night with DNF written beside their name. It was for the first time since their shot to dominance in 2008. Afterward, there were a lot of speculations made as to what lead to this heartbreaking moment and IAAF seemed to be at blame. Waiting. Warming up. Waiting. Warming up. It just should not happen. To have your champion go out like that, it's crazy.\"\n\nThe all these....they do remind people of some past events. since then for Britain has been one of missed chances and baton blunders. But no more, and the joy amongst the team was evident at the finish.\n\n\"We're world champions, world champions,\" Mitchell-Blake said through tears of happiness.\n\nWhile Britain celebrated, though, there were contrasting emotions for Bolt in the final race of his career.\n\nThe 30-year-old pulled up on the home straight as he sought to chase down the United States and Britain, hobbling for a few strides before falling to the track.\n\nHis team-mates gathered round him and the 19-time global champion was helped to his feet and limped over the line, applauding the crowd as he did so.\n\nIt was a sad way for Bolt to bring the curtain down on the greatest athletics career the world has ever seen, a man who has dominated, delighted and delivered ever since his record-breaking runs and gold medals at the 2008 Olympics.\n\nA golden farewell was what he deserved.\n\nBut last weekend, when Bolt had to settle for 100m bronze and drug cheat Justin Gatlin took his title, was proof enough that sport does not do fairy tales, not even for Bolt.\n\nElsewhere, Mo Farah missed out on his dream double after coming second in the 5000 metres at the World Championships.\n\nThe four-time Olympic champion failed to mount a third defence of the 5000m as Ethiopia's Muktar Edris claimed gold in London.\n\nFarah had already won the 10,000m last week.\n\nFarah, who had not lost a final in 2,176 days, having also won the 10,000m and 5,000m at the 2013 and 2015 World Championships, crossed the line in 13 minutes 33.22 seconds.\n\nBut he was defeated after failing to mount a recovery in the last 200m in a frantic sprint finish.\n\nEdris finished in 13mins 32.79secs, with the United States' Paul Chelimo third.\n\nAn emotional Farah collapsed on the track after the race and appeared almost inconsolable as he held his arms over his face.", "time": "22:01:00"}

"http://at.theaustralian.com.au/link/d0362877b944eb91ed31d44121d8445e?domain=theaustralian.com.au", "body": "In the most dramatic bookend to the most illustrious career Usain Bolt has pulled a hamstring in his final race, just 21 strides into the final leg of the World Championship 4x100m relay.\n\nIn one of the saddest scenes seen at the London Stadium, Bolt appeared in trouble about 40m after receiving the baton - just as he sought to accelerate and try to catch the British runner Nathaneel Mitchell-Blake and American runner Christian Coleman who were just ahead of him. But by the 50m mark he suddenly hopped in agony, screaming ''oh f...k'' and then collapsing to the track. After officials raced to his assistance, including one with a wheelchair, Bolt eventually got up, and in some pain hobbled across the finish line.\n\nNo one was anticipating such a excruciatingly painful goodbye to Bolt's international athletics career, which has left the global track and field community with a huge void to fill.\n\nBefore the race Bolt was in a jovial mood, boxing with the Championship mascot Hero the Hedgehog in the warmup room, and then emerging onto the track to a standing ovation. With a pre-planned shoulder roll with his team, he warmed up down the home straight, waving and cheering and clapping to the crowd. The moment was a little overwhelming, even for Bolt, as he realised this was it: his final sprint on the biggest of stages, but he wasn't to know he would end up in the medical room, rather than on a farewell lap of the stadium.\n\nYet the mood in the stadium, while stunned at Bolt's injury, turned to joy as the British team won the gold medal ahead of the United States. Japan won the bronze.\n\nThe capacity crowd of 55,000 also roared for Bolt, this time in a chorus of gratefulness, thanks and a huge dollop of sadness.\n\nBolt seared himself onto the consciousness of the world when his braggadocio antics and playful enthusiasm at the Beijing 2008 Olympic Games elevated him well beyond being the fastest man in the world. He continued to dominate the sprints - only a failed drug test by a relay team mate ultimately denied him the triple triple Olympic golds across the 100m,200m and 4x100m relay. Many have commented that Bolt stayed a year too long: that he should have retired at the Rio Olympics, but he had always committed to the London 2017 organisers that he would support their event and he wanted to return to the Olympic track where the crowds had given him so much love.\n\nBolt would often train in the south-west London, not far from the home of his agent Ricky Sims, and Both has long appreciated that the locals would leave him alone.\n\nEven now Bolt is linked to the successful Nitro Athletics in Australia and is likely to make a guest appearance at next year's series, perhaps in the relay, or in one of the odd distances. That decision may hinge on how much partying he enjoys in his retirement, or if his intent to take up professional football is a serious one.\n\nBolt wanted to retire as unbeatable - and while his bronze here from the 100m and his hobble in the relay was not the farewell he intended, he can be comforted that he will remain unbeatable as athletics' personality and his numerous records will stand for some time.\n\nHis 100m (9.58s) and 200m (19.19s) world records, set four days apart in Berlin in 2009 remains the zenith of the sport, and well beyond the gravitational pull of the current generation of sprinters.\n\nIn the past week the winning times in the sprints have been so slow the historians have had to go back 14 or 15 years to find comparable victory efforts.\n\nThe South African Wayde Van Niekerk is being promoted as his heir apparent, but he is too retiring, too sensitive and not nearly tough enough, or indeed talented enough, to consume the track in the way Bolt did.\n\nIn any case, such lofty promotion is something that will occur organically, despite the desperate efforts of athletics officials.\n\nThat point was rammed home when the 5000m send off for local hero Mo Farah was ruined by Ethiopian Mutkar Edris. Farah will compete in the Zurich Diamond League next month and then concentrate solely on marathons.\n\nIn the race, largely expected to be a procession for Farah, Edris took off from afar with his compatriot Yomif Kejelcha. Despite a desperate sprint finish Farah was unable to haul Edris back, claiming o have been boxed in, although the inside track opened up for him in the last 60m.\n\n''I gave 110 per cent. I don't think there was anything more I could have done,'' said Farah, 34, as he lost his first major race since 2011, before adding: ''They worked as a team. The better man won.''\n\nEdris, 23, won in 13minutes 32.79secs, with Farah 13minutes 33.22secs and Paul Chelimo picking the bronze in 13minutes 33.30secs.\n\n\"I was highly prepared for this race and I knew I was going to beat Mo Farah. After the 10km he was maybe tired so he did not have enough for the last kick. I was stronger.'' he said.\n\nAustralia's Patrick Tiernan had tried to force the pace and disrupt Farah's well honed late sprinting tactics, leading for three laps, but he couldn't match the final pace and faded to 11th in 13minutes 40.01secs.\n\nFor the first time in the Championships the IAAF anthem was played as defending world champion Maria Lasitkene won the high jump with 2.03m, not representing Russia, but competing as a neutral athlete.\n\nIn the womens 4x100m, world 100m champion Torrie Bowie took three grabs at the final changeover and was close to being disqualified, but she successfully anchored the victorious United States team in 41.82sec ahead of Great Britain and Northern Ireland 42.12sec and Jamaica 42.19sec.", "time": "22:19:00"}

{"eng": "Kai Kazmirek"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1340986"}], "url": "http://nationalpost.com/pmn/sports-pmn/bolt-farah-take-to-the-track-1-more-time-at-worlds/wcm/3167a695-2578-4c36-997b-34f83acac802", "body": "LONDON -- Usain Bolt ended his stellar career in excruciating pain.\n\nThe Jamaican great crumpled to the track with a left-leg injury as he was chasing a final gold medal for the Jamaican 4\u00d7100-meter relay team on Saturday at the world championships.\n\nHaving to make up lots of ground on the anchor leg, Bolt suddenly screamed and stumbled as he came down with his golden farewell shattered by the first injury he has experienced at a major competition.\n\nThat wasn't the only surprise. Britain went on to beat the United States in a tight finish.\n\nThe 60,000-capacity stadium was primed for one last Bolt show, one last \"To the World\" pose after a victory, but the injury made it blatantly clear why Bolt is ready to retire. His body can no longer hold up.\n\nHis teammates on the once-fabled Jamaican sprint squad were far from unmatchable, too. Bolt had just too much to make up in the final 100 metres as both Britain and the United States were ahead and even Japan was even.\n\nAs Bolt fell to the ground, the leg with the golden shoe giving way, the crowd still went wild because the home team went on to win gold in 37.47 seconds, .05 seconds ahead of the United States.\n\nIt was yet another amazing upset in a championship of so many.\n\nBefore Bolt came onto the track, he was consoling Mo Farah, his long-distance equivalent who had just lost his first major race since 2011 when he failed to get gold in the 5,000 metres.\n\nFarah also was bidding farewell to the track, coming up short of his fifth straight 5,000-10,000 double at major championships in a sprint against Muktar Edris Ethiopia.\n\n\"I gave it all,\" Farah said. \"I didn't have a single bit left at the end.\"\n\nInstead, Tori Bowie was the unlikely first double gold medallist at the championships, anchoring the U.S. team to the 4\u00d7100-meter relay title ahead of Britain and Jamaica.\n\nAt the same time, Allyson Felix, running the second leg on the winning team, earned a record 15th medal at the world championships in a career going back to 2005.\n\nBowie, who won the 100 metres this week, ran a strong anchor leg, leaving behind the opposition to finish in 41.82 seconds.\n\n\"Two gold medals is amazing for me,\" Bowie said. \"We are on top of the world.\"\n\nBritain took silver in 42.12 and two-time defending champion Jamaica earned bronze in 42.19.\n\nIf Bolt and Farah were about farewells, the decathlon was about renewal in the wake of the retirement of two-time Olympic and world champion Ashton Eaton. And Kevin Mayer is the new \"world's greatest athlete.\"\n\nThe Frenchman produced a dominant performance over two days and 10 events, ending with a celebratory 1,500 metres.\n\nMayer won with 8,768 points. Rico Freimuth took silver with 8,564 points, while German teammate Kai Kazmirek was third with 8,488.\n\nMayer is the first Frenchman to win the title. He had only one scare during the two days of competition -- when he scaled his opening mark of 5.10 metres in the pole vault on his third and last attempt.\n\nJohannes Vetter of Germany won the javelin title with an opening throw of 89.89 metres. The German beat Jakub Vadlejch of the Czech Republic by 16 centimetres. Another Czech, Petr Frydrych, took bronze with a last throw of 88.32 metres.\n\nIn the high jump, Mariya Lasitskene of Russia cleared 2.03 metres to win ahead of Yulia Levchenko of Ukraine and Kamila Licwinko of Poland.\n\nThere was at least one veteran who did produce Saturday as Sally Pearson got another gold medal at the Olympic Stadium in London after missing much of the past two seasons because of injury.\n\nFive years after winning the 100-meter hurdles at the London Games, Pearson won the world title in 12.59 seconds.\n\nDawn Harper-Nelson of the United States was second, .04 seconds behind, and Pamela Dutiewicz of Germany took bronze in 12.72.\n\n-- --\n\nMore AP track coverage: https://www.apnews.com/tag/London2017", "time": "21:51:00"}

The man considered the greatest sprinter of all time will run his last race as part of the 2017 IAAF World Championships. He'll join his fellow countrymen to run as part of the 4x100m relay team. After a heartbreaking finish to his last solo race, this is his last chance to go out on a high note. Will he do it? Fans better watch, as this will be the final time to see \"Lightning Bolt\" in action.\n\nIt was his first loss in over ten years, but Usain watched as the gold medal in the 100m slipped through his fingers on Aug. 6. While racing for his 12th World Championship, the man favored to win came in third place, behind second-place Christian Coleman and race winner, Justin Gatlin. Justin's time of 9.92 seconds was still .34 seconds slower than the world record, set by - you guessed it - Usain Bolt. Christian barely beat Usain, finishing at 9.94, a .01 faster than Bolt's 9.95.\n\n\"It's well-deserved. "http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/sports/2017/08/13/britain-stuns-us-to-win-4x100-metres-relay/", "body": "Bolt's final race ends in agony as he suffers a possible hamstring injury.\n\nLONDON: Usain Bolt's final appearance on the track ended in agony on Saturday as he pulled up injured running the final leg of the World Championships 4\u00d7100 metres relay as Britain stunned the United States to win a shock gold medal.\n\nBolt, who had to settle for bronze in the individual 100 metres, had been hoping to sign off from the sport by leading Jamaica to a fifth successive relay gold but they were struggling in third place when he collected the baton.\n\nAs he tried to gain ground, Bolt pulled up and fell to the floor with what looked like a hamstring injury.\n\nThe 60,000 in the stadium who had come to mark the farewell sport's greatest showman had only a split second to absorb what was happening as up ahead a new chapter was being written.\n\nThe US, with individual gold and silver medallists Justin Gatlin and Christian Coleman running the second and fourth legs, had been expected to push the Jamaicans all the way but they were always trailing the slick Britons.\n\nThe brilliantly executed race by Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Danny Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake gave Britain gold in 37.47 seconds, breaking an 18-year-old national record, and the world title for the first time.\n\n\"I wasn't sure if I had won or not, I gave it my all but I could see Christian Coleman out of the corner of my eye,\" said Mitchell-Blake.\n\n\"The feeling of euphoria was from infinity. I can't register it. We smashed the British record to pieces.\"\n\nBritain's only other men's global sprint relay golds came in the 1912 and 2004 Olympics.\n\nIt completed a great night for the host nation's sprinters after their women had earlier taken silver behind the Americans in the sprint relay, their best performance since the first championships in 1983.\n\nThe US men took silver in 37.52 but for a nation that used to be totally dominant in the event, it was only their second medal in the last eight global finals after a series of world championship and Olympic disqualifications. Japan took advantage of Jamaica's travails to take third in 38.04.", "time": "23:38:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mo_Farah", "label": {"eng": "Mo Farah"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "338647"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beijing_National_Stadium", "label": {"eng": "Beijing National Stadium"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "339491"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yohan_Blake", "label": {"eng": "Yohan Blake"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "343533"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_world_records_in_athletics", "label": {"eng": "List of world records in athletics"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "394893"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muktar_Edris", "label": {"eng": "Muktar Edris"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "709359"}], "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/aug/13/greatness-usain-bolt-burnished-injury-final-appearance", "body": "Usain Bolt, who has captivated our attention for nine years, hobbled over the finish line with a pulled hamstring in the 4x100m and won't thank the IAAF\n\nThis is how it ends then, with Usain Bolt face down on the track, 10 metres out from the finish line. Just when you wondered whether Bolt was going to accelerate counter-clockwise around the earth to reverse time, or announce that he had to return to his home planet and then fly off into the night sky, or disappear with the princess into the happily-ever-after, all the dragons dead behind him, he gave us a last reminder that he's only human after all. His hamstring went before he'd made it halfway home. He slowed to a halt while the field sped past him, then stumbled into a roll. It meant he crossed the line alone, and last. His first world championship final, in the 200m in 2005, finished the very same way.\n\nAfter the race, Bolt's three Jamaican team-mates all spoke about how long they had been made to wait in the call room before the race. Yohan Blake, Bolt's friend and training partner, was furious, Omar McLeod distraught. \"Ridiculous\" was the word he used. After all the buildup, the International Assocation of Athletics Federations somehow managed to bungle Bolt's farewell to the sport. The relay runners were made to wait 45 minutes backstage, while everyone in the stadium sat through the medal ceremonies and anthems for the men's 5,000m and the women's high jump. At this point, you wouldn't trust the IAAF's officials to fire a start gun without shooting themselves in the foot.\n\nPart of the reason Bolt was made to wait so long was because Mo Farah was busy making his own farewell. The organisers had made a video montage of Farah's greatest moments, intercut with a series of tributes from little kids, which they played on the big screens after the 5,000m was over. Farah, utterly spent after his desperate sprint to the line, seemed too busy sucking in fresh air to be moved by it. And for everyone else the effect was spoiled by the fact that Muktar Edris, who had dipped his hands to his head in imitation of Farah's usual celebrations when he won the race, was dancing a merry jig up by the finish line at the time.\n\nStill, Farah will be back, it's just that next season he won't be on the track because he'll be on the road instead. But's he's running again in Birmingham on 20 August. Bolt had said he might run another race or two this season as well. But he'll have to scrap that now. He's gone for good. The IAAF has seen to that. Or at least, he will be come Monday. The IAAF has arranged a \"special presentation\" for him here on Sunday night, when he'll get one last victory lap of the track, and, presumably, some profound apologies too. No doubt they'll have a montage ready. But it won't be a patch on the one that started playing in the memory the minute Bolt stepped out on to the track.\n\nThat first Saturday night in the Bird's Nest in Beijing, when he spread his arms and seemed almost to stop to look around while he was 20 metres from the line, the giddy exhilaration that followed the first look at the clock stopped on 9.69sec. Then the 200m final days later, when Bolt dipped for the line, even though there was no one near him. He wasn't competing against the field, but Michael Johnson's untouchable world record. He turned 22 the next day, but was mischievous as a kid, and cheerfully admitted he'd eaten chicken nuggets for breakfast, lunch and dinner 10 days in a row.\n\nThen August in Berlin a year later, when Bolt broke both his own records, so fast now that he stretched the outer limits of possibility, as if we had to draw new maps to reflect our understanding of how far, and how fast, human beings can go. Or Daegu in 2011, when we finally saw him flustered. He was disqualified for a false start. It was the only way anyone was going to beat him. At the London Olympics a year later, he had a real rival, Yohan Blake. At least, that's what we told ourselves before the Games.\n\nA fortnight later, when Bolt crossed the line first in the 200m, he held his finger to his lips, admonishing everyone who doubted him. Then he dropped to the track and started doing push-ups while Dizzee Rascal's Bonkers blasted out over the stadium PA. It was the iconic image of his Games. Well, that and the selfie he posted with the Swedish women's handball team at 3am in his hotel room the night after he won the 100m. \"I'm now a legend,\" he said that night, \"I'm also the greatest athlete to live.\" Who was going to argue? Justin Gatlin tried. He spent the next three years coming for Bolt, in Moscow and then again in Beijing. But he didn't catch him.\n\nIn 2016, there was the triple-triple, his third set of three Olympic gold medals and that photo of him cocking his head to shoot a grin at the camera as he finished his 100m semi-final, the roadrunner taunting seven coyotes. And then last Saturday, when Gatlin finally beat him in a big race. And even that, in its bittersweet way, burnished his legend. Bolt could have quit in 2016. He had no reason to be at these world championships. He had nothing left to prove, and nothing left to win, but he came anyway, to put it all on the line one last time. He was willing to gamble, and he lost, twice. There's something to admire in that, too. Truth is, the IAAF doesn't deserve him, and never did.", "time": "09:00:00"}

"1402134"}], "url": "http://gantdaily.com/2017/08/12/agony-for-usain-bolt-as-he-pulls-up-injured-in-track-farewell/", "body": "Usain Bolt's farewell appearance at the world championships ended in disastrous fashion as he pulled up injured on the final leg of the men's 4x100m relay Saturday.\n\nBolt took the baton for Jamaica in third place but within a few strides he had fallen to the ground, clutching his left leg, as host Britain secured a shock gold ahead of a United States team containing Justin Gatlin.\n\nBolt beaten into third in the individual 100m behind Gatlin and his US team compatriot Christian Coleman, was comforted by teammates after getting to his feet, his face etched in pain.\n\nThe capacity crowd in the London Stadium was still digesting the shock earlier defeat for home hero Mo Farah in the men's 5,000m final, before the drama of Bolt's last agonizing appearance.\n\nHe had been bidding for a 12th world championship gold to bring down the curtain on his glittering career, but instead limped out of the London Stadium arena.\n\nVictory for the British quartet of CJ Ujah, Adam Gemili, who ran a storming second leg, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake was stunning compensation for Farah's earlier defeat.\n\nThey won in 37.47 seconds, with the US taking silver at 0.05sec and Japan with a surprise bronze.\n\nFor his massive global following, the perfect script would have seen the Bolt of old running down Britain and the US for yet another gold, but it was not to be.\n\n\"He didn't tell us exactly what happened but from what I saw, it looked like a strain or a cramp of some sort,\" teammate Julian Forte told IAAF radio.\n\n\"He kept apologizing to us but we told him there was no need to apologize -- injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nJamaican team doctor Dr Kevin Jones told AFP that Bolt had suffered from \"cramp in his left hamstring\".\n\n\"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him,\" he added.\n\nJamaica's 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, who ran the first leg for the quartet, summed up the feeling of everyone.\n\nFarah, who won the 10,000 title in dramatic fashion of the opening day at the London Stadium, had to settle for silver behind Ethiopian Muktar Edris in his final championship race on the track.\n\nHe edged out American Paul Chelimo in a desperate dash for the line, the last mile of a hitherto slow run race run in just under four minutes.\n\nFarah, 34, will now turn his attention to the marathon after failing in his bid to double up at the Olympics or World Championship for the fifth time, including double gold in London 2012 and the Rio Games last year.\n\nEdris, a former world junior champion, timed his last lap burst to perfection to win in 13 minutes 32.79 seconds, copying Farah's famous Mobot gesture as he crossed the line.\n\nIt was not the farewell Farah wanted, but he pointed to his earlier exertions in a dramatic 10,000m final as reason for lacking his usual devastating finish.\n\n\"The 10,000m took a lot more out of me than I had realized,\" he told BBC Sport.\n\n\"I gave it my all. I didn't have a single thing left to give at the end.\"", "time": "22:50:00"}

"person", "id": "1177093"}], "url": "http://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/lead-stories/20170813/painful-end-womens-4x100m-bronze-only-bright-spark-penultimate-day", "body": "Jamaica's bronze medal winning 4x100m women's team (from left): Jura Levy, Natasha Morrison, Sashalee Forbes and Simone Facey.\n\nThe last image was painful, but his lasting image is covered in gold.\n\nFifteen years after his golden introduction, Usain Bolt's farewell from athletics did not come with the fairytale ending that his glorious career deserved.\n\nInstead, in a heap of pain after suffering an injury to his left hamstring during the 4x100m relay final, Bolt's final run at a major international championship quite eerily mirrored his first: the 2004 Olympics, where injury also crippled his campaign.\n\nFor the London Stadium crowd, confusion as they struggled to decide whether to celebrate Great Britain's first 4x100m gold medal at the World Championships or suffer with their hero, the sport's hero; who was saying goodbye after a generation-defining spell.\n\nEight Olympic titles, 11 world titles, 50 sub-10 second clocking in the 100m, and eight world-record-breaking performances and a lifetime of memorable performances propelled him to the forefront of global sporting celebrity.\n\nBolt would walk off the track to thunderous applause, with team doctor Dr Kevin Jones confirming the extent of the damage.\n\n\"It's a cramp in his left hamstring, but a lot of the pain is from the disappointment from losing the race. The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him,\" said Jones.\n\nHowever, The Sunday Gleaner was later informed that it was worse than a cramp and that he is to undergo an MRI today before being honoured at the stadium.\n\nJamaican sprint hurdler Omar McLeod was a picture of devastation. The gold medal winner requested a leg on the relay team specifically because he wanted to help ensure that Bolt received what he termed \"a golden sendoff\".\n\nMcLeod rushed out of the blocks on the opening leg, showing a bit of that 9.99 seconds speed over 100m, with Julian Forte powering down the backstretch after a smooth exchange. Yohan Blake's third leg was not as dominating, but when the baton settled in Bolt's left hand, the stage was set for another epic Bolt finish.\n\nAs was the case in the 100m final, it was not to be, as Bolt grabbed his hamstring and pulled up some 20 metres into his run.\n\n\"I felt like it happened to me,\" said teammate Forte, shaking his head. \"I was at the corner when it happened, and I just didn't want to believe it. It is devastating. I wanted to be a part of the team that sent Usain Bolt off in style. It's unfortunate, and it's one of the things that can happen in sports,\" added Forte.\n\n\"It's heart-wrenching. I gave it my all, and I wanted Usain to leave golden. We wanted to win. It was really heart-wrenching. I don't know what to say, really,\" said an emotional McLeod. \"I could not believe. I was shocked. I was in disbelief.\"\n\nIt was the first time since the 2007 World Championships that Jamaica was not winning the men's 4x100m relay.\n\nGreat Britain and Northern Ireland, 37.47, anchored by former Jamaica College schoolboy Nathaniel Mitchell-Blake, outlasted the United States' Christian Coleman to win his country's first gold in the event, with the Americans finishing second in 37.52. Japan was third in 38.04 seconds.\n\nThe women's 4x100m relay team of Jura Levy, Natasha Morrison, Simone Facey, and Sashalee Forbes was solid in securing bronze in a time of 42.19 seconds, finishing behind winners the United States, 41.82, and Great Britain and Northern Ireland, 42.12.\n\nKemoy Campbell finished 10th in 13:39.74 in the men's 5000m final, which saw hometown favourite Mo Farah, 13:33.22, beaten by Ethiopia's Muktar Edris, 13:32.79, with USA's Paul Chelimo, 13:33.30, in third.\n\nThe women's 4x400m relay team will compete in the final at 8:55 p.m. British time (2:55 p.m. in Jamaica) after winning their heat in 3:23.64 and with hopes of adding another medal to Jamaica's tally.", "time": "05:21:00"}

Farah experienced some of their greatest moments in their careers at the 2012 Olympics in London but five years on and back in the same stadium, misery replaced joy on Saturday.\n\nBolt, who won the individual 100 and 200m and the 4x100m relay in London in 2012, collapsed to the track injured anchoring the Jamaica 4x100 metres relay team.\n\nJamaican team doctor Dr Kevin Jones said Bolt had suffered from \"cramp in his left hamstring\".\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jones said.\n\n\"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nThe organisers brought on a wheelchair but Bolt shrugged them aside and he limped across the line, grimacing.\n\nJamaica's 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod and relay teammate said nothing had changed with regard to the reputation of Bolt.\n\n\"Usain Bolt's name will always live on,\" he said.\n\nBriton Farah, who had won the first of his four global double doubles of 5 000m and 10 000m to deafening cheers in London in 2012, put up a spirited and courageous effort but for the first time in six years of global championship competition he had to settle for silver behind Muktar Edris of Ethiopia.\n\nFarah, who started the championships in grand style by winning the 10,000m, had been left by Edris as the bell went and as hard as he tried he just didn't quite have the legs to pass his younger rival in the finishing straight.\n\n\"It's been amazing. It's been a long journey but it's been incredible,\" said Farah who was embraced by his fans as he made his way around the stadium on a lap of honour, stopping to sign autographs and pose for 'selfies'.\n\n\"It doesn't quite sink in until you compete here and cross the line -- I had a couple of minutes to myself -- that this is it.\"\n\nThe despair and disappointment of Bolt and Farah was in stark contrast to another hero from 2012 -- Australia's 100m hurdling great Sally Pearson.\n\nThe 30-year-old's grit and determination to come back from two years of injury hell -- she feared that she would have to have her hand amputated when she suffered a bone explosion in her wrist in 2015 -- was rewarded with her second world title.\n\nThe Australian celebrated in exuberant style, her mouth spread in a broad grin as she charged to the stands.\n\nShe tried to find her English mother Anne McLellan -- who had taken two jobs when she was raising her daughter as a single parent so she could go to training and achieve her dream -- and husband, childhood sweetheart Kieran, but without success.\n\n\"Far out, that was bloody hard,\" gasped Pearson.\n\n\"It's been a long journey back from injury, but to get this moment and go and celebrate in front of my family is unreal.\"\n\nBolt's dramatic failure to medal permitted American great Allyson Felix to sit on top of the overall career world medals table with 15 after she was part of the women's 4x100m relay gold-winning team.\n\nThe Americans had to fight hard to edge out the British team but in Bolt's relay it was the reverse as the host nation pulled off an impressive but shock win over the United States -- for whom 100m world champion two-time drugs cheat Justin Gatlin was booed by large sections of the stadium as he had been in the 100m even after he won the gold.\n\nElsewhere there was a gold for Russian Maria Lasitskene, competing as a neutral, who defended the women's high jump title and extended her winning streak to 25.\n\nIt was the first gold for Russian athletes competing at the championships but whose federation are still banned due to the doping scandal that affected all sports in the country.", "time": "22:49:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gatorade", "label": {"eng": "Gatorade"}, "score": 2, "type": "org", "id": "371897"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sport_of_athletics", "label": {"eng": "Sport of athletics"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1053871"}], "url": "http://time.com/money/4889506/usain-bolt-retires-career-earnings-net-worth/", "body": "Usain Bolt, the greatest sprinter in modern times, said he plans on retiring after running his final races this week at the world championships in London.\n\nLast Saturday, in what everyone expects was his final individual race, Bolt had a bad start in the 100m and had to settle for a bronze medal. On Saturday, August 12, Bolt is slated to run in his last race overall, representing Jamaica in the 4x100m relay finals.\n\nBolt has easily been the most celebrated and highest-earning track star for a decade. So how much has he earned during his career?\n\nThe 30-year-old Bolt will pull in $34.2 million this year, according to Forbes, making him the 23rd-highest-paid athlete in the world. His latest ranking puts him ahead of any baseball player, and just behind golfer Jordan Spieth and basketball player Derrick Rose. There is no other track star in the top 100.\n\nAlmost all of Bolt's money comes from endorsements, including deals with Puma, Sprint, and Advil, Forbes says. Only $2.5 million of his earnings in the past 12 months are reportedly from race winnings and appearance fees at track events.\n\nThe $34.2 million for 2017 tracks slightly higher than 2016, when Forbes pegged Bolt's earnings at $32.5 million.\n\nAccording to CNBC, Bolt has been with Puma since 2002, when the sprinter was just 16. Prior to the 2016 Olympics, the deal was paying him $10 million a year. It's not clear how much the deal is worth now. Before his $10 million contract, Puma was said to be paying him $1.5 million a year, according to the Financial Times.\n\nBolt took home gold medals in all three Olympics appearances during his career, starting in 2008 in Beijing, in both the 100m and 200m.\n\nAfter Beijing, Bolt signed deals with Gatorade, Hublot, Virgin, and Visa.\n\nBolt's annual earnings have crept up steadily over the years, and increased significantly as he began piling up his collection of eight gold medals. In a 2009 RunBlogRun post, Bolt's earnings were said to be up to $3 million. His 2012 earnings were estimated at $20 million, and by 2014 he was up to $23 million, according to Forbes, good enough to make him the 63rd and 45th richest athlete in the world in those respective years.\n\nBeing fairly conservative, we can estimate that over the past decade Bolt has made more than $100 million, and perhaps even over $150 million.\n\nThere is unlikely to ever be a track star as rich as Bolt, because athletics earnings generally pay so little even to those at the top of their field. For instance, first place in the biennial World Championships is worth $60,000, and world records carry bonuses of $100,000 in that event, according to Forbes.\n\nMany countries also pay their athletes for competing and winning at the Olympics, and Jamaica is no exception. But the medal payouts are a pittance compared to decent endorsement deals: In 2016, Jamaica paid roughly $10,000 for each gold medal an athlete brought home. So Bolt was rewarded with about $30,000 for his haul of three gold medals that year.\n\nBolt seems to enjoy his fame and fortune. He reportedly owns a black Nissan GT-R worth $105,000, according to Business Insider, and a large mansion near Jamaica's capital.\n\nBolt is also known to love a great party. But not everyone is fond of his lifestyle.\n\n\"Between the bikes, loud, horrid music, parties and screams, I honestly wish he would go back to where he came from,\" his neighbor-model Jodi Stewart-Henriques wrote on Facebook in 2015. \"He's a horrible neighbor.\"", "time": "22:00:00"}

"http://www.msn.com/en-us/money/careersandeducation/usain-bolt-is-retiring-heres-how-he-made-over-dollar100-million-in-10-years/ar-AApRufu?srcref=rss", "body": "Usain Bolt, the greatest sprinter in modern times, said he plans on retiring after running his final races this week at the world championships in London.\n\nLast Saturday, in what everyone expects was his final individual race, Bolt had a bad start in the 100m and had to settle for a bronze medal. On Saturday, August 12, Bolt is slated to run in his last race overall, representing Jamaica in the 4x100m relay finals.\n\nBolt has easily been the most celebrated and highest-earning track star for a decade. So how much has he earned during his career?\n\nThe 30-year-old Bolt will pull in $34.2 million this year, according to Forbes, making him the 23rd-highest-paid athlete in the world. His latest ranking puts him ahead of any baseball player, and just behind golfer Jordan Spieth and basketball player Derrick Rose. There is no other track star in the top 100.\n\nAlmost all of Bolt's money comes from endorsements, including deals with Puma, Sprint, and Advil, Forbes says. Only $2.5 million of his earnings in the past 12 months are reportedly from race winnings and appearance fees at track events.\n\nThe $34.2 million for 2017 tracks slightly higher than 2016, when Forbes pegged Bolt's earnings at $32.5 million.\n\nAccording to CNBC, Bolt has been with Puma since 2002, when the sprinter was just 16. Prior to the 2016 Olympics, the deal was paying him $10 million a year. It's not clear how much the deal is worth now. Before his $10 million contract, Puma was said to be paying him $1.5 million a year, according to the Financial Times.\n\nBolt took home gold medals in all three Olympics appearances during his career, starting in 2008 in Beijing, in both the 100m and 200m.\n\nAfter Beijing, Bolt signed deals with Gatorade, Hublot, Virgin, and Visa.\n\nBolt's annual earnings have crept up steadily over the years, and increased significantly as he began piling up his collection of eight gold medals. In a 2009 RunBlogRun post, Bolt's earnings were said to be up to $3 million. His 2012 earnings were estimated at $20 million, and by 2014 he was up to $23 million, according to Forbes, good enough to make him the 63rd and 45th richest athlete in the world in those respective years.\n\nBeing fairly conservative, we can estimate that over the past decade Bolt has made more than $100 million, and perhaps even over $150 million.\n\nThere is unlikely to ever be a track star as rich as Bolt, because athletics earnings generally pay so little even to those at the top of their field. For instance, first place in the biennial World Championships is worth $60,000, and world records carry bonuses of $100,000 in that event, according to Forbes.\n\nMany countries also pay their athletes for competing and winning at the Olympics, and Jamaica is no exception. But the medal payouts are a pittance compared to decent endorsement deals: In 2016, Jamaica paid roughly $10,000 for each gold medal an athlete brought home. So Bolt was rewarded with about $30,000 for his haul of three gold medals that year.\n\nBolt seems to enjoy his fame and fortune. He reportedly owns a black Nissan GT-R worth $105,000, according to Business Insider, and a large mansion near Jamaica's capital.\n\nBolt is also known to love a great party. But not everyone is fond of his lifestyle.\n\n\"Between the bikes, loud, horrid music, parties and screams, I honestly wish he would go back to where he came from,\" his neighbor-model Jodi Stewart-Henriques wrote on Facebook in 2015. \"He's a horrible neighbor.\"", "time": "06:52:00"}

"https://www.sportsjoe.ie/world-of-sport/usain-bolts-teammates-make-very-valid-point-about-how-legend-suffered-injury-133595", "body": "Usain Bolt was a vision of composure prior to his final showing.\n\nAs was to be expected, the Jamaican legend joked with the World Athletics Championship mascot before posing for his adoring fans inside the London Stadium.\n\nBut inside his head, long before the baton touched his palm, Bolt knew there was something wrong.\n\nScheduled for a 9.50pm start, the men's 4x100m relay final didn't start until after 10pm. Now that may not sound like much but athletes involved in sports which require explosive bursts will know all too well the importance of warming up.\n\nBolt was trusted with the final sprint of the Jamaican team's relay effort and he took off well when teammate Yohan Blake thrust the baton into his grasp but, just seconds later, Bolt was forced to pull up and a career of coasting to the finish line ended with the greatest sprinter of all time unable to even cross.\n\nAthletics fans would have felt that they'd had their fill of heartbreak an hour earlier, when Mo Farah was brought to tears after being forced to settle for silver in his last track race, but they quickly found out how cruel sport can be when Bolt had to limp away from his career in agony.\n\nFollowing the race, which was won by Great Britain, Bolt's teammates suggested the reason for the 30-year-old's hamstring injury.\n\n\"The race was 10 minutes late, we were kept 40 minutes. It was crazy,\" Blake said, via the BBC.\n\nAll those involved in the men's 4x100m relay final were forced to warm up several times because the delay resulted in their bodies cooling down.\n\n\"It was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run,\" 2011 world 100m champion Blake continued.\n\n\"We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us.\n\n\"It hurts to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggle like that.\"\n\nSaturday night was not exactly a warm one in London and Omar McLeod, who began Jamaica's effort, echoed Blake's frustration with the organisers.\n\n\"It was ridiculous. We were there waiting, and we were really trying to stay warm, but it was really ridiculous, we waited a really long time,\" McLeod said, via Jamaica-Gleaner.\n\nMo Farah's lengthy lap of honour and two medal presentation ceremonies were responsible for the postponement which, according to the second Jamaican runner, Julian Forte, may have resulted in Bolt's muscles being too cold come race time.\n\n\"They kept us in the call room extremely long in our running kits, we were getting cold and it's not the warmest weather over here and they kept us a while. I think they really need to look into that and do something about it,\" Forte said.", "time": "06:59:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starting_blocks", "label": {"eng": "Starting blocks"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "395093"}], "url": "http://zeenews.india.com/other-sports/watch-usain-bolt-limps-out-with-cramp-in-final-race-of-his-career-at-iaaf-world-championships-2032507.html", "body": "New Delhi: Heartbreak! A complete moment of heartbreak! Usain Bolt was all set to run the final race of his career - the 4x100 meters relay. But no one would have anticipated, not even in their wildest dreams that the greatest sprinter of all time would see such an end to his illustrious career. He pulled a cramp on his left hamstring as Jamaica Did Not Finish the race.\n\nIt was 9:50 into the night. London crowd waited with much anticipation for Bolt's final race of his career. Bang! Went the gun shot as the sprinters soared off their starting blocks. Great Britain took off with real pace, the Japanese followed behind. But the Jamaicans were slowly catching up. Yohan Blake blazed away to pass the baton to his final teammate, Bolt.\n\nGreat Britain was still leading then, followed by the Americans and the Jamaican team. Bolt clutched onto the baton and took off. Another sluggish start, but made an effort to tune up his speed. And just when it seemed he was catching up the hosts, he limped down the track as he had pulled a cramp on his left hamstring, sat down agonising in pain as Great Britain roared away with the gold. The team USA finished second, followed by Japan. Bolt sat there, tears rolled down his eyes as his teammates ran to console him.\n\nTwo moments of history at one time. Great Britain won their first 4x100m relay gold at World Athletics Championships. Silver twice, but gold for first time. The last time they had grabbed the top podium was in Olympics 2004 at Athens when they breezed past the then great Maurice Greene by one-hundreth of a second. Also, this was Jamaica's first defeat in this event since their shot to dominance in 2008. Not only did they miss out on their gold medal, but they failed to finish the race.\n\nJust one hundred meteres of space and now it has been inked in the pages of history. For Great Britain it was a moment to be applauded, to be cheered and for Bolt it was just consolation. But the crowd did salute as the Greatest Sprinter of all time waved with still tears running down his eyes, for one last time.", "time": "03:51:00"}

"1402134"}], "url": "http://www.erienewsnow.com/story/36122878/agony-for-usain-bolt-as-he-pulls-up-injured-in-track-farewell", "body": "(CNN) -- Usain Bolt's farewell appearance at the world championships ended in disastrous fashion as he pulled up injured on the final leg of the men's 4x100m relay Saturday.\n\nBolt took the baton for Jamaica in third place but within a few strides he had fallen to the ground, clutching his left leg, as host Britain secured a shock gold ahead of a United States team containing Justin Gatlin.\n\nBolt beaten into third in the individual 100m behind Gatlin and his US team compatriot Christian Coleman, was comforted by teammates after getting to his feet, his face etched in pain.\n\nThe capacity crowd in the London Stadium was still digesting the shock earlier defeat for home hero Mo Farah in the men's 5,000m final, before the drama of Bolt's last agonizing appearance.\n\nHe had been bidding for a 12th world championship gold to bring down the curtain on his glittering career, but instead limped out of the London Stadium arena.\n\nVictory for the British quartet of CJ Ujah, Adam Gemili, who ran a storming second leg, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake was stunning compensation for Farah's earlier defeat.\n\nThey won in 37.47 seconds, with the US taking silver at 0.05sec and Japan with a surprise bronze.\n\nFor his massive global following, the perfect script would have seen the Bolt of old running down Britain and the US for yet another gold, but it was not to be.\n\n\"He didn't tell us exactly what happened but from what I saw, it looked like a strain or a cramp of some sort,\" teammate Julian Forte told IAAF radio.\n\n\"He kept apologizing to us but we told him there was no need to apologize -- injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nJamaican team doctor Dr Kevin Jones told AFP that Bolt had suffered from \"cramp in his left hamstring\".\n\n\"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him,\" he added.\n\nJamaica's 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, who ran the first leg for the quartet, summed up the feeling of everyone.\n\nFarah, who won the 10,000 title in dramatic fashion of the opening day at the London Stadium, had to settle for silver behind Ethiopian Muktar Edris in his final championship race on the track.\n\nHe edged out American Paul Chelimo in a desperate dash for the line, the last mile of a hitherto slow run race run in just under four minutes.\n\nFarah, 34, will now turn his attention to the marathon after failing in his bid to double up at the Olympics or World Championship for the fifth time, including double gold in London 2012 and the Rio Games last year.\n\nEdris, a former world junior champion, timed his last lap burst to perfection to win in 13 minutes 32.79 seconds, copying Farah's famous Mobot gesture as he crossed the line.\n\nIt was not the farewell Farah wanted, but he pointed to his earlier exertions in a dramatic 10,000m final as reason for lacking his usual devastating finish.\n\n\"The 10,000m took a lot more out of me than I had realized,\" he told BBC Sport.\n\n\"I gave it my all. I didn't have a single thing left to give at the end.\"\n\nTM & \u00a9 2017 Cable News Network, Inc., a Time Warner Company. All rights reserved.", "time": "13:43:00"}
