"http://www.firstpost.com/sports/iaaf-world-athletics-championships-2017-usain-bolt-mo-farah-end-career-in-heartbreaking-circumstances-3924593.html", "body": "London: Athletics legends Usain Bolt and Mo Farah experienced some of their greatest moments in their careers at the 2012 Olympics in London but five years on and back in the same stadium, misery replaced joy on Saturday.\n\nBolt, who won the individual 100 and 200m and the 4x100m relay in London in 2012, collapsed to the track injured anchoring the Jamaica 4x100 metres relay team.\n\nIt was not the fairytale ending that fans of Usain Bolt and Mo Farah had imagined.\n\nJamaican team doctor Dr Kevin Jones said Bolt had suffered from \"cramp in his left hamstring\".\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jones said.\n\n\"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nThe organisers brought on a wheelchair but Bolt shrugged them aside and he limped across the line, grimacing.\n\nJamaica's 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod and relay team-mate said nothing had changed with regard to the reputation of Bolt.\n\n\"Usain Bolt's name will always live on,\" he said.\n\nBriton Farah, who had won the first of his four global double doubles of 5,000m and 10,000m to deafening cheers in London in 2012, put up a spirited and courageous effort but for the first time in six years of global championship competition, he had to settle for silver behind Muktar Edris of Ethiopia.\n\nFarah, who started the championships in grand style by winning the 10,000m, had been left by Edris as the bell went and as hard as he tried he just didn't quite have the legs to pass his younger rival in the finishing straight.\n\n\"It's been amazing. It's been a long journey but it's been incredible,\" said Farah who was embraced by his fans as he made his way around the stadium on a lap of honour, stopping to sign autographs and pose for 'selfies'.\n\n\"It doesn't quite sink in until you compete here and cross the line -- I had a couple of minutes to myself -- that this is it.\"\n\nThe despair and disappointment of Bolt and Farah was in stark contrast to another hero from 2012 -- Australia's 100m hurdling great Sally Pearson.\n\nThe 30-year-old's grit and determination to come back from two years of injury hell -- she feared that she would have to have her hand amputated when she suffered a bone explosion in her wrist in 2015 -- was rewarded with her second world title.\n\nThe Australian celebrated in exuberant style, her mouth spread into a broad grin as she charged into the stands.\n\nShe tried to find her English mother Anne McLellan -- who had taken two jobs when she was raising her daughter as a single parent so she could go to training and achieve her dream -- and husband, childhood sweetheart Kieran but without success.\n\n\"Far out, that was bloody hard,\" gasped Pearson.\n\n\"It's been a long journey back from injury, but to get this moment and go and celebrate in front of my family is unreal.\"\n\nBolt's dramatic failure to medal permitted American great Allyson Felix to sit on top of the overall career world medals table with 15 after she was part of the women's 4x100m relay gold-winning team.\n\nThe Americans had to fight hard to edge out the British team but in Bolt's relay it was the reverse as the host nation pulled off an impressive but shock win over the United States -- for whom 100m world champion two-time drugs cheat Justin Gatlin was booed by large sections of the stadium as he had been in the 100m even after he won the gold.\n\nElsewhere there was a gold for Russian Maria Lasitskene, competing as a neutral, who defended the women's high jump title and extended her winning streak to 25.\n\nIt was the first gold for Russian athletes competing at the championships but whose federation are still banned due to the doping scandal that affected all sports in the country.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 13, 2017 04:21 am | Updated Date: Aug 13, 2017 04:21 am\n\nTags :#000m race#100m sprint#2012 london olympics#5#Allyson felix#Athletics#Iaaf world athletics championships 2017#Justin gatlin#Maria lasitskene#Mo farah#Muktar edris#Sally pearson#Usain bolt", "time": "22:55:00"}

Usain Bolt, running the penultimate race of his career, led Jamaica safely through their semifinal in the 4x100m relay at the World Athletics Championships on Saturday while United States ran the fastest time of the year.\n\nBolt, who announced on Monday that he would also run in the heats, will race for the last time in the final on Saturday when he hopes to bow out with his 20th global championship title.\n\nRunning the last leg, Bolt eased home, looking over his shoulder, as Jamaica won the second of the two semi-final heats in 37.95 seconds, ahead of France (38.03) and China (38.20).\n\nJamaica are aiming for a fifth successive world title in the event but will face a stiff challenge from the U.S. who won the first heat in 37.70 seconds, with Christian Coleman, silver medallist in the 100 metres, running the anchor leg.\n\n\"It feels like second nature because we work well together. We are confident we can win. We will go and prepare well for tonight,\" said Michael Rogers, who ran the first leg for the United States.\n\nBritain were second in the first heat in 37.76, also faster than Jamaica's time, while Japan were third. Canada and Turkey also qualified as the fastest losers.\n\nBolt's presence ensured a capacity crowd for the morning session. \"It's hard to be sad because of the energy I'm getting from the crowd,\" said the Jamaican, who suffered a rare defeat in the 100 metres when he took bronze.\n\nNext Page >", "time": "12:59:00"}

McLeod"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1333564"}], "url": "https://www.stabroeknews.com/2017/sports/08/13/injury-floors-bolt-ruins-farewell/", "body": "LONDON, (Reuters) - Usain Bolt's unparalleled career ended in extraordinary drama on Saturday as he pulled up with injury on the anchor leg of his very last race, the 4\u00d7100 metres relay final at the World Championships.\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track.\n\nYet the sport's greatest enteartainer was determined that one of the finest careers in sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair. So the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried team mates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 metres to the line.\n\nThe official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the team mates he felt he had let down.\n\n\"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nMcLeod added: \"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nKevin Jones, the Jamaican team doctor, said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring.\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" he said. \"The last three weeks have been hard for him. We hope for the best for him\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favourite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track.\n\nFive years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics. Yet in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000 metres, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell.\n\nTheir leaving of the track scene leaves a void in the sport that does not look like being filled any time soon.", "time": "07:06:00"}

"wiki", "id": "1417682"}], "url": "http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2017/08/13/slick-britain-win-4x100-relay-bolt-pulls", "body": "LONDON (Reuters) - Usain Bolt's final appearance on the track ended in agony on Saturday as he pulled up injured running the final leg of the World Championships 4x100 metres relay as Britain stunned the United States to win a shock gold medal.\n\nBolt, who had to settle for bronze in the individual 100 metres, had been hoping to sign off from the sport by leading Jamaica to a fifth successive relay gold but they were struggling in third place when he collected the baton.\n\nAs he tried to gain ground, Bolt pulled up and fell to the floor with what looked like a hamstring injury.\n\nThe 60,000 in the stadium who had come to mark the farewell sport's greatest showman had only a split second to absorb what was happening as up ahead a new chapter was being written.\n\nThe U.S., with individual gold and silver medallists Justin Gatlin and Christian Coleman running the second and fourth legs, had been expected to push the Jamaicans all the way but they were always trailing the slick Britons.\n\nThe brilliantly executed race by Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Danny Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake gave Britain gold in 37.47 seconds, breaking an 18-year-old national record, and the world title for the first time.\n\n\"I wasn't sure if I had won or not, I gave it my all but I could see Christian Coleman out of the corner of my eye,\" said Mitchell-Blake.\n\n\"The feeling of euphoria was from infinity. I can't register it. We smashed the British record to pieces.\"\n\nBritain's only other men's global sprint relay golds came in the 1912 and 2004 Olympics.\n\nIt completed a great night for the host nation's sprinters after their women had earlier taken silver behind the Americans in the sprint relay, their best performance since the first championships in 1983.\n\nThe U.S. men took silver in 37.52 but for a nation that used to be totally dominant in the event, it was only their second medal in the last eight global finals after a series of world championship and Olympic disqualifications.\n\nJapan took advantage of Jamaica's travails to take third in 38.04.", "time": "21:59:00"}

3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1053871"}], "url": "http://www.nation.co.ke/sports/athletics/Usain-Bolt--most-memorable-quotes/1100-4055364-riqdmcz/index.html", "body": "Athletics superstar Usain Bolt's last championship race ended in dramatic fashion as he collapsed injured on the track anchoring Jamaica's 4x100 metres relay in the world championship final.\n\nHere AFP Sports picks out five of his best quotes and five about him since he first light up the championship track at the 2008 Beijing Olympics:\n\n- What they said about him -\n\n*****\n\n\"There is no athlete that can compete with him... he's a global superstar.\" - Bolt's predecessor as an athletics superstar, Michael Johnson, whose 200 metres world record Bolt broke in the 2008 Olympic final.\n\n\"You can compare us as sprinters, but the thing I am most proud of is that I did multiple events and I long-jumped.\" - Damned with faint and grudging praise by American legend Carl Lewis who also cast aspersions as to the Jamaican doping system to which Bolt retorted: \"Carl Lewis, I have no respect for him.\"\n\n\"He is an icon. He is the best sprinter of all time.\" - Former International Olympic Committee (IOC) President Jacques Rogge, who was chided at the 2012 London Olympics for refusing to say he was a legend. Former Olympic yachtsman Rogge instead opted to nominate British yachting icon Ben Ainslie as his star of the Games.\n\n\"Nobody's ever been faster than this guy! Ever! Of all the billions of people.\" - Then-US President Barack Obama reflects on the global nature of Bolt's stardom after meeting with him in Jamaica and then performing the lightning bolt pose with him.\n\n\"Usain Bolt is now Jamaica's biggest ambassador. His personality, his ability to draw people to him (and) his showmanship have really given a boost to Brand Jamaica.\" - Jamaican Prime Minister Andrew Holness neatly sums up Bolt's gift to the Caribbean island.\n\n- Bolt on himself -\n\n*****\n\n\"I am Lightning Bolt! I am not Flash Gordon or anybody. My name is Bolt, Lightning Bolt.\" - Bolt after smashing Michael Johnson's 200m world record in the 2008 Beijing Olympic final to complete his first of three individual Olympic sprint doubles.\n\n\"Manners is the key thing. Say for instance when you're growing up you're walking down the street you've got to tell everybody good morning. Everybody. You can't pass one person.\" - Bolt displaying why he has charmed everyone along the way, never forgetting the strict but grounded way he was brought up by his parents, father Wellesley and mother Jennifer.\n\n\"People come to see you run fast, but they also come to see a show, a performance... that's what I give them.\" - Bolt savvy as ever and why athletics will miss him so much: not just for his jaw-dropping brilliance but also his ability to entertain.\n\n\"I'm now a legend, I'm also the greatest athlete to live. I am in the same category as Michael Johnson.\" - Bolt after winning the 2012 Olympic 200m title to complete the individual sprint double double.\n\n\"If Queen Elizabeth knight hooded me and I would get the title Sir Usain Bolt. That would sound very nice.\" - Bolt on the possibility of joining Mo Farah as a knight of the Realm. Not wholly implausible as he has been athletics' knight in shining armour for nearly a decade.", "time": "21:28:00"}

{"eng": "Omar McLeod"}, "score": 5, "type": "wiki", "id": "1333564"}], "url": "http://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/sports/20170813/london-2017-tragic-wait-athletes-blame-race-delay-bolts-injury", "body": "Usain Bolt (second right) being consoled by his team members (from left) Julian Forte, Yohan Blake and Omar McLeod after he pulled up in the final of the Men's 4x100m relay at the IAAF World Championships yesterday.\n\nDevastated after watching Usain Bolt clutch his hamstring and crash to the floor during the anchor leg of the Men's 4x100 metres relay, his teammates are among those who are blaming a 30-minute wait as a possible cause for the iconic sprinter's injury.\n\nThe trio of Omar McLeod, Julian Forte, and Yohan Blake had safely transported the baton into the hands of Bolt, on anchor, with the Jamaican in touching distance, with American Christian Coleman and Great Britain's Nathaniel Mitchell-Blake on the last leg.\n\nBolt, however, suffered the injury some 20 metres after taking the stick and pulled up in agony 10 metres later.\n\nForte, McLeod, and Blake all complained about the wait and believes that that, coupled with the chilly conditions, contributed to the Bolt's injury.\n\nTheir argument was supported by American sprinter Justin Gatlin, who noted that the teams were held in the Call Room - a pre-race holding area - for over 30 minutes in their running gear, making it difficult to stay warm.\n\n\"I knew something bad would happen to someone. It was madness,\" Gatlin said.\n\nForte believes that the organisers should look seriously into the delay and have it addressed.\n\n\"They kept us in the Call Room extremely long in our running kits. We were getting cold, and it's not the warmest weather over here, and they kept us a while. I think they really need to look into that and do something about it,\" said Forte.\n\nThe race itself went off close to 10 minutes after its scheduled 9:50 p.m. start.\n\n\"It was ridiculous! We were there waiting. I think they had, like, three minutes, and we were really trying to stay warm, but it was really ridiculous. We waited a really long time,\" added an emotional McLeod, who said that he was desperate to help send off Bolt with another gold medal. \"I drank like two bottles of water.\"\n\nThe event was won by Great Britain and Northern Ireland in 37.47 seconds, with the USA taking the silver in 37.52. Japan were third in 38.04.\n\n\"It's tragic,\" Blake lamented. \"Everything didn't go according to plan. They were holding us too long in the Call Room. The race was 10 minutes late, inside was really cold, and Usain said to me 'Yohan, I don't like this'.\"\n\n\"We kept warning up, jumping up and down. I think the weather got the better of us. We were waiting too long, and there was a hell of a walk as well. It was just crazy and to see a true legend of the sport to go down like that, and we as Jamaicans and the world don't like to see that. We wanted him to go out in style, and we went out there to give it our all, and it came to that,\" Blake added.\n\nIt was Jamaica's first loss in a Men's 4x100m relay at the World Championships since 2007.", "time": "06:42:00"}

{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sport_of_athletics", "label": {"eng": "Sport of athletics"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "1053871"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omar_McLeod", "label": {"eng": "Omar McLeod"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1333564"}], "url": "http://www.namibian.com.na/index.php?page=read&id=57899", "body": "LONDON - Athletics legends Usain Bolt and Mo Farah experienced some of their greatest moments in their careers at the 2012 Olympics in London but five years on and back in the same stadium, misery replaced joy on Saturday.\n\nBolt, who won the individual 100 and 200m and the 4x100m relay in London in 2012, collapsed to the track injured anchoring the Jamaica 4x100 metres relay team.\n\nJamaican team doctor Dr Kevin Jones said Bolt had suffered from \"cramp in his left hamstring\".\n\n\"But a lot of pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jones said.\n\n\"The last three weeks have been hard for him, you know. We hope for the best for him.\"\n\nThe organisers brought on a wheelchair but Bolt shrugged them aside and he limped across the line, grimacing.\n\nJamaica's 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod and relay team-mate said nothing had changed with regard to the reputation of Bolt.\n\n\"Usain Bolt's name will always live on,\" he said.\n\nBriton Farah, who had won the first of his four global double doubles of 5,000m and 10,000m to deafening cheers in London in 2012, put up a spirited and courageous effort but for the first time in six years of global championship competition he had to settle for silver behind Muktar Edris of Ethiopia.\n\nFarah, who started the championships in grand style by winning the 10,000m, had been left by Edris as the bell went and as hard as he tried he just didn't quite have the legs to pass his younger rival in the finishing straight.\n\n\"It's been amazing. It's been a long journey but it's been incredible,\" said Farah who was embraced by his fans as he made his way around the stadium on a lap of honour, stopping to sign autographs and pose for 'selfies'.\n\n\"It doesn't quite sink in until you compete here and cross the line - I had a couple of minutes to myself - that this is it.\"\n\nThe despair and disappointment of Bolt and Farah was in stark contrast to another hero from 2012 - Australia's 100m hurdling great Sally Pearson.\n\nThe 30-year-old's grit and determination to come back from two years of injury hell - she feared that she would have to have her hand amputated when she suffered a bone explosion in her wrist in 2015 - was rewarded with her second world title.\n\nThe Australian celebrated in exuberant style, her mouth spread in a broad grin as she charged to the stands.\n\nShe tried to find her English mother Anne McLellan - who had taken two jobs when she was raising her daughter as a single parent so she could go to training and achieve her dream - and husband, childhood sweetheart Kieran but without success.\n\n\"Far out, that was bloody hard,\" gasped Pearson.\n\n\"It's been a long journey back from injury, but to get this moment and go and celebrate in front of my family is unreal.\"\n\nBolt's dramatic failure to medal permitted American great Allyson Felix to sit on top of the overall career world medals table with 15 after she was part of the women's 4x100m relay gold-winning team.\n\nThe Americans had to fight hard to edge out the British team but in Bolt's relay it was the reverse as the host nation pulled off an impressive but shock win over the United States - for whom 100m world champion two-time drugs cheat Justin Gatlin was booed by large sections of the stadium as he had been in the 100m even after he won the gold.\n\nElsewhere there was a gold for Russian Maria Lasitskene, competing as a neutral, who defended the women's high jump title and extended her winning streak to 25.\n\nIt was the first gold for Russian athletes competing at the championships but whose federation are still banned due to the doping scandal that affected all sports in the country. - Nampa-AFP", "time": "23:08:00"}

"http://www.shanghaidaily.com/sports/athletics/Win-or-lose-lightning-Bolt-is-the-king-in-swansong-race/shdaily.shtml", "body": "ON a very rare occasion in sports history, the bronze medalist received much more cheers and applause than the winner.\n\nJamaican \"lightning\" Usain Bolt lost his first-ever world championships final to his rivals, in the last 100m race of his career last Saturday, while 35-year-old American Justin Gatlin, 2005 world champion, emerged the surprise winner in 9.92 seconds, 0.03 seconds ahead of Bolt.\n\n\"The place is wonderful and I appreciated this crowd so much. It is just one of those things, thank you to London for all your love and appreciation,\" said Bolt, who was treated by the capacity crowd and the organizers as a winner, receiving undimished cheers and applause from the adoring spectators and doing the lap of honor as if he had won.\n\nAfter the race, Gatlin bowed down to Bolt as if saluting a king or being remorseful for ruining the Jamaican's chance of ending his career with a record fourth gold medal in the blue-ribbon 100m.\n\nBolt admitted he was disappointed but would never change his idea of retiring because the new life ahead is more inviting.\n\n\"I told you guys whatever happens this season I'd come out and do my best. I did it for the fans. I worked hard, I'm definitely disappointed I didn't win, but no one is going to be happy to not win,\" said Bolt after the race.\n\n\"It doesn't change anything, for me. I think I lost to a great competitor and a young kid who is coming up and is very talented, with a great future ahead of him. No regrets, I came out and did my best; win lose or draw. I was always going to walk away. I've done all I can for the sport, so it's time to go,\" he added.\n\n\"I'm excited to just live normally and get up and know that I have no training for once and can do what I want. I will miss the sport for sure, but I get a chance to live and travel when I want. I don't know where I will go or where my career will go, but it's exciting,\" he said.\n\nAlthough missing out on a golden finish in the individual race, Bolt, turning 31 next week, will still stand as the greatest sprinter in history.\n\nFor a decade, he has been this intimidating figure on the track for his opponents -- winning all the Olympic or world championship finals he was in, except one hiccup when he false started in the 100m final in Daegu world championships in 2011.\n\nAs his career extends, Bolt keeps making history, storming to eight Olympic golds and 11 world titles and holds the world records of 9.58 seconds in the 100m and 19.19 seconds in the 200m.\n\nHis legendary achievements were well recognized by the sports world as he was named IAAF Athlete of The Year six times and was a four-time Laureus Awards winner.\n\nAthletics' world governing body head Sebastian Coe lavished with praises for him.\n\n\"He is the best sprinter of all time,\" the British said a few days ago. \"Usain Bolt is a genius. I can't think, other than Muhammad Ali, of anybody that has so had an impact inside or beyond their sport.\n\n\"You can have the Friday-night-in-the-pub conversations about who is best footballer or tennis player, but there is no argument about this guy in sprinting.\"\n\nAdmirations also come from Bolt's peers. World and Olympic champion Allyson Felix spoke highly of the Jamaican.\n\n\"I think he's really changed the sport, he's brought a lot of excitement, he's a performer and we can all just appreciate it, everything he's done and given to this sport,\" she said at a pre-competition conference.\n\nBolt has won the affection of so many not just with his feats but also a charismatic personality.\n\nGrowing a goatee may give him a touch of maturity while he would still give the big innocent grin at the cameras on the starting line, joke with Hero the Hedgehog and flash thumbs-up sign to the crowd and make his trademark pose of shooting off invisible arrows despite the third place finish.\n\nAs Coe put it, what the crowd is going to miss is the personality, an athlete with humor, good grace as well as almost insurmountable sprinting achievements.\n\n\"We do want athletes with personality. It's nice to have someone who has a view and fills the room and fills a stadium,\" Coe said about Bolt who has 4,762,800 followers on Twitter and 18,775,000 followers on Facebook.\n\nNow Bolt is officially retiring, and the sport is left with a huge void for losing its most dazzling star.", "time": "17:48:00"}

Ian Thorpe joins marriage equality campaign\n\nOur most successful Olympian appeared at the City2Surf run encouraging all australians who aren't already enrolled to vote in the postal plebiscite on same sex marriage to do so.\n\nUp Next West Coast escape against Carlton West Coast escape against Carlton West Coast escape against Carlton\n\nJosh Kennedy bagged six as the Eagles kept their finals hopes alive with a 100-83 victory at home.\n\nMore videos Usain Bolt breaks down in final race\n\nEverything was working towards one last gold medal for the Jamaican.\n\n\"It was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run ... we were kept 40 minutes. It was crazy,\" Blake said. \"They were holding us too long.\n\n\"We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us.\n\n\"It hurts to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggle like that.\"\n\nThe track and field great \"kept apologising\" to teammates after he fell to the ground in the last leg of the 4x100m relay final in London.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nYou will now receive updates from Sport Newsletter Sport Newsletter\n\nGet the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.\n\nBy submitting your email you are agreeing to Fairfax Media's terms and conditions and privacy policy .\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track.\n\nThe sport's greatest entertainer was determined that one of the finest careers in sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair.\n\nSo the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried team mates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 metres to the line.\n\nThe official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the team mates he felt he had let down.\n\n\"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nMcLeod added: \"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nJustin Gatlin, the American winner of the individual 100 metres who had consigned Bolt to third place in his final individual race last Saturday, paid tribute to his rival.\n\n\"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury). I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\nKevin Jones, the Jamaican team doctor, said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring.\n\nJamaican team manager Ian Forbes praised Bolt for \"going out there and giving his all\" and added that the squad were \"very saddened\".\n\n\"The diagnostic work will be done shortly to determine how serious it is. He was able to walk to the team bus so hopefully that signals it's not as serious as it possibly could be,\" Forbes said.\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favourite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track.\n\nFive years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics.\n\nYet in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000 metres, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell.\n\nTheir leaving of the track scene leaves a void in the sport that does not look like being filled any time soon.\n\nReuters", "time": "04:09:00"}

"body": "By Mitch Phillips\n\nLONDON, Aug 12 (Reuters) - Usain Bolt's final appearance on the track ended in agony on Saturday as he pulled up injured running the final leg of the World Championships 4x100 metres relay as Britain stunned the United States to win a shock gold medal.\n\nBolt, who had to settle for bronze in the individual 100 metres, had been hoping to sign off from the sport by leading Jamaica to a fifth successive relay gold but they were struggling in third place when he collected the baton.\n\nAs he tried to gain ground, Bolt pulled up and fell to the floor with what looked like a hamstring injury.\n\nThe 60,000 in the stadium who had come to mark the farewell sport's greatest showman had only a split second to absorb what was happening as up ahead a new chapter was being written.\n\nThe U.S., with individual gold and silver medallists Justin Gatlin and Christian Coleman running the second and fourth legs, had been expected to push the Jamaicans all the way but they were always trailing the slick Britons.\n\nThe brilliantly executed race by Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Danny Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake gave Britain gold in 37.47 seconds, breaking an 18-year-old national record, and the world title for the first time.\n\n\"I wasn't sure if I had won or not, I gave it my all but I could see Christian Coleman out of the corner of my eye,\" said Mitchell-Blake.\n\n\"The feeling of euphoria was from infinity. I can't register it. We smashed the British record to pieces.\"\n\nBritain's only other men's global sprint relay golds came in the 1912 and 2004 Olympics.\n\nIt completed a great night for the host nation's sprinters after their women had earlier taken silver behind the Americans in the sprint relay, their best performance since the first championships in 1983.\n\nThe U.S. men took silver in 37.52 but for a nation that used to be totally dominant in the event, it was only their second medal in the last eight global finals after a series of world championship and Olympic disqualifications. Japan took advantage of Jamaica's travails to take third in 38.04. (Editing by Ed Osmond)", "time": "21:59:00"}

clutch his hamstring and crash to the floor during the anchor leg of the men's 4x100m relay, his team mates have pointed to what they described as an exorbitant wait as a possible cause for the iconic sprinter's injury.\n\nThe trio of Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake had safely transported the baton into the hands of Bolt on anchor, with the Jamaican in touching distance with American Christian Coleman and Great Britain's Nathaniel Mitchell-Blake on the last leg.\n\nBolt, however, suffered the injury some 20 metres after taking the stick and pulled up in agony 10 metres later.\n\nForte, McLeod and Blake all complained about the wait and believe that, coupled with the chilly conditions to contribute to the Bolt's injury.\n\n\"They kept us in the call room extremely long in our running kits, we were getting cold and it's not the warmest weather over here and they kept us a while. I think they really need to look into that and do something about it,\" said Forte.\n\nThe race began close to 10 minutes after it's scheduled 9:50 p.m. start and took place after a couple medal ceremonies.\n\n\"It was ridiculous. We were there waiting, and we were really trying to stay warm, but it was really ridiculous, we waited a really long time,\" added an emotional McLeod, who said he was desperate to help send off Bolt with another gold medal.\n\nThe event was won by Great Britain and Northern Ireland in 37.47 seconds with the USA taking the silver in 37.52. "1417682"}], "url": "http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/article/13/08/2017/Legend-Bolt-signs-off-in-pain-as-injury-spoils-farewell", "body": "Usain Bolt (centre) falls on Jamaica's anchor leg of the final of the men's 4x100m relay final at the 2017 IAAF World Championships in London yesterday.\n\nUsain Bolt's glittering career swansong came crashing to an end when he pulled up on the anchor leg of the world 4x100m relay won by Britain yesterday.\n\nBolt received the baton with Jamaica in third, but halfway down his leg the towering sprinter pulled up clutching his left thigh, eventually doing a forward roll to the ground, to gasps from the 60,000 sell out London Stadium.\n\nThe British quartet of Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Daniel Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake claimed gold in 37.47 seconds, with the Justin Gatlin-led US four taking silver at 0.05sec and Japan a surprise bronze (38.04).\n\nEarlier, Tori Bowie became the first double gold medallist at the world championships, anchoring the US team to the 4x100-meter relay title ahead of Britain and Jamaica.\n\nAt the same time, Allyson Felix, running the second leg on the winning team, earned a record 15th medal at the world championships in a career going back to 2005.\n\nBowie, who won the 100 meters this week, ran a strong anchor leg, leaving behind the opposition to finish in 41.82 seconds.\n\nBritain took silver in 42.12 and two-time defending champion Jamaica earned bronze in 42.19.\n\nGermany's Johannes Vetter won the javelin yesterday as his great rival and Olympic champion Thomas Rohler missed out on the podium.\n\nVetter's opening throw of 89.89 metres was enough to win the gold and the 24-year-old was overcome with emotion after clinching the title, mopping his tears on a German flag.\n\nCzech Republic pair Jakub VaQatar's Ahmed Budair finished 10th with a best throw of 81.77 metres.", "time": "23:54:00"}

"http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2017/08/12/bolt-leads-jamaica-final-us-run-years-fastest-time", "body": "LONDON (Reuters) - Usain Bolt, running the penultimate race of his career, led Jamaica safely through their semi-final in the 4x100 metres relay at the World Athletics Championships on Saturday while United States ran the fastest time of the year.\n\nBolt, who announced on Monday that he would also run in the heats, will race for the last time in the final on Saturday when he hopes to bow out with his 20th global championship title.\n\nRunning the last leg, Bolt eased home, looking over his shoulder, as Jamaica won the second of the two semi-final heats in 37.95 seconds, ahead of France (38.03) and China (38.20).\n\nJamaica are aiming for a fifth successive world title in the event but will face a stiff challenge from the U.S. who won the first heat in 37.70 seconds, with Christian Coleman, silver medallist in the 100 metres, running the anchor leg.\n\n\"It feels like second nature because we work well together. We are confident we can win. We will go and prepare well for tonight,\" said Michael Rogers, who ran the first leg for the United States.\n\nBritain were second in the first heat in 37.76, also faster than Jamaica's time, while Japan were third. Canada and Turkey also qualified as the fastest losers.\n\nBolt's presence ensured a capacity crowd for the morning session. \"It's hard to be sad because of the energy I'm getting from the crowd,\" said the Jamaican, who suffered a rare defeat in the 100 metres when he took bronze.", "time": "10:56:00"}

It was crazy,\" Blake said. \"They were holding us too long.\n\n\"We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us.\n\n\"It hurts to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggle like that.\"\n\nThe track and field great \"kept apologising\" to teammates after he fell to the ground in the last leg of the 4x100m relay final in London.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nYou will now receive updates from Sport Newsletter Sport Newsletter\n\nGet the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.\n\nBy submitting your email you are agreeing to Fairfax Media's terms and conditions and privacy policy .\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track.\n\nThe sport's greatest entertainer was determined that one of the finest careers in sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair.\n\nSo the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried team mates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 metres to the line.\n\nThe official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the team mates he felt he had let down.\n\n\"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nMcLeod added: \"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nJustin Gatlin, the American winner of the individual 100 metres who had consigned Bolt to third place in his final individual race last Saturday, paid tribute to his rival.\n\n\"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury). I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\nKevin Jones, the Jamaican team doctor, said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring.\n\nJamaican team manager Ian Forbes praised Bolt for \"going out there and giving his all\" and added that the squad were \"very saddened\".\n\n\"The diagnostic work will be done shortly to determine how serious it is. He was able to walk to the team bus so hopefully that signals it's not as serious as it possibly could be,\" Forbes said.\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favourite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track.\n\nFive years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics.\n\nYet in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000 metres, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell.\n\nTheir leaving of the track scene leaves a void in the sport that does not look like being filled any time soon.\n\nReuters", "time": "02:58:00"}

{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justin_Gatlin", "label": {"eng": "Justin Gatlin"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "320483"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4_\u00d7_100_metres_relay", "label": {"eng": "4 \u00d7 100 metres relay"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "320499"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamstring", "label": {"eng": "Hamstring"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "323465"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relay_race", "label": {"eng": "Relay race"}, "score": 5, "type": "wiki", "id": "332246"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brit_Awards", "label": {"eng": "Brit Awards"}, "score": 1, "type": "wiki", "id": "333223"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adam_Gemili", "label": {"eng": "Adam Gemili"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "340108"}], "url": "http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2017/08/13/slick-britain-win-shock-4x100-relay-gold-bolt-pulls", "body": "LONDON (Reuters) - Usain Bolt's final track appearance ended with pain and frustration on Saturday as he pulled up injured running the final leg of the World Championships 4x100 metres relay as Britain stunned the United States to win a shock gold medal.\n\nBolt, who had to settle for bronze in the individual 100 metres, had been hoping to sign off from the sport by leading Jamaica to a fifth successive world relay title but they were struggling in a distant third place when he collected the baton.\n\nAs he tried to gain ground, Bolt pulled up and fell to the floor midway down the home straight with what was later described as cramp in his left hamstring.\n\nHowever, the 60,000 in the stadium who had come to mark the farewell of sport's greatest showman had only a split second to absorb what was happening as up ahead history was being made by the host nation.\n\nThe United States, with individual 100m gold and silver medallists Justin Gatlin and Christian Coleman running the second and fourth legs, had been expected to push the Jamaicans all the way but they were always trailing the slick Britons.\n\nBrilliantly executed exchanges by Chijindu Ujah, Adam Gemili, Danny Talbot and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake gave Britain gold in 37.47 seconds, breaking an 18-year-old national record and European record and securing the world title for the first time.\n\n\"I wasn't sure if I had won or not, I gave it my all but I could see Christian Coleman out of the corner of my eye,\" said Mitchell-Blake.\n\n\"The feeling of euphoria was from infinity. I can't register it. We smashed the British record to pieces.\"\n\nFive years ago Talbot and the 18-year-old Gemili messed up a changeover as Britain were disqualified in the semi-finals of their own Olympics on the same London track so it was a particularly sweet moment for the two.\n\n\"To run it with Danny Talbot after such disappointment in London 2012, it is so special to come back,\" said Gemili, who was not selected for the individual races and missed an Olympic 200m bronze by three thousandths of a second last year.\n\n\"It's crazy. Honestly a dream and a reality tonight.\"\n\nBritain's only other men's global sprint relay golds came in the 1912 and 2004 Olympics while their winning time that beat their 1999 best of 37.73 has only been bettered by Jamaica and the U.S.\n\nIt completed a great night for the host nation's sprinters after their women had earlier taken silver behind the Americans in the sprint relay, their best performance since the first championships in 1983.\n\nThe U.S. men took silver in 37.52 but for a nation that used to be totally dominant in the event, it was only their second medal in the last eight global finals after a series of world and Olympic disqualifications.\n\n\"After DQs in recent years we knew we had to get the baton round and to finish the night smoothly is a fantastic achievement and we'll enjoy our moment on the podium,\" said Gatlin.\n\n\"The Brits had a hell of a race. You can't take it from them. They had the pressure of running on home soil and they delivered.\"\n\nOn his old rival Bolt he said: \"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now.\"\n\nJapan took advantage of Jamaica's travails to take third in 38.04, just holding off China (38.34).", "time": "22:32:00"}

Usain Bolt pulled up with cramp and could not finish the last race of his career.\n\nAh, this is one of the most heartbreaking things in sport ever.\n\nUsain Bolt's final race of his illustrious career ended with him pulling up with cramp on the anchor leg of the 4\u00d7100 metres relay final at the World Athletics Championships in London on Saturday.\n\nNot long after getting the baton from his teammate, Bolt pulled up with what looked like a dodgy hamstring. He hobbled, then stopped and did a forward roll on the track, unable to finish the race\n\nPissed off with the whole ordeal, Bolt's temmates blamed organisers for his injury.\n\n\"They were holding us too long in the call room,\" he said. \"Usain was really cold. 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1053871"}], "url": "https://www.independent.co.ug/bolt-in-quotes/", "body": "London, United Kingdom | AFP | Athletics superstar Usain Bolt's last championship race ended in dramatic fashion as he collapsed injured on the track anchoring Jamaica's 4\u00d7100 metres relay in the world championship final.\n\nHere AFP Sports picks out five of his best quotes and five about him since he first light up the championship track at the 2008 Beijing Olympics:\n\n- What they said about him -\n\n\"There is no athlete that can compete with him... he's a global superstar.\" -- Bolt's predecessor as an athletics superstar, Michael Johnson, whose 200 metres world record Bolt broke in the 2008 Olympic final.\n\n\"You can compare us as sprinters, but the thing I am most proud of is that I did multiple events and I long-jumped.\" -- Damned with faint and grudging praise by American legend Carl Lewis who also cast aspersions as to the Jamaican doping system to which Bolt retorted: \"Carl Lewis, I have no respect for him.\"\n\n\"He is an icon. He is the best sprinter of all time.\" -- Former International Olympic Committee (IOC) President Jacques Rogge, who was chided at the 2012 London Olympics for refusing to say he was a legend. Former Olympic yachtsman Rogge instead opted to nominate British yachting icon Ben Ainslie as his star of the Games.\n\n\"Nobody's ever been faster than this guy! Ever! Of all the billions of people.\" - Then-US President Barack Obama reflects on the global nature of Bolt's stardom after meeting with him in Jamaica and then performing the lightning bolt pose with him.\n\n\"Usain Bolt is now Jamaica's biggest ambassador. His personality, his ability to draw people to him (and) his showmanship have really given a boost to Brand Jamaica.\" - Jamaican Prime Minister Andrew Holness neatly sums up Bolt's gift to the Caribbean island.\n\n\"I am Lightning Bolt! I am not Flash Gordon or anybody. My name is Bolt, Lightning Bolt.\" - Bolt after smashing Michael Johnson's 200m world record in the 2008 Beijing Olympic final to complete his first of three individual Olympic sprint doubles.\n\n\"Manners is the key thing. Say for instance when you're growing up you're walking down the street you've got to tell everybody good morning. Everybody. You can't pass one person.\" - Bolt displaying why he has charmed everyone along the way, never forgetting the strict but grounded way he was brought up by his parents, father Wellesley and mother Jennifer.\n\n\"People come to see you run fast, but they also come to see a show, a performance... that's what I give them.\" - Bolt savvy as ever and why athletics will miss him so much: not just for his jaw-dropping brilliance but also his ability to entertain.\n\n\"I'm now a legend, I'm also the greatest athlete to live. I am in the same category as Michael Johnson.\" - Bolt after winning the 2012 Olympic 200m title to complete the individual sprint double double.\n\n\"If Queen Elizabeth knighthooded me and I would get the title Sir Usain Bolt. Hart: Tough for English keepers to get Premier League team\n\nWest Ham's Joe Hart believes it is becoming more difficult for English keepers to get a chance in the Premier League.\n\nUp Next Farah narrowly misses 5000m gold Farah narrowly misses 5000m gold Farah narrowly misses 5000m gold\n\nMo Farah finished second in the 5,000 metres final at the World Athletics Championships in London, narrowly missing out on a fifth consecutive major tournament distance double.\n\nUp Next Jason Day slips off pace after horror final hole Jason Day slips off pace after horror ... Jason Day slips off pace after horror final hole\n\nThe third round of the PGA Championships had a bit of everything as Kevin Kisner retained the lead, while Jason Day's quadruple-bogey eight at the 18th leaves him seven shots off the pace.\n\nMore videos Usain Bolt breaks down in final race\n\nEverything was working towards one last gold medal for the Jamaican.\n\n\"It was 40 minutes and two medal presentations before our run ... we were kept 40 minutes. It was crazy,\" Blake said. \"They were holding us too long.\n\n\"We keep warming up and waiting, then warming up and waiting. I think it got the better of us.\n\n\"It hurts to see a true legend, a true champion go out there and struggle like that.\"\n\nThe track and field great \"kept apologising\" to teammates after he fell to the ground in the last leg of the 4x100m relay final in London.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe 30-year-old had taken the baton for Jamaica a few metres adrift of the two leaders when, straining hard to catch them, he stopped abruptly with cramp in his left hamstring, began hobbling and tumbled to a halt after a forward roll.\n\nAs Britain went on to win gold, Bolt lay on his back in his lane, his head in hands, being tended to by medics as one waited with a wheelchair to help push him off the track.\n\nThe sport's greatest entertainer was determined that one of the finest careers in sport was not going to end with him in a wheelchair.\n\nSo the fastest man of all-time, surrounded by his three worried team mates, Omar McLeod, Julian Forte and Yohan Blake, rose gingerly to his feet and limped the last 30 metres to the line.\n\nThe official result recorded that the Jamaicans did not finish but Bolt had been absolutely determined to ensure he completed the last race after a matchless career in which he won 19 major championship gold medals.\n\nTypically, Bolt's only thoughts were with the team mates he felt he had let down.\n\n\"He kept apologising to us but we told him there was no need to apologise,\" Forte said. \"Injuries are part of the sport.\"\n\nMcLeod added: \"It just happened - Usain Bolt's name will always live on.\"\n\nJustin Gatlin, the American winner of the individual 100 metres who had consigned Bolt to third place in his final individual race last Saturday, paid tribute to his rival.\n\n\"I think it was the elements (that caused the injury). I'm sorry he got this injury. He is still the best in the world,\" Gatlin said.\n\n\"This is farewell time, I am sentimental about it already now. In the warm-up area, we give ourselves respect and greeted each other. Usain Bolt is a great athlete.\"\n\nKevin Jones, the Jamaican team doctor, said Bolt had suffered cramp in his left hamstring.\n\nJamaican team manager Ian Forbes praised Bolt for \"going out there and giving his all\" and added that the squad were \"very saddened\".\n\n\"The diagnostic work will be done shortly to determine how serious it is. He was able to walk to the team bus so hopefully that signals it's not as serious as it possibly could be,\" Forbes said.\n\nWith the 56,000-strong crowd going wild about the British victory, there was still time for them to hail the sport's favourite performer, who waved to them a mite forlornly while hobbling away from the track.\n\nFive years ago, almost to the very night, British distance running hero Mo Farah had broken into Bolt's lightning bolt pose in this same stadium and the Jamaican had reciprocated with the Briton's trademark \"Mobot\" to mark their joyous supremacy at the London Olympics.\n\nYet in the same stadium on Saturday, they attempted in vain to reprise that triumphant night, Farah ending up with silver in his final track race, over 5,000 metres, and Bolt suffering his anti-climactic farewell.\n\nTheir leaving of the track scene leaves a void in the sport that does not look like being filled any time soon.\n\nReuters", "time": "06:44:00"}

"https://www.aol.co.uk/sport/2017/08/12/bolts-farewell-spoiled-by-cramp-felix-makes-history/", "body": "It was far from the most fitting of farewells to the iconic Usain Bolt as he sustained cramp in his hamstring and failed to finish the IAAF World Championships 4x100 metres relay final.\n\nBolt, whose final individual event was the 100m decider last weekend and in which he could only take bronze, bowed out in distressing fashion, laying in pain on the ground and failing to finish as Great Britain took gold from the United States.\n\nThe Jamaican - an eight-time Olympic champion and 14-time World Championships medallist - was helped up by his team-mates and hobbled off the track as the crowd inside London Stadium celebrated a first GB gold in the event since Athens 2004.\n\nThere was a slice of history for Allyson Felix as she picked up a 15th medal on this stage with the US taking gold in the women's 4x100m, while Mo Farah's final track race at this level failed to bring a fifth-straight distance double and Sally Pearson returned to her throne as the 100m hurdles champion.\n\nJamaica were third when Bolt took the baton from Yohan Blake, an injury doubt before the race, and his eagerness to catch Christian Coleman and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake proved his undoing.\n\nThe 30-year-old cramped up and failed to finish, with Britain ending up the unlikely winners ahead of a US team that included 100m champion Justin Gatlin and Japan.\n\nIt provided a disappointing end to the iconic sprinter's career, but 110m hurdles champion Omar McLeod, who ran the first leg for Jamaica, assured Bolt will always be remembered as one of the all-time greats.\n\n\"Everybody was jelly, everybody was pumped. Usain Bolt's name will always live on,\" he told reporters.\n\nAn injury sustained while diving across the line to take gold in the 100m final last weekend forced Tori Bowie to withdraw from the 200m.\n\nAfter skipping the 4x100m heat, Bowie showed the electric pace that secured her individual medal by holding off Great Britain's Daryll Neita on the final leg, with Jamaica - who did not have Elaine Thompson in their line-up - coming third.\n\nTheir time of 41.82s was the fastest of the year and the gold provided Felix with a record-breaking 15th medal at the World Championships, taking her past the hauls of Merlene Ottey and Bolt.\n\nShe has a chance of adding to her unprecedented tally in the 4x400m relay on Sunday.\n\nFarah has dominated distance racing on the track since his first of four straight 5000m and 10,000m doubles at the 2012 Olympics, but he could not make it five on the trot back at the site of his first.\n\nThe 34-year-old led the pack for the majority of the race and reeled in the final breakaway from Patrick Tiernan with 600m remaining. However, Muktar Edris had more left in his legs down the home straight and the 23-year-old forced the 10,000m champion to settle for silver as he celebrated with his rival's trademark 'Mobot' celebration.\n\nFarah set off on a lap of honour to wave goodbye to the home crowd who have supported him so brilliantly throughout the Championships, with his future laying on the tarmac after the Diamond League final in Zurich later this month.\n\n\"It's been amazing. It's been a long journey but it's been incredible. It doesn't quite sink in until you compete here and cross the line - I had a couple of minutes to myself - that this is it,\" he said.\n\nAfter missing the 2015 World Championships due to a horror wrist injury and Rio 2016 with a hamstring tear, Pearson reclaimed her throne at the site of her greatest triumph with a time of 12.59s.\n\n\"It's been a long journey back from injury, but to get this moment and go and celebrate in front of my family is unreal,\" said Pearson. \"My husband is in the crowd there somewhere, I'll try and find him and give him a hug soon. This is just so incredible to be a world champion again.\"\n\nMassive congrats to @sallypearson on an amazing comeback from injury. We're all better when Sally is in the blocks next to us. #IAAFWorlds -- USATF (@usatf)\n\nAugust 12, 2017\n\nDawn Harper Nelson took silver with a season's best 12.63s while Pamela Dutkiewicz edged world-record holder Harrison out by two hundredths.\n\nAfter a strong start Harrison clipped the second and third hurdles, providing more disappointment after she missed out on a spot at last year's Olympics.", "time": "21:59:00"}

"http://at.theaustralian.com.au/link/cb5443ac4906f1ee93c66db9c896c801?domain=theaustralian.com.au", "body": "The world's greatest sprinter Usain Bolt made a surprise appearance on the track in the 4 X 100m relay heats today as he counts down to his final championship race tonight.\n\nBolt, 30, has announced he will retire after the world championships in London but he took the opportunity to enjoy one more race in front of an adoring 50,000-strong crowd by anchoring the Jamaican team to victory in today's relay heats.\n\nThe Jamaican team, the current Olympic and world champions in this event, are desperate to send Bolt out a winner after his bronze medal result in the individual 100m last weekend.\n\nThe quartet of Tyquendo Tracey, Julian Forte, Michael Campbell and Bolt combined to win their heat in 37.95 sec, the third fastest time of the round.\n\n\"There are no words to describe how I am feeling,'' Bolt said after another might roar of support from the crowd.\n\n\"I get so much support from the crowd. I appreciate that a lot. The young runners in our team -- it is just about executing and coming through the race for them.\n\n\"All the energy I am getting from the crowd. It is brilliant. We have been training that relay, there were some camps. Still there were some mistakes. Yohan Blake coming in for the final is definitely good.\"\n\nThe US foursome, which included controversial individual world champion Justin Gatlin and 21-year-old silver medallist Christian Coleman, won the first heat in 37.70 sec from the British squad in 37.76 sec.\n\nThe Americans will again look to upstage Bolt in his farewell race in the final.\n\n\"We are confident we can win,'' lead-off man Michael Rodgers said.\n\n\"We will go and prepare well for tonight.\"\n\nBut the Jamaicans are expected to include former world champion Yohan Blake and 110m hurdles world champion Omar McLeod in their final combination to give them more fire power tonight.\n\nThe Australian team of national champion Trae Williams, Tom Gamble, Nick Andrews and Rohan Browning finished seventh in their heat (38.88sec) and were eliminated.\n\nIn the women's 4 X 400m relay, the Australian quartet of Anneliese Rubie, schoolgirl Ella Connolly, 400m hurdler Lauren Wells and Morgan Mitchell were fifth in their heat (3:28.02) and narrowly missed the final, finishing tenth.", "time": "12:43:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sport_of_athletics", "label": {"eng": "Sport of athletics"}, "score": 5, "type": "wiki", "id": "1053871"}], "url": "http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2017/08/13/usain-bolt-collapses-injured-dramatic-end-athletics-career-london", "body": "Usain Bolt's incredible career has ended with the Jamaican sprinter breaking down in his final race at the world athletics championships in London.\n\nThe Jamaican great brought the curtain down on his glittering career by limping across the line injured in the 4x100 metres relay at the world athletics championships in London.\n\nFor a man who has won 19 global titles, who has transformed athletics, it was a sorry way to go. But dramatic too. And Bolt does drama in big time.\n\nNine years after exploding onto the world stage with two jaw-dropping world records at the Beijing Olympics, five after he declared himself a \"living legend\" by retaining his titles in London, and one after lighting up yet another Games in Rio, Bolt waved goodbye to the crowd as he hobbled down the home straight at the London Stadium.\n\nThe greatest career athletics has even seen - over.\n\nBut the 30-year-old was so much more than a medal machine.\n\nThe saviour of athletics: it is a tag Bolt has lived with through the dark days of doping scandals during which it sometimes seemed that only he could keep the sport from going under.\n\nThe task of how to fill the void his departure will leave is a gargantuan one.\n\nBolt appeared destined for greatness since becoming, aged 15 in 2002, the youngest world junior champion by taking 200m gold on home soil in Kingston.\n\nIf that set the teenager from Trelawny on the road to stardom, his performances at the Beijing Olympics six years later sealed it.\n\nFuelled by a diet of chicken nuggets, he set a 100m world record of 9.69, despite celebrating well before crossing the line, spreading his arms and slapping his chest.\n\nInternational Olympic Committee president Jacques Rogge branded his showboating disrespectful. He could not have been more out of touch.\n\nHere was a man to take athletics into a new stratosphere.\n\nThe following year he set world records - 9.58secs over 100m, 19.19s over 200m - which look set to stand for years.\n\nThey were mind-boggling marks from a sprinter who looked different too.\n\nAt 6ft 5in he towered over his rivals and, once he had recovered from his always troublesome start, his speed was awesome.\n\nBut it has always been about so much more than the race with Bolt. It is the whole show. He has made athletics fun like no one else.\n\nBe it his dancing, his joking, his celebrating, his 'Lightning Bolt' pose - no one does it better.\n\nEnergy, excitement, humour, charisma - it is all there, even in the briefest of moments.\n\nSprinters of the past used to prowl around the start line, sporting their best menacing looks, before a race. Bolt has made them all look just a little bit foolish.\n\nBolt has, somehow, managed to tread the line between arrogance and humility exactly right.\n\nHe knows he is special and he is not afraid to say it.\n\nBut he is also aware of his responsibility to the sport, particularly in an age of repeated doping scandals, and when his biggest rival, Justin Gatlin, is a two-time drug cheat.\n\nBolt has been directly affected by doping. He is no longer a nine-time Olympic champion, having lost his 4x100m gold from the 2008 Olympics when teammate Nesta Carter failed a retrospective drugs test.\n\nThat fact will not affect his legacy, though.\n\nNor will the fact he had to settle for 100m bronze, behind champion Gatlin and young American Christian Coleman, in the 100m in London, the final individual race of his career.\n\nHis hero status is secure.\n\nBolt has hailed South Africa's 400m world record holder Wayde van Niekerk as the man to inherit his mantle.\n\nYet the pair are contrasting characters and expecting Van Niekerk to fill the void left by the larger-than-life, one-of-a-kind Jamaican is hugely unfair.\n\nIf athletics chiefs want a new Bolt, they could be in for a long wait.", "time": "00:00:00"}

the first time since 2008 that Jamaica lost the event at a major track competition, according to the Washington Post.\n\nThe painful defeat was a stunning reminder that anything can happen in live "http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/front-page/dramatic-end-bolt-closes-stellar-athletics-career-with-agonising-tumble-but-refuses-wheelchair-and-walks-across-finish-line_107648?profile=1373", "body": "Bolt closes stellar athletics career with agonising tumble but refuses wheelchair and walks across finish line\n\nIt wasn't the perfect ending that the world had hoped for. However, even as Usain Bolt folded onto the track in agony from a hamstring cramp while anchoring the Jamaican 4x100m team in his final competitive race, it was clear that global athletics will miss him.\n\nAlthough the tumble denied Bolt one final medal, the sprint legend, after apologising to his teammates, refused a wheelchair and limped across the finish line at the 16th IAAF World Championships in London to end what has been an outstanding career.\n\nIt's the nature of the man who left the world wide-eyed and O-mouthed when he broke the 100m and 200m records at the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games, then lowered both marks at the Berlin World Championships in 2009.\n\nOver the past decade Bolt has won 156 of his 168 races and now has eight Olympic gold, 11 World Championship gold and a Commonwealth gold.\n\nIn his column posted on the Daily Telegraph website last night, the newspaper's Chief Sports Feature Writer Oliver Brown stated: \"Losing Usain Bolt to athletics is like losing the air. He is an elemental presence; the one figure capable of elevating a humble foot race to a mid-summer blockbuster.\n\n\"When he begins life on Sunday as an ex-athlete, his last race run, he stands to be missed more than even he, with his carefree Caribbean swagger, can comprehend.\"\n\nPointing out that Bolt takes 41 strides to cover 100m when most of his rivals needed 44, Brown stated emphatically that \"Bolt saved athletics at a time when few realised it needed saving. He became supra-national, belonging as much to Jamaica as to the world.\"\n\nIndeed, Brown pointed to a most appropriate quote from IAAF President Sebastian Lord Coe to describe Bolt: \"I can't think of anybody else besides Muhammad Ali who has captured the public imagination or a global audience like Bolt,\" Lord Coe said. \"He has gone way, way beyond athletics.\"", "time": "03:28:00"}

"http://www.stltoday.com/sports/other/digest-sprinter-bolt-injured-in-final-race-of-career/article_2f28e243-7e11-559f-bd72-7499181922bb.html", "body": "Sprinter Bolt injured in final race of career\n\nUsain Bolt ended his stellar career in excruciating pain.\n\nThe Jamaican great crumpled to the track with a left-leg injury as he was chasing a final gold medal for the Jamaican 4x100-meter relay team Saturday at the world championships in London.\n\nHaving to make up lots of ground on the anchor leg, Bolt suddenly screamed and stumbled as he came down with his farewell shattered by the first injury he has experienced at a major competition.\n\nJamaican team doctor Kevin Jones said Usain Bolt had a cramp in his left hamstring.\n\n\"A lot of the pain is from disappointment from losing the race,\" Jones said.\n\nThat wasn't the only surprise. Britain went on to beat the United States in a tight finish.\n\nThe 60,000-seat stadium was primed for one last Bolt show, one last \"To the World\" pose after a victory, but the injury made it blatantly clear why Bolt is ready to retire. His body can no longer hold up.\n\nAs Bolt fell to the ground, the leg with the golden shoe giving way, the crowd still went wild because the home team went on to win gold in 37.47 seconds, .05 seconds ahead of the United States.\n\nIt was yet another amazing upset in a championship of so many.\n\nBefore Bolt came onto the track, he was consoling Mo Farah, his long-distance equivalent who had just lost his first major race since 2011 when he failed to get gold in the 5,000 meters.\n\nFarah also was bidding farewell to the track.\n\nTori Bowie was the unlikely first double gold medalist at the championships, anchoring the U.S. team to the 4x100-meter relay title ahead of Britain and Jamaica.\n\nAt the same time, Allyson Felix, running the second leg on the winning team, earned a record 15th medal at the world championships in a career going back to 2005.\n\nBowie also won the 100 meters.\n\nIn the 100-meter hurdles, East St. Louis native Dawn Harper-Nelson was second to Australia's Sally Pearson. Harper-Nelson was the 2008 Beijing Games champion, with Pearson taking silver. Four years later at the London Olympics, the order was reversed.\n\nFormer NHL coach Murray dies * Bryan Murray, the longtime coach and general manager who worked in the NHL for 35 consecutive seasons, has died at 74.\n\nHe was diagnosed in 2014 with incurable colon cancer. Murray worked that season and another as general manager of the Ottawa Senators, who confirmed his death Saturday.\n\nOne of the most respected and well-liked figures in hockey, Murray served as general manager in Anaheim, Florida, Detroit and Ottawa and coached in Washington, Detroit, Florida, Anaheim and Ottawa. He won the Jack Adams Award as NHL coach of the year with the Capitals in 1983-84 and reached the Stanley Cup Finals with the Senators in 2007.\n\nFederer advances to Rogers Cup final * Roger Federer advanced to the Rogers Cup final with a 6-3, 7-6 (5) victory over unseeded Robin Haase of the Netherlands Saturday in Montreal.\n\nThe second-seeded Federer is seeking a third Rogers Cup title to go with wins in 2004 and 2006. The 36-year-old is on a 16-match winning streak, his longest since 2012. In Sunday's final, Federer will face 20-year-old Alexander Zverev of Germany.\n\nThe women's final Sunday in Toronto will feature fifth-seeded Elina Svitolina and sixth-seeded Caroline Wozniacki.\n\nAssociated Press", "time": "03:24:00"}

Britain's quartet celebrated a shock gold medal, the Jamaican Yohan Blake, who passed the baton to Bolt, said he was furious at what had happened. \"They were holding us too long in the call room,\" he said. \"Usain was really cold. It was really heart-wrenching. I couldn't believe it, I'm in shock, utter disbelief.\n\n\"It was ridiculous,\" he added. \"We were there around 45 minutes waiting outside, I think they had three medal ceremonies before we went out so we were really trying our hardest to stay warm and keep upbeat. But it was ridiculous. We waited a really long time.\"\n\nHis team-mate Julian Forte was also shocked. \"I felt like it happened to me, I was on the corner at the time when it happened, it's devastating,\" he said.\n\nBritain's men set a national record of 37.47sec to take gold, with the United States second in 37.52 and Japan third in 38.04. "http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/sport/olympics/world-championships-jamaican-team-hold-usain-bolt-s-fate-in-their-hands-1-8699491", "body": "Usain Bolt bows out of mainstream athletics tonight as he runs for the final time at the London Stadium in the 4x100m relay.\n\nProvided his Jamaican team-mates escape a mistake in this morning's heats, Bolt will line up for one final swansong at 9.50pm. Jamaica, and Bolt, have won the last four world titles and a fifth victory would break the record for the most consecutive relay wins.\n\nDespite announcing his imminent retirement, the relay may not be the final time Bolt runs on the track should he decide to return to the Nitro Athletics meeting he helped establish in Australia next year. Nevertheless, one last golden moment would give Bolt the 20th global title of a 10-year career spent at the height of athletics.\n\nThe United States, featuring 100m champion Justin Gatlin, will provide the biggest danger in their aim to win the event for a first time in ten years.\n\nCanada hold the fastest time of 2017 but are without No. 1 sprinter Andre de Grasse while the 2015 silver medallists Chinese, who have clocked 38.19 this season, will also be in contention.\n\nTeesside's Richard Kilty pulled out of the Great British squad through injury. 100m finalist Reece Prescod will be joined by CJ Ujah, Danny Talbot, Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake, Zharnel Hughes and Harry Aikines-Aryeetey.", "time": "07:37:00"}

relay at IAAF World Championships 2017 in London on Saturday, August 12. Heartbreaking!Andy Lyons/Getty Images\n\nThe above picture certainly tells a thousand words!\n\nUsain Bolt ended his celebrated career in the worst possible way by losing an event, in which he had won three straight Olympic Gold and four World Championships titles.\n\nUsain Bolt.David Ramos/Getty Images\n\nThe Jamaican great pulled up with an injury in the anchor leg of the 4x100m final at IAAF World Championships on Saturday, leaving his fans, who were witnessing the historic moment, devastated.\n\nThe 30-year-old, after an initial sprint, started hobbling and ended up rolling on the track with a hamstring injury, according to reports.\n\nEven as Great Britain stunned the United States to take the Gold, Bolt was lying flat on the track and was a personification of despair. Like the millions who had watched the race live, Bolt seemed he himself did not believe what was going on at the Olympic Stadium.\n\nThe 4x100m final was Bolt's farewell race and a lot was being said about it, especially after the Jamaican legend was beaten in the 100m final last week.\n\nIn the morning session on Saturday, the eight-time Olympic Gold medalist made sure there was no hiccups as Jamaica won the second of the two semi-final heats, ahead of France and China. bronze medal in his last individual race, last weekend's 100m final, Bolt had hoped to bow out with a 12th World Championships gold.\n\nSUPER SALLY: Pearson seals comeback with gold in 100m hurdles\n\nFINALLY BEATEN: Mo Farah's extraordinary reign ended\n\nHowever, after taking the baton in the anchor role for Jamaica, Bolt dramatically failed to finish, instead falling to the ground women's high jump.\n\n\"They were holding us too long,\" said Blake. \"To be holding us so long was atrocious.\n\n\"That long wait contributed. Inside it was cold. We kept on warming up.\n\nBlake consoles an injured Bolt. Pic: Getty\n\n\"You have to think about the athletes ... because we were in the mixed zone too long, over 40 minutes.\n\n\"That's our true friend, Usain, that's our training partner. I felt it. A hero of the sport to go down like that? As a true friend, I didn't like it one bit.\n\n\"He was saying he was sorry, but there was nothing to be sorry for, he's done it for us [over his career].\"\n\nDr Kevin Jones, the Jamaica team doctor, said of Bolt's injury: \"It's cramp in his left hamstring but a lot of pain is from the disappointment from losing the race.\n\n\"The last three weeks have been hard for him.
